It's still difficult to imagine the Feelies in the rising fury of late '80s alt-mania. They never quite fit in
column2: the boys and girl with perpetual nervousness from Haledon
column3: New Jersey who'd influenced members of R.E.M. and Yo La Tengo in the late '70s before dissolving into a blaze of homespun spinoffs. But new reissues from Bar/None of 1988's Only Life and 1991's Time For A Witness train a new lens on the band's late middle period
column4: after their 1986 Good Earth return and before their two-decade dissolution. As part of the second generation of CBGB bands
column5: they first became known for their caffeinated energy
column6: but these two albums found the now-stable quintet coming into stylistic maturity
column7: settling gracefully into their signature sound: reliable Velvet Underground chug
column8: rust-burning solos
column9: occasional acoustic guitar
column10: and their distinct double-drummer rhythm section featuring Dave Weckerman on a smaller second percussion set-up.

column1: Even 28 years later
column2: this combination of Weckerman and kit drummer Stan Demeski continues to distinguish the Feelies from the jingle-jangle velvet rockers they'd influenced via R.E.M.. Stripping extraneous cymbal crashes and replacing them with any number of other colorations
column3: sometimes not immediately obvious
column4: the two make inventive frames for chief songwriter Glenn Mercer's increasingly monosyllabic rumination and fat-toned lead guitar. The band's obsessive percussive roots can be heard most clearly on Only Life's ""The Undertow"": Beginning with a drum/woodblock polyrhythm and a slow guitar fade-in
column5: the insistent layers turn together like jittering clockwork
column6: a meticulously arranged through-line to the band's pepped-up Crazy Rhythms-era minimalism featuring former Pere Ubu drummer Anton Fier. The effect is cathartic
column7:
neuroses drowned in motion.

The wild Feelies beat can be heard clearly
column8: too
column9: on the earlier album's ""Away
column10: Mercer's slide guitar surfing cooly on Demeski's brilliantly metronomic snare. A Jonathan Demme-directed video for the song was filmed at Maxwell's in Hoboken
column11: home to Coyote Records
column12: the indie label belonging to club owner Steve Fallon
column13: who'd released 1986's The Good Earth. The two albums capture a band consolidating the wild fun of Crazy Rhythms and the living room-epiphanies of their earlier iteration as the Trypes into a cohesive musical vision that didn't require total deconstruction between each album.

column1: Unlike Nirvana or Dinosaur Jr. or many other up and coming guitar-wielders on the club circuit
column2: the Feelies remained grounded in the un-scorched earth of a pre-metal/pre-hardcore world. Despite this
column3: there is a surprisingly grunge-like angst coiled inside Mercer's songs. Arranged for a different rhythm section and pumped up by Andy Wallace
column4: the repetitive half-sentences of ""What She Said"" could be a Kurt Cobain lyric (and even slightly anticipate Nirvana's ""Breed
column5: released later that year). Live
column6: the Feelies' rhythms might've engendered moshing in the go-go '90s
column7: but even when they tag a cover of the Stooges' ""Real Cool Time"" to Time For A Witness
column8: Mercer's invitation still seems considerably more chill than Iggy's bare-chested crowd-surfing come-on. The Feelies rock hard
column9: but they rock for themselves
column10:
on a course of their own.

""I don't talk much 'cause it gets in the way
column11: don't let it get in the way
column12: Mercer sang quite articulately on ""Crazy Rhythms
column13: an early signature song. By the time of Time For A Witness
column14: Mercer's songwriting persona spoke less and less
column15: too
column16: chiseling his lyrics down to phrases that traded between terse
column17: profound
column18: and nearly generic recombinations drawn from rock's lingua franca. Sometimes
column21: perhaps the closest they ever veered to pop. With only one couplet about a party on a lawn
column22: Mercer transforms the otherwise-vague lyrics of ""Invitation"" into a specific memory of a long-ago evening. But in many other places
column23: the songs feel less like individual expressions and more like convenient platform for the Feelies to lock into their now-signature groove.

column1: The eight digital bonus tracks split between the Only Life and Time For A Witness reissues are all from the band's third and most recent period
column2: live and acoustic versions of songs from the two 1988 and 1991 albums plus a few covers recorded since their 2008 reunion. And while the new studio renderings of Only Life's wisdom-dispensing title track and 1991's ""Find A Way"" are fairly exquisite
column3: and the live tracks are good fun
column4: the absence of contemporary supplementary material is a little bit of a bummer. One show from the period available on BitTorrent sites finds the Feelies in France in 1989
column5: recorded on a well-mixed soundboard
column6: Glenn Mercer's guitar achieving a gorgeous and barely-contained bell-clear tone
column7: recalling Another Green World-era Robert Fripp
column8: a voice all but missing from the two studio albums. A fierce live band
column9: their personal intensity transmuted into collective joy
column10: songs from the two albums returned to the Feelies' repertoire when they returned
column11: hardly a band to revert only to their acknowledged classics
column12: but unfussily recovering their unacknowledged classics
column13: too.

came from ""The Boy With The Perpetual Nervousness."" It was in fact from ""Crazy Rhythms.""

On ""A New Kind of Water
column2: the penultimate track on This Heat’s last full-length album
column3: Deceit
column4: guitarist/vocalist Charles Bullen sings in a strangulated sneer: ""Of course
column5: it's innate we're selfish/ But what if there's not enough to go round?"" That he was embittered and frustrated at the start of Margaret Thatcher’s reign is obvious and in a recent interview
column6: he spoke of his disenchantment of playing in a band at that time: ""I’m singing to the people who get lulled into thinking
column7: ‘Oh
column8: don’t worry about air pollution. They’ll invent a new way to breathe.’""

column1: This Heat broke up soon after that. But before Bullen threw himself into pursuits outside of punk (activism and education on the politics of health and agriculture)
column2: he self-released a solo album as Lifetones. Written and recorded during the bleakest of times for an activist such as himself
column3: after Thatcher’s landslide re-election in 1983
column4: For a Reason remains a strange amalgam of post-punk’s desolation set to dub reggae’s sunny lilt. It’s also been impossible to hear since the reign of the ""Iron Lady
column5: left off of numerous rounds of This Heat reissues over the ensuing decades. There have even been two reissues of bandmate Gareth Williams’s equally rare Flaming Tunes record in the intervening years.

column1: Thankfully
column2: Lifetones’s lone album is part of Light in the Attic’s recent This Heat reissue campaign. And while it’s not nearly as vital or serrated as that band’s output
column3: there’s something enchanting about For a Reason. While 1983 was the year that another British punk band that absorbed and wore its reggae influences on their sleeves were releasing their biggest album in Synchronicity
column4: Bullen’s take on Jamaican dub feels gloomy
column5: sullen
column6: deeply personal.

column1: While anger was often the default of punk and post-punk vocalists alike
column2: and one can feel the feral howls of Charles Heyward on a This Heat track like ""Paper Hats
column3: Bullen’s voice is disarming and dry in comparison. It doesn’t arise too often on the album
column4: but when it does
column5: its artlessness gets multi-tracked into a mass chant that at times reminds me of old British folk singers
column6: delivering their message flat and without affect. Tinny keyboards and distant dub drums open ""For a Reason"" and Bullen imparts a sense of purpose with the echoing incant of ""Do everything for a reason."" Against that skitter of snares and needling guitar
column7: he repeats phrases like ""Love the life you live/ live the life you love"" and ""You have to work so hard"" until they act as a mantra.

column1: Too often
column2: the album meanders through instrumentals
column3: not quite getting into a deep groove. Dub effects swaddle an instrumental like ""Decide
column4: its one-chord guitar riff turned into effervescence against the echoing drums while ""Distance No Object"" adds a trill of melodica and chintzy keys to the mix. But unlike most reggae
column5: the beats here are lo-fi
column6: oddly stiff and British. The album’s most interesting track is  ""Travelling"" which forgoes Jamaican tropes entirely and instead roves into Bedouin territory. Full of snaking violins
column7: woodwinds in an Eastern mode
column8: it’s only in the last minute of this mesmerizing track that Bullen sings in his stuffed nose drone: ""In the past I was that way/ now I’m this way/ No one is to blame."" He sounds like an old punk opening his worldview and finding another reason to continue to fight the system.

Recording as Egyptrixx
column2: Toronto's David Psutka helped to define the sound of London's Night Slugs label. His albums Bible Eyes and A/B Til Infinity took techno rhythms
column3: gleaming synth melodies
column4: and noxious ambient atmospheres and spun them into exciting new variants. His new project Ceramic TL represents a break with Egyptrixx's style: The beats are gone and the melodies have run dry; with an emphasis on buzzing drones and detuned bell tones
column5: it's all atmosphere
column6: and it is more noxious than ever
column7: heady as huffing aerosol.

column1: Sign of the Cross Every Mile to the Border is pitched as ""seven meditations on optimism and faith through the prism of environmental cataclysm."" It's a theme that might bring to mind his former labelmate Jam City's recent album Dream a Garden
column2: which was described by its creator as an attempt to locate  beauty and healing in the fight against oppression. But the music couldn't be further away from Jam City's dreamy mood board
column3: with its gauzy echoes of Scritti Politti and Prince and vintage 4AD. Psutka's '80s borrowings are limited to the suffocating cacophony of Glenn Branca's guitar symphonies and the persistent swoosh of digital phaser effects. His fondness for black metal is evident in the charred rumbling of a track like ""Life on Earth
column4: in which ringing bells melt together into an unbroken din and a low hum crackles like a burning bass amp. At the track's close
column5: a car revs in the distance and the sound of wind and fire whips across the landscape
column6: bringing the album's environmental themes to the fore.

column1: The opening track
column2: a burnished bell-tone whine
column3: is remarkably similar to the stopped-watch loops of Thomas Brinkmann's What You Hear (Is What You Hear) and it scans as pure texture. The entire album
column4: in fact
column5: is almost entirely devoid of conventional musical or rhythmic events
column6: preferring the static repetition of granular loops stretched to infinity. Ceramic TL—does that ""TL"" stand for ""timeline""?—seems to be a project about taking a time-based medium and squeezing the life out of it
column7: stopping it dead in its tracks and flattening it beyond recognition: music as roadkill
column8: as flatline.

column1: Where the music is austere
column2: the track titles are positively Byzantine. ""I Attached To and Pored Over Photos of Places I Loved That Were Reduced to Ash"" is one; ""I Often Wondered How the Group Would React When Eco-Apocalypse Finally Struck"" is another. Some sound like they might be clippings from YA novels (""This Looks Just Like It
column3: the Answer to My Prayers - I Thought My Life Was Over Until Two Years Later I Arrived"")
column4: but it's also possible to imagine them
column5: not uncharitably
column6: as Black Metal Cats captions. Of course
column7: black metal itself is no stranger to florid iconography
column8: and the deep purple of Psutka's prose
column9: as faintly ridiculous as it may be
column10: has the effect of doubling down on his theme
column11: practically daring you not to meet the album on its own ambitious terms.

column1: <div><span>The final track
column2: called simply ""Clearing
column3: is a welcome breath of fresh air after the labyrinthine path that has led up to it. Amid a fluttering of birdsong
column4: an automobile's open-door chime beeps
column5: the door slams
column6: and a metallic chop of rotors
column7: indicating sudden liftoff
column8: flashes back to the zap and chug of Egyptrixx. Whether or not it suggests a return in the future to his more club-oriented work
column9: who knows. But it makes a fitting finish for Ceramic TL's claustrophobic audio play
column10: in which sound itself is dramatized as a life-or-death struggle for oxygen. And
column11: at long last
column12: Psutka's bet on ""optimism and faith"" pays off."|21606.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21606-sign-of-the-cross-every-mile-to-the-border/|7.0|Philip Sherburne

column2:
we face a shining future|4418.0|Underworld|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Astralwerks']|2016-03-15 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 16:00:19.013151|"

Let’s talk about love—with Underworld
column3: you kind of have to. Though still best known for shouting ""lager
column4: lager
column5: lager"" in their epochal 1996 hit ""Born Slippy.NUXX
column6: the long-running dance duo
column7: consisting of singer-lyricist-multi-instrumentalist Karl Hyde and producer Rick Smith
column8: have quietly but persistently placed matters of the heart at the center of their best songs. Their breakthrough single ""Cowgirl"" pledged ""I wanna give you everything
column9: robotically chanting the final word like a mantra for emphasis. ""Jumbo
column10: the buoyant highlight of 1999’s Beaucoup Fish
column11: took a (literally) sweeter approach
column12: with singer Karl Hyde purring ""I need sugar"" when ""I get thoughts about you."" And despite the involvement of a series of guest producers whose work never quite gelled
column13: UW’s last studio album Barking was held together by a chain of out-and-out love songs
column14: from its singles ""Scribble"" to its tremulous closing ballad ""Louisiana"" (""When you touch me
column15: planets in sweet collision""). Regardless of their reputation for turning late-night urban-hedonism anthems into festival-filling crowdpleasers
column16: Underworld remain romantics at heart.

column1: Nowhere is this more apparent than on Barbara Barbara
column2: we face a shining future—perhaps because Smith and Hyde’s own creative romance needed rekindling. Though their post-Barking period saw them collaborate with director Danny Boyle on both his stage adaptation of Frankenstein and the opening ceremony he helmed for London’s 2012 Olympics
column3: recent years have seen them go largely their separate ways: Hyde recorded a solo album and two well-reviewed projects with Brian Eno
column4: while Smith reteamed with Boyle to score the Trainspotting auteur’s Trance on his own. All told
column5: Barbara is their first proper album in over half a decade.

column1: Opening track and lead single ""I Exhale
column2: then
column3: establishes the pair's reunion as a party-in-progress. The two-note synth-bass riff and stomping glitter-rock rhythm provide Hyde with a solid foundation for a madcap spoken-word romp whose introductory lines—""Life / It’s a touch / Everything is golden / Open""—set a tone as upbeat as the album’s utopian title. The second song
column4: ""If Rah
column5: features Hyde's absurd proclamation that ""the origin of numbers is a questionable hypothesis."" Not many acts could recover from an opening gambit that ridiculous
column6: but Smith (working here as throughout the record with co-producer High Contrast) constructs a groove relentless enough to contextualize that non sequitur as just another outburst from a fellow reveler
column7: dimly heard over the din of the speakers.

column1: The celebratory vibe takes a somber but sensual turn with ""Low Burn."" A pulsing throwback to the soundscapes of early albums dubnobasswithmyheadman and Second Toughest in the Infants
column2: its lyrics are a cyclic incantation—""time / first time / blush / be bold / be beautiful / free""—that call to mind landmark moments of initial liberation
column3: whether on the dancefloor or in the bedroom. The song makes a strong enough impression that the pair of comparatively slight downtempo tracks that follow it
column4: the acoustic guitar interlude ""Santiago Cuatro"" and ""Motorhome"" (a gentle plea to ""keep away from the dark side"" marked by a ""Baba O’Riley""esque synthesized highland reel in the background) can be forgiven as a necessary comedown.

column1: They also provide a breather before closing tracks ""Ova Nova"" and ""Nylon Strung
column2: the strongest one-two punch in the band’s catalog since ""Dirty Epic"" faded into ""Cowgirl"" on dubnobasswithmyheadman 22 years ago. Strikingly
column3: ""Ova Nova"" is the first time on Barbara that Hyde sings more than a single sentence at a time
column4: and beautifully at that. Smith gives his high lilting tenor a digital shimmer
column5: making the refrain of ""change your mind"" sound less about decision-making than actual transformation. But the emergence of bonafide back-up vocals—provided by Esme Smith and Tyler Hyde
column6: the duo’s daughters—set ""Ova"" off not just from the blunt singing of the rest of the album
column7: but from the band’s entire oeuvre.

column1: Fittingly for an album that looks to the future in its very title
column2: Barbara saves the best for last. The rhapsodic ""Nylon Strung"" starts with a hint of urban decay
column3: with Hyde’s voice echoing ""Sliding between the dust of a scorched earth."" But the sadness doesn’t last in the face of what’s to come. The voices of Karl and Tyler Hyde and Esme Smith weave around the lines ""Open me up / I want to hold you
column4: laughing
column5: over and over and over
column6: with Smith’s classical soprano soaring high above. The repetition
column7: long the most frequently employed tool in Underworld’s lyrical arsenal
column8: is powerfully moving: Each iteration of the line brings you closer to the absolute vulnerability inherent in loving another person
column9: whether a parent or a partner
column10: a lover or a daughter or a son. The effect is stunning
column11:
the kind of music that makes you sob happysad tears in your car in the Sunday afternoon sunlight as you think about the people you wish were riding with you. Underworld’s never had trouble getting listeners to their feet. This gorgeously love-drunk finale makes Barbara a record that can bring them to their knees.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/22946/homepage_large.cdbab4eb.jpg|No One Deserves Happiness|10726.0|The Body|['Metal']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Thrill Jockey']|2016-03-15 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 16:00:19.633830|"

 With No One Deserves Happiness
column2: Portland metal experimentalists The Body don’t add any new elements to their sound or introduce any new collaborators. Instead
column3: they reconfigure their core elements — Chip King’s self-waged war between his shrieks and thick sheets of riff-noise
column4: Lee Buford’s man-machine hammer
column5: frequent collaborator Chrissy Wolpert’s vocals and chorus arrangements —and conscript them into their widening vision of the spot where metal intersects with other dark genres.  The result is less sprawling than All The Waters of Earth Turn to Blood and scarier for its concision.

column1: Wolpert’s contributions over the years makes her almost a third member
column2: and on Happiness she fights against the usual notion of women metal vocalists as pretty voices in the background or magnets for male gaze by becoming the confrontational center. The Body have often lashed out at the world through envisioning its end
column3: and Wolpert turns that anxiety inward
column4: proving that
column5: yes
column6: they can get more uncomfortable. The songs in which she has the heaviest hand are Happiness’ most powerful. Her chants of ""go it alone"" throughout leadoff track ""Wanderings"" feel like a visceral reminder of unremitting horror
column7: and her chamber-pop instincts take on an alien tinge next to King’s shrill wail. She can also play off herself
column8: as she does by combining a more brooding croon with brief soaring highs in ""The Fall and The Guilt
column9: the album’s most devastating track.

column1: ""Adamah"" sees guest vocalist Maralie Armstrong channelling Kate Bush over Buford’s clipping thuds
column2: not too far off from Rabit’s bullets-as-percussion approach.  Combined with King’s clipped rhythm
column3: which recalls Blood’s ""A Curse
column4: it's the closest to pop that The Body have ever come. This isn’t a huge leap for them: They’ve covered Sinéad O’Connor’s ""Black Boys in Mopeds
column5: Nine Inch Nails' ""Terrible Lie
column6: (with Thou) and Fleetwood Mac’s ""The Chain"" (also with Thou); never before has it seeped into their composition like this.

column1: Pop and metal have more in common than diehards of both would prefer to admit
column2: and one is both rely heavily on structure and tight performance. The Body aren’t improvisatory live
column3: but they don’t play it straight like most metal bands do either
column4: putting it all into an endurance test that’s made them both the heaviest live metal act and guaranteed death for punk houses’ electrical systems. King leans on noise on Happiness more than ever before
column5: from subtle squeals in ""Shelter is Illusory"" and the undercurrent of ""Hallow / Hollow"" to the complete absence of chord structure in ""For You"" and ""Guilt."" When ""The Myth Arc
column6: the final song
column7: kicks in
column8: King blurs the line between doom metal and total noise abstraction. Buford is also a freer player than before
column9: incorporating the punch of harsh techno beats but without an interest in keeping listeners in line with a steady
column10: comfortable tempo. In a way
column11: The Body has always been obsessed with feelings of consuming futility
column12: and in kicking free of conventional structures and following Wolpert's lead
column13: they've come closer than ever to their truest selves on record.

column1:
Correction: An earlier version of this review misidentified the vocalist on ""Adamah"" as Chrissy Wolpert. It is Maralie Armstrong.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/23047/homepage_large.2850a553.jpg|Bothic|33574.0|ZelooperZ|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Bruiser Brigade']|2016-03-15 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 16:00:20.162941|"

For an artist struggling to stand out
column2: it can be a smart move to focus on your strangest qualities and amplify them. If a conventional approach is failing
column3: then there's no downside to trying something different and getting weirder. On previous projects
column4: 21-year-old Detroit rapper ZelooperZ showed hints of an outsider waiting to break out
column5: but 2011's Coon N the Room is a teenager's failed concept album
column6: and 2014's Help stood out only for its stilted verses (especially considering mentor and Bruiser Brigade leader Danny Brown appears twice and excels). But on his latest album Bothic
column7: ZelooperZ is now both more refined and eccentric than ever. It's nearly impossible to identify a single conventionally rapped verse on the album
column8: which somehow works to its advantage. For the most part
column9: Bothic lacks straightforward melody and ZelooperZ's delivery borders on grating
column10: yet the result is still occasionally enthralling.

column1: ZelooperZ opens the album with his best Lil B impression on ""Summit"" over a beat reminiscent of Clams Casino. It's truly an inauspicious start to the project; ZelooperZ is not as observational as Lil B
column2: nor does he give off any semblance of stream-of-consciousness rapping
column3: which makes the track simply sound the work of a bad rapper–someone who tries and fails to rhyme or flow. From there
column4: however
column5: Bothic picks up. ""Bothic Bout It"" is a banger despite (or perhaps due to) a complete lack of comprehensible lyrics. The consistent repetition of ""bothic"" (a portmanteau for ""bruiser gothic"" that ZelooperZ coined) suggests that we don't need much more than heavy bass
column6: rhythm
column7: and a couple of well-chosen words or sounds for a song to communicate intensity. ZelooperZ has a rudimentary flow
column8: but the momentary offbeat bits of flair that show he has a feel for the grace notes outside traditional structure. ""Bothic
column9: rockin' Rick Owens in Hot Topic / Popped a pack for 175
column10: blew a bag
column11: then I made some profit"" is intentionally askew and is easily one of the most memorable lines on the record
column12: not only for its humor
column13: but also for how ZelooperZ withholds certain sounds
column14: creating small bursts of energy.

column1: At times
column2: it sounds like ZelooperZ is ignoring the production around him
column3: like on ""Scale
column4: where he moans over jaunty piano. Still
column5: it works
column6: its haphazard parts colliding together to form a mess
column7: but a compelling one. Ratking's Wiki shows up on ""Heart"" for the Bothic's only guest appearance; he clearly outshines ZelooperZ lyrically
column8: but while his quick ""where I'm from"" narrative is welcome
column9: it's somehow not as notable ZelooperZ's frenzied shrieks.

column1: Bothic requires a fair amount of immersion to enjoy. With the exception of ""Bothic Bout It
column2: ""Heart
column3: and ""ISBD
column4: most tracks would probably be skipped immediately if heard out of context. ""Ocean
column5: for instance
column6: is a relaxing comedown
column7: but ZelooperZ's delivery of ""ocean"" as ""oshaaah"" doesn't work without hearing him go through warped exercises on ""Scale"" and ""Automatic."" As a whole
column8: Bothic seems intended to be heard as the work of a next-level auteur
column9: but there are still too many moments that beg the question whether it's successful or just plain strange. ZelooperZ is not a finished product as an artist
column10: but if Bothic is any indication
column11:
he's willing to push boundaries and could potentially create a style all his own.

Boston's Horse Jumper of Love are a self-proclaimed “slow rock” trio that
column3: despite declaring themselves a band
column4: more strongly resemble a solo project. A few years into their career
column5: the group’s already busted into the top tier of the Boston house show scene—a considerable accomplishment for any young rock band
column6: considering the scene’s predilections towards snoozy folk and hostile hardcore. But while Horse Jumper of Love's live performances recall the low
column7: slow burn of bands like Silver Jews and Arab Strap
column8: their Bandcamp output hinges on one man: lyricist and frontman Dimitri Giannopoulos
column9: whose combination of wan croons
column10: melancholic strumming
column11: and ramshackle production place the group’s erstwhile recordings in Microphones territory.

column1: Like their local
column2: recently-disbanded contemporaries Krill
column3: Horse Jumper of Love seek to balance the intimate with the acerbic. Now
column4: with the arrival of their full-length debut
column5: the time has come for those two spheres to merge. Drummer Jamie Vadala-Doran and bassist John Margaris plod at a tortoise-like pace
column6: dragging their leader’s acoustic arrangements out of the bedroom and into the open. These songs’ momentum may be minimal—Carissa’s Weird look like the Casualties by comparison—but their warmth proves deceptively hypnotic
column7: making the deviations more attention-grabbing. On “Ugly Brunette
column8: ”the trio draw the listener into a lull by way of syrupy
column9: straggling chords only to repeatedly trip up the beat
column10: the whammy-wailing hook swaying like a drunkard. The leisurely arpeggios on “Spaceman
column11: ” meanwhile
column12: spiral gently into the void until they’re swallowed up by a fuzzed-out roar. There's suspense in the slump.

column1: Where Giannopoulos the musician seeks to pit sheltered songs against haggard arrangements
column2: Giannopoulos the lyricist is up against the universe at large. He’s openly admitted in an interview with the Allston Pudding that as a teenager
column3: he thought “nothing was real
column4: ” angst worsened by the cultural and linguistic divides inherent in his Greek-American upbringing. Rather than tell meandering stories à la Slint
column5: Giannopoulos repeatedly shifts his focus to hyper-specific (if awkwardly-worded) motifs: “America towels
column6: ” “July 5th
column7: ” and “i love you very much forever
column8: ” the latter two of which title transitional lo-fi interludes. He’s a natural at creating sensual
column9: oddball imagery (""Peel an apple with your nails/and there is dirt and there is juice
column10: ” “I talk with your teeth
column11: ”) but his descriptions feel distant and needlessly vague.

column1: For a full length record
column2: Horse Jumper of Love is actually pretty scant. Three of the eight songs comprising its less-than-thirty-minute runtime are inconsequential ambient pieces that serve little purpose aside from creating the illusion of momentum and progress down in the doldrums.(Their inclusion feels inevitable
column3: given Giannopoulos’ prior dabblings with electronics in the band’s early material and with his solo project the Meat Tree.) The penultimate track
column4: “Sun Poisoning
column5: ” proves downright unlistenable; Vadala-Doran
column6: a serviceable percussionist on the rest of the album
column7: suddenly fumbles around like a novice
column8:
struggling to keep in step with his bandmates’ funereal pace. The result is a meek introduction to a modest band that feels simultaneously overdue and undercooked.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/22929/homepage_large.0dcda697.jpg|The Sentence|33513.0|Zach Cooper|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Styles Upon Styles']|2016-03-15 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 16:00:21.294842|"

There's a not-so-hidden message encoded in composer Zach Cooper's debut album
column2: The Sentence: ""This is for us to incite stillness in our hearts and minds."" That call to mindfulness
column3: inspired by Cooper's own meditation practice
column4: is spelled out by the one-word titles of the album's 12 cuts
column5: which spin acoustic instruments
column6: electric kit
column7: and synthesizers and electronic effects into a
column8: shifting whole that's part chamber music
column9: part post-rock
column10: and part musique concrète.

column1: For a record that advocates stillness
column2: The Sentence covers a lot of ground. It collages together many years' worth of work
column3: from high-school home recordings to work with the Vermont Contemporary Music Ensemble to assorted rehearsal tapes and—well
column4: who knows what
column5: really. As you might guess from songs titled things like ""This
column6: ""To
column7: and ""In
column8: the individual tracks on The Sentence function less as standalone songs than as parts of an indivisible whole
column9: and it's well-nigh impossible to tease out which bits date to which moments. As a scrapbook
column10: the album's timeline will be legible only to Cooper
column11: although that's presumably partly the point of the whole exercise: to explore the way musical moments repeat
column12: echo
column13: and evolve across the course of a life
column14: piling up on tape in an image of eternal now-ness.

column1: The music's tone is largely hushed
column2: with lots of breathy wind instruments and muted electric and acoustic guitar; there are five percussionists credited on the album
column3: but their contributions tend to emphasize scrapes and thumps and the faraway thunder of reverberant tympani—sounds used more for color than timekeeping. Compositionally
column4: Cooper tends to tease soft melodic phrases out of dissonant
column5: abstract passages
column6: like drawing smooth a tangle of thread in fits and starts. Occasionally
column7: a startlingly beautiful vista opens up: The pensive guitar and horns of ""To"" sound a little like Tortoise at their most sentimental. But Cooper doesn't dwell on any one idea for very long. That lyric centerpiece is followed by a shout (""<span id=""docs-internal-guid-8bb3f6c9-7707-2b17-38e2-b31f92fb6196""><span>Yo
column8: play the jam! We’re gonna jam
column9: dude!"") and a two-minute run of vibraphone
column10: cymbal
column11: and electronics that suggests a druggy
column12: paranoid Raymond Scott.

column1: When The Sentence works best
column2: it's led forward by a combination of smart pacing and surprising ideas. But the record has trouble building and keeping momentum. ""Stillness
column3: just 3:18 long
column4: encompasses three distinct parts separated by garbed electronics and random clatter: a watery orchestral passage
column5: a folky meditation for acoustic guitar and monophonic synth
column6: and solo acoustic guitar bit that sounds like it was recorded on a Dictaphone. All offer nice sounds and worthy musical ideas
column7: but lead nowhere. Too often the album seems to lack an organizing principle
column8: a structure to make all its discrete moments make sense
column9: and the back half of the 32-minute album drags. It's hard to maintain much investment in a record that simply rolls on of its own accord
column10: like a stream
column11:
oblivious to the presence of the listener.

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/23045/homepage_large.3d3d68ba.jpg|III EP|32569.0|Sheer Mag|['Rock']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Static Shock'
column3: Skinny Lizzy
column4: that's all I need
column5: sang Christina Halladay on ""Sit and Cry
column6: the second song off Sheer Mag's debut 2014 EP. Many rock bands swear allegiance to Lizzy-inspired
column7: booze-fueled riff rock
column8: but Sheer Mag make the formula sound uniquely vital
column9: which makes them uncommon amongst most rock bands in 2016. Their music stuffs hip-shaking hooks and burly riffs within impeccably structured pop songs
column10: wrapped in lyrics both open-hearted and openly political. They're the Jackson 5 raised to play punk rock
column11: with an F-5 tornado for a singer.

column1: Earlier this month they released III
column2: their third EP in the last three years. It upholds the band's gold standard as they continue to refine their formula: kick drums like rifle shots
column3: earworm guitar riffs played with electric glee
column4: no-frills solos no less punk rock for their existence. Halladay still sounds like she's coming through a crackling speaker
column5: as does the rest of the band
column6: but her soulful
column7: gale-force voice is more legible than ever. It's thirteen-and-a-half minutes of pure pleasure.

column1: III is evenly split between love songs and political songs. ""Can't Stop Fighting"" addresses the chronic violence against women in Ciudad Juarez and in the world at large
column2: with Halladay howling for collective action. ""Night Isn't Bright"" accomplishes the astonishing task of delivering lines like ""It's plain to see these days that there's an agitation / We live and we die by a politics of simplification"" without coming off as joyless. Sheer Mag will trick you into dancing while singing about overthrowing the system. You will have fun as you debate whether voting for Bernie over Hillary represents true change
column3: or just a rearranging of the Titanic deck chairs. The songs are imbued with the tangible
column4: bleeding passion that often accompanies political awareness
column5: lest you think wokeness to be the sole province of the dour. They remind me of the MC5
column6: another working-class garage band who used swaggering rock as a vehicle for righteousness.

column1: The love songs find Halladay sounding more vulnerable than usual. She sings about men who've wronged her through their apathy
column2: despite her fearlessness in seeking clarity. ""At least I tried
column3: she sings on ""Worth the Tears
column4: ""and the time we had was worth the tears that you made me cry."" The highlight might be ""Nobody's Baby
column5: which is built around a clipped riff and a refrain both defiant and depressed. ""I'm nobody's baby
column6: I'm nobody's girl
column7: she sings
column8: with the resignation of someone attempting to stay strong despite the pain they feel. The fearlessness of Sheer Mag's politics makes them stick out
column9: but they're also unafraid to get bruised—a contrast of tough and tender that makes their music all the more potent.

column1: It bears mentioning that Sheer Mag are strident anti-capitalists. III was released with no head's up and no PR
column2: all for the price of a latte. (You can stream the EP in its entirety without paying a dime.) The lyrics are printed on their Bandcamp
column3: lest anyone mistake their pointed intentions. They've reportedly turned down offers from plenty of labels. Their upcoming Coachella set seems hilariously out-of-place
column4: though one imagines them concluding a furious set by burning their cash fee on stage ala the KLF. The string of EPs would naturally point toward an upcoming LP
column5: though we can't be sure. For now
column6: they're more than welcome in these limited bursts. They're totally locked into the sound
column7:
for all it'll give them. Pour another drink and turn it up.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/22991/homepage_large.c9b695d2.jpg|The Last Panthers|4987.0|Clark|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warp']|2016-03-14 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 16:00:22.643442|"

When the announcement hit last fall that David Bowie had recorded the theme to a British crime serial called The Last Panthers
column2: a smaller piece of news got drowned out in the hubbub: Chris Clark
column3: aka Clark of Warp Records
column4: was tasked with composing the sound and music for the show itself. It was a surprising connection to many
column5: but becomes perhaps less so when you realize that The Last Panthers show is produced by Warp Films
column6: a burgeoning offshoot of the venerated electronic label. As they did with Broadcast for the studio’s indie horror film Berberian Sound Studio
column7: Warp have decided to release Clark's work as a standalone effort.

column1: It’s worth noting that Clark and Warp have chosen to present The Last Panthers as another chapter in Clark’s discography rather than as an ""Original Soundtrack"" or a ""Music From..."" Clark's catalog is deep and well-respected
column2: and The Last Panthers is kind of a curious entry. It presents itself with two separate tests to pass: 1) Is it an effective soundtrack to a show? 2) Does it stand up on its own
column3: without visual context?

column1: To the first question
column2: the answer is a resounding yes (U.S. viewers will get the chance to judge for themselves later this year
column3: when the show is released Stateside). The dark
column4: rain-soaked impressionism of the cinematography
column5: coupled with the quiet
column6: low-key dialogue
column7: spoken in a variety of languages
column8: creates a cold
column9: gray and glassy world which the viewer feels they can observe at a distance but never penetrate. Clark’s work plays as much of a role in shaping this world as the visuals
column10: making his cues not just appropriate but intrinsic to the show.

column1: Answering the second question
column2: how well The Last Panthers stands on its own
column3: is a bit trickier. Clark has always been a stylistically varied artist
column4: working in a range of tempos and textures
column5: but The Last Panthers is most notable for the total absence of  the faster
column6: louder numbers
column7: or the incredible low-end beats for which he is known
column8: like 2003’s ""Early Moss"" or ""Banjo"" from 2014's Clark.  He’s basically constructed an entire record of miniatures like ""Ship is Flooding"" and ""Strength Through Fragility"" (both also from Clark)
column9: or ""Pleen 1930s"" (the first track from his very first record in 2001)--tracks that typically ran short on his records and often felt more like interludes than compositions.

column1: Coincidentally or not
column2: many pieces feel reminiscent of the spindly instrumentals populating the back halves of Bowie's Heroes and Low. ""Panther Bass Plock"" and ""Chloroform Sauna"" practically channel ""Neuköln"" from Heroes at the altar
column3: particularly the low-end sea burbles underneath the rising synths.  Tim Hecker is evoked throughout
column4: especially with the gently ebbing waves of ""Upward Evaporation
column5: while ""Serbian Daffodil""’s warbling reverb-heavy synths recall Boards of Canada interludes and ""Omni Vignette"" is Erik Satie by way of Drukqs-era Aphex’s plaintive sustained piano.

column1: But ""sounds likes…"" aside
column2: what is most impressive about The Last Panthers is the way in which Clark has taken all of this incidental music and shaped it into a flowing 48-minute suite that conjures almost as much of an imagined visual story as The Last Panthers show itself. Due to the subdued nature of the proceedings along with short track times and a smattering of dreamily repeated theme refrains throughout
column3: the listening experience doesn’t lend itself to tracks standing out on their own. Exceptions
column4: however
column5: are the awesomely titled ""Strangled to Death in a Public Toilet
column6: with its beautiful dead-angel chorus reminiscent of Gavin Bryar’s ""The Sinking of the Titanic""; ""Diamonds Aren’t Forever"" and it's follow-up ""II
column7: which both break down midway through fogs of noisy synth to reveal plaintive repeated piano and violin; and album closer ""Hide On the Treads 3""
column8: whose ascending and pumping glockenspiel arpeggios provide the closest thing to sunshine on this otherwise completely gray sound collage. It's been suggested before that Clark is writing the soundtrack to the end of the world; if so
column9:
The Last Panthers feels like the lonely soundtrack for whatever's left after that.

Trotros are to Accra what the subway is to New York
column3: in that neither city would function without them. On Trotro
column4: DJ Katapila pays homage to Accra
column5: and on its title track
column6: he tips his hat to its infamous minibus system. From the song's outset
column7: a cartoonish voice exclaims
column8: ""Makola
column9: UTC
column10: Kaneshie!""
column11: imitating the mates (drivers' assistants) who lean out the side of the trotros calling out their destinations. That same kind of humor and depiction of daily life runs through much of DJ Katapila's music
column12: which is a mix of neo/traditional Ga dance music
column13: and old-school house and techno.

column1: DJ Katapila
column2: aka Ishmael Abbey
column3: grew up in the '70s in the coastal district of Jamestown in Accra
column4: a historically Ga area. The now-40-something became known for his marathon DJ sets
column5: to the point where his tirelessness earned him the nickname ""Katapila
column6: after Caterpillar construction equipment. Yet it wasn't until several years ago that he started actually producing
column7: and in 2009
column8: he self-released his debut album
column9: Trotro. Since then
column10: a number of his tracks have circulated on bootleg tapes
column11: which is also how Awesome Tapes From Africa found his music and ended up partnering with him to issue this rerelease.

column1: The album was never actually pressed to cassette
column2: yet it still sounds as if it were playing back through a thin layer of dust. This rawness comes in part from Katapila's own production
column3: in part from the spirit of early Chicago house and Detroit techno
column4: and in part from Ga music. The album is grounded as much by the four-on-the-floor thump of Chicago house as it is by the programmed son clave patterns that are common to so many genres of music across the Black Atlantic
column5: including kpanlogo. Kpanlogo is a type of neotraditional Ga dance music that combines older sounds like gome drumming and street processional music with elements of highlife and '60s-era rock (ie the Twist). It also happens to be a precursor to azonto
column6: whose inflections can be heard throughout Trotro. For instance
column7: on ""Sakawa
column8: the rhythm comes through in the snare
column9: on ""Trotro"" through the handclaps
column10: and on ""Cocoawra"" and ""Lalokat
column11: very clearly in the cowbell.

column1: Besides house and azonto though
column2: DJ Katapila also often references other kinds of contemporary
column3: black club music
column4: while still largely staying within the sphere of Accra life. ""Nkran Dokunu"" refers to Accra kenkey
column5: a corn-based staple food of Ghana. The track bounces along at around 140 BPM and feels almost like a slower
column6: crunchier shangaan electro. <span>Midway through it
column7: as a toy Casio-like figure plinks along over a galloping snare
column8: two cartoon-voiced characters chant in Ga
column9: “Accra kenkey is delicious! We’re eating it!”

column1: By contrast
column2: ""Ice-Inc"" is a lot darker in mood. It's a direct line to old-school Detroit techno
column3: complete with 808-sounding electrofunk cowbell
column4: and the time-warped
column5: intergalactic quality of a Kraftwerk song. It may not scream ""Accra""like some of the other songs on the album. But as a part of Trotro as a whole
column6: it speaks to the multitude of musical and cultural influences that have been exported and imported to the city over time. That
column7:
and the propensity to approach the otherwise unremarkable with a remarkable sense of humor.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/22980/homepage_large.f1a96b07.jpg|Mercy EP|33543.0|Fake Boyfriend|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sad Cactus']|2016-03-14 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 16:00:23.761354|"

For almost a year
column2: the band Fake Boyfriend has had no music available
column3: their website offering only a 27-second recording titled ""gimmick."" ""Hi
column4: um
column5: we’re Fake Boyfriend
column6: a voice begins with a vacant affect
column7: before building up to a screaming eruption ""and we’re—a… GIMMICK!"" The last word’s howl hovers uncertainly between complaint and celebration
column8: but
column9: musically
column10: ""Gimmick"" is a statement of pure vocal power. Fake Boyfriend pits that power against ""the preconceived notions of how women are supposed to behave and process emotions
column11: as band member Abi Reimold
column12: who just put out her own acclaimed solo LP
column13: recently told Stereogum. If the songs ""are about giving into your feelings
column14: then ""Gimmick"" gives into and lets out its rage over the inevitable equation that Fake Boyfriend is a girl band and being a ""girl band"" equals being a gimmick. By yawping their self-identification with the label
column15: Fake Boyfriend reclaims the ""girl band"" moniker but still acknowledges the commoditizing function it otherwise performs.

column1: Their debut EP Mercy merges post-punk with the poppier indie-rock stylings associated with acts like Waxatachee and Girlpool
column2: full of thrashing guitar blasts and churning bass. <span id=""docs-internal-guid-1674e650-676c-ea2a-57b1-a0bdf4435ac4"">""Expire"" has the fiercest snarl on the EP
column3: but ""Ship"" best exemplifies the soft/hard
column4: light/dark interplay of their songwriting—a juxtaposition of screaming and soft vocals.  Midway through ""Ship
column5: the chugging guitar and drums dissolve
column6: leaving only bass as singer and guitarist Ashley Tryba shifts into narcotic tones for the 40-second bridge’s intonation: ""In my dreams
column7: in my dreams…"" When the drums and guitar come back
column8: this fugue state ends and returns the speaker to her post-traumatic reality. ""I’ve got a room of my own but nothing to write/ I’ve got an anger that burns but no one to fight
column9: Tryba sings
column10: chants
column11: and finally shouts—invoking the classic Virginia Woolf essay and suggesting that a room of one’s own offers no reprieve.

column1: Throughout
column2: Fake Boyfriend make it clear they're determined to tackle bigger ills than ex-lovers. At the Mercy release party
column3: Tryba prefaced the performance of ""Ship"" with an angry redress: ""This song is about the self-blame
column4: shame
column5: and confusion that comes after being sexually harassed… Despite what the fucking journalists say."" They seem unconcerned with the rituals and niceties of getting covered or noticed by press
column6: a refreshing resurgence of true punk ethos within the often-sycophantic world of of contemporary indie rock. This  attitude has its most potent expression in their clunky
column7: obnoxious
column8: unpolished
column9: and often rapturous live shows: ""Sometimes we mix Trans-Siberian Orchestra with Evanescence
column10: and that’s us
column11: bassist Sarah Myers once informed an audience.

column1: Each band member plays a different instrument than she learned prior to joining Fake Boyfriend.  Far from sounding amateurish
column2: this quality gives Mercy’s four songs their special beauty
column3: an improvisational intimacy like two new lovers undressing each other—fumbling into just the right groove.  The compositional unsteadiness to ""Bumtown
column4: which seems to stumble and drag its way through its verses
column5: only adds to the force of the explosion into the chorus. ""Bumtown"" and the hypnotic ""Wax"" display latent pop sensibilities that best serve Mercy as brief flashes of contrast to the album’s abrasive swirl. But they also sounds like hints at a capacity for full-throttle pop anthems as well. Who would have thought the Hole heard on 1991’s Pretty On The Inside would later produce a song like ""Heaven Tonight""? On Mercy
column6:
Fake Boyfriend bristle with all manner of possibility.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/22925/homepage_large.b4971abd.jpg|Transition|33585.0|Immix Ensemble & Vessel|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Erased Tapes']|2016-03-14 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 16:00:24.932275|"

Most musical instruments are frozen in history
column2: timeless in function but stuck in the contexts that surround their invention. Spurred on by this idea
column3: saxophonist Daniel Thorne and his Immix Ensemble teamed up with Bristolian producer Sebastian Gainsborough (Vessel) to compose Transition. Transition is a four-movement suite
column4: stylized as a conversation between concert-hall orchestration and left-field electronic production--something which in the last few years is a rapidly growing intersection. Each of the work’s four songs is supposed to highlight the historical snapshots of specific instruments (the trumpet
column5: the saxophone
column6: the oboe
column7: etc) and how their contexts can be remixed or garbled with the presence of an electronic partner.

column1: It’s not necessarily a groundbreaking concept. For last the decade
column2: artists like Nils Frahm
column3: Max Richter
column4: or Daniel Wohl have been stretching the boundaries of the conversation between contemporary classical music and avant-garde composition that Thorne and Gainsborough are just entering. The piece is actually two years old
column5: having been originally commissioned in the fall of 2014 for performances at Tate Britain and the University of Liverpool. The performances also stressed a collaboration between video art and orchestration
column6: meaning it often feels like something substantial just listening to the album.

column1: To its credit
column2: Transition is an extremely breezy listen for a record of experimental classical music--running a little over 26 minutes
column3: with only one song extending over eight minutes. The economy and pacing allows Thorne and Gainsborough to play with a wide range of elements without any feeling of excess or wasted space. Each of the four movements use their minutes wisely
column4: allowing for more exploration than you’d think possible.

column1: Starting with “What Hath God Wrought
column2: ” the artists decided to pair the bass clarinet and saxophone
column3: the instruments whose sounds compliment and challenge each other the best across the entire album. There is something dancerly about the ways the two instruments weave around each other. Their faceoff is made interestingly discomfiting by a low drone that Vessel overlays on top of the action
column4: something that very slowly takes over the song. His electronic touch is barely perceptible at first
column5: but he sneakily washes out the sounds
column6: making them feel older and less stable by generating a series of bleeps and fields of static that give the recording the character of an old radio broadcast.  “What Hath God Wrought” gets more and more crowded
column7: allowing the analog and electronic sources to crash into each other and becoming indistinguishable. It seems to make the argument very early on that these sounds can’t exactly coexist naturally
column8: that they always generate friction by sharing the same space.

column1: Following “What Hath God Wrought” is “De Revolutionibus” (“On Revolutions” in Latin)
column2: a movement that furthers the tension Transition wants to make very apparent. Of the four movements
column3: it seems to be the most influenced by Vessel’s history of moody and industrial productions. It’s undeniably Gothic in mood
column4: with violins screaming in the presence of electronic squeals and hisses. There are brief horrifying moments where it sounds like insects are crawling around the recording microphones. The instruments are artfully crumpled together
column5: adding to the texture of a song that seems to draw inspiration from bumper-to-bumper traffic and free jazz. It’s the most interesting eight minutes of the entire album.

column1: “Scope” was the only one of the songs not co-penned by Gainsborough
column2: and as a Thorne-focused affair
column3: it lacks the same tense conversation of the two pieces that preceded it. The electronics seem to disappear for nearly six minutes
column4: and it makes for a conventional and wan listening experience. To make up it seems they packed the closer “Battle Cry” with all the violence its title suggests--transforming the conversation between the musicians into a full blown argument. Fittingly “Battle Cry” ends abruptly. The last squeaks of the trumpet cut the rope
column5: and curtains fall down on Transition almost with no warning.

column1:
Overall Transition is never as probing as it can be. It doesn’t allow for total investment from a listener because the marriage of sounds is incomplete and fitful. The thought experiment that should be at the core of the album sometimes felt lost in a confusing morass of interjections and trip-ups. But there are enough moments of pure gold that peek its head out of the morass that make the experience worth it in the end.

"|21612.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21612-transition/|7.0|Kevin Lozano

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/22873/homepage_large.aae0eb9d.jpg|Potential|31225.0|The Range|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Domino']|2016-03-11 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 16:00:26.091260|"

James Hinton uses samples like he invented the entire concept. The Brooklyn-based producer
column2: who just released his second album as the Range
column3: doesn’t do anything with the technique we haven’t heard before. Quite the opposite in fact—the songs on Potential touch on instrumental hip-hop
column4: dubstep
column5: twinkling electro-pop
column6: and more
column7: and they’re defined above else by their immediate familiarity. But Hinton dives into his samples with the verve of a producer who just this morning discovered the jolt of creative joy that comes from flipping a vocal fragment just so and finding a way to repeat it that brings a cascading wave of emotion. His work may not feel new
column8: but it crackles with a sense of discovery.

column1: Hinton got to this point by honoring the act of listening. Most of the tracks on Potential were built around samples of people he found singing on YouTube. But he didn’t focus on the pop stars
column2: or even the viral sensations
column3: but the amateur performers whose work survives deep
column4: deep down search holes
column5: the videos that were uploaded in a rush of expression and were subsequently seen by almost no one. As he described in an interview with Pitchfork
column6: Hinton found these videos
column7: assembling phrases from them that had a certain musicality but also carried an ineffable feeling. Though he transforms the voices with the usual techniques of pitch-shifting
column8: echo
column9: reverb
column10: and so on
column11: you can get the tiniest sense of the individual behind each utterance. Pay attention to the feeling of yearning in a young person saying “Right now I don’t have a backup plan for if I don’t make it
column12: ” in “Regular
column13: ” or the extra tug of effort around each R&B-inflected phrase in “Superimpose.” The voices feel anonymous but somehow closer because of that; they are faces in the crowd
column14: just like us.

column1: Around these voices
column2: Hinton crafts songs
column3: full of house piano loops
column4: clapping drum sounds
column5: and tightly sequenced synth patches. This is music designed for uplift
column6: with carefully plotted builds yielding to big choruses
column7: and it taps into electronic music's sense of possibility not by pushing things further
column8: but by simplifying and paring back. Hinton brings to mind specific eras not from direct reference or slavish devotion to genre
column9: but by striving to remember the historical moment when a specific element of sound first clicked—the squelching synth in “Genius of Love
column10: ” the ghost vocal loop in “Xtal
column11: ” the piano in “Building Steam With a Grain of Salt.” Because of this bedrock positivity (and
column12: probably
column13: because so many of the voices come from the UK) it also obliquely recalls the optimistic rave moment when the right combination of people and the right DJ could make you feel like you were part of something that mattered.

column1: All of this positivity means
column2: naturally
column3: there’s not a lot of darkness to explore in this music. The only pain present seems like the kind that that music is able to zero in on and explode
column4: which is certainly not true of every kind of pain. At times
column5: this uniformity of mood threatens to blunt the emotional pull of the album
column6: but then there’s always a clever turn-around or defiantly catchy vocal loop to snap attention back in place.

column1: Perhaps unusually
column2: Hinton tracked down the forgotten sources of his YouTube samples and signed them on for a share of his publishing. It may or may not lead to financial gain (though it’s pretty easy to imagine many of these tracks sounding good on TV in any number of contexts)
column3: but the gesture affirms the interconnectedness of life at this moment
column4: how watching a random homemade video on YouTube can be thought of as a collaborative act. Hinton has an ability
column5: not unlike the Books when they first hit the scene 14 years ago
column6: of making shopworn techniques in sound manipulations seem strangely fresh
column7:
and Potential is the kind of music that makes you think about what your own part in a seemingly passive musical transaction of music might mean.

"|21563.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21563-potential/|8.0|Mark Richardson

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/22990/homepage_large.0f00464f.jpg|Long Way Home|33546.0|Låpsley|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['XL']|2016-03-11 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 16:00:26.609480|"

Longing is an emotion generated by absence
column2: which makes it tricky to convey well in pop songs. When rendered with economy
column3: on a song like Madonna's ""Live to Tell
column4: longing becomes part of the atmosphere
column5: something unspoken that is too subtle and subatomic to see. When it's blown up to become the only feeling a in a song
column6: it becomes alienating: Adele songs
column7: for example
column8: sometimes feel like vast deserts of longing in which she is the sole inhabitant.

column1: 19-year-old British musician Låpsley combines something of both approaches. Her work
column2: a kind of shimmering synth-pop that also inherits its more reptilian rhythms from trip hop
column3: attracted the notice of the BBC Radio 1 DJ Annie Mac in 2014
column4: who invited her to contribute to a compilation. Now
column5: Låpsley (full name Holly Låpsley Flesher) has been signed to XL Recordings
column6: and her debut album for them expands on the crisp flutterings of her early EPs. Her music tends to be subtle in texture but direct in composition; “Hurt Me
column7: ” one of the singles from her debut album Long Way Home
column8: is an adult contemporary pop ballad packaged in a glittering exoskeleton. It unfolds in discrete cellular units
column9: like most songs on her record; a piano
column10: a finger snap
column11: the muted pulse of a kick drum
column12: which eventually combine and flower into a small terrarium. Her vocal moves through this environment with the kind of sublimated warmth that powers Sade records and her many lesser imitators.

column1: The unusual dependence on space in the arrangements can make the interiors of Låpsley’s songs seem uncannily empty
column2: glassy structures with their insides removed so all that’s left is angled crystal. Låpsley’s thick
column3: gelatinous voice is ostensibly intended to seal these isolated textures together
column4: and she makes “Hurt Me” work almost despite itself; the melodrama of her vocal contrasts so much with the percussive decay of the backing track that it feels faintly violent. The song sounds both intimate and enormous as a result. “Operator (He Doesn’t Call Me)” employs the retrofuturism of disco and then refracts it through a second nostalgic lens
column5: a sample of the 1975 Manhattan Transfer gospel single “Operator.” Here Låpsley’s sense of space benefits the song; the sample and the light
column6: rolling disco collide at odd
column7: interesting angles
column8: like light passing through glass.

column1: But in other instances her voice dissolves into an overabundance of negative space
column2: and listening to the less-inspired sections of Long Way Home can feel like trying to remember something boring that happened to you once. Strangely
column3: the most exciting songs on the record are both the oldest and most shapeless. On “Station
column4: ” Låpsley’s voice is processed at three different speeds
column5: and all three vocals are arranged so that it seems she’s interacting and harmonizing with three different versions of herself. “Painter” resembles the frozen swirl inside a single marble. Both songs resist verses and choruses; instead they inhabit a central melodic idea until it is sufficiently complicated
column6: then abandon it
column7: while the remainder of the track drains gently away. These songs are her most direct expressions of longing
column8: a form of desire that can be aesthetically assumed and discarded
column9:
but which is a vast and illegible universe of feeling when fallen into.

M. Ward has admitted that the whole point of More Rain was to be the sort of thing to listen to when the weather is shit. As such
column2: he's made a collection that attempts to persistently and gently wash away the negativity from
column3: well
column4: everything. The opening minute of pattering rain sets the mood as Ward dives headfirst into a collection of songs trying to square the big-picture ugliness of the world with its tiny details of everyday beauty.

column1: The album works best when he leans all the way into his sleepy
column2: slouchy songs. These songs might be the result of hours of careful
column3: precise attention
column4: but they feel magnificent in their decadent laziness: It is indeed the kind of record you put on when the day is soaked in gloom and dimness; you listen to when you’re loafing so hard that you can barely bring yourself to flip the record
column5: much less leave the house and brave the elements.

column1: More Rain can’t reasonably be called a folk record
column2: even with its acoustic underpinnings
column3: but Ward does wield some folk elements to his benefit. Pedal steel—forever underrated and unfairly dismissed as a pop-country prop—occasionally lilts into the mix
column4: with mandolin popping up
column5: too. Album opener ""Pirate Dial"" is a mellow
column6: patient folk-pop number that serves as the album’s high point.  On ""Girl from Conejo Valley
column7: those eight strings stand in contrast with a sliding synth line
column8: making for an unexpected complement.

column1: There are moments
column2: though
column3: when these textures become overwhelming. More Rain feels smothering in its intimacy at times
column4: like a thick down pillow pressed to your face. The mixes are so close
column5: the reverb so heavy
column6: and the tones so richly warm
column7: that Ward leaves little breathing room within his songs. Staying inside on a rainy day usually starts out pleasant and slowly grows claustrophobic
column8: and so it goes with More Rain.

column1: And while the instrumentation can often feel like too much
column2: Ward’s flat lyrics feel like too little. ""Slow Driving Man"" starts with ""This is a song about a slow driving man/And I’m about to sing it just as slow as I can."" He proceeds to do just that. The cloying pattern of ""Doo wop""s
column3: ""sha la la la""s
column4: and ""yip yip""'s on ""Little Baby"" don’t do much good
column5: either.

column1: Ward rallies for the closing track ""I’m Going Higher
column2: which slides in at the end of More Rain as a gospel tune disguised as a rock song. It’s solid
column3: but resounds with the album’s over-arching theme of being a little too on the nose. The rain is gone and now there’s sunshine
column4: praise the Lord! Though it’s mostly a pleasant record
column5: there’s not much from it that sticks around long after listening—for all the talk of deluge
column6: More Rain manages to wash itself away.

column1:
Correction: The original version of this review failed to identify the song ""You're So Good To Me"" as a Beach Boys cover. 

"|21644.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21644-more-rain/|5.9|Allison Hussey

'Brace Yourself']|2016-03-11 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 16:00:27.354516|"

Brooklyn quartet Big Ups have been referred as a post-hardcore band
column4: an umbrella term meant to tell us that that they blend the pummel of straight-up hardcore with tension and seemingly bucolic moments. While this was a fair description of their discordant and vicious 2014 debut
column5: Eighteen Hours of Static
column6: each note feeling like it was being forced ruthlessly into the mosh pit typical at most Big Ups shows
column7: it is even more accurate for their sophomore record Before a Million Universes. While these lapses into chaos are still very much present
column8: Big Ups place a greater emphasis on quiet moments
column9: on gradual buildups
column10: which of course then allow the instrumental fits of Brendan Finn (drums)
column11: Amar Lal (guitar)
column12: and Carlos Salguero (bass) to feel even more explosive by contrast. Every phrase Galarraga screams
column13: every phrase that he does not
column14: every burst of noise within a track’s connective fiber are carefully calculated tabs on their audience’s emotional pulse.

column1: Eighteen Hours of Static spent a lot of time deep in the thick of things
column2: questioning and distrusting society with relentless fury (""Everybody says it’s getting better all the time / But it’s bad still bad""). Before a Million Universes focuses on ""dissecting"" their problems
column3: as singer Joe Galarraga explained in an interview. Accordingly
column4: they spend less time directly confronting bureaucratic bullshit (One glaring exception is the seething ""Capitalized"" with its sardonic query
column5: ""Tell me what you’re worth/Salary
column6: two weeks off from work?/Call them benefits and perks"") and instead focus on how the macrocosm affects the individual. ""Why live in the moment/If the moment is broken? There could be hope for someone/If we fix it
column7: Galarraga asks on ""Hope for Someone.""

column1: Their political ideologies
column2: meanwhile
column3: have simmered below the surface of the music
column4: expressing themselves in the song’s unpredictable dynamics. ""Meet Where We Are"" is largely muted
column5: growing a little more manic for each repetition of the title and only releasing the tension at the end with an electric jolt.  ""Negative""’s moments of peace are designated for its brief intro before the chaos rolls in via sharp
column6: punctuated shouts and rolling guitar s. ""So Much You"" hits hardest with its simplicity
column7: its sullen comment that ""I haven’t been with myself at all."" None of these songs would have the same effect if rushed
column8: which is what set Big Ups apart from many of their peers.

column1: Before a Million Universes borrows its title from section 48 of Walt Whitman’s ""Song of Myself"" from Leaves of Grass: ""And I say to any man or woman
column2: Let your soul stand cool and composed before a million universes."" Although the quote is never spoken verbatim on the record
column3: Big Ups clearly understand their place within the cosmos. When their time to stand before a million universes arrives
column4: they will approach the unknown with confidence and calmness
column5: like the shadowy figure in Caspar David Friedrich’s ""Wanderer Above the Sea of Fog.""

column1: Nowhere is this so apparent than on ""National Parks
column2: which lies unobtrusively in the later half of the record and is perhaps the standout track. The song is a meditation on the financial difficulties faced by a woman metaphorically meant to reflect Galarraga’s own upbringing. The song concludes with the subject and narrator traveling together: ""We got on a plane and flew across the country/And saw the biggest trees /Bigger than the ones that lined her streets/Bigger than she'd ever seen/Bigger than one could think to exist/I think I saw her say to herself-/""This is everything I've missed."" It is in this moment
column3: with an aerial perspective of the vast world
column4:
that Big Ups open themselves to a million universes and accept the sublime.

 As one of the most isolated cities on the planet
column2: Perth has proven fertile ground for autonomous eccentrics and studio shut-ins
column3: from Sleepy Jackson/Empire of the Sun impresario Luke Steele to Tame Impala mastermind Kevin Parker. And to that list we can now add Jake Webb
column4: who launched his equally wiggy outfit
column5: Methyl Ethel
column6: as a solo home-recording pursuit in 2013. But while mounting acclaim prompted Webb to turn his private concern into a flesh-and-blood touring band
column7: Methyl Ethel’s debut full-length
column8: Oh Inhuman Spectacle
column9: is reflective of the project’s humble
column10: hermetic beginnings
column11: with Webb handling all the production and instrumentation.

column1: Webb is clearly a devout student of 21st-century art-rock
column2: where old-school psychedelia converges with modern technology—think Radiohead circa Kid A (complete with a song called ""Everything Is As It Should Be"")
column3: Yoshimi-era Flaming Lips
column4: Animal Collective’s Merriweather Post Pavilion
column5: the more meditative end of MGMT. But he melts these sources into something more intimate and claustrophobic
column6: with a distinct
column7: disarming voice that infuses his deceptively serene soundscapes with a nervous tension. Through the haunted-house fog of ""Also <span id=""docs-internal-guid-12775de3-62da-96b3-c756-c4e823968288"">Gesellschaft
column8: he delivers his mission statement with Gollum-like creepiness: ""Sometimes
column9: I want to dig a hole and then crawl into it/ I don’t even know if I will come out again/ but I invited you inside."" The result is dream-pop for insomniacs—shadowy
column10: nocturnal music whose surface shimmer barely conceals the fidgety
column11: restless soul lurking underneath.

column1: In spite of the obvious attention to getting the mood right
column2: parts of Oh Inhuman Spectacle feel like works in progress. ""To Swim"" introduces an entrancing
column3: quiet-storm R&B groove but breaks its spell after a too-brief two minutes where ""Depth Perception"" takes its sweet time building up only to sputter out after a single verse. Webb is still working out the difference between channeling his influences and mimicking them: from its space-bound harmonies to its pulsing backdrop
column4: ""Unbalancing Acts"" is such a blatant act of AnCo karaoke that some disillusioned fans may actually prefer it to anything on Painting With.

column1: But if Webb is still mastering the finer points of songcraft
column2: he’s got a handle on melody
column3: the most important piece. The trembling guitar line of ""Rogues"" is pure ’80s dream-pop
column4: but the song’s vacuum-sealed groove and confessional vocal hew closer to ""Dreams."" On the jangly highlight ""Twilight Driving
column5: Webb lets in a little sunlight through the drapes. ""It’s the early morning baby
column6: I say
column7: why don’t you hit the snooze
column8: Webb sings
column9: before the relationship is consummated with a bedsheet-rustling sax solo. On an album that’s mostly consumed with paranoid
column10: paralyzing 3 a.m. thoughts about unfulfilled desire
column11: alien abductions
column12: and fever dreams filled with ""10
column13: 000 screams
column14:
""Twilight Driving"" extols the virtues of staying in bed for the right reasons: because you have someone there to share it with.
