0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/22895/homepage_large.e6ea053b.jpg|Post Pop Depression|3369.0|Iggy Pop|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Loma Vista']|2016-03-10 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 16:00:28.454887|"

 In June of 1977
column2: Iggy Pop appeared on Dinah Shore’s morning variety show
column3: ostensibly to promote his debut solo album
column4: The Idiot
column5: with its producer—David Bowie—in tow to provide moral support. Instead
column6: what transpired was almost an intervention
column7: with Shore expressing quaint maternal concern for Iggy’s troubling behaviour
column8: which included (but wasn’t limited to) chest-slashing and abandoning teenage groupies at airports.  He may go down in history as the patriarch of punk and one of rock’s greatest provocateurs
column9: but Pop's most subversive quality has always been his ability to charm the squares—after all
column10: this is a guy whose songs have been covered by G.G. Allin and Tom Jones.

column1: Some four decades on from his Dinah! stint
column2: Iggy is once again making the rounds on the talk-show circuit with a dapper
column3: red-haired rock-star pal who can help him gain a foothold in the mainstream: Queens of the Stone Age kingpin Josh Homme. While Iggy may no longer be paraded before national audience for the freak-show factor (he seemed positively bashful in the face of reverential audience applause on his recent Colbert appearance)
column4: he finds himself in the same position he was in during the mid-’70s
column5: with the future of the (reformed) Stooges in doubt and the singer in need of direction. Where Bowie whisked Iggy off to Europe to be his electro-shocked ""guinea pig
column6: Homme lured him out to Joshua Tree last year to take stock of his life
column7: reflect on his legacy
column8: and contemplate his place in a modern world where he’s no longer the first ""Iggy"" to come up on a Google search.

column1: The result of these private sessions is Post Pop Depression
column2: a record that recaptures the avant-rock frisson of Iggy’s Bowie collaborations
column3: in exploratory spirit if not explicitly in sound. For a frontman
column4: Iggy has always done his greatest work as a passenger
column5: riding shotgun with a musical force as potent as his personality (be it Bowie
column6: Ron Asheton or James Williamson)
column7: and submitting himself to their sonic abuse just as he’s subjected himself to pelted ice cubes and batteries from his audience. Now
column8: with the man making none-too-subtle hints about impending retirement
column9: he has found a co-conspirator that can nudge him out of his comfort zone.

column1: The album may have been recorded in secrecy
column2: but it has  become an act of public mourning. Homme's friends in The Eagles of Death Metal were caught in the crossfire of last November’s terrorist attacks in Paris
column3: and Iggy is grieving the recent loss of his long-time champion and career savior. As the name and context suggests
column4: Post Pop Depression is awash in a fog of melancholy. The title reads like a harbinger of the come-down that will kick in when he inevitably has to hang up his shirt (or
column5: in his case
column6: put one on). ""I’ve got nothing but my name… I am nothing but my name
column7: he ruefully intones during a moment of quiet reflection
column8: bracing himself for the moment when Iggy Pop has to go back to being Jim Osterberg. Essentially
column9: Post Pop Depression furthers the existential conversations Iggy initiated on 2013’s (likely) Stooges swan song
column10: Ready to Die
column11: though here he’s given more freedom to be introspective without having to overcompensate with songs about worshipping big-breasted women. But unlike previous dark-alley detours like Avenue B or Préliminaires
column12: Post Pop Depression d0esn't sacrifice his swagger.

column1: Musically
column2: the album is certainly not the Queens of the Stooge Age psych-punk blowout the advance billing may have suggested and
column3: at times
column4: the album's ruminative nature makes you long for a little less search and a little more destroy. But it channels Iggy’s legacy in more oblique fashion
column5: through hypnotic
column6: bass-battering grooves (bolstered by QOTSA/Dead Weather multi-instrumentalist Dean Fertita and Arctic Monkeys drummer Matt Helders) that hearken back to the singer’s original Detroit assembly-line inspirations. And that thunderous thump is matched by lush textures: the radiant shoegazey shuffle of ""Gardenia""; the orchestral swirl that caps the tough disco rumble of ""Sunday""; the Kraftwerkian synth shading on ""Break Into Your Heart"" and the ""China Girl"" echoes of ""American Valhalla.""

column1: The record also reasserts Iggy’s facility with simple
column2: suggestive phrases. Pick-up lines don’t get much creepier than the album’s opening couplet: ""I’m gonna break into your heart/ I’m gonna crawl under your skin"". The difference is that this time
column3: he's singing about a culture of me-first indulgence and accordingly
column4: Iggy spends much of Post Pop Depression trying to curb his appetite for excess. ""Gardenia"" may playfully revel in film-noir images of seedy motel hook-ups
column5: but amid the hedonistic throb of ""Sunday"" and jazz-punk swing of ""In the Lobby
column6: he posits that a lustful life can only lead to a six-foot ditch. (""I hope I’m not losing my life tonight
column7: he sings on the latter
column8: punctuating that last word with genuinely terrified

Since the beginning of the year Boeing has been running an ad called ""You Just Wait"" to celebrate the aircraft company’s centennial. In it
column2: Boeing forecasts an extremely optimistic vision of 2116—a future where Boeing’s cutting-edge research helps create a spotless and conflict-free world replete with colonies on Mars
column3: regular travel to the Moon
column4: unlimited clean energy
column5: and smiling innocent children. It's a startlingly ironic piece of corporate lip-service that sidesteps the company’s long history of defense contracts and early pioneering in the military industrial complex. I first saw the ad in the gym
column6: being broadcast across an array of large flat-screen televisions—a dramatic commercial break that followed ominous speculations on the incoming results of the South Carolina primary.

column1: The album I was listening to at the time was Fatima Al Qadiri’s Brute
column2: a piece of music ideally suited to a time of shadowy corporate manipulation and apocalyptic political theater. Qadiri started writing Brute last year while recovering from a knee injury in Kuwait
column3: unable to move much for more than a month. The injury coincided with the height of the horrific news cycle that included the events of Ferguson
column4: Baltimore
column5: and more. Reminded of the first large-scale protest she attended as a freshman in college and shaken by the sheer scale of the police force that met the protesters
column6: she conceived of Brute as a celebration of the right of protest
column7: which is funny when you’ve listened to its 11 songs and realize there isn't all that much celebrating going on. If anything
column8: the album runs as direct counterpoint to the optimistic future that Boeing presents in its ad.

column1: This is made immediately clear by the album’s disconcerting cover: a dead-eyed and inhuman Teletubbie in SWAT gear. The art was designed by the artist Josh Kline
column2: borrowing from his piece Freedom
column3: which the New Yorker described as an ""elegy to lost hope and broken promises."" This is an equally apt description of Qadiri's dystopian music: Starting with ""Endzone
column4: Fatima creates an ominous découpé from live recordings of the unrest in Ferguson. The sounds of gun shots
column5: walkie-talkie beeps
column6: explosions
column7: crowds screaming
column8: overwhelming confusion
column9: and the weaponization of sound via the police’s use of LRADs (Long Range Acoustic Device) is mixed together with a slow burning thump—resulting in a heart-palpitating minute of music. In fact
column10: the album’s three best moments come from the songs that feature extended sample use. In ""Blows"" Al Qadiri opens and closes the track with a now-infamous report by MSNBC news anchor Lawrence O'Donnell chastising the excessive police brutality at Occupy Wall Street. And in the album’s closer ""Power
column11: arguably the album’s only danceable moment
column12: she deftly inserts a cutting interview with ex-LAPD sergeant Cheryl Dorsey on the abuse of police power in the middle of a dizzyingly spacious and confident sonic environment.

column1: These moments bring Qadiri's music somewhere outside the usual purview of electronic music: Brute is in some ways closer to a piece of Brechtian theater than a traditional album. But outside of the successful manipulation of samples and found sounds
column2: there are large blocks of shapeless tracks that excessively borrow from her previous projects. The descending chord progression and sweep of vocals in ""Blood Moon"" feels like it was copy-and-pasted from ""Hydra
column3: a track from her Desert Strike EP. ""Breach
column4: with its swooping helicopter sample and belching bass
column5: is similarly a pastiche
column6: mixing elements of Desert Strike and her last two albums: Asiatisch and Future Brown. There are far too many of these moments in Brute: ""Fragmentation
column7: a moody and string-heavy track in the album’s back half
column8: might have been cut from Asiatisch and retrofitted for Brute.

column1: Overall Brute is a frustrating mish-mosh of middling and artful. When it’s working
column2: there is a certain panache in the high-powered
column3: informationally dense musical speedballs she creates. Tracks like ""Oubliette"" (a reference to claustrophobic French dungeons) and ""10-34"" (the police code for riots) are perfect examples of the push-and-pull animating Qadiri’s most interesting work. When you listen to some of these songs you feel as if you’re being followed. As a conceptual piece
column4: it’s unlike any politically driven electronic music being made today. It illustrates how exhausting and draining it is to be attuned to the problems of the world
column5:
but also how worthwhile it is keep yourself awake and see through the artifice.

column6: for instance

column9: rippling bass beneath Treise’s eerily enchanting voice.

column6: but passion most often dovetails with destruction: ""And I loved hard like iron

column8: Treise is ""sucked up and fucked up"" and a ""sleazebag scumbag scumfuck"" whose face is a ""wretched cliché."" And yet
column9: the track is called

Carter Tanton is a tough guy to pin down. Since 2005
column2: he’s fronted hyped rock bands (the sadly defunct Tulsa)
column3: released solo records that jumped wildly from genre to genre
column4: and collaborated with numerous top-tier indie acts
column5: including Lower Dens
column6: Twin Shadow
column7: and Marissa Nadler. He's a hard worker with serious chops—as a guitarist
column8: a vocalist
column9: and a producer—but his career’s volatility has tended to keep these talents on the sidelines.

column1: Jettison the Valley marks a fresh start for the Baltimore native
column2: an attempt to reintroduce Tanton as a thoughtfully earnest singer-songwriter. (Tanton considers Jettison to be his first proper solo album even though it’s the third he’s released under his own name.) His last effort

column4: flirted with synth-heavy electronica

column6: shoegaze and Paul Westerberg-worshipping indie rock—all recorded under a lo-fi haze. On Jettison

column2: a source of lazy metaphors and cheap emotion. But Tanton handles the story (Carter and his British girlfriend move to England
column3: where they live in a caravan outside Bristol and later in a tiny attic apartment in Oxford
column4: before calling it quits) with nuance and compassion. Tanton wrote the entire record in Britain while the relationship disintegrated

column6: over-bright production.

column2: pedal steel
column3: thick harmonies
column4: and supple
column5: kick-heavy percussion reminiscent of Neil Young’s Harvest—a vision of sun-dappled California as seen through rain-drenched British pub windows. On the gorgeous opener
column6: ""Twenty-Nine Palms
column7: Tanton finds himself standing in the California desert with his mind on a woman (possibly across the Atlantic
column8: it’s not entirely clear) ""who took me rather far out of view."" While on the next track
column9: ""Fresh Faced Claire
column10: the perspective flips: Now Tanton’s stuck in ""the old empire"" living in a ""halfway home for the breaking down
column11: his relationship slowly collapsing as he longs to return to the sunny West Coast. This dichotomy—California vs. England
column12: sunlight vs. clouds
column13: movement vs. stasis—remains in tension throughout Jettison

column1: Beck’s Sea Change—a shining example of the hoary old breakup record if there ever was one—would be the obvious musical touchstone here
column2: if it wasn’t for Tanton’s emotive
column3: breathy
column4: very un-Beck-like tenor. It’s an undeniably beautiful thing

column8: as they are on the brooding Smiths-tribute ""Poison in the Dart.""

column1: All of which leaves Tanton’s fluidly inventive guitar playing as the record’s most enduring pleasure. British folkies like Richard Thompson and Michael Chapman are lodestars
column2: as is
column3: oddly enough

There are surprises too: The rambling title track (starring Marissa Nadler on lead vocals) stops abruptly just before the four-minute mark before embarking on an extended instrumental coda that builds to a hot rash of dueling 6- and 12-string guitars.

column1: For his first major statement as a solo artist
column2: Tanton could have made an entire record of jagged indie rock (see Free Clouds’ ""Horrorscope"")

column4: or Day-Glo electronica (see anything from his recent synth project Luxury Liners). Instead

column10:
transforms himself into a singer-songwriter. Surely that is a statement worth making.

column4: Downtown cool

Two events have defined the British electro-rock band the Big Pink since their last

column1: Try
column2: if you can
column3: to close your eyes and picture the environment in which the Big Pink released their first
column4: and still best
column5: record <i>A Brief History of Love
column6: in 2009. Bloggers are losing their grip on the meritocracy of independent music
column7: the general aesthetic is shifting from fluorescent party attire to nouveau goth black and basic athletic wear. On the strength of two meteoric singles
column8: ""Velvet"" and the boisterous
column9: anthemic peak of ""Dominos

column1: Which brings us to ""Hightimes"" the lead single off of Empire Underground

And the message couched behind the layers of distortion couldn't be more clear: ""It's about high time/ Better than the last time"" wails Furze as Charteris' pleasantly smooth vocals sail beneath his. Big booming drums and rubbery basslines roll across the song
column3: almost but never quite succumbing to a sheen of static. It's obvious that the Big Pink were aware that their future depended on getting in touch with the sound that made them

column7: where some of the most interesting musical innovations are being made
column8: is a coveted skill. It boasts an instantly catchy hook
column9: a memorable chorus and a world-weary quality that cuts through any traces of saccharine. The band have already announced a third album in the works

In an era when music is primarily distributed digitally

column3: though
column4: connotes the same wholeness and completion as any given album

column7: rounded project that does not ask very much of its listener. With its quick runtime and tight structure
column8: it is neither groundbreaking nor entirely lacking inspiration. Though prone to drift into the background

column1: A disciple of Flying Lotus (and the first woman signed to his Brainfeeder label)
column2: Lee began her career as an L.A. beatmaker

column4: samples
column5: and smooth instrumentals. On 2013's Ultra-released Half Shadows
column6: she largely maintained her warped ethos

column8: Lee began crafting songs with room for singers to perform. With that transition

column11: nor was it terribly distinct from that of other producers creating club-ready tracks that were still cool enough for solo listening. Not even a then-unheralded Anderson .Paak made much of a lasting impression.

column2: Fovere has five. (Lee samples her own ""Hemisphere"" with Gavin Turek on opener ""I'm Waiting
column3: too
column4: making it more like six out of seven.) Nevertheless
column5: their lyrics are largely ignorable. A suddenly empowered .Paak
column6: the exception to the rule
column7: turns in a commanding performance on ""Put It Down"" (which also features KRNE)
column8: but everyone else is just an agreeable element in a pop-ready electronic track.

column1: There is hardly a daring track on Fovere. ""Put It Down"" is its most impressive
column2: but neatly fits Lee's previously laid framework
column3: simply a couple notches up on the intensity scale
column4: complete with Skrillex-ian drops. ""Penny"" is a potentially strong ballad hamstrung by nonsensical songwriting. Closer ""Wound Up""  cues up some house sounds
column5: a genre in which Lee sounds more like a visitor than an innovator. Even if it's lacking highs (or lows)
column6: Fovere is strong enough to be pleasant. It doesn't ask to be grappled with nor taken at much more than face value
column7:
but it finds Jennifer Lee further cementing herself as a viable pop composer.

""I made To Pimp a Butterfly for you

column1: No other rapper has taken up so much real estate in the past 12 months while releasing so little music and sharing as little about themselves as Kendrick. TPAB—a Grammy-winning ride of densely knotted rhymes
column2: tangled ideas
column3: and deep sounds—positioned Kendrick Lamar as a reluctant messiah figure
column4: and its dialogues with self and manifestations of God resisted quick-and-easy unpacking. Now
column5: he’s released a handful-and-a-half of song sketches in a project that's neither album nor mixtape (or even EP or LP)

column2: subtitled with a date of ""05.28.2013

column1: One of the most enchanting things about this project is hearing how Kendrick manipulates his own voice before the studio modulations kick in. His vocal tics and morphs have long been technologically-aided affairs
column2: but on ""untitled 02"" he's full of elastic long tails—partially gleeful Lil Wayne
column3: wholly sanctifying choir sinner. He's crying for his bosses—both Top Dawg and God—while lamenting urban addiction and dysfunction
column4: and contemplating mortality. ""World is going brazy/ Where did we go wrong?/ It's a tidal wave/ It's a thunderdome
column5: he sing-raps
column6: sounding half-possessed
column7: half-saved. For the second half of the song
column8: he includes the firestarter verse he performed in January on ""The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon."" But the scorching iteration of that live performance is nowhere here—he's laid-back and matter-of-fact
column9: but his threat just as heavy: ""I can put a rapper on life support/ Guarantee that's something none of you want.""

column1: At times Kendrick is joined by other voices—TDE's Jay Rock and Punch
column2: and Wise (again) on ""untitled 05
column3: which sounds like a long jazz-groove session made just to find the best parts; Cee-Lo Green shows up over the bossa nova breeziness of Adrian Younge and Ali Shaheed Muhammed's ""untitled 06""—but
column4: much like TPAB

column6: and its refrain is ""head is the answer/head is the future""—which may or may not be a multiple-entendre about sex
column7: life and spirituality. Because Kendrick is so share-averse

column1: These numbers are packed with more information and moods than the 35-minute running time suggests. On ""untitled 01"" he dons his robes as God's servant

column3: New Zealand-based singer-guitarist Kane Strang traffics in off-the-cuff
column4: off-kilter indie-rock songs that somehow sound like the products of great struggle and effort. Listening to Blue Cheese

column1: Blue Cheese was recorded by Strang while house-sitting his parents’ house
column2: but it’s hardly a reservoir of sensitive
column3: singer-songwriterly introspection. Rather
column4: it’s the sound of a young
column5: restless soul taking full advantage of the empty environs by making an inspired racket and broadcasting his innermost musings to no one in particular. Kane Strang isn't just this guy's name
column6: it's also a handily onomatopoetic descriptin of the odd jangle of his guitar. Strang actually plays all the instruments here
column7: a fact betrayed by the sludgy
column8: rumbling bass lines
column9: the lumbering
column10: drum machines
column11: and the one-finger synths that feel like placeholders for the brass and string sections he can’t yet afford.

column1: And though Blue Cheese is being billed as a proper debut in the wake of 2013’s demos collection
column2: A Pebble and a Paper Crane
column3: a certain slapdash aesthetic remains: songs have a tendency cut out before they even reach a chorus
column4: and the uniformity of their sound
column5: arrangements
column6: and temperament suggests it was all cranked out sequentially in a single session
column7: with the console settings untouched from one song to the next. Over its brief 28-minute run time
column8: there are moments when you’ll be itching for a change of scenery
column9: but Strang has a gift for pulling diamonds from the rough

column1: In his most inspired moments
column2: Strang comes off like Panda Bear doing a one-man garage-band remount of Pixies slow jams. He shares both acts' penchant for twisting innocent sing-alongs into bizarro meditations: On the surface
column3: ""The Web"" is an optimistic
column4: wide-eyed ode to blossoming romance
column5: but it soon becomes clear Strang’s paramour is an online connection he’s never met IRL. He never quite works up a sweat—even the album’s lone rave-up ""Never Kissed a Blonde"" is more of a wallow  than a romp. As per its DIY design
column6: this album is about doing what you can with what you've got. But like the unattainable women Strang is fond of serenading
column7:
the album’s pop potential leaves you imagining all that could be under different circumstances.

column3: Anna Meredith sounded drunk on power and spoiling for a fight. The 2012 cut was the acclaimed Scottish composer's first mainstream release after nearly two decades in the classical world

column5: which she wages with miraculous and exhilarating builds: ""Scrimshaw"" starts out sounding melancholy and graceful eventually bursts into an unrelenting cosmic endorphin rush. On ""Last Rose
column6: Her plaintive
column7: piercing vocals intensify the song's sense of loss. Her crescendos don't always lead to a drop

column2: and
column3: wouldn't you know it

column1: Meredith's diverse array of classical commissions has included making music inspired by MRI scanners

Her first wholly indepedent project reveals her to be one of the most innovative minds in modern British music: She wears her obvious theoretical grounding lightly and never lets it obstruct her ecstatic quest for new ideas and deranged stimuli. And Varmints is a knockout

Over the course of four albums
column2: Thao Nguyen has been on a mission to get down more than stay down. From her winsome 2008 debut onward
column3: twee has given way to twitch
column4: her formative folksiness gradually overpowered by funk. And with that shift

column7: We the Common

column3: lyrically

The only car that can even begin to fit Mary Lattimore’s 47-string Lyon and Healy harp is a vintage Volvo Station Wagon

column3: the harp hogging all of the car’s square footage

column5: Kurt Vile
column6: Thurston Moore

column10: playing by herself

column12: practicing

column1: In 2014 she was awarded a Pew Fellowship

column4: she comes close

column1: At the Dam’s latter half is more concerned with explicit archiving—it’s obsessed with freezing transient or chance moments. ""The Quiet at Night
column2: ""Jaxine Drive
column3: and ""Ferris Wheel

column6: trail off into nooks and crannies
column7: and bubble up towards unknown directions. Lattimore uses stray harp-string plucks to suggest the blips of a submarine’s radar throughout

column3: this kind of slowness ""invites reciprocity: it makes the listener want to fill the spaces with his own content."" The disjunctions and hiccups in the sound

column7: Lattimore borrows from the same decaying spirit that defined William Basinski's The Disintegration Loops. On its face a seemingly modest project

column9:
offering a meditation on the ever-evolving relationship Lattimore has to her instrument and the spaces she shares it with.

Soulwax are nothing if not mercurial. The band was founded in the mid '90s as a sort of Flemish take on Britpop
column2: only to trade grunge guitars for analog synths a few years later. Around the same time

column6: among other things

column8: as the group remixed fellow dance punk acts like LCD Soundsystem and weirdly — and most successfully — their own material
column9: with 2005's Nite Versions. During their most active period
column10: Soulwax had an uncanny ability to stay on trend

column12: European electro and big-tent EDM consecutively. Today
column13: you could either laud them for their foresight or accuse them of carpetbagging

column1: <div><span>Lately
column2: though
column3: the band has kept a lower profile
column4: occupying themselves with their Radio Soulwax project

column8: Soulwax's hometown. For the sixteen-track album
column9: the band invented fifteen fictional personas
column10: each with its own sound
column11: aesthetic
column12: and backstory that draw from different decades of club culture. <span>Genres range from Studio 1 reggae to indie rock
column13: under pseudonyms like Burning Phlegm
column14: White Virgins
column15: and Noah's Dark. (The Shitz do double duty – no pun intended.) That a band could attempt a project like this with such strict historical verisimilitude is a fascinating technical exercise; the fact that many of these songs are actually decent is just an added bonus.

column1: The album opens with ""The Best Thing
column2: a synthpop track starring a vocalist named Charlotte
column3: who plays the role of R&B diva. ""You're the worst thing that always happens to me
column4: she sings
column5: over percolating synths. The effect is more Jessie Ware than Janet Jackson
column6: but it's a decent pop song that sounds authentic enough to be an actual
column7: if unremarkable
column8: '90s single. Then it's on to The Shitz with ""How Long
column9: a slab of angular indie rock ripped from the pages of NME. (RIYL: Arctic Monkeys
column10: Franz Ferdinand
column11: The Libertines). Listening to these two tracks together provides a good idea of what you're in for over the course of the album: disparate sounds stacked together in ways that make little sense outside the context of the movie they soundtrack. Sometimes it works: There's probably no reason why Turkish pop should play next to Italian electro
column12: but ""Çölde Kutup Ayisi"" and ""Ti Ricordi Di Me"" are legitimately enjoyable back-to-back.

column1: Probably because it's closest to their ""real"" sound

column3: which is pretty often. White Virgins' ""Turn Off The Lights
column4: for instance

column8: but what made ""Radio Soulwax"" and Nite Visions great was how the band holistically united various styles with little effort. Nothing felt overthought; it just worked.

column1: Belgica

In the end Belgica sounds like what it is: an impressive exercise in musicology that never quite transcends its core concept. Soulwax deserve to be celebrated for their ambition and their enormous contribution to the film

The level of pure athleticism required to play the violin reveals the pained rock faces of the classic rock axe-slingers to be a dramatic ruse. The touch it takes to make an electric guitar sing is unbelievably light
column2: and there’s a strap to hold it in place. Violinists (and violists and string bassists
column3: for that matter) not only must hold a not-insignificantly heavy wooden body up for an extended period of time
column4: they also have to maintain a steady bowing arm and pivot carefully to maintain control of the sound. Composer and violinist Sarah Neufeld — a career-long touring and recording member of Arcade Fire — delivers her fair share of grimaces in the band’s energetic live show
column5: and she’s clearly earning them.

column1: In her compositions as a solo artist
column2: the relentless physicality of her technique is part of the listening experience
column3: and immediately central to its appeal. In the short pieces that make up Neufeld’s latest album The Ridge
column4: the sound of her bow moving frenetically back and forth across the bridge of her violin often settles into a blur. There is a sharp contradiction between the gossamer blocks of sound we hear
column5: and the limber
column6: near-constant motion that makes them possible. Neufeld presses down on the strings to create a whistle-like harmonic that surges in between notes and chords; it’s the violin equivalent of the otherworldly-sounding tones her comrade-in-arms Colin Stetson (who appears here playing lyricon) favors in his sax playing. Reverb and delay effects enhance the atmospheric effect of Neufeld’s playing
column7: creating moments where sound seems to be coming from another room.

column1: While Neufeld’s previous solo outing Hero Brother daringly explored the overlap between classical minimalism and regional American fiddling techniques
column2: The Ridge’s musical vocabulary is more familiar and less transportive. It starts unconvincingly with the title track
column3: a piece of high-dramatic ""chamber rock"" which recalls the Arcade Fire-related instrumental unit Bell Orchestre in which Neufeld participated in during the '00s. Wringing out a few unsurprising chords for maximal self-importance
column4: it’s a propulsive
column5: amelodic piece which seems like it could work better on traditional rock instruments
column6: or with a denser ensemble.

column1: Neufeld largely avoids linear melodies  — her feathery
column2: very intermittent vocals add little in this regard — in favor of rhythmic cells in the Philip Glass tradition. Often
column3: with the help of effects
column4: these are reduced to synthetic-sounding pulsations. Like a good several-times-removed disciple of the minimalists
column5: her writing is best when it revels in contradictory rhythms overlaid on top of each other -- when complexity is more of a focal point. The appealing
column6: fractured Afrobeat cadence of ""We’ve Got a Lot"" gradually falls together like gears locking into place
column7: and the explosive pizzicato of ""The Glow"" experiment with unsteady meter changes.

column1: Though compositionally The Ridge feels less exploratory than Neufield’s previous work
column2: it is still a moving document of her engaging
column3: virtuosic playing. It’s hard to make strings-based
column4: indie-rock-tinged instrumental music in this vein sound fresh. But as in her past work
column5: Neufeld’s focused
column6: restless recordings invite the listener to share in the intensity of her ritual as a performer
column7:
creating a necessary and refreshing air of intimacy.

column1: In the first half of the five-track EP

column3: monochromatic cafe chatter: ""<i>En'ne'NE'ga'ger
column4: En'ne'NE'ga'ger
column5: En'ne'NE'ga'ger""—""Let’s talk
column6: let’s talk
column7: let’s talk."" A bass player warms up nearby
column8: and street sounds tumble in whenever the door swishes open. Slowly
column9: in a sort of drawn-out Proustian moment
column10: the artist’s past rises to meet him: a low liturgical drone emerges as if from thin air; a krar (lyre) melody bubbles to the surface; his reverie thickens; and the listener sinks in deeper with him.

column7: longing

column13:
already off through the next portal to another dimension somewhere closer to freedom.

Post-rock bands aren't bound by the same rules that rock bands are. Take Yndi Halda
column3: from Brighton
column4: England. <span>They completely ignored that old rock aphorism that ""you have your whole life to make your first album and six months to make the second."" Nearly a decade after their debut
column5: Enjoy Eternal Bliss
column6: the band are finally releasing their second LP. But post-rock bands do have their own set of boxes to check off albeit ones that are slightly more specific. Twinkling guitar and bass harmonics? Present! Songs that sprawl uniformly over ten minutes? Absolutely! Moments of quiet that build toward overwrought crescendos? Just look at the wavelengths of these songs on SoundCloud!

column1: Although these traits are all present on Under Summer
column2: they are used sparingly
column3: alongside new aspirations of a band who are clearly challenging themselves and the very conventions of post-rock. Like its predecessor
column4: Under Summer contains only four songs
column5: each more than 10 minutes in length with distinct movements. The elegiac violin that created a niche for the band with the first album is still here too. But the biggest difference is the appearance of vocals
column6: and not just the choral la-la placeholders of Enjoy Eternal Bliss. The lyrics here are mostly outdoorsy and naturalistic
column7: with moments of powerful simplicity.

column1: But there are also occasional dropped articles—""We sneak out at night
column2: in time with owl cry""—and crammed syllables. This occasional awkwardness is the only aspect of Under Summer that feels tentative. A heartfelt line like
column3: ""It's something I know
column4: not just something I believe
column5: on Under Summer's final track
column6: ""This Very Flight
column7: should sting with spiritual conviction
column8: especially alongside the orchestral intensity of the moment
column9: but the line is delivered demurely like they don't trust the importance of what they're saying.

column1: Yndi Halda's growth shouldn't simply be measured by the fact that they're singing now
column2: though. Enjoy Eternal Bliss felt like a band studying the post-rock playbook
column3: and its consciously mournful songs felt forced. Here they take more risks
column4: like taking a sharp turn at what would have logically been a swelling crescendo on ""Helena
column5: the album's sole instrumental number
column6: and deciding to pull into a Fender Rhodes piano groove. Or using what sounds like a banjo and slide guitar. How very un-post-rock! And the last four minutes of the album are gently strummed major chords on an acoustic guitar accompanied by elementary—but nevertheless inspired—piano. With a more adventurous spirit and less rigid adherence to rules than its precursor
column7:
this album seems more concerned with expressing feelings than manufacturing them.

It shouldn't come as a surprise that Loretta Lynn
column2: even over half a century into her musical career
column3: has made another strong album. There are few to zero significant aberrations in the Kentucky-born country singer's 55-strong discography; no arranger or producer (admittedly
column4: she mostly stuck with the same one) has ever managed to obfuscate her deeply ingrained musical personality
column5: which is always a little bigger than the specific song she is singing. Most of her albums—her last
column6: 2004's Jack White-produced <i>Van Lear Rose
column7: being the primary outlier—only feature three or four of her much-remarked-upon originals
column8: and her latest
column9: Full Circle
column10: is no exception. As always
column11: the unmistakable
column12: self-assured perspective of her original music is present in her delivery of others' material
column13: making her able to breathe new life into songs country fans have heard dozens of times.

column1: There are countless popular-music legacy figures out there who continue to tour and record every five years
column2: even though they are millionaires several times over
column3: seemingly out of habit or because they don't know what else to do. Sometimes they do so in flagrant opposition to doctor's orders
column4: and we're left with trails of YouTube documentation of vocal deterioration. The situation couldn't be more different for the equally persistent 83-year-old Lynn
column5: whose voice remains miraculously well-preserved. Its slight fluctuations are commensurate with her age and a lifetime of ardent performing
column6: relatively untouched by overexertion or hard living (Lynn has always prided herself on staying well away from that). Throughout Full Circle
column7: she often hovers in the airier middle range on her voice
column8: choosing her throaty power notes wisely.

column1: This elegant and tenuous note in her singing provides a new poignance. Her slight
column2: ribboning strains of vibrato make the revisits of earlier hits included here—""Fist City"" and ""Whispering Sea
column3: the B-side from her first single—feel like meaningful recastings rather than retreads. Stripped of golden-era Nashville glitz
column4: they affectionately and winkingly recall of the attitude that made Lynn an instant anomaly and sensation when her first records hit radio circulation at the dawn of the 1960s.

column1: Full Circle's covers also reflect back on Lynn's past. ""Always On My Mind"" was a cross-genre hit for soul-disco diva Gwen McCrae before it became a standard for Elvis and Willie Nelson; here
column2: Lynn presents the malleable song—a wistful portrait of a troubled-but-passionate relationship that ended as suddenly as it began—in the guise of country-gospel. Lynn's controversial amour fou relationship with her husband Oliver
column3: or ""Doo
column4: has been widely documented—most notoriously by Tommy Lee Jones in the popular 1980 film adaptation of Lynn's first memoir
column5: Coal Miner's Daughter—and one can't help but recall Lynn's many bittersweet descriptions of the marriage while listening. The ballad is the most affecting of several songs on Full Circle which find the narrator
column6: with an air of finality
column7: reflecting back on a life they lived as best they knew how. Others
column8: like the distinctly modern Nelson duet ""Lay Me Down
column9: directly contemplate mortality—in the context of this record
column10: somewhat discomfitingly.

column2: Full Circle finds her assembling a time capsule. The album is a snapshot
column3: intimate and largely acoustic

column7: even by Lynn herself

column9: it's clear from listening to the two Carter Family tunes Lynn covers here the easy command she has on their more austere
column10: folksong-influenced style. Lynn sounds just as natural singing these centuries-old melodies as her own. The upbeat ""Black Jack David
column11: recorded by the Carters in 1940
column12: turns out to be one of Full Circle's most spirited vocal performances

column14: Autoharp-driven ""I Never Will Marry"" its most moving.

column1: However
column2: you don't need to appreciate the lineage of the music

column4: to sense the breadth of time and musical tradition reflected here. Lynn's deft phrasing and bold delivery

column6: is sustenance enough. Only a interpreter as shrewd and tasteful as Loretta Lynn could find the inherent commonalities in these songs

but like a powerful choice.

Imagine that you had made a great
column2: enduring piece of art with a couple of your friends when you were barely out of your teens. Now imagine that it's more than 30 years later
column3: you no longer have anything in common with your former comrades
column4: and all anybody wants to hear from you is that one glorious burst of hormonal fury you came up with as alienated kids.

column1: That's roughly the position in which Violent Femmes find themselves in 2016
column2: as they release their first album of new material since 2000. Singer/guitarist Gordon Gano has recently noted that he and bassist Brian Ritchie ""don't agree on most basic things""
column3: which is putting it mildly: Ritchie sued Gano in 2007
column4: and snapped that ""it is his karma that he lost his songwriting ability many years ago"". Original drummer Victor DeLorenzo rejoined the group when it reunited to play Coachella 2013
column5: but quickly left
column6: citing <a href=""http://www.jsonline.com/entertainment/musicandnightlife/victor-delorenzo-speaks-out-about-leaving-violent-femmes-b9955275z1-215664571.html"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">""disrespect
column7: dishonesty and greed"".

column1: Somehow
column2: though
column3: Gano
column4: Ritchie and DeLorenzo's replacement
column5: Dresden Dolls' Brian Viglione (who departed the group at the end of last year)
column6: managed to scrape together an album's worth of tunes. Some of them were resuscitated from demo tapes dating back to the era when that meant ""cassettes""; three were co-written by Gano and a handful of song doctors; ""What You Really Mean"" is a cover of a song by Gano's sister.

column1: The charitable way to describe We Can Do Anything is that it's a back-to-basics record: ten brief songs in the band's most immediately recognizable idiom
column2: with Gano singing and strumming with the twitchiness of a guilty teenager
column3: Ritchie snapping strings like he's shooting rubber bands
column4: and Viglione's brushes smacking the hell out of a single snare drum. A less charitable perspective is that it's a pale Silly Putty copy of Violent Femmes
column5: with the vocal and instrumental tone reprised precisely from 33 years ago. It touches on all of the Femmes' familiar themes: masturbation (""Foothills"")
column6: Christian awe (""Holy Ghost"")
column7: lady troubles (""Big Car""
column8: which starts as leaden double-entendre and becomes a leaden murder ballad in its final line). The closest thing to a deviation from the formula here is ""I Could Be Anything""
column9: a beer-kegger polka (with accordion!) about a dragon-slaying hero
column10: which seems like it's heading toward a narrative twist but never comes up with one.

column1: Violent Femmes have spent most of their career in the shadow of their debut album. (On their 2014 tour
column2: they played it in its entirety
column3: and last year's gigs inevitably began with ""Blister in the Sun"" and ""Kiss Off"" and ended with ""Add It Up."") But they used to get some juice out of trying to get out from under it. The most memorable recordings of their subsequent career have been the biggest departures: the industrial fever-hallucination ""Machine""
column4: the holy-rolling shock-skronk of ""Black Girls""
column5: the in-your-face T. Rex cover ""Children of the Revolution."" They're not trying to pull off anything like that any more; instead
column6: they're polishing up the durable façade of their signature sound
column7:
while the songwriting that it used to support has crumbled.

column6: to become more attuned to old-school cosmic energies.

column1: At the time
column2: bands like Comets on Fire
column3: Six Organs of Admittance
column4: Dead Meadow
column5: and OM were ascendant
column6: drawing both from underground American noise music and vintage psychedelic rock. The music was familiar
column7: but strange and extreme—drawing from the past
column8: but not overly reverential of it. And then it just sort of passed out of view
column9: with true believers continuing to plug away in a slightly diminished spotlight.

column1: The members of Heron Oblivion made heavy creative contributions to that scene. Singer and drummer Meg Baird performed in Philadelphia-based folk collective Espers and released three solo records via Drag City. Ethan Miller and guitarist Noel Von Harmonson both played in Comets on Fire
column2: while Miller also lead the breezier Comets offshoot
column3: Howlin Rain. Second guitarist Charlie Saufley played in San Francisco’s Assemble Head in Sunburst Sound. In other words
column4: their pedigree in this small world is without parallel.

column1: Though there’s plenty of common ground
column2: Heron Oblivion is
column3: in a way
column4: an unlikely alignment of talents. Baird’s previous projects were hushed and pastoral
column5: while Comets were unhinged and explosive. It’s the ability to navigate between these two extremes that makes the quartet’s debut compelling. The songs slip easily between dynamics—harmony to dissonance
column6: quiet to loud. Baird’s stripped-down drumming style prevents Miller—a guitarist
column7: here relegated to bass duties in an effort to keep things fresh—from veering into choogling territory. A shared yen for searing fuzz tones keeps extended zone-outs lively.

column1: Between Kurt Vile
column2: Solar Motel
column3: Endless Boogie
column4: and Steve Gunn
column5: there’s no shortage of excellent cosmic-sounding guitar music at the moment. But Heron Oblivion is an outlier— louder
column6: spookier
column7: and less optimistic. The songs are moody and dark
column8: with clear moments of guitar solo-driven catharsis. In that regard
column9: Heron Oblivion feel more indebted to the the original wave of cosmic guitar rock
column10: the one that crested during the political ferment of the '60s. A long guitar solo
column11: at that time
column12: implied a certain spiritual heft
column13: a yearning for transformation. There's a moment at the end of album closer ""Your Hollows"" where Baird's voice ascends and hovers on a single note
column14: blurring into what sounds like a sustained guitar tone or delay trail. The sound is organic
column15:
but unnatural in its timbre and length. It’s a howl that slips seamlessly from the earthly into the supernatural.

Anenon's Petrol is bookended by the sounds of freeway noise
column2: so you don't have to look very far to find the meaning behind the title. But it's fortuitous that the album
column3: with its viscous
column4: reverberant swirls of reeds and violin
column5: has the same dusky resonance as the color. If this is an album about Anenon's native Los Angeles
column6: the setting is somewhere just past sundown
column7: the sky steadily leeched of color as lines of cars streak toward the horizon like rivers full of embers.

column1: Anenon is Brian Allen Simon
column2: an electronic producer and saxophone player
column3: and Petrol is his third album. It represents a major step forward for him. His debut
column4: 2012's Inner Hue
column5: evoked Tycho and the Field in its shimmering ambient sketches and crisp drums; 2014's Sagrada went further in its pursuit of a new kind of beat music composed using acoustic instruments
column6: Fender Rhodes
column7: and tons of reverb. <span>But its rhythms lacked distinction—""Lights and Rocks"" was basically an Aphex Twin pastiche
column8: and the TR-808 sounds elsewhere on the album seemed out of place—while his saxophone melodies sometimes scanned as rote. But Petrol
column9: a looser
column10: messier album
column11: does a better job of communicating new ideas
column12: and its emotional depth feels less gestural and more genuine.

column1: The album's raw material comes from an improvisation session alongside violinist Yvette Holzwarth and bass clarinetist Max Kaplan; back in his studio
column2: working with the drummer Jon-Kyle Mohr
column3: he reworked those tapes
column4: cutting and resampling them into their final
column5: hybrid electronic form. The opening ""Body"" is typical for the album
column6: with cool
column7: analog-style synthesizers and the humming of distant cars creating a buoyant cushion for Simon's melancholy saxophone riffing. The mood is evocative of Vangelis' Blade Runner soundtrack
column8: but elsewhere things are less placid and misty-eyed; the drums on ""Once"" and ""CXP""  recreate the head-over-heels tumble of drum 'n' bass
column9: inspiring greater urgency in Simon's sax work. ""Mouth"" and ""Petrol
column10: meanwhile
column11: bring to mind Philip Glass' work. Simon has described how the album was partly inspired by the experience of standing on a pedestrian walkway above the freeway—""I found a sense of Zen in that as I was making the record
column12: he told the Fader—and it's easy to hear parallels between the spinning chrome wheels his music evokes and the sped-up industrial choreography of the Glass-scored Koyaanisqatsi.

column1: But some of the finest moments on Petrol turn out to be the simplest. ""Hinoki"" is nothing but two minutes of downcast sax melody over fathomless reverb
column2: and ""Panes"" takes a similar idea and adds a bassline fashioned from bleating bass clarinet. In the first few seconds of ""Panes
column3: a human voice is briefly audible—as far as I can make out
column4: it says ""Maybe""—before it disappears into the murk again. It's the only voice on the album
column5: but its appearance seems fitting; if Petrol's twin themes are the way that cars and distance define the experience of Los Angeles
column6: that snippet of speech is what creates a sense of human scale before the album's lonely denouement
column7:
when everything that has come before disappears beneath the din of freeway noise.

column3: the adventurous band has explored the astral infinity of extreme psychedelia and the grim oblivion of extreme metal. As the name Oranssi Pazuzu (essentially ""orange demon"") suggests

column1: Heavy metal hasn’t disappeared from their sound. ""Havuluu
column2: for instance
column3: folds great
column4: big
column5: back-of-the-throat yells into its fuzz and
column6: about halfway in
column7: pivots on a blast beat and a ghastly scream that suggest Darkthrone. ""Lahja"" is powered by a Deep Purple proto-metal riff

column13: with barked imprecations and martial drums pitted against sparkling vibraphone and guitars so free and bright they recall Sonny Sharrock. With Värähtelijä

column16: what you bring to it

column3: to make them work together through relatively concise songs with discrete structures. You could almost imagine those tunes coming through the speakers of some large outdoor festival
column4: like the aggressive Finnish answer to Sweden’s Dungen. Here
column5: though
column6: Oranssi Pazuzu show no such concern for restraint or expectation. The 17-minute ""Vasemman Käden Hierarkia"" feels like an album unto itself
column7: brilliantly twisting between noise-rock outbursts and electric Miles allusions
column8: distorted doom passages and sinister soundtrack references.

column1: Typically
column2: when bands dig themselves out of black metal pigeonholes (or
column3: really
column4: metal pigeonholes at large) and fold their ideas inside other
column5: more accessible styles
column6: worlds of possibility and popularity can open up. See
column7: for instance
column8: Tribulation’s own turn out of death metal basics during the last two years or Deafheaven’s climb toward the light across its own half-decade. Oranssi Pazuza’s step out of metal
column9: though

column11: grotesque record

column13: Oranssi Pazuzu is out of the old black metal box and lost—wonderfully
column14:
strangely—somewhere between heaven and hell.

Sixteen years after being released on CD
column2: Bowie at the Beeb finally gets the vinyl box set treatment
column3: with some scanty bonus bits: a fantastic 1971 rendition of ""Oh! You Pretty Things"" where Bowie and Mick Ronson perform as a duo
column4: from the Japanese CD
column5: and a previously unheard version of ""The Supermen
column6: from March 1970
column7: where he's backed by the Hype. It's tempting to assume the collection of his early BBC sessions is a posthumous cash-in
column8: except that it was announced in December
column9: three weeks before Bowie's death
column10: thus making it a viable part of his beautifully choreographed stage exit. While the rush to winkle out clues from Blackstar in the wake of his passing felt a bit like pointing out how a magician does his tricks
column11: it's worth asking why he pushed us toward these formative live sessions as he knew his life was coming to its end.

column1: Simply put
column2: perhaps it's nothing more than a show of gratitude toward an organization whose early belief in him never wavered (and whose publicly funded existence is always under threat from Britain's Conservative government). Bowie recalled failing a 1965 audition to work with the BBC
column3: who stated
column4: in their classic patrician tone
column5: ""'This vocalist is devoid of personality and sings all the wrong notes.'"" And yet they gave him another shot
column6: as Bowie pointed out: ""So in your inimitable manner and with tremendous enthusiasm you got me back on for another audition
column7: which I passed the second time around
column8: which gave me freewheeling access to a lifetime of singing all the wrong notes.""

column1: This four-LP collection spans Bowie's second-ever BBC session
column3: through to May 1972
column4: after which he wouldn't record another until 1991. Rather than a sign of rupture
column5: that 19-year gap is possibly an indirect result of the BBC's support: After Bowie performed ""Starman"" on the network's ""Top of the Pops"" in July 1972
column6: his fame rose enormously
column7: leading him to America
column8: tax exile in Switzerland and Germany
column9: and into periods of immense productivity (and
column10: of course
column11: druggy preoccupations). Manager Tony DeFries may not have seen the point in having him do more sessions.

column1: Yet in the early days
column2: back when Bowie was still an earnest Anthony Newley wannabe whose career could never get seem to get off the ground
column3: Auntie's arms were always there to scoop him up and give him another shot. His first chances came from John Peel
column4: and from there he trickled down through Radio 1's primetime slots; by 1970
column5: he was being given hour-long live appearances on the station. It's an appealingly linear type of progress
column6: and a literal one
column7: too; unlike Five Years and other more carefully curated Bowie box sets
column8: Bowie at the Beeb is an anatomy of how he became a rock star.

column1: The first session here (and second
column2: historically) was recorded for Peel in May 1968
column3: and finds Bowie in romantic mode
column4: though bigger ideas are taking shape: the swoony ""London Bye
column5: Ta-Ta"" characterizes the influx of immigrant communities to London as two lovers who don't make it. ""Karma Man"" and ""Silly Boy Blue"" both deal with Buddhism
column6: but the latter gives the very timely fixation a Bowie spin
column7: as he empathizes with a monk who doesn't fit in with his community. By October 1969
column8: there's been a perceptible shift in attitudes: ""Let Me Sleep Beside You"" and ""Janine"" are tougher in sound and spirit.

column1: Bowie's February 1970 session with the Tony Visconti Trio—aka the Hype—starts inauspiciously. He covers Jacques Brel's ""Amsterdam"" competently
column2: and the acoustic ""God Knows I'm Good"" is a tedious ditty about a woman being caught shoplifting. But then comes ""The Width of a Circle
column3: and Mick Ronson's first-ever performance with Bowie. Maybe the subtlety of their work together here is a sign of a tentative new relationship: Ronson's riff is much more muted and ingrained in the mix than it would be on record
column4: but still gorgeous. Their dynamic picks up steam on ""Unwashed and Somewhat Slightly Dazed
column5: as Bowie's frustrations at the loss of his father preempt a brilliantly wiggy Ronson solo.

column1: As David Cavanagh's excellent book on John Peel's sessions points out
column2: Bowie was hardly gigging even by 1971
column3: when he had had a bona fide hit with ""Space Oddity"": ""He doesn't have a regular band
column4: his albums don't sell
column5: and he's prone to being in a state of artistic flux."" So the hour-long
column6: June 1971 Radio 1 performance by David Bowie and Friends at London's Paris Theater was a huge showcase
column7: preempting the release of Hunky Dory that December. Never mind the size of his ensemble
column8: however; the highlight is a box-fresh
column9: solo rendition of ""Kooks

column11: Zowie.

column1: Bowie always called himself a ""tasteful thief
column2: and the permeability of his brain becomes clear on the third LP of the set
column3: which deals with late 1971 and early 1972. Bowie had just returned from New York
column4: where he met Andy Warhol
column5: Lou Reed
column6: and Iggy Pop. In early 1972
column7: his covers of ""Waiting for the Man"" and ""White Light/White Heat"" are a little unconvincing
column8: but no matter; the transformative experience has brought out a new ability in Bowie to really sell his own songs live as he never had before
column9: ramping up his infectious
column10: virile energy. You can hear the Spiders From Mars hitting their stride
column11: and a lizardy streetwise quality appearing in Bowie's voice.

column1: Of course
column2: all this nascent rockstardom comes to a head in The Rise and Fall of Ziggy Stardust and the Spiders From Mars
column3: which Bowie previewed live on Radio 1 a month prior to release in June '72
column4: across two separate sessions. By this point
column5: ""Starman"" had been DJ Johnnie Walker's single of the week
column6: which earned it daily plays
column7: and allowed Bowie to delve a little further back into his catalog for hidden greatest hits: ""Space Oddity
column8: and ""Changes
column9: where Ronson transforms the original's hammered piano riff. But in the here and now
column10: Bowie's ravishing yowl makes an early appearance on ""Moonage Daydream
column11: and you hear him start to reach outward
column12: beyond the intimacy of radio into the visceral performer he would become. His May 22
column13: 1972 session ends with—what else—""Rock'n'Roll Suicide
column14: the last song he would play live on the BBC for 19 years.

column1: As ever
column2: nothing was accidental. Beyond the vinyl reissue of Bowie at the Beeb
column3: Bowie reached out to the BBC one last time before he died. His last round of Twitter follows included BBC 6Music and some of the station's flagship DJs (along with a cheeky parody account: God). The new music industry ecosystems mean that bands are no longer built up by single organizations in the same way that Bowie was by the BBC at the turn of the 1970s
column4: which made the day of his death all the more remarkable. Like thousands of other Brits

column7: but it represents a foundational part of British culture
column8:
and upholds the importance of public broadcasting as a mutually beneficial relationship.

column3: perhaps

column5: less successfully
column6: sluggish slow-motion sketches

column17:
it is an excellent first stab at terraforming.

We’ve all felt alone at some point or another. In those moments
column2: it seems the world passes by while you sit in painful silence. It’s a common emotion

column11: loosely built to set a pensive vibe shaded with desperation and hopelessness.

column5: ""Red Buttons
column6: and ""Sickum
column7: sprinkling light keys and horns into the fray; the aforementioned ""Peace and Pain"" is a seething electro-rock hybrid similar to the work of OPN or Trent Reznor. This is easy listening
column8: but it has all the psychedelic grit you’d expect from a Quelle release. He’s pushed beyond his usual arc
column9: leading to a wonderfully ambient release that should be mentioned with the genre’s trendsetters.

column1: Then again

column4: though
column5: Quelle has discussed his career path with the same level of angst we’ve all expressed in our respective fields. He ponders the road ahead and choices he’s made along the way. He's wondered why he's slept on and what it'll take to move past those doldrums. Over several projects

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/22983/homepage_large.48dda79e.jpg|January Sun|33361.0|Kedr Livanskiy|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['2MR']|2016-03-02 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 16:00:51.936498|"

The first thing you hear on January Sun
column2: the debut EP by Russian singer/electronic producer Kedr Livanskiy (real name Yana Kedrina) is a Nintendo-like synth figure fading away
column3: an envelope filter squeezing the life out of it. A rudimentary combination of beats emerges
column4: one of which sounds like the sped-up bossa nova preset on an inexpensive junk keyboard meant for kids ages 3 and up; the other a prototypical hi-hat figure that has ""I’ve just started experimenting with house music"" written all over it. As dreamy-but-crude synth pads
column5: hand claps
column6: and Kedrina's vocals all join in
column7: it's easy to mistake the song (""Razrushitelniy Krug"") as an unremarkable piece of lo-fi house music
column8: made by someone without a developed sense for how to arrange an instrumental backdrop.

column1: But she quickly proves that not to be the case. Her production touch is too delicate to consign this EP to the same bin as other music current music that arrives already dated because it reeks of Instagram. Where so many artists give their work the sonic equivalent of a fake tan when they try to ""warm"" it up
column2: Kedrina captures the charm of listening to dance music that’s been taped off a late-night radio broadcast. As such
column3: her nods to the past appear to stem from romance rather than cynical fascination with kitsch.

column1: ""Winds of May
column2: for example
column3: begins with a wash of queasy synth melodrama
column4: the likes of which Boards Of Canada turned into a career 20 years ago. Like many tracks on this EP
column5: it sounds like it’s being played on a sluggish tape deck
column6: but here there’s an occasional pitch-up effect
column7: as if you were listening to a tape that sat in a basement for years and skitters forward every time one of its reels makes a full turn. On ""Sgoraet"" (The Burning Down) and the title track
column8: Kedrina dons her David Gahan hat and captures the flashy brooding of Black Celebration/Music for the Masses-era Depeche Mode. Of course
column9: Depeche Mode’s stock in trade was to turn personal angst into stadium-sized gestures that mimicked the collective hysteria of political rallies. Kedrina turns that vibe on its ear by catching a tiny bit of it in a bottle and setting it loose on a dingy
column10: half-empty dancefloor.

column1: A close look at the lyrics reveals further layers of interpretation and displacement. The EP title appears on the album cover in Russian
column2: while the song titles alternate between Russian and English. Kedrina's vocals alternate between the two languages as well
column3: but are all listed in English. And even when she does sing in English
column4: her delivery verges on formless much like those wordless ethereal female vocals that became Orbital’s trademark. So even when you’re reading the James Joyce verses that she quotes on ""Winds of May""—""Winds of May
column5: that dance on the sea / Dancing a ring-around in glee / From furrow to furrow
column6: while overhead / The foam flies up to be garlanded""—her phrasing creates a sense of distance that isn’t attributable to language barrier alone.

column1: January Sun closes with an acappella version of ""Razrushitelniy Krug""/Destructive Cycle (alternately listed as ""Cyclic Strength of Destruction"")that
column2: even coming as it does after a bunch of songs with spartan arrangements heavy with primitive reverbs
column3: feels like a curveball. With her voice echoing as if across a valley
column4: Kedrina frees the EP from the confines of her home-recording setup
column5: or the provincial Russian club where one can easily imagine her spinning records on an off night. On their own
column6: her vocals take on a stately elegance
column7: and her unbound Russian verses carry and drift. As a coda to her first musical statement
column8: it is both striking and subtle. Whatever direction Kedrina chooses to move in with Kedr Livanskiy from here
column9: the agility she shows on January Sun suggests that we should be watching her.

column1:
Correction: The original version of this review referred to producer/singer Yana Kedrina as ""Kedr Livanskiy."" Kedr Livanskiy is the name of the project.

Whether you are a hardcore fan of the National or think the Brooklyn-based band is everything wrong and annoying about indie rock (and to judge from their YouTube comments
column2: there are a fair number of you in both camps)
column3: it's hard to argue against the prowess of the Dessner twins
column4: Bryce and Aaron
column5: who help power the band's sound. They are frequently namechecked as the engine behind the band: Both help run the venerable artpop boutique label Brassland Records
column6: whose flagship act Clogs is one of the foremost names in indie classical. Bryce
column7: meanwhile
column8: collaborated with Ryuichi Sakamoto and Alva Noto on the Golden Globe-nominated score to The Revenant and recently saw his compositions interpreted by the Kronos Quartet. Additionally
column9: both Dessners performed in Scandinavia last year with the Copenhagen Philharmonic and the Amsterdam Sinfonetta.

column1: But now it's time for the National's other pair of brothers
column2: Bryan and Scott Devendorf
column3: to show their willingness to go off the grid. Working in collaboration with fellow 4AD signee Benjamin Lanz of Beirut
column4: the newly minted trio LNZNDRF recorded their eight-song debut LP in two and a half days inside of an old church in the brothers' hometown of Cincinnati. Yet from the direction the group is taking here
column5: you'd think they transported themselves to Conny Plank's Cologne studio in the early days of Sky Records. The group chose to play Germany before New York on their brief international tour leading up to the album's release
column6: and the pulse of motorik powers the songs here. Yet this is no aimless joyride down the Autobahn: Lanz and the Devendorfs are as much fans of the 4AD label as they are clientele
column7: and the influence of the imprint's more psychedelic excursions are palpable
column8: especially across the four mesmerizing instrumental cuts here
column9: all of which were mostly improvised as producer Justin Newton rolled tape.

column1: The hypnotic groove of Lanz's guitar on opening cut ""Future You
column2: for instance
column3: invokes a more visceral variation of Michael Brook's work with Pieter Nooten of Clan of Xymox. As the backbone of the National
column4: Bryan Devendorf isn't really given the kind of material that really brings out his true chops as a drummer
column5: but on the perpetual-motion machine of ""Hypno-Skate"" or the bubbling
column6: Spacemen 3-spiced closer ""Samarra
column7: he gets to reveal himself as a student of such krautrock masters as Jaki Liebezeit of Can and Neu!'s Klaus Dinger in ways he never could otherwise.

column1: That the Achilles' heel of LNZNDRF comes from the vocal territory should come as no surprise. But it's not as though the singing
column2: done by both Lanz and Scott Devendorf
column3: is no good. It's just that when you hear a pedestrian
column4: moderately chillwave-ish song like ""Mt. Storm"" or ""Kind Things"" sitting amongst the instrumentals that tower over them
column5: it feels woefully mismatched in the same way that cover of David Essex's ""Rock On"" sits like a wart in the middle of the new Tortoise album. The two sides finally come together on the record's penultimate cut
column6: ""Monument
column7: a convincing homage to the Pale Saints.

column1: The Pale Saints are ancient history to 4AD now: These days
column2: the label is more known for their advancements in the world of next-level dance pop like Grimes
column3: Purity Ring
column4: Holly Herndon
column5: and tUnE-yArDs. LNZNDRF is a fine-if-flawed testament to the company's Thatcher years
column6: but it could have been tremendous if they had kept it strictly instrumental. If the Devendorfs were allowed to bring some of this fried psychedelia to the National
column7: alongside the Dessner twins' neo-classical grandiloquence
column8:
the National's next album could really be something.

1985 and 1986 were rather productive years for the Chicago producer Larry Heard. Using a wide array of aliases—be it Disco D
column2: The It
column3: Gherkin Jerks
column4: Fingers
column5: Inc. or Mr. Fingers—he pressed up singles like ""Mystery of Love
column6: ""It's Over
column7: ""A Path
column8: ""Donnie
column9: and ""Bring Down the Walls
column10: almost all of them epochal
column11: codifying dance music in their wake. Heard did jack
column12: acid
column13: and house like few before him and fewer since
column14: to where his decades-old productions still jerk the heartstrings
column15: from new love to heartache
column16: well into the present.

column1: If you were a rock band with that many sterling singles in your arsenal
column2: you'd release a deluxe edition and put the band back together 30 years later to cash in
column3: but Heard's re-emergence now feels different. Late last year
column4: he finally reissued Another Side on his own Alleviated label
column5: rightly considered the greatest vocal house record of all time
column6: and this month sees his first release as Mr. Fingers since 2005.

column1: Which is not to suggest that his label has been dormant in the intervening years. Just last year
column2: Alleviated released two strong singles from newcomers Ken Gill and Lee Pearson Jr. Collective. Heard sounds emboldened by the new blood; the four tracks that comprise this EP don't scan as old tracks dusted off and spruced up for a new generation of deep house fans
column3: nor do they sound like Heard dabbling in the newfangled so as to prove his relevance on the EDM market. ""Outer Acid
column4: metered by closed hi-hats and canned claps
column5: has the telltale gurgle of a 303 flowing underneath it. But Heard programs the track at the pace of a babbling brook rather than a Warehouse rager
column6: acid house as dulcet and calming
column7: with Heard judiciously adding a metallophone melody to give the track a buoyant charm.

column1: ""Nodyahead"" is a clattering
column2: upbeat house track while ""Aether"" is downtempo with a nimbus about its fringes. With its spotlight sweep of chords across the patient house beat
column3: ""Qwazars"" is luminous
column4: from its subject matter to its melody
column5: the sample of ""What’s going on?"" ""Quasars"" dialogue (purportedly lifted from a Neil deGrasse Tyson lecture) a nice touch. It shows that Mr. Fingers’ return isn't to rehash or cash in on his old work
column6: but rather to elucidate it
column7: to carry on this dialogue with his machines in a new century.

column1: Correction: The original version of this review incorrectly stated the title of the EP. It is the Outer Acid EP
column2:
not the Mr. Fingers EP.

No two genres are as similar in spirit as punk rock and rap. Both were created by poor young people as a way to express disdain with the status quo and provide some insight into the minds and hearts of people who usually don’t get a seat at the table. Both encourage a spirit of self-reliance that allows for a kid in Small Town X to create something that can stand confidently next to an icon. Both have been co-opted by the mainstream at large when they proved to be financially beneficial. Both have been sneered at by lames for not requiring much musical ""skill"" to execute.
Given all this
column2: you'd think more punk and rap collaborations would turn out better. But usually
column3: the people interested in uniting the genres go the laziest
column4: most obvious route imaginable
column5: and for every Death Grips you get someting like the self-titled G.O.O.D. Music debut from Nigel ""HXLT"" Holt's (F.K.A. rapper Hollywood Holt). The album aims to revisit a time when Debbie Harry and Grandmaster Flash rubbed elbows at New York’s Danceteria—creating a culture in the process— but ultimately ends up feeling like being invited to a friend's art show—you’re rooting for the guy but man
column6: some of this stuff is brutal.

column1: The album's sound is uncomplicated. He could have gone overboard with screeching guitars
column2: but HXLT keeps things spare
column3: closer to post-punk than punk. ""Why"" is a decent dark wave homage
column4: taking dashes of the sound (choppy rhythm guitar
column5: disinterested vocal stylings) and forcing the synths to get along with a drum machine doing yeoman's work. There’s elements of social awareness
column6: too. On ""Guitar
column7: the Mano-produced standout
column8: HXLT laments that he’d like to be famous solely to bring attention to real issues (the chorus: ""I wish I could play guitar/ And write all the songs to make me rich/ Use it all to save the kids""). No complaints there.

column1: The lyrics are another story; there are a ton of eyeroll moments here. While no one expects this guy to be Lou Reed
column2: there’s gotta be something out there better than ""Rock N Roll""’s ""I wanna get into a fight in front of you and knock his lights out/ I wanna ride a motorbike
column3: make you jump on it and we ride out."" It’s a damn shame
column4: too
column5: because HXLT is an undeniable live performer
column6: full of charisma: Put him on a stage right now anywhere and he's walking out with five new fans. Somewhere in him he might have a real punk anthem
column7: but none of the songs on the record accurately bottle that energy. Other than ""Sick
column8: a song about the frustration of loving someone you honestly can’t stand half the time
column9: the whole thing kind of ambles. Even the Kathleen Hanna-guested ""Together"" doesn’t gnash its teeth as much as you’d like it to. (Sidebar: Getting Kathleen Hanna on your first album has to be the punk equivalent of getting a Jay Z feature on your debut
column10: right?)

column1: A lot of the narrative surrounding this record has been about Holt finally embracing the influences traditional rap heads considered too weird
column2: or ""too white."" Clap for him for sticking to his convictions but speaking frankly
column3: a lot of people wouldn’t be giving this the time of day were it not presented via the Kanye West/G.O.O.D. Music/Def Jam co-sign. The missed opportunity is the most frustrating part. What could have been a real shift in culture ends up feeling like moving into a new apartment: There’s some potential
column4:
but things are still all over the place.

When a band reaches into its box of old demos on hitting the third-album mark
column2: that’s usually a sign that either the ideas have started to run low or that the musicians are no longer getting together to write songs as often as they once did. Likewise
column3: groups of songs spanning several years often fail to hang together as a coherent whole. The third album from indie/psych/folk quartet Quilt might come from old demos
column4: but it bucks these common trends by showing that disparity can serve as a creative asset.

column1: Like a kind of musical Bermuda quadrangle
column2: the convergence of pop-leaning indie rock
column3: psychedelia
column4: vintage British folk
column5: and Americana has lulled many a band to sink into generic facelessness. Not so here. The only times Plaza comes across as less than convincing are the moments where Shane Butler and company tip their hand a tad too heavily
column6: such as on closing number ""Own Ways
column7: which falls just short of featuring faux English accents and sounds like Quilt’s musical answer to a '60s mod costume party.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: though
column3: they steer clear of slavish recreation
column4: cleverly revealing new wrinkles in the arrangements from one song to the next. When Anna Fox Rochinski and Butler throw in a key shift on opener ""Passerby"" that evokes a sitar-like
column5: resonator guitar tone
column6: it’s as if they hit the whammy bar on the song itself during playback. It’s a trick they manage several times throughout this new set
column7: where the entire band
column8: which also includes drummer John Andrews and new bassist Keven Lareau
column9: will suddenly go slack before the arrangement as a whole automatically snaps back like a guitar returning to its default string tension. At these times
column10: usually the band will be cruising along at a pleasant pace before swerving toward a jagged
column11: seemingly out-of-place chord or element
column12: and the overall effect is like a friend suddenly tousling your hair.

column1: On ""Roller
column2: Quilt re-reappropriates Elastica’s appropriation of Wire
column3: but instead of returning the angular guitar riff to its rightful owner
column4: tosses it into a dreamlike backdrop of keyboards and Rochinski vocals that smudge out in trails of thickening reverb
column5: simulating our semi-conscious day-to-day train of thought as it focuses on banal tasks then blurs into daydreams until those nagging bits of reality pull our attention back down to Earth. If you were to stop and take stock of how many times your mind does this in the course of a single day
column6: you’d likely be surprised because the process unfolds so smoothly that you mostly don’t even register that it’s happening. Quilt executes these transitions with similar ease.

column1: On the chorus of ""Your Island
column2: for example
column3: Rochinski’s reverb-drenched vocals scrape the upper stratosphere of shoegaze—only without typical shoegaze instrumentation. It’s as if the band stripped a Lush tune of its vocals and transplanted them in a stripped-down
column4: downtempo song that could have been written by the Duke Spirit. ""O’Connor’s Barn"" marries Whip-Smart-era Liz Phair’s cottony impressionism with the slightest touch of a Pavement-styled guitar hook circa Crooked Rain
column5: Crooked Rain. ""Padova"" excavates the experimental streak that seemed so promising about Gomez before that band surrendered to slick pop
column6: while ""Hissing My Plea"" emulates the strings that Beck stole from Funkadelic’s ""If You Don’t Like the Effects
column7: Don’t Produce the Cause."" Elsewhere
column8: jangly nods to Fairport Convention and barebones Americana rear their heads as well.

column1: In all of these cases
column2: though
column3: Quilt either significantly expands on or reframes these references
column4: bringing substance
column5: character and a modern production sheen to older ideas. They have always been a quietly stylish band
column6: with diligently crafted songs
column7: savvy arrangement instincts
column8: and a discreet
column9: almost unassuming way of asserting their own voice while embracing influences. Without even trying
column10: Plaza offers a rebuttal to all those people who argue that every artist steals. Wrong—some
column11: like Quilt
column12:
know the difference between stealing and honoring.
