column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/22935/homepage_large.77863a9c.jpg|Carta|33515.0|Especia|['Global'
column3: Japanese music labels went niche over the last five years. They catered to very specific demographics rather than listeners at large via ""idol pop"" groups devoted to subcultures. The best case scenario was a group like Babymetal going viral and reaching a more general audience
column4: but catering to steampunk aficionados or fans of um
column5: ""chubbiness"" proved just as efficient. Yet no pop group’s identity has been stranger than Especia’s
column6: a five-piece frequently billed as ""Japanese vaporwave idols."" They’ve embraced the stylings of an Internet subgenre infatuated with pitched-down vocals and old technology
column7: while their primary producer has openly mentioned how influential acts such as Espirit空想 and Saint Pepsi (now Skylar Spence) have been to their sound. The commitment goes deep—they’ve recorded entire live shows onto VHS tape.

column1: Yet Especia is more complicated than simple microgenre imitation. Look beneath the Grecian busts and Windows 95 logos
column2: and you’ll find many vaporwave artists using slowed-down Japanese songs from the 1980s as source material
column3: particularly from a glitzy genre called city pop
column4: indebted to American AOR and funk
column5: that reflected Japan's then-decadent lifestyle. Especia’s actual music leans closer to real-deal city pop
column6: blessed with big hooks and copious saxophone solos
column7: than anything by James Ferraro or Oneohtrix Point Never.

column1: Carta
column2: the group’s third album and first for a major label
column3: continues their brand of vaporwave-inspired dabbling—look closely at the straight-out-of-Myst cover art and you’ll see what looks suspiciously like the Enron logo—but offers a mostly straight-ahead set of mellow pop. It’s the outfit’s final release as a quintet
column4: as three members are set to ""graduate"" shortly after its release
column5: and even though it doesn’t reach the heights of earlier works
column6: it’s a solid snapshot of what Especia has done so well in recent times to stand out on a purely sonic level.

column1: The bulk of Carta leans toward easygoing music punched up by brass sections and bubbly synthesizer
column2: the sort of songs that sound best as the evening is just settling in. The trio Hi-Fi City (featuring Especia’s main producer Schtein&Longer
column3: PellyColo
column4: and saxophonist Yoshiro Nakagawa) handle most of the songwriting and production
column5: bringing a deep knowledge of style that helps Especia’s music rise above simple recycling. ""Over Time"" and ""Sunshower"" sway at the pace of Brand New Heavies
column6: while the squiggly bass and saxophone blurts of ""Mistake"" nail the urban drama of city pop wonderfully. These are solid recreations of retro sounds not hiding their influences—""Rittenhouse Square""'s title reveals the Philadelphia soul approximation before the first horn stab—that at their worst still sound smooth and pleasant.

column1: But Carta works in a smattering of other sounds to keep things moving. Hip-hop plays a prominent role
column2: the members of Especia breaking into rap at various points that channels the same time period the rest of the album does. Less charming—and
column3: positioned as the album opener
column4: a horrible introduction—is ""Clover
column5: an arena-sized rock ballad assembled by a trio of older Japanese rockers. It would be cheesy in any decade
column6: but made worse by how unnatural it forces Especia to sing
column7: their voices better suited for mellow than soaring. Also mixed in is one direct embrace of vaporwave sound on ""Saudade
column8: produced by Brazilian artist VHS Logos and featuring narcotized recordings of the group’s members playing a game. It’s a nice breather.

column1: Most of Carta registers as simply ""solid
column2: if a bit thin."" Yet the album—and the current version of Especia—ends on a high
column3: courtesy of the collection’s two big pop moments
column4: the tropical-scented shuffler ""Boogie Aroma"" and the high-stepping ""Aviator
column5:
the latter in particularly delivering the album’s most charged-up hook. These instances highlight what have made Especia stand out in Japan even more than the vaporwave wallpaper—catchy earworms every bit as good as the silly videos.

The consensus critical acclaim for Hop Along’s sophomore LP
column2: Painted Shut

column2: Hop Along weren’t the robust

column4: Modest Mouse
column5: and Dr. Dog. Get Disowned's original release also happened at least a year before any of the narratives that would either directly or peripherally benefit the band—Philadelphia emerging as the nation’s indie rock capital

column6: really funny

column1: The humor of Get Disowned may have deflected from just how brutally honest and devastating it is. In 2012
column2: Quinlan described her ultimate songwriting goal as
column3: “<a href=""http://www.phawker.com/2012/05/31/rawk-tawk-qa-with-phillys-hop-along/"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">finding [a] character and creating a world
column4: ” which seemed more in line with the literary
column5: referential Painted Shut than it does with the songs here. The tragedies and personal failings on Get Disowned feel more like autobiography—“Trouble Found Me” expresses the horrifying imagery of her stepfather after suffering a catastrophic accident (“you came in with your jaw torn
column6: still talking”)
column7: along with the vivid memories of technicalities that tend to stick with trauma sufferers. Quinlan remembers things like the chicken in the oven before arriving to the hospital and seeing nurses playing poker while a blind man convalesces in the next bed over. The account of a family friend’s death on the rollicking roots-rocker “Sally II” starts with a literally breathtaking mention of “that unsettling smell had gotten into all the tenants’ rooms
column8: ” and it’s the mundane forensic details that are even more unnerving: the apartment is littered with weightlifting magazines and a piece of junk mail with a fake million-dollar check (“you thought it was the real thing”).

column1: Get Disowned is a meditation on death and loss every bit as compelling as Southeastern
column2: Benji
column3: or Carrie & Lowell
column4: and boasts more inventive language than any of them. But Hop Along
column5: in part because the project was so new
column6: initially had a harder time getting noticed. And while Quinlan’s voice is unusually expressive—she often screams and restrains herself at the same time
column7: so it sounds like her lungs might burst—it rarely sounds objectively sad in a way that immediately conveys gravitas or fragility to a casual listener. Play “Sally II” at a party
column8: ask a friend what it’s about and see how close they get to “an older man dying alone in his apartment.”

column1: The record’s most pressing issue may be one that was hit upon in an interview with Quinlan and her brother Mark
column2: Hop Along’s drummer. Frances described the prevailing theme of Get Disowned as “baggage
column3: ” to which Mark added
column4: “not being able to have your mistakes written off just because you’re young.” Right there
column5: the siblings touched the nerve that rightfully triggers a shudder in anyone who’s been the target of all those “why can’t these entitled millennials just wash their cereal bowls like we did in the good ol’ days?”-style pieces
column6: written by someone who refuses to take ownership of the degraded world they’ve left for the younger generation. It feels like the Quinlans were speaking to how people can be seriously damaged by their youth and still not be taken seriously.

column1: Sure
column2: kids might learn to process and turn these experiences into assets—“Hop Along” itself was a nickname given to Quinlan in high school for being a slow walker. Or they may repress them and have them mutate into something uglier and intractable that continues throughout their lives. Even if a middle-schooler is aware of what’s at stake in the upcoming presidential election or reads an article about Flint’s water crisis
column3: if they got picked on at school
column4: that’s probably the most important thing in the world to them right now. Get Disowned lends dignity to the truth that each person’s struggle and recovery is theirs
column5: regardless of how it may present to outsiders or how it seems relative to more pervasive and global concerns. As Hop Along would soon find out
column6:
the first step to a breakthrough is just to be heard.

"|21510.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21510-get-disowned/|8.5|Ian Cohen

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/22917/homepage_large.74d0a072.jpg|Jerome Raheem Fortune|31525.0|Rome Fortune|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|"[""Fool's Gold""]"|2016-02-29 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 16:00:55.317925|"

Atlanta rapper Rome Fortune is a working-class MC
column2: an independent artist who has paid his dues on the mixtape circuit
column3: even if he’s still not a member of rap’s functional middle class. In an age of viral rap stars thriving on the Instagram snippet economy
column4: Fortune has taken a more methodical approach
column5: building a cult following over several years with his two-part Beautiful Pimp mixtape series and a host of collaborative projects
column6: among them YEP with rapper OG Maco and EPs/tapes with local producers Dun Deal
column7: Childish Major
column8: and CeeJ (from the rap collective Two-9). You can hear the labor in his method
column9: in the mechanics of how he puts his words together.

column1: It’s fitting
column2: then
column3: that the self-titled Jerome Raheem Fortune focuses on his toils
column4: from living in a motel with his single mother to paying back loans to missing the birthdays of loved ones due to the punishing schedule of life as an aspiring rapper. Fortune seeks to humanize and not deify
column5: and this is the most personal he has ever been in his writing
column6: with lyrics that are closer to journal entries than rap verses. The songs are at times almost uncomfortably autobiographical
column7: a look behind the veil of moderate Internet-based fame: Fortune talks openly about family dynamics
column8: being broke
column9: and his entire life outside rap
column10: everything from how he ended up with two baby mamas to how he plans to pay for his kids’ pull-ups. On ""Still I Fight On
column11: he establishes his priorities
column12: summarizing with ""Fuck an album placement/ I fought for survival."" For him
column13: rap is a means to an end; he believes himself to be a dynamic artist
column14: yes
column15: but he’s constantly got his eye on the bottom line.

column1: This desire for financial stability and proud DIY mentality fuels everything Fortune does
column2: and here he attempts to earn his keep narrating his life. Jerome Raheem Fortune builds on the sound of 2013’s Beautiful Pimp—quick-splitting
column3: electronic-leaning productions with snug verses that lean heavily on charismatic vocal performances
column4: songs actively seeking to buck Atlanta trap trends—but he’s never gone this far out. The dark
column5: coke-powered ""Heavy as Feathers
column6: which whirrs like a UFO desperately trying to stay afloat
column7: clicking and clanging and breaking apart
column8: is the centerpiece for his sound-warping escapades. When the experimentation works
column9: there are songs like ""Past Future
column10: a collapsing multi-tone palace that pairs his best writing (""The writing on the wall was a movie script"") with his most captivating rapping.

column1: Rome Fortune’s strongest attribute is his comfort with virtually any production
column2: and that serves him well on the constantly-shifting Jerome Raheem Fortune. There are lush
column3: blooming tracks scattered thought (""Alone Tonight"" builds slowly and woozily before switching dramatically into a strutting riff; ""Find My Way"" false starts into trickling synths)
column4: and he’s good at finding the open space despite all the continuous movement
column5: sliding in and out of the grooves with intimate admissions. But while Fortune bares his soul
column6: he isn’t a particularly gifted wordsmith and some of the storytelling gets muddled a bit because of it. Still
column7: he’s an exceptional performer and overcomes his limitations with sheer energy. Jerome Raheem Fortune is the work of an artist who is still figuring it all out
column8:
a flawed but ambitious art piece that’s the culmination of several years of growth.

"|21604.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21604-rome-fortune-jerome-raheem-fortune/|7.0|Sheldon Pearce

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/22877/homepage_large.0ce960e0.jpg|Stranger Things|28604.0|Yuck|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Mamé']|2016-02-29 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 16:00:56.801379|"

Like 2013’s Glow & Behold and any future albums this lineup of Yuck might go on to record
column2: Stranger Things carries an implied asterisk. This isn’t the work of the same band that released a lovably frazzled
column3: fondly remembered self-titled album in 2011. Since frontman Daniel Blumberg quit the group and guitarist Max Bloom took over as its leader
column4: Yuck have carried on as a faded copy of themselves
column5: retaining their devotion to '90s indie rock but losing the misfit energy that made revisiting sounds that have already been recycled many
column6: many times before seem like a genuinely exciting proposition. Bloom and Blumberg’s voices are superficially similar enough that casual listeners might not even be able to pinpoint exactly what’s changed
column7: but they’ll almost certainly notice the diminishing returns. The scrappy enthusiasm of Yuck’s debut has been replaced by bland
column8: box-checking competence.

column1: Given that a few of his songs on Stranger Things hint at the anxiety caused by the public pressure of filling in for his old bandmate
column2: it feels mean-spirited to single Bloom out for particular criticism. But it’s hard not to. He’s the Doug Yule to Blumberg’s Lou Reed
column3: a passable enough fill in for a song or two who lacks the charisma
column4: personality
column5: and way with words to carry an entire album on his own. And while his flat
column6: cheerless vocals are the type of limitation that a more self-aware band might work around
column7: the group’s self-produced third album counterintuitively plays them up
column8: plastering them at the front of the mix. It’s a voice you can really grow to resent over 47 minutes
column9: and Stranger Things locks you in such close quarters with it that when bassist Mariko Doi finally takes her lone lead vocal turn on ""As I Walk Away
column10: it feels like hard-earned relief.

column1: Under Blumberg’s reign
column2: Yuck muddled their influences together into a fluid pastiche—a little Pavement here
column3: a little Yo La Tengo there
column4: a big splash of Dinosaur Jr. on top of that—but Bloom tends toward more structured
column5: predictable homages. ""Cannonball"" shares a name with a Breeders song but plays like a Superchunk song. There’s also a stab at an Elliott Smith song (""Like a Moth"")
column6: a Teenage Fanclub song (""Only Silence"") and a Matthew Sweet song (the title track
column7: which features the extremely '90s chorus ""I hate myself
column8: only none of the black humor that era’s songwriters used to cut that kind of sentiment with). The record ends with a pair of Built to Spill rips. ""Down"" is the more effective of the two
column9: because Bloom nails Doug Martsch’s boyish innocence—it’s one of his best performances
column10: even if like everything else on the album it feels secondhand. He sounds way out of his element
column11: though
column12: on the thundering
column13: six-and-a-half minute ""Yr Face
column14: an attempt at ""Broken Chairs""-style gravitas that runs in circles instead of building to something. Built to Spill could pull off that kind of song because they had big ideas to convey. Yuck do not.

column1: So
column2: rough album. Glow & Behold was no great shakes either
column3: but at least that record compensated for Blumberg’s absence with richer instrumentation
column4: and some smartly deployed shoegaze textures that helped conceal Bloom’s vocal deficiencies. Where that album felt like an expansion
column5: albeit a minor one
column6: Stranger Things feels like a retreat. The group recorded it themselves in an effort to reconjure the rawer
column7: fuzzier sound of their debut
column8: and for a band that’s trying to escape their own shadow
column9: that’s probably the worst thing they could have done. Yuck have always invited comparisons to other bands
column10: but these days
column11:
the one that flatters them the least is the comparison to themselves.

"|21567.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21567-yuck-stranger-things/|5.2|Evan Rytlewski

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/22924/homepage_large.d59f7789.jpg|Cellar EP|33507.0|NA|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Fade to Mind']|2016-02-29 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 16:00:57.475927|"

Working with a large cohort of friends and collaborators spread across the globe (he’s one-half of Nguzunguzu)
column2: producer Daniel Pineda has transformed club dancefloors into zones of unmitigated free expression. In some ways
column3: his second solo release as NA feels more like a busy construction site than a collection of dance music: It’s 21 minutes of unrelentingly hot
column4: noisy
column5: messy electronic thumps. Thematically
column6: each of Cellar’s five songs is supposed to represent a different dark and claustrophobic room in a large dungeon
column7: complete with its own set of problems and pleasures. The extended architectural metaphor at the heart of Cellar is a fitting description for an artist whose career has been defined by spatial dimensions as much as sonic ones.

column1: The music’s physical tenor is steamy and crowded—it’s like a top down shot of a dance floor
column2: with poor souls trying to claw their way out of the mass of bodies. On ""Brass Claims
column3: Pineda adds aggressive horns to his wild array of percussive sounds. The middle chunk of the EP: ""Menace"" and ""Definite Sentence"" attempt to scale back the tone and lighten the mood
column4: lowering the frenetic BPM
column5: but the rhythmic zig-zags accomplish little more than creating an anxious block of music. There are a handful of lighter moments in ""Definite Sentence"" where it sounds like Pineda is sampling a dog’s squeaky toy. And the closer
column6: ""NA in a Mood
column7: is surprisingly open and airy. It’s a long fade out that nears ambient music in the relaxation it can somehow pull out of the metallic and mordant sounds Pineda trades in.

column1: At its best
column2: the EP’s pure visceral nature is a stark reminder of the body’s central place in dance music. At its worst
column3: it’s a numbing and grating experience that would never be able to extend past its short runtime. The EP’s attempt at pacing is never smooth but closer to flagellating
column4: and if it did not end at least a little bit gently
column5: the vice-grip it clamps on to your ears would start to feel oppressive. On the whole
column6: though
column7:
Cellar is a focused curation of the simple and harsh sounds that were the strongest parts of Pineda’s work in Future Brown and Nguzunguzu.

"|21611.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21611-cellar-ep/|7.5|Kevin Lozano

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/22955/homepage_large.5c59ed60.jpg|God Don't Never Change: The Songs of Blind Willie Johnson|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Alligator']|2016-02-29 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 16:00:58.116984|"

What's the point of a tribute album? Is it to show how the influence of an icon has spread
column2: seeping into and informing far-flung styles that then sprawl from the center like branches of a healthy family tree? Is it to use the star power of gathered singers and bands to raise the reputation of some underserved idol
column3: giving a second chance to the perpetually overlooked? Or
column4: more cynically
column5: is it a label-based attempt to package together a potpourri of disparate artists and capitalize on their disconnected fanbases and that of the tribute subject?

column1: God Don’t Never Change
column2: an 11-song ode to the great blues howler and gospel progenitor Blind Willie Johnson
column3: feels a little like all of those at once. Produced by tribute-compilation veteran Jeffrey Gaskill
column4: powered by an ambitious crowdfunding campaign
column5: and issued by roots imprint Alligator Records
column6: God Don’t Never Change attempts to grapple with Johnson’s impact on popular artists and genre purists alike. Crossover giants such as Tom Waits
column7: Lucinda Williams
column8: and Sinéad O’Connor share the tracklist with gospel- and blues-based acts
column9: from the institutional Blind Boys of Alabama to North Mississippi Allstar leader Luther Dickinson. It is
column10: as with almost all tribute records
column11: an uneven listen. Still
column12: it's a fine homage to Johnson’s brutally honest
column13: occasionally inspirational songs that leaves some deep questions about how far his influence goes.

column1: Many of these interpretations are excellent
column2: reflecting music’s evolutionary arc since Johnson’s time and the idiosyncratic styles of these performers themselves. Waits
column3: for instance
column4: is perfect for ""The Soul of a Man
column5: a song that questions why we’re here and what ""we"" even are. Backed by childlike harmonies
column6: parlor piano
column7: and heavy handclaps
column8: it's a joyful lecture delivered under the auspices of a sweltering summer revival. (His junkyard moan through ""John the Revelator
column9: however
column10: is so melodramatic it seems glib.) And exalting above his ragged slide work and the dainty whistle of a fife
column11: Dickinson sounds like the Delta doppelgänger of Devendra Banhart
column12: his voice curling skyward. It’s an exquisite
column13: personal update.

column1: The real highlight arrives with Sinéad O’Connor’s ""Trouble Will Soon Be Over
column2: a song that’s a sermon about how the struggles of this life will sublimate into redemption when it’s over. O’Connor sings of death as sweet relief here
column3: her resilient voice rising over a guitar line that drones more like the blues of West Africa than those of Johnson’s central Texas. That subtle transnational nod is a sharp tribute to the durability and relevance of these songs. Nearly a century after many of these numbers were written
column4: we’re still grappling with the worries of Johnson’s world
column5: which he articulated with such grace and aired with such grit.

column1: That realization is a damning one for God Don’t Never Change
column2: a collection that leaves so much on the table in terms of possibility. Many of these selections are too on-the-nose
column3: kowtowing to Johnson’s legacy as though kneeling before his corpse at a wake. Susan Tedeschi and Derek Trucks simply redeliver ""Keep Your Lamp Trimmed and Burning
column4: while Maria McKee belts ""Let Your Light Shine on Me"" as an act of historical anachronism. God Don’t Never Change ends with the impression that there’s work to be done
column5: interpretations yet left to hear. Johnson’s songs were often elliptical and vague; see
column6: <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BNj2BXW852g"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">his largely instrumental masterpiece
column7: ""Dark Was the Night
column8: Cold Was the Ground."" But God Don’t Never Change never really opens itself up beyond obvious Americana. What does rap in 2016 have to say about Blind Willie Johnson? Or metal? Or a sample-driven producer? Plenty
column9: I’d wager. It’s reflexive and naïve to think his influence ends here.

column1: The paleness of the entire enterprise only exacerbates that feeling. Yes
column2: the Blind Boys ease their way through the emotional turmoil of ""Mother’s Children Have a Hard Time
column3: but every other player of color here (and there are very few) is tucked into the background
column4: like the hand-clapping Mike Mattison or the fife-adding Shardé Thomas. The only black-led act is the most polite and polished of the entire set
column5: with Waits and O’Connor left to raise the set’s real ruckus. If the point of a tribute album is to show how an artist’s work has metastasized and impacted others
column6:
God Don’t Never Change allows a too narrow of a window for doing so.  

"|21639.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21639-god-dont-never-change-the-songs-of-blind-willie-johnson/|5.8|Grayson Haver Currin

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/22814/homepage_large.4984cf76.jpg|This Unruly Mess I've Made|33566.0|Macklemore|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2016-02-26 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 16:00:58.290775|"

""You got robbed
column2: begins the most guilt-ridden apology of the 21st century. ""I wanted you to win. You should have. It's weird and it sucks that I robbed you."" The screencap seen 'round the world explains the duality of Ben Haggerty
column3: aka Macklemore
column4: whose unexpected mainstream appeal has enabled him and his music partner
column5: Ryan Lewis
column6: to rise to the top of the industry. At the 2014 Grammys
column7: the duo’s The Heist had defeated Kendrick Lamar’s good kid
column8: m.A.A.d city for the Best Rap Album Grammy
column9: an upset that weighed on Macklemore’s conscience. He reached out to Lamar
column10: screencapping the mea culpa for Instagram so everyone could see how just how hard he’d fallen on his sword.

column1: Macklemore understood that the only people who thought The Heist was better or more important than good kid were Grammy voters and misguided white teenagers. But he also needed deeply for the world to know he understood. This same tension between humility and ego fueled his crossover smash hit ""Same Love
column2: which advocated for the very non-controversial idea that ""being gay is okay"" and made them unlikely spokesmen for easily digestible social justice. It also prompted criticisms that they weren’t ready to preach from the mount
column3: and after a few years spent internalizing those criticisms
column4: they’ve returned with This Unruly Mess I’ve Made
column5: a blend of juvenile joke raps
column6: inquisitive woke raps
column7: and diaristic contemplations of Macklemore’s life that attempts to prove they belong—that they’re not just white saviors trying to project their face onto the culture.

column1: ""Music was intended to be that one thing that we could rely on to disrupt the norm
column2: Macklemore said in a video announcing the album. ""Start conversations and change the way that we think and we feel."" When he released ""White Privilege II
column3: a sprawling monologue in which wonders if he’s an interloper and lectures about the literal definition of white supremacy
column4: he didn’t just drop the mic and try to let the song speak for itself. Instead
column5: he gave interviews about the song with non-white publications
column6: and launched a website in which he and his collaborators—including Chicago singer Jamila Woods (who sung the hook on Donnie Trumpet & the Social Experiment’s ""Sunday Candy"")
column7: community organizer Dustin Washington
column8: activist Nikkita Oliver
column9: and more—detailed its conception. There was a lot of effort to convince you he was taking the issue of white privilege very
column10: very seriously. Call him the rap game Matt McGorry—the rare white pop star making political music with explicitly middlebrow outreach.

column1: And make no mistake
column2: Macklemore is taking a lot of issues very seriously. ""Same Love"" wasn’t complicated
column3: but it put a human face on gay marriage that was able to connect with millions of Americans. Here
column4: the clattering funk of ""Kevin"" reaches for a similar understanding about the prescription drug crisis
column5: as the accessibility of opioids like Oxycontin has devastated low-income (and white) communities across the country. Macklemore is a former addict
column6: and his invective about the parasitic sway of drug abuse (""We play Russian Roulette/ And try to find a life where we could be content/ ‘Cause for us
column7: we're just trying to minimize the fear of being alive"") carries the moral authority of lived experience. (In interviews
column8: he’s said he also lapsed back into his addiction within the past few years
column9: giving his words a different urgency.)

column1: But Leon Bridges’ hook is too moralizing
column2: and it has the maudlin feel of a song written to solve a problem. Macklemore has more appeal as the everyman—a normal guy who who just stumbled into all this pageantry. On the opener ""Light Tunnels
column3: he narrates a trip to an awards show: He feels desperately out of place in his town car and his tux
column4: the industry’s eyes on him without his friends for support. (""I wish I had the homies with me here but nope/ Most of the artists I know don’t get invited to this show."") He waxes about how ""they"" want gossip
column5: drama
column6: for Kanye's rant ""to go on longer."" As he accepts an award (which may be the Grammy he robbed Kendrick of)
column7: he ponders how he’ll explain ""this unruly mess I’ve made""—a slightly disingenuous ""aw shucks"" characterization of his career that nevertheless communicates some truth about the weight of his expectations.

column1: ""Buckshot
column2: meanwhile
column3: reflects on his days as a rebellious graffiti artist
column4: featuring KRS-One and DJ Premier
column5: and ""St. Ides"" is a tender travelogue of his days as a teenage alcoholic. On ""Growing Up
column6: Macklemore dictates a comprehensive list of cool-dad lessons for his newborn child (""Listen to your teachers
column7: but cheat in calculus""; ""Take your girl to the prom
column8: but don’t get too drunk hanging out the limo."") His knowledge is slightly undermined when he recommends reading Langston Hughes’ A Raisin in the Sun (Langston Hughes did not write A Raisin in the Sun)
column9: but hey
column10: nobody’s perfect.

column1: He developed the big-tent struggle gospel sound of The Heist with Ryan Lewis after a decade spent as an underground rapper
column2: and the formula hasn’t changed much here: There are still lots of choirs
column3: dramatic string cues
column4: and dewy pianos set to tug heart strings. Even a goofy song like ""Dance Off"" gets a swelling horror-movie organ intro before a big dancehall rhythm kicks in. It’s atypical backing music for a rap album
column5: but Macklemore is kind of an atypical rapper. His cadence tends to fall between ""impassioned slam poet"" and ""guy talking in your ear
column6: and when he’s doing the latter
column7: the lights dim on the production. ""The Train"" is set solely to piano and the sound of a train whizzing over the tracks
column8: as he softly raps about how his growing responsibilities have pulled him away from his family. ""St. Ides"" is almost completely muted but for a pealing guitar riff. It sounds like the reference track was Buffalo Springfield’s ""For What It’s Worth
column9: or like
column10: the Mountain Goats.

column1: The hit here is ""Downtown
column2: which features three legitimate rap pioneers—Melle Mel
column3: Kool Moe Dee
column4: and Grandmaster Caz—and passionate vocal theatrics from Foxy Shazam’s Eric Nally. Macklemore’s verses are trivial—the opening verse details his attempt to purchase a Moped—but there’s an appealing breeziness to his low-stakes ribbing. The rap O.G.s aren’t given much to do
column5: acting as a chanting Greek chorus and flexing in the video
column6: but their presence gives the song the feeling of an event and allows Macklemore to show he knows and respects his history. (According to Kool Moe Dee
column7: it was Big Daddy Kane who brokered the collaboration.) ""Downtown"" is a Broadway song
column8: basically—rap for people who loved Hamilton. I hear it and imagine parades
column9: streamers
column10: the Super Bowl half-time show they will probably someday play.

column1: Macklemore is also a skilled mimic. He presses hat to heart when Chance the Rapper is around
column2: spits with cocksure nostalgia around KRS-One and DJ Premier
column3: does budget OG Maco-flow trading lines with YG on ""Bolo Tie."" On album highlight ""Need to Know
column4: Chance delivers a thoughtful verse about the pitfalls of fame—being alienated from the white girls who ""call me nigga at my show
column5: feeling the pressure to strip the spirituality out of his music and ""just leave the cool parts."" (Meanwhile
column6: Macklemore offers hashtag rap in the guise of self-awareness: ""I only think about my worth
column7: I only think about my come up/ Capitalism."") It’s the opposite of Chance’s stint on Kanye’s ""Ultralight Beam
column8: where he exclaimed ""I’m just having fun with it!"" But Chance isn’t here to have fun
column9: because Macklemore is so granite-faced on the serious songs that his guest stars have no choice but to match his mood.

column1: ""Fun"" is reserved for songs like ""Dance Off"" (in which Idris Elba challenges you to a dance off) or ""Brad Pitt’s Cousin"" (in which Macklemore boasts that ""every white dude in America went to the barbershop: 'Give me the Macklemore haircut'""). That said
column2: it isn’t always easy to tell when Macklemore is trying to be fun
column3: or when we are having fun at his expense. ""Let’s Eat"" is presumably about our collective body image issues
column4: but the jokiness prevents it from getting a foothold. Macklemore would not be the first rapper to alternate between goofiness and gravitas
column5: but the gulf between sober analysis of Oxycontin abuse and white privilege
column6: and the ""DEEZ NUTS"" jokes is just too wide. If he’s serious about wanting to ""start conversations and change the way that we think and we feel
column7: he needs to sound as comfortable serving wisdom as he does shooting Sandler-esque wisecracks.

column1: The trumped-up portentousness of ""White Privilege II"" is still difficult to digest. It’s a messy explainer of his still-forming politics
column2: a Facebook status come to life. His heart is in the right place
column3: but it’s hard to justify on musical terms. He doesn’t deserve a free pass for being well-intentioned
column4: of course. But ""White Privilege II"" is different from
column5: say
column6: Brad Paisley and LL Cool J’s ""Accidental Racist
column7: another race-focused song with its heart in the right place that nevertheless missed the mark because it made no attempt to examine its founding premises. (""If you don’t judge my gold chains
column8: I’ll forget the iron chains"" is not a fair trade.) Instead
column9: Macklemore is laboring to show us
column10: brick by awkwardly-rapped brick
column11: how he laid the foundation of his new ideology. It isn’t a link to a Wikipedia page—it’s the whole article. As a song
column12: it’s not great. As an endeavor
column13: it’s hard to be snide about. His credibility regarding his intellectual growing pains is the most essential part of his music
column14: even as it’s also the part that makes him seem doe-eyed and naive.

column1: In other words: Do you want to argue that more public discussion of systemic power imbalances is a bad thing? More than one person I follow on Twitter expressed surprise that anyone needs white privilege explained to them
column2: but Donald Trump has won three presidential primaries and counting
column3: so maybe Macklemore has a better bead on the country than some are willing to admit. We can also dispense with the take that his motivation in writing songs like ""White Privilege II"" is cynical

Two songs on Richmond-based singer/songwriter Lucy Dacus' debut album No Burden contain the same chorus: ""Without you I am surely the last of our kind/ Without you I am surely the last of my kind."" The songs
column2: ""Dream State..."" and ""...Familiar Place
column3: seem to complete each other elliptically
column4: and approach their shared lyric through two different paths; the first describes a flood
column5: both emotional and physical
column6: while the second finds its narrator crawling through a dead garden. Both choruses seem to obey the physics of dreams: people are lost irretrievably
column7: landscapes shift from domestic to alpine. Dacus conveys the warm
column8: human perspective at the center of this turning vortex
column9: a person trying to survive the infinite flow of change.

column1: No Burden is an uncommonly warm indie rock record. Lead guitar lines pour in like slow columns of sunlight
column2: and Dacus' voice itself is a comforting blur. ""I let my mind get turned inside out/ Just to see what the kids were laughing about

column5: permissive dimension that usually slips in after two or three drinks. ""I thought you'd hit rock bottom
column6: but I'm starting to think that it doesn't exist
column7: she sings in ""Strange Torpedo."" ""You've been falling for so long and you haven't hit anything solid yet.""

column1: The record is full of these candid and severe observations. ""I Don't Wanna Be Funny Anymore"" describes the arthritic inflexibility of social roles. ""Is there room in the band?"" Dacus asks. ""I don't need to be the frontman/ If not then I'll be the biggest fan."" Dacus herself intended to study film before focusing on music; ""I Don't Wanna Be Funny Anymore"" and the rest of No Burden seems a product of this wavering and observational focus. The people in her songs seem to naturally settle into realms of instability and ambiguity.
Becoming ""no burden"" means exerting zero pressure on the world
column2: suspending yourself in a sphere of your own consciousness
column3: as if sealed into a dream. Of course
column4: removing yourself from the world and others is its own inverse pressure. Your body
column5: mind
column6: and their obscure combinations will carry
column7: shift
column8: and broadcast weight from any position they take up in space. ""If you hadn’t come over
column9: I would be so much colder
column10: Dacus sings in ""Dream State…"" ""I would be much less confused."" Everything
column11: No Burden seems to suggest
column12:
is burden.

With the possible exception of Godsmack
column2: no band name is more indicative of a main influence than Pinkshinyultrablast. It was previously the title of the third LP by Astrobrite

column4: evocatively named lovesliescrushing
column5: projects that approached shoegaze while maintaining a basis in electronic noise—other ""truth in advertising"" Astrobrite releases include Whitenoise Superstar and Supercrush. It’s a style far more obtuse than the guitar-pop model that spawned genre titans like My Bloody Valentine and Ride

column7: more than a decade after the original Pinkshinyultrablast

column9: Pinkshinyultrablast sought to go further toward the margins—noisier
column10: more electronic
column11: more dense
column12: simply more. And yet
column13: they became something much closer to a guitar-pop band in the process

column1: In a literal sense

column3: Pinkshinyultrablast hits them with such force that the name becomes almost stupidly obvious. It’s the equivalent of getting showered with a firehose pumping spangly glitter.

column12:
but the first impression tends to be the only one it makes.

Guerilla Toss may project themselves as deeply weeded hippie-punks

column4: NNA Tapes

column1: Now signed to New York's DFA
column2: Guerilla Toss have simmered down a little. The band’s first full-length for the label
column3: Eraser Stargazer
column4: finds them less manic and more zoned-out
column5: augmenting pulsing repetition with heaps of gurgling psychedelic jewelry and elastic basslines. In terms of DFA’s classic catalog

column7: embodying a fluid and streamlined rhythmic sensibility. Guerilla Toss' music is more like the burbling glop at the top of the Slurpee machine—viscous and messy. Think Chocolate Synthesizer-era Boredoms spliced with The Uplift Mofo Party Plan-era Red Hot Chili Peppers. No
column8: don't laugh. That's not a takedown. On <i>Eraser Stargazer
column9: Guerilla Toss suggests funkiness without channeling the grody and ultra-masculine energy that seems forever sewn to punk-funk. Not exactly an easy thing to do.

column1: In a way

column3: Guerilla Toss’ alternative-era source material is not so much MTV as the jam band world. Which shouldn’t suggest that they are given to jamming. That kinship comes more through a lack of musical self-consciousness—the willingness to seek transcendence via improvisation and weirdo genre bending. On Eraser Stargazer
column4: Guerilla Toss captures that crowd’s yin and yang—the blissed-out hippie vibe and also the druggy parking lot creep-out factor.

column1: But like the jam bands of yesteryear
column2: Guerilla Toss’ on-stage appeal is not easily consumed through the thin reed of a SoundCloud single
column3: a YouTube video
column4: or even a LP. In concert
column5: the band can survive on sheer intensity. But as a record

column7: but not always much to grip. It is a forward move for the band
column8: though. Where Guerilla Toss’ music was once driven by the push and pull between abrasive elements

column10:
but no less strange.

Wilco drummer Glenn Kotche has added some impressive entries to his new-classical resume in recent years. With his 2014 full-length debut as a composer
column2: Adventureland
column3: he displayed a facility for rich
column4: percussive-driven works—and also a skill for writing multi-movement pieces that included parts for string instruments and electronics. He’s been equally successful as a performer in this field (as a powerhouse 2015 recording of John Luther Adams’s Ilimaq demonstrated). In light of this
column5: a collaboration between Kotche and the elite contemporary classical group So Percussion seems inevitable
column6: in the best possible way.

column1: At crucial points
column2: the pieces that make up Drumkit Quartets can fail to sound as purposeful as those on Adventureland. The album’s opening and closing tracks give a sense of this indecisive quality
column3: with Kotche’s ""Drumkit Quartet #51"" receiving two different presentations. The first version is subtitled ""Tokyo
column4: Brisbane & Berlin"" (indicating cities where Kotche worked on the piece
column5: or else where he made field recordings). Here
column6: competing rhythms for marimbas cycle through the composition amiably
column7: without creating much tension. Kotche’s collage of pre-recorded noises is frequently spare to a point of seeming aimless. A brief haiku by Kotche (voiced by Yuka Honda) has its say in the final third
column8: and the strongest feeling it imparts is a quizzical one.

column1: Texture-obsessed writing isn’t objectionable on its own
column2: but 10 minutes of it is a lot of time for a 51-minute set—especially when the closing ""Chicago Realization"" of the very same composition generates much more excitement. In this version
column3: Kotche’s denser background recording highlights the subtle turns of the marimba writing and preserves the delicacy Kotche is obviously aiming for.

column1: Presenting different ""realizations"" of the same piece can make sense when John Cage-style ""chance operations"" are part of the mix. But these versions just shift around the arrangement of pre-recorded parts
column2: suggesting compositional diffidence. In his liner notes
column3: Kotche makes reference to these pieces being conceived during a period in which he was ""touring extensively"" with Wilco. He also admits that finishing another of the longest tracks here
column4: ""Drumkit Quartet #50
column5: was ""challenging."" The labor is audible.

column1: Still
column2: sketchbook albums from skilled artists can have their moments. Kotche’s miniatures fare quite well. Two propulsive items—""Drumkit Quartet #1"" and ""Drumkit Quartet #54""—are full of ingenuity as well as power. The brief
column3: three-movement ""Drumkit Quartet #3"" moves from dry cymbal work to more resonant pitched percussion with a serene focus. Together with ""Drumkit Quartet #51 (Chicago Realization)
column4: there’s enough intriguing work here to make Drumkit Quartets worth investigating. Hopefully Kotche will reconnect with the players of So Percussion again at some point in the future
column5:
when he has something more clearly fashioned in mind.

column12: a needlessly gruesome pivot—Cale isn’t even present—and one that director James Marsh must have believed embodies Cale’s volatility throughout his long career.

column1: Cale has long carved mercurial paths—first in the Velvet Underground
column2: where his eerie bass
column3: piano
column4: and viola parts pushed the band toward the eccentric end of the art-rock spectrum
column5: then as a producer
column6: when he captured the raw spirits of the Stooges and Patti Smith on both artists’ classic debut albums. The 73-year-old’s 15 solo albums touch on protopunk and classical and are niche to the point that some have been out of print for years; one of those works
column7: 1982’s Music for a New Society
column8: has been singled out as a pernicious lost masterpiece
column9: the spare and depressive about-face to his agitpop screed of the previous year
column10: Honi Soit.

column1: When Music was finally reissued this year
column2: it came bundled Jekyll-Hyde style with M:FANS
column3: a new reworking of the album. The latter isn’t as hagiographic as the acronym suggests—Nick Zinner isn’t here shaking a tambourine or anything—but is rather Cale’s attempt to revisit bleak characters through a lens of rage instead of sorrow
column4: as well as process the death of his occasional nemesis Lou Reed. Hearing both versions of the album together
column5: especially by hopscotching to compare tracks directly
column6: is a harrowing yet rewarding spree
column7: not least because Cale’s originals often sound more modern than the new versions.

column1: On Music for a New Society
column2: sparse keyboard lines languish in chilly air
column3: arid spaces imbued with acute confidence. Cale unfurls somber
column4: detached appraisals of miserable lost souls
column5: including mothers on murder sprees (""Taking Your Life in Your Hands"") and loners exhaling their death rattles (""Sanctus (Sanities)"")
column6: atop deconstructed bleats of churchy organs and dissonant strings. There are wisps of tight pop melodies perched atop a confluence of oddities—""Thoughtless Kind
column7: a spooky dirge
column8: pairs a thickly processed a capella refrain (""The best of times/ With the thoughtless kind"") with rough cackling and an agitating percussion line reminiscent of a ticking clock. ""Close Watch
column9: its title cribbed from Cale’s septuagenarian spirit animal Johnny Cash
column10: anatomizes loneliness via plodding piano and decomposing bagpipe bursts. Aside from the lone straightforward rocker
column11: ""Changes Made
column12: on which Allen Lanier of Blue Öyster Cult plays guitar
column13: the semi-improvised record feels meticulously plotted and borderline intrusive—the most revealing scrawls yet from the solitary confinement of Cale’s fulminating mind.

column1: M:FANS is less reclusive
column2: just by virtue of its premise—Cale is collaborating with himself
column3: the ultimate glum foil—but also because it fills every swatch of white space with his later-career electro-industrial leanings. That needling chronograph tick on ""Thoughtless Kind"" is now gregarious
column4: beefy with fizzing synths and hyper-processed coos. Amber Coffman of Dirty Projectors joins him to sing staccato microtones on ""Close Watch
column5: a brusque and R&B-leaning reimagining virtually unrecognizable from its weepy source material. ""Sanctus (Sanities)"" also proves malleable
column6: Cale intoning a requiem of personal and general-interest doom (""It was a marriage made… in the grave!"" is not the least histrionic line) over a driving mechanical stomp Nine Inch Nails would’ve relished. It’s a lot of futurism sourced from the '90s
column7: which highlights Cale’s prescience in the first go-‘round.

column1: Cale is clearly still curious as an artist; in recent years
column2: he’s collaborated with Danger Mouse and represented the motherland at the Venice Biennale. Hell
column3: he practically flirted with Bond villainy two years ago
column4: when he commanded a horde of wasp drones onstage in London. Still
column5: there’s a greater vigor
column6: and a real lack of vanity
column7: to releasing a notorious lost album and upending it in the same breath. That these projects work in tandem
column8: three decades removed
column9:
gives nostalgia a good name.

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/22739/homepage_large.5651d12a.jpg|Principe del Norte|7602.0|Prins Thomas|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Smalltown Supersound']|2016-02-25 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 16:01:04.598376|"<div class=""contents dropcap"" data-reactid="".1t5xsg3rwg.1.6:0.1.0.$21435/=1$21435.0.3.2.0.1.0.1""><div>For an album with a royal pedigree right there in its title
column2: Prins Thomas' Principe del Norte is a record with nothing to prove. The shortest of its nine untitled tracks is nearly eight minutes long
column3: and three run to 13 minutes or more. You don't get the sense the track lengths stem from any sort of desire to grandstand; it just looks like Thomas didn't much feel like editing himself. The whole album runs more than an hour and a half
column4: beats halting and restarting
column5: synths drifting willy-nilly over muted basslines
column6: and arrangements wandering free as clouds. It is a vision of ambient music in bathrobe and slippers
column7: slurping milk straight from the carton at the all-night grocery; it is The Dude of ambient.

column1: Of course
column2: the Dude was pretty cool
column3: and so is Principe del Norte
column4: which comes across as genial
column5: charmingly rumpled
column6: and totally unflappable. These songs appear to have been improvised and recorded across long studio jams
column7: and the main compositional guideline seems to dictate only that the music is limited to what Thomas can play with his own two hands—or his sequencers—at any given moment. <span>Take ""C
column8: which begins with patient
column9: parallel synthesizer lines
column10: teases with a pitter-pat beat
column11: falls back into a beatless breakdown—mashed keys
column12: a wrong note or two—and then ramps back up into its full chug. There's yet another false ending at the eight-and-a-half minute mark
column13: before the arpeggios fire up again for a four-minute denouement.Disco's pulse is implicit in the four-to-the-floor beats of the album's heavier cuts (""E
column15: ""G"") and in faintly funky basslines that crop up here and there
column16: but the album draws most of its inspiration from '70s German electronic artists like Tangerine Dream and Manuel Göttsching.

column1: In his notes to the album
column2: Thomas cites the influence of '90s ambient artists like the KLF
column3: the Orb
column4: and the Black Dog
column5: but for the most part
column6: Principe del Norte scans as a logical extension of Thomas' previous work
column7: just with the drums dialed way down. The lone exception is the final track
column9: which might be one of the heaviest things he's ever recorded; with its thudding bass kicks
column10: cavernous bass kicks
column11: and monotone clatter and grind
column12: it sounds almost like his attempt at Berghain-style techno. (""D
column13: which uses some of the same elements
column14: scans more as Thomas' interpretation of dub techno in the tradition of Chain Reaction.) Unlike proper warehouse techno
column15: though
column16: ""H"" retains all of Thomas' habitual characteristics—idiosyncratic
column17: loosey-goosey
column18: a little unkempt. Does anyone need 13-plus minutes of it? Perhaps not
column19: but you don't come to Principe del Norte for concision. You come to kick back
column21: and forget about time for a while. It's not music for airports; it's music for beanbag chairs

The first thing you need to know about French Montana is that back-to-back subsections on his otherwise disorganized Wikipedia page are ""Shooting Attempts"" and ""Exotic Pets."" At the beginning of this decade
column2: the Bronx-bred rapper was drifting somewhere between ""budding star"" and ""also-ran
column3: hawking DVDs and mixtapes anchored by his more-famous friends. By the end of 2014
column4: he was living a parallel life as Fitzgeraldian social climber stuck in a real-life safari of leopards and Kardashians. (Here's a video called ""2 Chainz and French Montana Feed a $40K Giraffe."")

column1: Last May
column2: Chinx
column3: a Far Rockaway native who was a close friend to and collaborator with French
column4: was killed in a still-unsolved shooting. (The NYPD has said that they believe his murder might be tied to the 2007 killing of Stack Bundles
column5: another collaborator.) It's in the shadow of that tragedy that French's new mixtape
column6: Wave Gods
column7: begins: ""They threw me in the black hole
column8: I had to climb up/ Once Chinx passed
column9: I took some time off."" On the tape's cover
column10: French is joined by Max B
column11: his kindred creative spirit who isn't up for parole until 2042. He's finally at the top—or at least adjacent to it—but he had to come alone.

column1: Wave Gods hears French bring moments of tragedy and Technicolor excess to life frequently and in equal measure. ""Holy Moly"" is all joy (""My bitch from Cuba and my lawyer Jewish""); on the ""Sanctuary"" remix
column2: he borrows the Weeknd's ""Bring the drugs
column3: baby
column4: I'ma bring my pain."" Sometimes
column5: they're shoehorned into the same verse: on the Kanye West- and Nas-featuring ""Figure It Out
column6: French considers Chinx and Max
column7: Eazy E
column8: Allen Iverson
column9: and Bill Cosby
column10: but also slips in ""Why I fucked them both when they said they're sisters?"" and you can practically hear him grinning at the camera.

column1: Until now
column2: French had spent much of his career as the weakest
column3: or at least most anonymous rapper in the room. Most fans push both Coke Wave installments into the Max B canon. His introduction to pop audiences came on ""Stay Schemin
column4: which was more noted for Drake's shots at Common and Vanessa Bryant. His 2013 Bad Boy/Maybach Music Group debut
column5: Excuse My French
column6: had more guests (Drake
column7: Nicki
column8: Wayne
column9: Snoop) than tracks
column10: suffered dismal reviews
column11: and failed to sell 100
column12: 000 copies. Worse still
column13: his detractors—many of whom were presumably unfamiliar with his earlier work—wrote him off as a relic from a dead era
column14: a last gasp for old New York heads who couldn't or wouldn't get with the times.

column1: In reality
column2: French was never a classicist in any sense
column3: and certainly not a '90s revivalist. His golden age was the mid- and late-2000s
column4: when Wayne and T-Pain dominated radio
column5: and when Max was turning Harlem into a grim
column6: funhouse mirror version of that sound. On Wave Gods
column7: French has improved his writing
column8: sure
column9: but more importantly has imagined a world where that sound became the dominant commercial mode
column10: where the precision of trap or the maximalism of drill never took over
column11: where we're left with something more stripped down
column12: woozier
column13: wavier.

column1: And so this time
column2: the guests bend into his orbit. Quavo's staccato triplets on ""Groupie Love"" are blunted by the Auto-Tune. Kodak Black is 13 years younger and from 1
column3: 200 miles south
column4: but on ""Lock Jaw"" sounds like he's been locked in a give-and-go for years. On ""Jackson 5
column5: he puts an original stamp on the same sort of soul loops that have been dominating the city's mixtape circuit since the early W. Bush years. The prevailing atmosphere on Wave Gods is so strong that the one time French does yield home court
column6: to Future on ""Miley Cyrus
column7: it's jarring
column8: despite being an excellent song in its own right.

column1: Wave Gods ends with two appearances from Chinx—""All Over"" and yet another remix of ""Off the Rip."" It's a touching tribute from an artist who was eager to share the spotlight when it was a necessity
column2: and remains so now that he can carry songs on his own. ""Rip"" in particular is moving in this new context

column4: the song's latest guest
column5: implores the audience to ""pay attention

column7:
but it isn't anymore.

In the summer of 1976
column2: a variety show called ""The Jacksons"" debuted on CBS. The program came about during a relatively fallow period for the showbiz brood
column3: after the Jackson 5 ignited nationwide fervor with hits like ""ABC"" and ""I’ll Be There"" but before Michael Jackson set out for solo superstardom. Their future success seemed in doubt
column4: and the show—with its glaring lights
column5: sparkling costumes
column6: and rampant cheesiness—was a Vegas-style extravaganza that played to well-worn pleasures. One recurring segment called ""On the Wall"" saw Michael inviting various guest hosts to sign a fake brick facade and do a little dance before everyone eventually ended up in a frozen ta-dah! pose. Though Michael was all smiles on ""The Jacksons
column7: he later claimed that he ""hated every minute"" of it. During the show’s year-long run
column8: he was smack in the middle of gangly teenagedom
column9: acne and all. Raised in the limelight by an infamously strict father
column10: Michael was painfully self-conscious
column11: worried that he might never be able to shake his child stardom. He didn’t want to merely cling to his family’s fading notoriety. He wanted to break away from it completely.

column1: Off the Wall is the sound of that liberation. And he knew exactly what he was doing. On November 6
column3: just as the album was starting to take off
column4: Michael wrote a note to himself on the back of a tour itinerary
column5: a proclamation of self so ambitious it could make Kanye blush. ""MJ will be my new name
column6: no more Michael Jackson. I want a whole new character
column7: a whole new look
column8: I should be a totally different person. People should never think of me as the kid who sang ‘ABC’ [and] ‘I Want You Back
column9: ’"" he jotted down. ""I should be a new incredible actor singer dancer that will shock the world. I will do no interviews. I will be magic. I will be a perfectionist
column10: a researcher
column11: a trainer
column12: a masterer… I will study and look back on the whole world of entertainment and perfect it. Take it steps further from where the greats left off.""

column1: Those words were eerily prescient in many ways
column2: of course
column3: but they also highlight one of Michael’s most important dualities: He wanted to be magical—to defy expectation and reality—but he knew that such skills could not materialize from thin air. He understood that exceptionalism took hard work. Growing up in the Motown system
column4: he would often sit in on sessions
column5: soaking up lessons from the greats: Diana Ross
column6: Marvin Gaye
column7: the Temptations. He studied the way James Brown
column8: Sammy Davis Jr.
column9: and Fred Astaire moved their feet onstage
column10: in movies
column11: and on TV. At 17
column12: he counted hallowed masters like Irving Berlin
column13: George Gershwin
column14: and Duke Ellington among his favorite songwriters. He had released four solo albums in the early ’70s
column15: but Off the Wall
column16: which came out when he was 21
column17: finally allowed him to flex all those hours of research into something that was his.

column1: It also marked a moment of idealism. Around the time of Off the Wall
column2: Michael’s musical and physical changes felt natural—joyous extensions of the black American experience. Disco was overwhelmingly popular
column3: breaking down color lines and radio formats while offering utopia on the dancefloor. Coming from the segregated
column4: working-class city of Gary
column5: Ind.
column6: Jackson's achievements and acceptance represented a rosy view of the country’s future. But 1979 was scarred by the beginning of the quasi-racist ""disco sucks"" backlash; Michael also got his first nose job that year
column7: narrowing his nostrils. And though he would become even more successful in the '80s
column8: those astronomical heights sometimes catered to white tastes—in both appearance and sound—in a way that could seem effortful
column9: cynical
column10: and sad.

column1: So part of the reason why Off the Wall remains so unabashedly fun to return to involves that lack of baggage. For 41 minutes
column2: we can live in the eternally young Neverland Michael longed for
column3: a universe largely without consequence or death. This lasting affection is reiterated by a new Spike Lee documentary
column4: Michael Jackson's Journey from Motown to Off the Wall
column5: which is included in this CD/DVD reissue and finds Jackson family members and associates
column6: along with more modern stars like the Weeknd’s Abel Tesfaye
column7: ?uestlove
column8: and Pharrell
column9: paying tribute to Michael’s earliest incarnations. ""Off the Wall was definitely the one that made me feel like I could sing
column10: says Tesfaye in the doc
column11: which was in part produced by executors of Michael’s estate and barely mentions anything about the artist’s life after Off the Wall.

column1: The album was released toward the tail end of the disco era and it managed to encompass much of what made that style so infectious while also pushing out its edges. ""Our underlying plan was to take disco out. That was the bottom line
column2: the record’s producer
column3: Quincy Jones
column4: once said. ""I admired disco
column5: don’t get me wrong. I just thought it had gone far enough."" Jones
column6: a calm
column7: jazzy Zen master who had worked with Dizzy Gillespie
column8: Frank Sinatra
column9: and Count Basie
column10: helped Michael flesh out his own songs as well as tracks written by others
column11: putting forth a record that is at once beautifully simple and sneakily complex.

column1: Most of these songs follow the most basic disco tenet: Put all of your worries behind you and just dance. Michael took part in this type of ecstasy while filming 1978’s The Wiz in New York City
column2: when he would spend his downtime brushing shoulders with the likes of Woody Allen
column3: Liza Minelli
column4: Steven Tyler
column5: and Jane Fonda at Studio 54. By all accounts
column6: Michael didn’t take part in the club’s notorious orgies of sex and drugs
column7: but he observed it
column8: standing by the DJ booth and noticing which songs drew the biggest reactions. And he would dance
column9: getting high off of the music and movement around him.

column1: Alongside Jones
column2: Michael made his own disco anthems
column3: but rather than merely copying what came before
column4: he expanded the form with dense
column5: orchestral arrangements that mixed in sophisticated layers of strings
column6: horns
column7: and syncopation while never never losing their underlying funk. This is heard on iconic opener ""Don’t Stop ‘Til You Get Enough
column8: the first song Michael ever wrote by himself and the first of four record-breaking Top 10 hits from the album
column9: which has now sold 30 million copies worldwide. It's an ode to the power of romantic love
column10: something Michael had little experience with at that point. But the track’s intricacies
column11: as well as the singer’s effortlessly rhythmic yelps and phrasing
column12: suggest a deeper understanding
column13: one that goes beyond words. Another Michael-penned track
column14: ""Working Day and Night
column15: hints at the detrimental effects of his workaholic upbringing and an encroaching paranoia
column16: though ricocheting guitar lines and exuberant horns keep the groove moving along smoothly.

column1: There are more overt experiments here
column2: too. ""Off the Wall"" begins with 15 seconds of sinister-sounding laughter and spaced-out instrumentation—a precursor to the high-wattage oddities of ""Thriller""; co-written by Stevie Wonder and originally intended for Songs in the Key of Life
column3: ""I Can’t Help It"" incorporates smooth jazz and twinkling synths—its influence on Pharrell’s off-kilter funk cannot be overstated. The ballad ""She’s Out of My Life"" risks stopping the album cold with its beat-less melodrama but ends up being a classic of the form
column4: with Michael audibly moved to tears at the end of the song
column5: his voice cracking. It’s an imperfect moment from a noted perfectionist
column6: and Jones’ production handles the emotion with understated grace. ""A lesser producer would have milked all that drama for all it’s worth
column7: says ?uestlove in the doc
column8: laughing. ""Trust me
column9: if Puffy was producing ‘She’s Out of My Life’ he would have had… Kleenex sponsor the tour.""

column1: The joke resonates. Off the Wall is the product of a boy who was reared by his father to be a product
column2: whose idols were often found on his TV screen
column3: who understood his own commodification enough to want to reject it—while also aiming to sell a gazillion albums and unite the world and become the ultimate entertainer. There are many contradictions in that quest and
column4: in hindsight
column5: Michael’s subsequent pitfalls almost seem inevitable. But Off the Wall was that unlikely moment of balance
column6: when Michael Jackson’s purity and innocence still seemed holy
column7: not stunted or distorted. When he cried on record
column8: he was living his art
column9:
giving us a genuine performance.

Team George—now that’s a fierce genus of Beatlemaniac. They’ve inspected and cast aside the iconoclast cool of John
column3: girded themselves against the snug
column4: romantic haze of Paul. (A basic lack of sociopathy steers them from Ringo trutherism.) Harrison’s tribe is possessive because he
column5: along with Bowie and Morrissey
column6: was one of rock’s great shepherds of outsiders—a gentle mascot for those who also feel a bit too curious
column7: a little too sensitive when held to bright lights. His consistent relegation to second-tier creative status inside the Beatles—one of the most famous yet undermined faces in the world
column8: plunked courtside next to two massive egos—gave his songwriting a special undertow of empathy that his bandmates never touched. Those who identify with his dark-horse journey are a motley
column9: loyal breed.

column1: A similar reverence runs through George Fest: A Night to Celebrate the Music of George Harrison
column2: a live double album with the ramshackle
column3: collaborative warmth of a Traveling Wilburys set. Taped at L.A.’s Fonda Theatre in September 2014
column4: the evening cribs together a varied roster—including Brian Wilson
column5: the Flaming Lips
column6: Norah Jones
column7: Britt Daniel of Spoon
column8: Brandon Flowers of the Killers
column9: and Harrison’s dopplegänger son
column10: Dhani Harrison—for campfire spins on familiar Beatles and solo fare. It’s an amiable
column11: unofficial sort of sequel to The Concert for George
column12: which was held at Royal Albert Hall in 2002 with Paul and Ringo
column13: Eric Clapton
column14: Tom Petty
column15: and Billy Preston—but this time
column16: it’s staffed largely with Dhani’s peers. (He co-produced the charity event
column17: which will also be released on DVD.)

column1: Like most tributes
column2: it’s not a particularly exploratory evening
column3: but the parish is earnest. Song allotments are logical
column4: and most artists hew closely to Harrison’s vocal cadences and cryptic guitars. Britt Daniel lends some yowling panache to ""I Me Mine"" (off Let It Be) and the underrated folk singer/model Karen Elson adds a reedy quaver through ""I’d Have You Anytime
column5: the delicate opening of Harrison’s stellar triple album All Things Must Pass (and a bromantic ode to Bob Dylan). Norah Jones
column6: daughter of one of Harrison’s most influential collaborators
column7: the late sitarist Ravi Shankar—and a lovely voice who never quite gets her due for melodic winsomeness—adds subtle inversions to ""Something
column8: an evening standout. Dhani Harrison
column9: a truly uncanny vocal and visual heir
column10: spurs on some of the night’s liveliest moments with the White Album eccentricity ""Savoy Truffle"" and the more contemplative solo missive ""Let It Down.""  Those not following along on the tracklist might furrow their brows to the billowing chorus of ""What Is Life""—that is
column11: indeed
column12: ""Weird Al"" Yankovic
column13: crooning the euphoric All Things Must Pass hit utterly straight
column14: not even tweaking the lyrics into ""Hobbit Strife"" or anything.

column1: The evening’s highlight
column2: not least for rarity: Brian Wilson
column3: tackling Harrison’s contentious classic ""My Sweet Lord
column4: with support from fellow Beach Boy Al Jardine
column5: Ann Wilson of Heart
column6: and others. It’s fair to say Wilson wouldn’t have his legacy today without Harrison and the Beatles—his watershed Pet Sounds was an attempt to outshine their Rubber Soul
column7: and the friendly ensuing arms race beget Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band and the Smile sessions. There’s welcome ardor in Wilson’s scratchy delivery; he sounds more enlivened than in many other recent projects
column8: including much of his last studio album and the Beach Boys’ 50th anniversary tour. (As he recalls boyishly in the film’s trailer
column9: of a moment several decades prior
column10: ""When I heard ‘My Sweet Lord
column11: ’ I just about croaked!"")

column1: There are a few stumbles—Cold War Kids’ yodeling
column2: slack delivery of ""Taxman"" sounds borderline drunk
column3: and the Black Ryder’s ""Isn’t It a Pity"" is a bit static for such an elegy. No one touches ""While My Guitar Gently Weeps
column4: a surprising omission; maybe Dhani is sick of hearing it mangled every time he pops into Guitar Center. But as an act of low-impact celebration
column5:
George Fest is a fine affair. More noise for the Quiet Beatle is welcome anytime.

The Mekons could have easily ridden out an entire career off the energy of their grimy start in the Leeds art-school scene. Instead
column2: when they started anew following a brief hiatus in the early '80s
column3: frontman and co-founder Jon Langford chose to train their gaze across the pond
column4: led by the spirit guides of Johnny Cash and Hank Williams. Their next album
column5: 1985’s Fear and Whiskey
column6: didn’t just execute a brilliant and unlikely-seeming stylistic merger
column7: it ushered in a whole new generation of imitators
column8: acolytes
column9: and even icons.

column1: Langford's continued interest in Americana has produced several Chicago-based side projects
column2: as well: There's Pine Valley Cosmonauts
column3: a revolving door of tributes covers for artists like Cash and Bob Wills
column4: and then there's the Waco Brothers
column5: a heavier group with a more deliberate populist pulse. Following a decade of dalliances—a covers album and B-sides collection here
column6: a collaboration with songwriter Paul Burch there—the latter band’s returned with Going Down in History
column7: their first studio LP since 2005’s Freedom and Weep and a tight (if occasionally underwhelming) set of aggressive heartland rock.

column1: Twenty years on
column2: the Bros’ grizzled sonics are set. Opener ""DIYBYOB
column3: set off by Dean ""Deano"" Schlabowske's throaty twang and clattering axe
column4: immediately brings us back into familiar territory. Therein lies the genius of Schlabowske's first line: ""This is the first track from the last album/ No one knows which way this ship will head."" Depending on your interpretation
column5: the lyric could be a knowing wink to the same ol’-same ol’ of the band’s chosen style
column6: a masochistic joke
column7: or even a tongue-in-cheek resignation—either way
column8: it adds a crucial twist to an otherwise straightforward bit of songcraft.

column1: Indeed
column2: playfulness abounds on Going Down in History. For a reflection on the dead-end determinism of the status quo
column3: ""Building Our Own Prison"" proves downright chipper
column4: with an onomatopoeiac
column5: syncopated hook (a spirited ""Click clack clackety-clack
column6: right on the beat of the jagged fretwork). Meanwhile
column7: ""We Know It"" offers an all-purpose anthem for
column8: well
column9: anything; Langford’s croons of ""We know it when we see it/ We know it by its name"" could stand in for God
column10: the Devil
column11: or the mold beneath your kitchen tiles.

column1: It’s not all fun and games
column2: though—political disillusionment and hand-wringing reflections of the working class remain a perennial concern for the Waco Brothers
column3: and the pervading outsider’s perspective resonates strongly in a tumultuous campaign season. Going Down in History may not mark a sea change for Langford and company
column4: but between the humor
column5: the honky-tonk
column6: and the affable
column7: full-bodied sound
column8:
it’s an awesome chance to catch up.

While the boundary between hip-hop and electronic music has always been permeable
column2: in recent years it’s begun to show signs of dissolving completely. Trap-influenced drum patterns dominate electro-pop
column3: spaced-out synths are de rigueur in rap
column4: and hybrid producers have become some of electronic music's biggest stars. As what’s left of the wall crumbles
column5: we’re seeing more extended collaborations between rappers and electro-pop artists
column6: like Danny Brown’s work with Purity Ring or Big Boi and Phantogram’s Big Grams.

column1: AMTHST is the latest partnership in this mold. It finds Bay Area rapper and producer Droop-E teaming up with Ramona Gonzalez
column2: the singer/songwriter behind L.A. synth-pop act Nite Jewel. This isn’t the first time the pair have linked up--Droop-E’s 2013 song ""N the Traffic"" featured Gonzales on the hook—though this time around
column3: they’re working together more closely
column4: collaborating on the production as well as the songwriting. Euphoria
column5: their debut EP under the name AMTHST
column6: is a record that revels in distance: the distance between hip-hop and electro-pop
column7: the distance between men and women
column8: the distance between L.A. and the Bay.

column1: Droop-E and Gonzales do have plenty in common musically
column2: though
column3: and they quickly find a sonic middle ground on Euphoria
column4: marrying the laid-back bounce of Bay-Area rap to the gauzy atmospherics of Nite Jewel’s early work. This is nocturnal music
column5: built from layers of synths
column6: wet snare hits
column7: and plenty of echo. The songs unfurl at a languid
column8: practically chopped-and-screwed pace
column9: and both Droop-E and Gonzalez luxuriate in the production
column10: trading off verses and choruses with an easy cadence.

column1: While Droop-E and Gonzalez are a natural fit as musicians
column2: Euphoria’s most compelling moments leverage their divergent vocal approaches. ""Thug Passion
column3: a smoldering trip-hop number
column4: casts the pair as two lovers talking past one another. ""You don’t call me back
column5: Gonzales sighs. ""You don’t know me."" Droop-E
column6: meanwhile
column7: mutters noncomittally in the background
column8: suggesting
column9: ""We can just chill out
column10: relax."" ""I Wonder"" flips this script: Droop-E is in full pursuit
column11: thirstily spitting game
column12: while Gonzales eludes his advances. ""You tell me lots of things/ What do they really mean?/ The more I wonder
column13: she chirps back. Both of these songs feel like nuanced counterpoints to the one-sided narratives that drive most hip-hop and pop songs—they’re conversations
column14: not accusations.

column1: ""Over Zone
column2: a meditation on intoxication and its consequences
column3: goes further yet
column4: digging into the ways that gender mediates our pursuit of euphoria. On first listen
column5: the song recalls a similar anthem—its pitched-down call-and-reponse refrain is pretty similar to that of Kendrick Lamar’s ""Swimming Pools (Drank)""—but merits a closer reading. During a set piece in the song’s midsection
column6: Gonzales drunkenly attempts to leave a club—when she’s stopped
column7: she insists that she just needs some fresh air. ""Nah
column8: I saw you stumbling out there
column9: you’re not fooling anyone
column10: a sinister voice responds
column11: as water-logged synths close in around the track. The scene then switches to Droop-E
column12: who finds himself in a similar predicament
column13: careening down a hallway in search of a place to vomit. ""Give me some bread and some spring water and I’ll be cool
column14: shit
column15: he raps—a bit of bravado
column16: perhaps
column17: but also a tacit acknowledgement that his safety isn’t in question despite his drunkenness.

column1: For a five-song EP
column2: Euphoria packs quite a bit of depth. Both Droop-E and Gonzalez have managed to preserve what makes them distinctive while working in tandem; the reward here lies in examining the seams where two very different approaches collide. Admittedly
column3: there is a background music quality to these songs—the consistently drowsy pace holds the EP back from fully engaging the listener at times—though that slow simmer suits the subject matter well. Nonetheless
column4: Euphoria’s five songs effectively evoke the distance of a strained conversation
column5:
even if they are clearly the product of a deep mutual understanding.
