column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/22934/homepage_large.70a28c7c.jpg|Talk to Me So I Can Fall Asleep|33514.0|Crater|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Help Yourself']|2016-02-24 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 16:01:08.731064|"

Most of us have experienced the annoyance of dining with someone who won’t put down their phone
column2: even as we’d rather be on our phones ourselves
column3: but few musicians have captured that feeling of hypocritical frustration as acutely as Crater’s Ceci Gomez and Kessiah Gordon. The Seattle electro-pop duo populate their debut album Talk to Me So I Can Fall Asleep with distant couples who hide behind glowing screens
column4: barely speaking
column5: and veiling their limited exchanges in so many layers of irony that they can hardly decode each other when they speak.

column1: On opener ""Crater Head
column2: the duo single out a culprit behind this lonely existence: ""I blame the Internet
column3: they sing. At first the line reads like a joke
column4: a dig at the Internet using the quippy language of the Internet
column5: but with each repeated listen it sounds more like a genuine thesis statement. Talk to Me is filled with lyrics like this
column6: little asides that seem cheeky or aloof until suddenly they don't anymore.

column1: Gomez and Gordon cast their stones knowing full well they live in a glass house. The Internet has fostered a generation of jaded
column2: apathetic cynics
column3: and they're just as driftless and disaffected as anybody else. Gomez spends ""Habits Die Slow"" drawing on a sleeping lover's face because she's bored
column4: then getting stoned and blowing off what few weekend responsibilities she had. Mostly she just sits around
column5: watching her relationship rot but doing nothing to stop it
column6: like her life is a TV show and Netflix keeps auto-playing the next episode without her so much as pressing a button.

column1: Crater’s music has been labeled as industrial
column2: but that term suggests a level of aggression even the group's most beat-heavy tracks never quite muster. For the most part
column3: Talk to Me is too dreamy and congenial
column4: too good-humored
column5: to be industrial. The album's early highlight ""Ain't Right"" is a straight pop song
column6: so personable and deliriously catchy it could be a Tegan and Sara single
column7: right down to the perky new-wave guitars and merrily self-loathing chorus.

column1: That song delivers such a dopamine rush you spend the rest of the album hoping there might be another just like it. There isn't
column2: but what follows is pretty good in its own right. ""Lucky Lucy"" rocks a heavy ""Safety Dance"" keyboard lick
column3: while ""Summer Skin"" and ""Hardly at All"" both boil over with feverish trip-hop beats. ""Holy Ground"" and ""Sick Sad World
column4: meanwhile
column5: each rotate around frigid basslines caked in the frost of an early Cure album. The record thrives on these sorts of hot and cold extremes. Some passages swell with emotion; others are dispassionately robotic. Most songs find room for both.

column1: The last record to cycle through electronic
column2: post-punk
column3: dub
column4: and R&B textures with this kind of assured dream logic was Warpaint's self-titled album. Warpaint is nominally a rock band and Crater is nominally an electronic act
column5: but both share a gift for creating intrigue that makes even their patchier songs fascinating to hear unfold. Both acts also cultivate cooler-than-thou personas seemingly for the sake of deflating them
column6: letting their guard down during unexpected moments of vulnerability. One of Talk to Me's most poignant ones comes on the hard-thumping closer ""Brew
column7: when Gomez cuts through the bullshit and finally spells out her relationship desires: ""Won't you take good care of me and we can dance for each other?"" And while we don't learn if her request is answered
column8: the sheer act of making it feels like a step in the right direction: no mind games
column9: no Internet speak—just an open plea for a meaningful connection. There's no guarantee of reciprocity
column10:
but it's a start.

In retrospect
column2: Santigold's debut album was something of a miracle. Freshly split from her massively underrated Philly ska-punk/new wave band Stiffed
column3: she found her way to a fresher
column4: grimier rock-pop sound. Eight years later
column5: Santogold pretty much stands as filler-free document of its time
column6: and it maintains its integrity no matter how many Bud Light Limes it sold. In the meantime
column7: Santi White has released a darker sophomore effort (2012's Master of My Make-Believe)
column8: had a baby
column9: took on acting jobs
column10: and is now attempting to shed her more jaded side for a sunshine-bright pop album
column11: shaded with biting commentary on consumerism and the price of art. It comes across as a pointed reaction to her own success over the past decade: If Master of My Make-Believe was a trip down the rabbit hole post-Santogold
column12: 99¢ tries to be the yin to its yang: a hyper-positive
column13: yet self-aware
column14: happy-pill remedy.

column1: The moment on 99¢ where it all comes together is on ""Banshee
column2: an absolute firestorm of a track co-written with Cathy Dennis
column3: the bonafide genius hit-maker behind chart-toppers from ""Can't Get You Out of My Head"" to ""Toxic."" A bubbling cauldron of handclaps and perky synths

column5: co-written and produced by Rostam Batmanglij
column6: which basically plods along inoffensively until it ends. The faltering momentum grinds to a complete halt during ""Walking in a Circle
column7: which resembles a trap version of the Siamese twin cats' song from The Lady and the Tramp.

column1: 99¢'s other major winning moment is ""Who Be Lovin’ Me
column2: which reinforces the theory that there are few things iLoveMakonnen's soft and sleepy flow can't improve. Santi matches his rhymes beat for beat
column3: meanwhile
column4: revealing surprising prowess as a rapper. ""Rendezvous Girl"" is a tasty nugget of '80s synthpop (down to the lyrics about a powerful businesswoman ""sashaying through town"")
column5: driving the second half of the album into more stable territory. ""Outside the War"" begins to dip again
column6: but luckily the end is salvaged by the ""Run the Races
column7: an effectively plaintive ballad co-produced with Batmanglij that profits from wailing guitars from Yeah Yeah Yeahs' Nick Zinner
column8: and ""Who I Thought You Were
column9: the album's upbeat rock-pop closer.

column1: The album veers awkwardly like this
column2: sometimes giving the impression that Santigold is getting in her own way. At her best
column3: she elevates the party song to an artform; ""Walking in a Circle"" and its soundalikes lack the enthusiasm and focus that we know she is capable of
column4: as if these lulls are the result of trying to balance out 99¢’s serotonin rush. Self-consciousness is usually the enemy of a good party
column5: and the downtempo moments feel like she’s pumping the brakes on her own talent. The album is presented as a consumerist critique
column6: intentionally blurring the line between artist and product
column7: but the quality of the songs varies too widely to pull off an actual concept album.

column1: Even as a tongue-in-cheek statement
column2: Santigold is worth more than her self-affixed 99¢ price tag
column3: and the peaks of this record just about outweigh its valleys. But for all its colorful packaging and flirtations with bubblegum pop
column4: 99¢ feels constrained
column5: like she took the cover image literally and vacuum-sealed all of her best traits—reggae-tinted riffs
column6: candy-colored fashion
column7: Casio synths—into one too-neat package. On 99¢
column8: sealed away they remain
column9:
poking through the plastic just enough to tantalize.

Yo Gotti has been a Memphis rap star for so long that you can hear his voice deepening over the years even as his subject matter hasn't. If you listen to his first regional hit
column2: 2000’s ""After I Fuck Your Bitch
column3: and then his recent viral breakout
column4: last year’s ""Down in the DM
column5: you’ll hear the same guy rapping about pretty much the same thing in slightly different registers. But at the age of 36
column6: and after two decades in hip-hop (he first released music under the name Lil Yo when he was 14)
column7: Gotti has finally firmed up his status as a major-label rap artist. And while his latest album
column8: The Art of Hustle
column9: is unquestionably the biggest of Gotti’s career
column10: it also feels like just another notch in his belt.

column1: As a rapper
column2: Gotti is practiced but lyrically unambitious. His bars are straight-to-the-point and matter-of-fact
column3: and it’s his willingness to open up that endears. On ""Momma
column4: one of The Art of Hustle’s best and most personal songs
column5: Gotti raps about being raised by six women and a man that wasn’t his father
column6: accounting for the highs and lows of a life built on hustling and basking in the relief of going legit. For opener ""My City
column7: Gotti enlists K. Michelle to lament and pay homage to their shared hometown. But for all his pride and investment in the city—Gotti’s Collective Music Group label has signed local up-and-comers like Blac Youngsta
column8: Snootie Wild
column9: and Zed Zilla—The Art of Hustle reads generically Southern.

column1: Despite an impressive head count of industry heavyweights
column2: the album doesn't fare well as a whole. Lil Wayne shows up on ""Bible"" for a rote banger; Future punches in a forgettable verse on a flat trap anthem called ""General""; Pusha T snarls appropriately on the middle of ""Hunnid."" The collaborations are evidence of Gotti’s industry footprint rather than creative matchmaking
column3: and the only one that strikes a spark is mold-breaker ""Law
column4: which folds E-40 comfortably into a slinky beat with bells ringing in the background.

column1: And then there’s the album’s money-maker. ""Down in the DM"" isn’t a fluke hit
column2: but it’s enjoyed the type of viral success that can’t be forced. In the last week alone: <a href=""http://www.spin.com/2016/02/lil-mama-memes-music-video-crying-breakfast-club-watch/?utm_source=spintwitter&utm_medium=social&utm_campaign=spintwitter"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">Lil Mama shared a video called ""Memes
column3: Lil' Kim enlisted Kevin Gates for a Valentine's Day track called ""#Mine""
column4: and Soulja Boy offered a sleazy artwork-toting single called ""Snapchat."" All three are lame attempts to recapture what ""Down in the DM"" does so naturally
column5: revelling in the shallowness of Instagram. The addition of two full-fledged verses from Nicki Minaj improves on the original and also gives the album its best and most memorable burst of rapping.

column1: In a recent podcast interview with Rap Radar
column2: Gotti admitted that ""Down in the DM"" was ""just another song."" ""I’m making three
column3: four
column4: five songs a day
column5: he said. ""To be honest with you
column6: I’m not even dwelling into the music that long."" It’s an unsurprising piece of insight that accounts for the album’s generally low-stakes vibe. Noticeably
column7: on the same day that Gotti released this eighth album in his catalog
column8: another Memphis rapper released his first. Young Dolph’s King of Memphis seems almost like a provocation
column9: but that there’s a crown worth snatching at all is a testament to Gotti having molded it for himself. Unfortunately
column10: The Art of Hustle is mostly forgettable as a major-label rap record
column11:
but it bears out a teachable truth about Gotti's career: sometimes showing up is more than half the battle.

In April 2013
column2: a little band out of Baltimore called the Snails put out a double 7'' EP called Worth the Wait. Two of the band’s members
column3: bassist William Cashion and frontman Sam Herring
column4: had higher profiles with their band Future Islands
column5: but that outfit had yet to take off
column6: and the Snails were just another venture with a different pack of pals. All of the Snails’ personnel committed to the group’s big bit: Onstage in Raleigh
column7: N.C.
column8: band members donned colorful headpieces that looked like snails’ eye stalks
column9: and Herring thanked a friend of the band for making sure the Snails got to the venue safely from Baltimore in a shoebox stashed under the passenger seat. Later
column10: the Snails would lay down a full LP
column11: but Future Islands’ sudden wave of success in 2014 meant the Snails and their Songs From the Shoebox were more or less shelved—until now
column12: that is.

column1: Songs From the Shoebox is a rough-around-the-edges record that bursts at the seams with excitement. The record feels like it could fall apart at any moment
column2: but it somehow never does: Everything sounds a little fried
column3: from the fuzz-caked guitar and bass riffs that dominate to the slick
column4: squealy saxophone parts that work their way in. Herring doesn’t so much sing as he shouts
column5: with his vocals sometimes bordering on outright screeching. Where Future Islands has always done well at delivering sad songs you can kind of dance to
column6: the Snails mostly focus on fun. ""Tight Side of Life"" is a thick
column7: rollicking opener
column8: with Herring bellowing
column9: ""We’re on the tight side of life
column10: everything is going to be all right."" The song is so forceful that you feel like you have no choice to believe it’s the truth.

column1: The tracklisting is loopy
column2: but in a way that suits the project. ""Flames"" makes for an appropriately named scorcher late in the record before sliding into the droopy instrumental ""Do Like You Do."" The downer tune feels out of step with the rest of the album
column3: but the band picks back up again with ""Snails Christmas (I Want a New Shell)."" It’s a non sequitur
column4: but then again
column5: the band’s over-arching concept is songs by and about snails—so
column6: sure
column7: why not a Christmas song
column8: too?

column1: Though Songs From the Shoebox’s completion was delayed by Future Islands’ massive touring schedule in 2014
column2: the timing of its release is perfect. We’re in the agonizing home stretch of winter
column3: and the album carries the promise that summertime’s carefree
column4: sunburnt Saturday afternoons are right around the corner. With Songs From the Shoebox
column5: then
column6:
the Snails offer a brief opportunity to escape to that happiest place.

"|21638.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21638-songs-from-the-shoebox/|7.4|Allison Hussey

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/22759/homepage_large.488ec8f6.jpg|Higher Power|33434.0|The Dirty Nil|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Dine Alone']|2016-02-23 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 16:01:11.144269|"

As the name suggests
column2: the Ontario band Dirty Nil are profoundly aware of their emptiness and impurity
column3: and the only thing that rouses Luke Bentham and Dave Nardi out of their self-loathing is despising someone else even more. Maybe it was inspired by drinking alone in a dingy apartment

column5: meant for big rooms. They’re professed classic rock fans and gear snobs and it shows
column6: as Higher Power is an album that sounds like it expects to be paid for. However antisocial Dirty Nil get

column1: They’re not really interested in the philosophical restrictions and elitism that often constitutes punk rock anyway. Dirty Nil released a 7” on skate-punk stronghold Fat Wreck Chords and played the Warped Tour—both tend to be a point of no return for bands deciding between a captive pop-punk audience and critical credibility. But it’s all rock'n'roll to Dirty Nil: They boast equal facility with PUP-style beer bongin’ with the devil (""No Weaknesses"")
column2: Dilly Dally’s knee-buckling dynamics (""Zombie Eyed"")
column3: and the hectoring sing-speak of tourmates Single Mothers and Greys. Higher Power serves as proof that the boundaries separating ""indie
column4: ""pop punk"" and ""alt-rock"" have collapsed as they’ve been drawn into closer quarters

column6: they do all of the above just within the first four tracks.

column1: There isn’t really an original note here

column3: Dirty Nil continue to expand their range
column4: yet the sequencing makes it sound like a retreat. The satisfying brutality of ""Fugue State"" starts a run of three songs crammed into less than five minutes; the highs of Side A were bound to make Higher Power sound frontloaded anyway
column5: but Side B practically vanishes before get-in-the-van anthem ""Bury Me at the Rodeo Show"" ends the record with the closest thing to a Dirty Nil love song.

column1: Even when the music intentionally plays dumb

column5: drugs (""Zombie Eyed"") and rock'n'roll. But they have too much fun with it all to even pretend that hitting rock bottom is actually a bad thing. ""Friends in the Sky"" aligns Bentham with Satan against Jesus

column9: ""And even though we never got along/ I’ll say I was wrong/ 'Cause you know we can be friends in the sky."" Despite their protestations
column10:
only a true punk band would try to pull a fast one on God.

When Terry Riley turned 80 last year
column2: the requisite ink was spilled
column3: commemorative concerts played
column4: parties thrown. The byproducts of the ongoing retrospective are still spilling into 2016 as he nears 81
column5: and it makes sense
column6: because it’s hard not to think and talk in gushing platitudes when looking at what Riley wrought in the last half century. <span id=""docs-internal-guid-60762b34-0a42-f945-985c-b2f4f7412bd5"">Even if you don’t know his name
column7: you’ve felt his influence via ""Baba O'Riley
column8: Pete Townsend’s tribute to Riley’s modal improvisation and Meher Baba’s spiritual teachings. You could even credit him with one of the earliest remixes
column10: with his tape loop manipulations of the Harvey Averne Dozen's ""You're No Good."" And of course
column11: there’s In C
column12: which in countless performances has become a living
column13: breathing
column14: and self-generating monument to the minimalist floodgate Riley helped open in 1964.

column1: One of the most interesting homages to Riley took place at London’s Barbican Centre and Amsterdam’s Muziekgebouw during April of last year
column2: at a pair of events called Hello Terry Riley. British musicians James Holden and Luke Abbott were invited to compose live improvisational electronic pieces influenced by engagement with Riley’s work. The recordings on Outdoor Museum Of Fractals / 555Hz are taken from their rehearsals prior to the Barbican and Muziekgebouw concerts. In a little over an hour of continuous improvisational performance
column3: Holden and Abbott showcase how making music in the style of Terry Riley could still produce something startlingly new and mesmerizing.

column1: To compose ""Outdoor Museum of Fractals"" James Holden designed a special sequencer for his modular synthesizer
column2: which works on a perpetually repetitive and purposefully chaotic set of rules
column3: generating a wide range of melodic patterns from even the slightest change in initial input. He claims that the inputs in his system
column4: if mapped in mathematical space
column5: could give you the picture of a fractal—that ubiquitous and eternally mysterious geometrical pattern that naturally occurs in the shape of DNA
column6: snowflakes
column7: ocean waves
column8: the drawings of M. C. Escher
column9: and in the novels of Vladimir Nabokov and David Foster Wallace.

column1: To Holden
column2: the 46 minutes of ""Outdoor Museum of Fractals"" is a ""a very slow tour of some landmarks in this fractal"" he created with his co-pilot Camilo Tirado
column3: a tabla player trained in the classical Indian traditions
column4: which Riley drew heavily from in his work. Their two instruments are in constant conversation
column5: as Tirado’s drumming triggers James' arpeggiations. Holden’s use of a sequencer also helps generate more notes and melodies than he could physically play
column6: extending the limitations of his keyboard skills. And if you’ve ever seen videos of Riley playing
column7: Holden’s experiment makes sense
column8: because you quickly realize that very few people have the dexterity and focus to dance between the notes of a keyboard like Riley.

column1: Similar to the best Riley compositions
column2: ""Outdoor Museum of Fractals"" resembles an exquisitely and almost incomprehensibly detailed model train set
column3: its slow-moving progression unfolding with more and more information and narrative. It’s hard to believe Holden and Tirado’s improvisation sounds as smooth and pleasurable as it does
column4: because Holden’s system is constantly inviting chaos. He described learning how to control his rig as a ""blind man feeling around in one small corner with some vague memory of what's nearby.""

column1: Abbott’s contribution
column3: is inspired by the numerological and mythological qualities of the number five and an interest in new age theories about the healing properties of specific sonic frequencies. His interest was stoked by Thomas Browne’s The Garden of Cyrus
column4: a Renaissance-era manifesto on intelligent design that attributes fractal-like vastness to the number five’s relation to the organization of natural life
column5: from the structure of honeycombs to the leaves of artichokes. ""555Hz"" is centered around a sine-wave drone tuned to 555Hz and a modified 26'' gong that echoes and resonate in response to slight shifts in the drone.

column1: ""555Hz"" veers farther from signature Riley sounds
column2: and more closely mirrors La Monte Young’s exploration of drone
column3: specifically in works like Drift Study. This piece is more caustic and less relaxing
column4: but it’s also lighter and more ambient. In that way it is far more meditative than Holden’s
column5: because the ongoing drone never forces the listener to descend into the music
column6: but rather effortlessly float on its surface. Abbott’s piece is also less steady
column7: its pitches shift more wildly
column8: and the sounds climb up and down more athletically throughout. And similar to Holden’s improvisation
column9: it’s hard not to be impressed by the smooth progression of Abbott's performance. There are many moments where the drone unravels
column10: but Abbott’s ability to paint through the chaos of his sounds with perfectly timed gong echoes and slight shifts in the drone’s tone pulls it all together. I’m reminded of Brian Eno’s description of Philip Glass’ music ""as a viscous bath of pure
column11: thick energy"" when listening to the two companion pieces back to back. In Outdoor Museum of Fractals / 555Hz
column12: Abbott and Holden have demonstrated quite effectively that electronic musicians don’t have to be just guys pressing play on their computers
column13:
but very serious and cognitively engaged composers.

column5: yes

column1: The excellent eight-minute opener ""Good Morning My Love"" is based on someone telling their partner that they need to rekindle their love

column1: The thing you realize listening to these songs
column2: though
column3: is that intimate details quickly take on the feel of metaphor. There's a profound weight

column9: for all of us

it's always a bit of both.

Over their 10-year career
column2: Ra Ra Riot have presented two extreme versions of themselves. On one end there is their 2008 breakout The Rhumb Line
column3: an orchestral pop record distinguished by collegiate literary references and scarred by trauma. On the other is 2009’s ""Can You Discover?
column4: a synthy
column5: Auto-Tuned reworking of one of their debut’s tracks by Discovery
column6: a collaboration between frontman Wes Miles and former Vampire Weekend member Rostam Batmanglij. In between these two poles
column7: Ra Ra Riot have struggled for balance. Their sophomore record The Orchard played it safe
column8: not falling too far from the tree of its predecessor
column9: while their 2013 foray into electro-pop
column10: Beta Love
column11: explored an abundance of new sounds but lacked cohesion.

column1: On Need Your Light
column2: they finally hit the sweet spot. Working once again with Rostam
column3: they key back into the chirpy
column4: buoyant electronics of ""Can You Discover?"" and blend them with the string-heavy compositions of The Rhumb Line. The result could sit comfortably next to Passion Pit. On Beta Love
column5: Miles’ vocals occasionally drifted into uncanny-valley territory
column6: but Need Your Light brings him back down to Earth. On ""Water
column7: Miles’ falsetto constricts as he sings ""Don’t punish me for what I feel"" and then tightens even further to near-desperation as he imagines crawling out the back door
column8: ripping off his tight clothes
column9: and leaping into the water. ""I Need Your Light"" (also by Batmanglij) is the record’s biggest showstopper
column10: with Miles’ voice repeating the title until it swells from a wisp into a belting
column11: burning swan song.

column1: But rather than feeling like outliers
column2: the Rostam-produced tracks fit in well with the remaining eight songs produced by Ryan Hadlock
column3: which lean toward a more traditional Ra Ra Riot mix of tight instrumentation embellished with processed flourishes. All the synths are large and loud
column4: the violins glittering
column5: and any memories of calm are quickly overshadowed by the music's insistent ""dance yourself clean"" imperative. ""Instant Breakup"" blooms slowly
column6: hand claps and heavy drums creeping in before twisting into a synthy sugar spiral. The chorus of ""Every Time I’m Ready to Hug"" is an invitation to dance until your limbs are tangled.

column1: Thematically
column2: most of the 10 tracks on Need Your Light suggest taking a leap of faith—in this case
column3: putting trust in love. The lyrics tilt towards the anthemic and dramatic: ""'Cause I can’t see nothing without your light
column4: ""Love will get me up again
column5: ""I wanna know that love can change you."" ""Absolutely""’s lyrics
column6: however
column7: resemble a painful drunken New Year’s proclamation: ""It’s the year of/ Absolutely being/ Absolutely nothing/ Absolutely crushing/ Absolutely everything/ Absolutely loving."" On a bright record full of balanced sweetness
column8: it’s the only moment that cloys
column9:
a reminder of the missteps that brought Ra Ra Riot here.

column7: the Pains of Being Pure at Heart loudly tore into the C86 revival
column8: declaring ""This Love Is Fucking Right!"" Emotions were strong
column9: guitars were soft and fuzzy
column10: and synths were sugary. But no record embraced romantic grandeur like Wild Nothing's Gemini. The then-21-year-old's debut communicated through instrumental atmosphere and texture
column11: jumping between dreamy pessimism and sleepy introspection
column12: eliciting comparisons to the big influential UK bands of the late '80s and early '90s: Cocteau Twins
column13: the Cure
column14: the Smiths
column15: the Jesus and Mary Chain
column16: etc.

column1: Perhaps most appealingly
column2: Gemini's innocence and purity are heavily rooted in nostalgia. ""Do you remember the lightning storm?/ It was the first time that I really felt you
column3: Tatum sang on ""Live in Dreams
column4: with the detached desire of a crush who is too afraid to say ""I love you"" but will write and perform a song for you. However
column5: the thing about nostalgia is that it maintains the ability to quietly exist in the back of your brain

column7: six years after its release

column1: Tatum capped off 2010 with the Golden Haze EP and eventually released his second full-length
column2: Nocturne
column3: in 2012. Unlike Gemini
column4: which was recorded in Tatum's Blacksburg dorm room

column6: Wild Nothing's sophomore effort is cleaner
column7: with a more diverse array of sounds and a considerably brighter tone. Nocturne made clear that Tatum intended to develop his sound from his bedroom pop debut. A year later
column8: Wild Nothing released the Empty Estate EP
column9: which attempted to zero in on the scattered electro-pop shimmer of Nocturne but ultimately came across as distant due to a deficit of textural variations and engaging lyrics. Wild Nothing's third full-length offered a chance for reinvention
column10: and while Tatum has clearly evolved as a musician

column1: From the opening
column2: carbonated
column3: notes of marimba on ""Reichpop
column4: Life of Pause presents itself as Wild Nothing's cheeriest record. Tatum has said that he wanted his third full-length to sound more ""organic"" or ""gelled
column5: and to give his audience a sense of physical space. To strengthen this idea
column6: Tatum created an actual room to represent the album's world for the cover shoot. Tatum's fabricated atmosphere is a warm and groovy 1970s pad
column7: with dashes of curiosities like a checkered teapot and a mysterious bouquet of flowers. But unlike this room
column8: which existed only temporarily in a warehouse in Long Island City
column9: Tatum recorded Life of Pause in Los Angeles and Stockholm
column10: at a studio once owned by ABBA.

column1: Tatum admitted that he was listening to ""a lot of Philly soul
column2: sweet soul music"" while working on the record. When these moments
column3: particularly the notes of funk and disco
column4: are pushed
column5: it feels like a move in the right direction. This is the most PG-13 Wild Nothing has been on record yet: The steamy sax on ""Whenever I"" paired with Tatum's silky drawl could be a track in a David Lynch nightclub; his voice on ""A Woman's Wisdom"" is a husky plea for intimate insight. ""Reichpop"" is stunning
column6: with the aforementioned marimba played by Peter Bjorn and John drummer John Eriksson.

column1: It's a high-bar statement of an opener
column2: but the album rarely reaches that energy level again. ""Japanese Alice"" brings new life to the middle of the record with psych-pop guitars reminiscent of Deerhunter
column3: and the title track's synth throbs have a hint of Neon Indian to them. Following these two
column4: the stoned ""Alien"" feels like a setback
column5: but the brief
column6: noisy breakdowns save it from being a completely absurd outlier.

column1: So why does Life of Pause not completely succeed? To begin with
column2: the record is not emotionally accessible or relatable
column3: which isn't a huge surprise considering Tatum favors sound over lyrics. The trouble is that it's unclear exactly what Life of Pause's mood is intended to be. Tonally and instrumentally
column4: the album is a change in style
column5: but there is no moment of surprise; it still feels very predictable. There is nothing wrong with being formulaic; it worked for…well
column6: pretty much everyone. But there is no moment that truly grabs you
column7: no emotional climax
column8: no reason to truly care. Life of Pause is a straight
column9: albeit funky
column10: line.

column1: Life of Pause's monotony is only heightened by its monochromatic songwriting. In a majority of the songs
column2: Tatum asks some sort of question (""Can I learn to wait for my life?
column3: ""Will I find a way to make sense of/ The way that you love me?
column4: ""How can we want love?
column5: etc etc) only to conclude during ""To Know You"" that ""There is no answer to the question."" All this amorous
column6: existential pondering seems to prevent him from doing anything
column7: from taking a risk
column8: from making a statement that sticks. It doesn't help that these questions are delivered in such an aloof manner that even if they pique interest for a second
column9:
they will melt away quickly. It seems like Tatum is living a lyric from ""Reichpop:"" ""The less you say the less that you get wrong.""

In his recent book The Other Paris
column2: Luc Sante describes an annual ritual of the city's laundresses
column3: who numbered close to 100
column4: 000 by the end of the 19th century: ""Every lavoir would elect a queen and all the employees would parade
column5: merrily borrowing the finest accoutrements that had been left with them for cleaning."" Nobody outside of detergent commercials dances up to a washing machine. We sweat through clothes on Saturday night; we reluctantly clean them Sunday afternoon. But the ambient sounds at a laundromat
column6: those wetly spiraling colors
column7: the unconscious motions of loading and folding and wringing—are they so easy to divide away from clubbing? Not according to Matmos
column8: whose new album Ultimate Care II was entirely generated by the Whirlpool washing machine of the same name. They hit the appliance
column9: massaged it
column10: processed it
column11: and jolted it with samples of its own noise.

column1: It's not such a strange instrument for Matmos. Drew Daniel and Martin Schmidt
column2: partners in all things
column3: have wrung electronic music out of surgical tools
column4: a cigarette burn
column5: Björk reciting Wittgenstein
column6: and quivering crayfish. Lots of it you can even dance to. Their practice became more abstract in recent years: Supreme Balloon only used synthesizers
column7: while 2013's The Marriage of True Minds was determined by a series of parapsychological experiments. ""High-concept"" is the wrong phrase for something so tactile
column8: but the new album does take inspiration
column9: in classic Matmos style
column10: from a deadpan joke: Ultimate Care II is the machine
column11: and the machine is Ultimate Care II. (It could also be the name of a monthly rave circa 1989.) Daniel and Schmidt have always been fascinated by texture
column12: and here they focus on it intently
column13: exploring dozens of ways that water can fall
column14: slosh
column15: churn
column16: or hiss. During calmer interludes
column17: drones move past as if floating through an amniotic sac.

column1: Like Manuel Göttsching's techno opening E2-E4
column2: Matmos sequenced Ultimate Care II as a single 38-minute-long track
column3: elaborating on itself over the length of a standard cycle. The first moments are relatively straightforward
column4: considering that we're talking about an album recorded from a washing machine: Somebody turns the dial
column5: and the chamber floods. Polyrhythmic drumming slowly intensifies
column6: before subsiding into amphibian breathing noises. There's this coarse timbre that resembles a wildly overblown saxophone—fingers rubbing the chassis
column7: sensuality experienced as agony. For long minutes rhythm fades away
column8: leaving a reverie of computer signals inside the machine's brain
column9: and then returns to deluge them
column10: seizing up briefly with a muffled conk. What follows must be the first piece of music braiding together free jazz and the sewer level from ""Sonic the Hedgehog 3.""

column1: Ultimate Care II ends in thrilling panic
column2: a squall of rapid percussion moving over glitchy effects: drum-and-bass that's hard and wet
column3: like the misted breakbeats on A Guy Called Gerald's Black Secret Technology. But the real un-climax comes just before that
column4: when Matmos allow the rinse cycle to run through with only minimal filtering. It lasts for four minutes yet feels boundless. I thought of Virginia Woolf's The Waves: ""The spray
column5: leaping high
column6: spattered the walls of a cave that had been dry before
column7: and left pools inland
column8: where some fish
column9: stranded
column10: lashed its tail as the wave drew back."" Time seems to leak out everywhere
column11: as if you looked away from Matmos' knotted loop to find
column12: feet slickly adrift
column13: that the machine had sprouted a river.

column1: John Cage realized there was no such thing as silence when he visited an anechoic chamber insulated from the rest of Harvard and heard two sounds
column2: one high and one low: the pulse of his nervous system and the circulation of his blood. ""There is always something to see
column3: he said later on
column4: ""something to hear."" (It was probably actually tinnitus
column5: but that makes the omnipresence of music even clearer.) I imagine Matmos glancing around their laundry room and deciding that any space could hold a dancefloor
column6: or a DIY noise show—a basement is a basement
column7: after all. Caressing obsolete technology
column8: they've parodied labor's drudgeries as play. Ultimate Care II is a daydream of domesticity
column9:
a chore ignored. Call it the revolutions of everyday life.

Jack Garratt has only just released his debut album

column4: he won the Brits Critics' Choice Award for 2016; last month

column8: it's a case of mutually assured industry triumph: Garratt dominates radio
column9: plays sweet televised spots at major festivals
column10: boosts live revenues
column11: and makes the organizations that backed him look smart. Such are the perks of signing to Island
column12: an imprint of Universal
column13: who have had Garratt in a development deal for years—and scooped 11 of the past 14 BBC Sound of... polls thanks to their massive spending power.

column1: Brits are cynical of being marketed to

column3: so Island have carefully made Garratt look Very Authentic. There's a lovelorn songwriter at the heart of his music—a side he displayed when he covered Disclosure's ""Latch"" in earnest bluesman fashion—that's been coated with lightly fizzing electronica. Phase seems forged from the sounds of James Blake's CMYK EP and Jai Paul's ""BTSTU"": subaquatic synth motifs and juddering basslines that burst into scrunching supernova choruses. There's also lots of gospel-influenced warbling and soft
column4: bluesy piano. Whenever Garratt plays the latter

column1: Marketing aside

column4: swimmy first verse of opener ""Coalesce (Synesthesia Pt. II)"" suddenly goes hyperdrive

column8: with screaming mosquito synths and agile bass driving the hectic pace.

column1: Things get weaker from there: ""Weathered"" has the unctuous sentimentality of Mumford & Sons (whom Garratt has supported in stadiums)
column2: and its lyrics are the equivalent of those manipulative commercials showing a child turn into a senior citizen in 45 seconds: ""When I grow old/ The sun will cope/ Shine down on every youth stain
column3: Garratt simpers. He has a tendency to reach for grandiose overstatements as shorthand for profundity
column4: a tendency that gives his romantic lyrics an unwittingly sinister edge. His neediness is intense: ""To love you takes every waking thought I have
column5: he declares on ""Fire."" On ""The Love You're Given
column6: he sings
column7: ""I promise if you're gonna lock me out I will stay as your ghost/ But if you take the love you're given I will leave you alone
column8: and echoes the sentiment on ""I Know All What I Do"": ""If I ever leave you

column4: selfish

column8: it feels empty
column9: drawing from overcooked cultural tropes about urgency. Somewhere within all this bombast is a sensitive man who's trying to explore his flaws and desires candidly. You sense that the thing that he needs is intimacy
column10: a smaller scale. And it's the one luxury he's not going to get
column11:
because Jack Garratt is too big to fail.

Despite a dance music career now stretching into its third decade
column2: it’s rare for the man born Kenny Dixon

column6: my SP-1200
column7: my bass

column5: looping grooves (Jitwam)
column6: Moody moves at a flâneur’s pace

You could be forgiven for assuming that Heather McEntire was moonlighting on Mount Moriah’s first album. Before her foray into country music
column2: the singer had led the Chapel Hill band Bellafea through two distinct iterations
column3: first as a quiet/loud indie duo then as a snarling punk trio

column1: Two albums on

column4: that voice was the star attraction on Mount Moriah’s first albums

column6: How to Dance

column7: his guitar gradually recedes to clear room for a waltzing violin

column3: most soulful performances

column5: she drops to her knees and prays ""to something for some kind
column6: any kind of light

column9: she discovers God underneath a water tower near Fishdam Road. On ""Higher Mind"" she meets him at the North Carolina fishing resort Oceanana Pier. She peppers her lyrics with the names of unassuming places where these kinds of revelations could conceivably occur: Grizzly Peak
column10: Baker Beach
column11: Okefenokee
column12: Davis Square
column13: Crooked River
column14: Honey Lake
column15: Newport River
column16: and so on. You could lose an afternoon researching all the landmarks she mentions

column1: There’s some irony in a band named for one of the bible’s most holy sites setting an album about magnificent religious awakenings almost exclusively in small-town locales of no biblical significance

column4: despite being far from the textbook representation of either community

column7:
anywhere.

Lushlife is a true Philadelphia hybrid
column2: an artist who has spent his career bridging the gap between the city’s hip-hop and indie rock scenes. First as a mash-up artist and more recently
column3: as a rapper and producer
column4: he’s worked to convene dissimilar sounds and musicians in service of his vision. On his latest full-length
column5: Ritualize
column6: his curatorial instincts have kicked into overdrive. ""We on that lush Primavera sound
column7: Lushlife quips on the title track. And indeed
column8: the credits for the album read like the lineup for an eclectic music festival
column9: ranging from singer/songwriter Marissa Nadler to little-known Philly rapper Yikes the Zero.

column1: This time around
column2: Lushlife has even outsourced some of the production
column3: abandoning the warm boom-bap of his earlier
column4: self-produced work in favor of collaborations with Philly electro trio CSLSX. The end result is a soaring
column5: cinematic sound rooted in live instruments that’s more M83 than Mobb Deep. There’s an impressive range on display here
column6: from the orchestral prog of ""Burt Reynolds (Desert Visions)"" to the William Basinski tribute ""Integration Loop."" Many of the album's guests add to the richness of the production as well. RJD2 gets a co-production credit on the heady
column7: multi-part ""Toynbee Suite
column8: I Break Horses contribute swells of psychedelic guitar and spectral backing vocals to ""The Waking World
column9: and Ariel Pink stops by for some unabashed Vangelis worship
column10: helping evoke the neon glow of Blade Runner’s slick
column11: wet streets on""Hong Kong (Lady of Love).""

column1: While all this music provides ample grist for the mill
column2: Lushlife rarely manages to wrest the listener’s attention away from the backdrop. He essentially has one flow—a breathless
column3: nasal
column4: Ghostface-esque cadence—but lacks Tony Starks’ charisma or storytelling ability. Lyrically
column5: his bars are peppered with signifiers of taste: he’s shouting out Roky Erickson
column6: Mary Timony
column7: and Isabella Rossellini
column8: sipping on barleywine and La Fin du Monde. Thanks to his straight-faced delivery
column9: however
column10: all these references feel humorless
column11: like Das Racist without the irony. He attempts to squirm into a few interesting perspectives—for example
column12: Mark David Chapman’s on ""The Waking World""—but largely trawls the surface
column13: delivering punchlines like
column14: ""He hold the heat standing outside of the Dakota watching/ While Holden Caulfield just telling him when to let the glock spit."" At one point he refers to his style as ""Bottle Rocket rap
column15: which certainly doesn't help the perception that this is hip-hop music for the Wes Anderson set.

column1: These deficiencies come into sharper focus when Lushlife is forced to share space with more seasoned rappers. Philly lifer Freeway sounds revitalized on ""Strawberry Mansion
column2: following serious health issues last year; while his performance isn’t quite ""Cannon""-level here
column3: hearing him rap over a sunny
column4: synth-driven instrumental is a thrill unto itself. By his own high standards
column5: Killer Mike’s verse on ""This Ecstatic Cult"" sounds phoned in but even so
column6: he manages to run circles around Lushlife without lifting a finger. Perhaps unsurprisingly
column7: the best verse on Ritualize comes from the hungriest emcee of the bunch: North Carolina rapper Deniro Farrar. Farrar's deliberate
column8: grime-influenced flow sounds genuinely menacing set against ""Incantation""’s  spare backdrop of echoing snare hits and palm-muted guitar (Lushlife and CSLSX wisely let the otherwise busy beat drop out before Farrar gets on the mic).

column1: While there is no shortage of interesting ideas or capable musicians on Ritualize
column2: in the absence of a compelling vision
column3: it doesn’t add up to much. As Lushlife surely knows
column4: the thrill of a good mash-up comes from the tension of two disparate ideas rubbing up against each other and there are far too few of those moments to be found here. Ultimately
column5:
Ritualize feels like a party with plenty of interesting guests but little conversation—it’s hard not to blame the host.

There was a time when you mostly knew what to expect from a Tri Angle release

column5: and noise in unpredictable ways (so long as the atmosphere mostly remains sufficiently chilly). ""Everyone I choose to work with

column5: and Lotic

(Brood Ma has described the record as ""a documentary of the military engagements played out amongst adults and children across worldwide server space and an attempted critique of the current obsession with survival playtime
column3: played out through politically prosed pop references and narratives of fictional
column4: future juvenilia""—which
column5: OK

column7: but rarely does any singular genre tag capture the uncanniness
column8: or uncategorizable Brood Ma-ness

column10: grime-oriented beats
column11: and ominous sub-bass.

column2: the producer released music via the Untold-run Hemlock Recordings as well as Quantum Natives
column3: a UK label/collective whose members embody the intersection of Internet provocation and underground rave culture. (The label's website is an unofficial Google map showing an alien planet that recalls StarCraft and drone surveillance photography; its Soundcloud description: ""a battle for survival in the nightmare undercity (in the grim darkness of the far future
column4: there is only war)"".) Like much of the artists released by his previous labels
column5: this is music whose technocratic aesthetic is impossible to divorce from the listening process. The album cover may recall an occult bonfire
column6: but Brood Ma is more Neuromancer than necromancer.

column1: Part of the success of Daze is how fully Brood Ma commits to his sonic palette without committing to a singular musical style. ""Molten Brownian Motion"" pounds like hardcore (of the drum and bass variety) injected with Xenomorph DNA
column2: while ""Social Re-Entry"" is apocalyptic bass music with a twisted vocal sample that's both something soulful and sinister. Many of the tracks have a sculptural feel to them

column4: but its title is unabashedly cheeky. There's also
column5: perhaps surprisingly
column6: actual hooks to be found when the tracks are given time to unfurl. ""Sacrificial Youth"" is danceable enough that it could use another three minutes attached to its runtime
column7: which is both a compliment and a criticism: How often do you wish that a club track was 110% longer? Then again
column8: this is the sort of intellectual party where we're supposed to think about how we got here rather than lose ourselves in the music. Daze is one last defiant middle finger emoji to a world crumbling in on itself—scarily contemporary
column9: often caustic
column10:
but not without a sense of humor.

Before there were charts and public access programs full of it

column1: Today

column5: the most in-demand mercenary musicians in town were part of the deal. The result of Hester’s sessions with the ""Taking Care (of) Business"" band—famous for backing Elvis during this time—was <i>Benny...

column4: Ren Faire aspect

column3: Animal Collective's music has always evoked a primitive kind of purity. Early on they wore masks—a gesture that connected them not only to the lucid dreams of playtime but to traditions of shamanism and present-day Mardi Gras
column4: where people hide their faces not to disguise their natures but reveal them. Their songs morphed and rambled and writhed with the liveness of kimchi or kombucha
column5: less finished product than something that fermented and evolved as you listened. Onstage
column6: they looked more like astronauts than musicians; on record
column7: they sounded less like musicians than cavemen
column8: or lost wolves howling for an impossible moon: Modern guys seeking a spiritual basement deep below the civilized self.

column1: Like most seekers
column2: they get made fun of a lot. It's actually hard to think of music whose bad reputation is more disproportionately out of balance with its good intentions than Animal Collective's without dipping into Christian radio or trip-hop. Whether the jokes—which are mostly about drum circles
column3: jam bands and shakily understood allusions to ""shrooms""—are onto something or just contaminated by the tellers' own personal fears is in the eye of the beholder; suffice it to say that I agree with Nietzsche when he said that it is man alone who suffers so deeply that he had to invent laughter.

column1: No doubt said jokers will be happy to hear that the band prepared for their new album
column2: Painting With
column3: by bringing baby pools into the studio and projecting dinosaurs on the wall. Like 2012's Centipede Hz
column4: Painting With is a bright
column5: epileptically busy piece of music that crams every element of the band's sound into a landscape without depth or recess. Instead of the aquatic lullabies of Merriweather Post Pavilion or the naturalism of Sung Tongs
column6: we get something like a 1980s Frank Stella or one of Jeff Koons' balloon dogs: Rad
column7: synthetic and ready to jump directly into your face.

column1: Depth and hiddenness become metaphors here. Watching the rockets' red glare over Baghdad in April
column3: I was ready for an album like Here Comes the Indian
column4: whose nightmarish volatility reminded me that whatever evil men do starts in the heart; after the 2008 election I vibed unapologetically with the optimism of ""My Girls
column5: which sounded like Peter Pan taking the wheel and telling the Darling children everything was going to be all right.

column1: Now
column2: values and messages that once seemed implicit in the band's music—love
column3: freedom
column4: the general idea that modern life is an interesting but fucked-up endeavor from which something very dear has been lost—are stitched right into the sleeves of their windbreakers. ""Where's the bridge that's gonna take me home?"" goes the coda of Painting With's giddy opening song
column5: ""FloriDada."" ""The bridge that someone's fighting over / That bridge that someone's paying for / A bridge so old so let it go."" Seconds earlier
column6: they sample the ""Wipe Out
column7: just to make sure you know they come in peace and packed all the toys. Even the title ""FloriDada
column8: has the quality of a joke explained. Though it pains me to say it
column9: there are times that Painting With feels less like Animal Collective than Animal Collective: the Ride.

column1: In the absence of a less effable genius
column2: there's always elbow grease. Painting With feels
column3: more than anything
column4: like a kind of construction project: Each sound meticulously built and only faintly familiar
column5: each second crammed with doodads
column6: as though the band was worried either they or their audience might get bored. The human voice
column7: which in the past has given their music not just a so-called human element but a devotional
column8: almost religious glow
column9: has been reduced to a party trick
column10: with Avey Tare and Panda Bear trading syllables like two anxious Globetrotters. The album's best songs—""Golden Gal
column11: ""Recycling""—aren't just highlights
column12: they're breathers.

column1: As someone who has no hangups about admitting that this band changed not only how I think about music but how I thought about life
column2: it's easy to wonder if Painting With and Centipede Hz signal an ending
column3: or at least a consequential lull. Fifteen years is longer than most bands last
column4: let alone great ones. Part of Animal Collective's image—or my image of them
column5: at least—entailed fantasy of three to four guys sacrificing themselves at the foot of their loop pedals to conjure some other
column6: bigger
column7: more powerful god. Now
column8: they're parents living in different zip codes and riding the festival circuit. Panda Bear's solo albums are more interesting than they've ever been and Avey Tare has kept busy
column9: but the time that they were a bellwether for the horizon of independent music seems in ebb. Old heads will tell you that the most exciting part of seeing them live was hearing songs months

column11: for example

column13: Virginia
column14: watching Feels before anyone knew it existed
column15: or wading through Webster Hall to a gorgeous
column16: slowly dawning song they later called ""Banshee Beat."" The feeling of that moment is hard to describe
column17: but it was something like standing in the light of a secret. Times change
column18: life intervenes. Painting With was the first time the band jumped right into the studio. Work can be scheduled

Punk is officially over the hill at this point

column3:

The rap scene in Minneapolis and St. Paul has splintered in curious ways. From the late '90s through the end of the Bush years
column2: the Twin Cities were known nationally for the Rhymesayers roster above all else. Atmosphere
column3: Brother Ali
column4: and Eyedea typified the Cities' dominant styles: self-deprecating
column5: socially conscious
column6: abstract. This music was sometimes cordoned off as ""backpack rap

column8: this aesthetic mostly trickled down to the local scenes and the promoters who curated it.

column1: But as two of the three aforementioned acts moved into middle age (and after Eyedea tragically died in 2010)
column2: it left a stylistic vacuum that artists from all corners rushed to fill. Some of the new decade's most exciting work has been tailored for the live setting: Grrrl Party springs to mind
column3: as does wag music
column4: a glitchy
column5: stuttering type of party rap that indulges all its best and weirdest impulses. The Stand4rd earned national attention with ghost-infested R&B; Mike the Martyr is bringing back Starburys from the discount bin at Foot Locker; Finding Novyon is rapping about beloved cartoon characters. And Why Khaliq
column6: a young upstart from St. Paul
column7: is turning out some of the Cities' most forward-thinking music
column8: and he's doing it by circling way
column9: way back.

column1: Under the Perspective Tree
column2: his new seven-song EP
column3: takes the visual and musical signifiers of late-'90s and early-'00s conscious rap and injects into them welcome doses of immediacy and personal detail

column7: and gold chains. Slave hymnals bookend the opening song itself. But it hones in immediately: <i>It's 3 a.m.
column8: I'm in my baby mama's mama's house. And that's what Khaliq does time and time again over the course of the record—zoom in when you expect the sweeping argument.

column1: Producer Lelan Foley can be largely credited for how loose and improvisational Perspective Tree feels. The EP leans heavily on jazz piano and pavement-hard drum programming
column2: arranged in such a way that each part of a song feels as if it shifts into the next of its own accord. On “Knew the Half
column3: ” Foley brings in the type of rolling hi-hats that are more often found in contemporary trap music
column4: but lays them under one of the tape's warmest melodies to hypnotic effect.

column1: Khaliq is a precise rapper and a personal
column2: colorful writer. To stay on “Knew the Half”: he drags your focus in and out of the drum pattern
column3: letting his syllables fall consistently but switching where he places the emphasis in each bar. Later in that song
column4: and in a handful of others (“For You
column5: ” “Nonchalant Interlude”)
column6: Khaliq deploys a captivating singing voice
column7:
which breaks up the sound and structure of the project. Why Khaliq is the type of rapper superbly suited for his time: one who understands how to use the past to move forward. It would be a shock if the next year or so doesn't afford him a chance to latch on to the present.

Since his release from prison in March of 2014
column2: Boosie Badazz has made some of the best ""adult"" rap music imaginable. This is partly by design: Baton Rouge and the backwoods Southern communities that gravitated toward Boosie appreciated him for the thoughtful street rapper he always was
column3: even as he came to fame off songs like ""Wipe Me Down"" and ratchet culture
column4: and since his release
column5: it feels as though Boosie has committed to living up to the 2Pac comparisons those fans gave to him. The other part of this is that Boosie (government name Torrance Hatch) has been through so much strife and ill will that it would be hard to talk about anything else on record. Past the familiar story of the existential dread that comes from street hustling
column6: he went from staring the possibility of a death penalty in the face to serving time in one of the harshest prisons in Louisiana to a freedom nobody believed he’d get to see to the discovery that he had kidney cancer.

column1: It’s this diagnosis that led to Boosie’s most emotionally gripping album to date: In My Feelings (Goin’ Thru It)
column2: released just earlier this year. After a nephrectomy to remove half his kidney

column4: filled with solemn musings about the old-school street life he came from
column5: the people lost to prison
column6: death
column7: or just time over the years
column8: and his inability to understand how much street codes have changed amongst the youth of today. ""We grew up youngstas on the corner
column9: tryna make a livin/ Tryna make it back home
column10: so we take a pistol
column11: he begins on ""Takem Back
column12: painting a grim snapshot of the most impressionable and vulnerable time in a young black man’s life in a rough environment.

column1: Throughout Out My Feelings
column2: Boosie reflects on a life covered in scars and pain. Not just his own
column3: but those of the people around him and people he’s interacted with; on ""Look at Life Different"" he raps about a mother with sons who are stuck in jail
column4: one who is gangbanging and another abusing drugs. His tone is somber but resigned—he knows this story too well: ""Asked me to pray wit her and asked me can I call Johnny/ That’s her baby boy who wylin’
column5: catchin body after body."" It's clear from his ragged delivery that he hurts for her and her sons the way he hurts for his own mother and the grief he brought her during his own wild days. ""Thank God for Boosie"" is repeated throughout the song
column6: and the implication is that rap was the only thing that saved Torrance Hatch from these dire fates.

column1: Out My Feelings doesn’t have the rawness of In My Feelings
column2: but its production is impeccable where that one was spotty
column3: and it soars when Boosie reminisces on his pre-rap days or makes statements in line with Black Lives Matter about the murders of unarmed black people by cops. Its lows come more sporadically and feel uncomfortable—like the homophobic lyrics found on ""The Truth
column4: for example—and the lecturing to young street kids about not sticking to the code of his youth is understandable but carries an ""old man yelling at a cloud"" vibe after awhile.

column1: Incidentally
column2: one of the best songs on the album is ""Wanna B Heard
column3: a wistful love letter to the forgotten where Boosie raps about the pull of gang life and the cry for help that the violence and crime committed by street kids really is. The most potent line: ""I saw Glenn had something on his mind
column4: I should’ve asked him what’s wrong/ Probably would’ve told me instead of blasting his dome."" Above anything else
column5: Boosie’s intense popularity began with those most ignored. He was their star
column6:
because he listened and he understood and recognized that their pain was real and it mattered in a way a lot of self-proclaimed ""street"" rappers have never been able to do. Thank God for Boosie.

Abi Reimold's voice is ripe with pure emotion. On her debut full-length
column2: Wriggling

column5: and it sounds goddamn exhausting. The album art
column6: an open can of worms—yes
column7: they're wriggling—in tight focus
column8: mirrors her sound well. There's slime
column9: dirt
column10: and awkwardness in all 12 tracks

column12: and for good reason. At 23 years old
column13: that's a mantra
column14: not a one-time thought.

column1: Reimold wrote much of the material two years ago when she came into legal adulthood. Wriggling carries that intimacy
column2: the wide-eyed fear of what's to come after the façade of teenagerdom disintegrates
column3: particularly in the record's folkier moments. ""An illusion of an elevator: how we create our creator
column4: she sings on ""Machine
column5: somewhat hopeless
column6: before continuing: ""Grant me my mortality
column7: make me blind so I won't see/ That there's no scheme
column8: there is no plan
column9: we grow where our seeds happen to land."" On ""Vessel
column10: she claws at her own organs with diaristic imagery (""Perhaps the bolts themselves will tighten/ Sit on my ass waiting for you to ripen"") and eventually turns to instruments like pedal steel on ""Trap"" to create the fullness of a '60s country-rock song.

column1: When Reimold switches to electric guitar
column2: she locks into late '90s alt-rock mode. ""Bad Seed"" starts full throttle with help from Philly neighbors Mumblr for the rhythm section. Things turn heavier with ""Clouded"" and ""Mask
column3: songs that could easily be mistaken for early Speedy Ortiz demos
column4: as she reverts to thick riffs and sings through a delay pedal for vocal distortion. Throughout the album
column5: Reimold communicates the sensation that she's working through memories in real time
column6: ones that are clearly still fresh enough to punch her in the gut. It gives her songs the feel of being performed right in front of you.

column1: Combining those two styles of songwriting can feel lopsided
column2: but she pulls it off. The mix of rock and folk is soldered with lo-fi recordings of intimate moments: a room's silent hum while someone texts
column3: a passing car whose music can be heard through closed windows
column4: a playground in the distance where children shriek during a game of tag. Those poetic inserts never take themselves too seriously.

column1: Wriggling's darkest moments recall the gloominess of Cat Power's quieter material or Torres' Sprinter. Two-minute track ""Dust"" finds her beating herself up repeatedly. The song's only two lines (""I will learn what dust tastes like/ I am not immune"") change shape each time they leave her mouth. Each repetition is cushioned by new sounds
column2: switching from bedroom guitar strums to guitars overcome with shrill feedback. Like many of her Philly peers
column3: from Hop Along to Radiator Hospital to every self-described DIY band in between

column5: but her delivery sets her apart from the rest. Her voice is just coarse enough to sound painful

column8:
life has already claimed that title—and she's still in the process of learning that it won't let up anytime soon.

Despite having a Bandcamp page as thick as a double-stuffed booklet of CDs

column5: but an individual sound emanates through their influence. Knxwledge's ongoing Wraptaypes series is a good place to get a feel for his aesthetic: On these mixes
column6: he layers a mixture of vocals and audio clips laid atop his production—vintage beat tapes with voices for added emphasis. The Wraptaypes anthology compiles 26 such productions created between 2011 and 2015 into a highlight reel. His sample selections are noteworthy
column7: but his repurposing of them is the resonant accomplishment.

column1: Wraptaypes involves Knxwledge stripping original works of their elements
column2: taking the remains he deemed useful and engraving them with his signature. It's an aggressive
column3: dissociative process
column4: in which he basically decapitates source material like action figures and sews the heads onto music he's composed. The face (or
column5: rather
column6: the voice) is the same
column7: but the limbs
column8: extremities
column9: and heart are all different. As a result
column10: the ensemble of bit players Knxwledge weaves into each web becomes part of something original.

column1: Knxwledge allows each track—no matter how short or unpolished it is—to stand as its own entity. In each instance
column2: the outcome is rewardingly distinct. ""Strtdfrmthebttm"" slows Drake's ""humble"" recollections
column3: trading urgency for a warm
column4: mellow haze for the better part of two minutes. (Kudos to Knxwledge for reimagining a club anthem as a lush
column5: scenic Urban Outfitters composition—that's a feat.) An Eazy-E verse from ""Tha Muthaphukkin Real"" contrasts the lazy strings and 808s on ""Iwish"" before Carl Thomas' voice literally chirps in
column6: accelerated to Alvin and the Chipmunks speeds
column7: Heatmakerz style. Inebriated keys turn Sheek Louch and Jadakiss into charming lounge singers on ""Choosewun""; the first portion of ""Choppas"" does the same to Lil Wayne.

column1: The anthology also showcases Knxwledge's perceptive grasp of how certain instruments drive songs
column2: namely the unrestrained '80s sitcom sax on ""21kwestions"" and Ernie Isley's screaming guitar on ""Allwegot."" Details count
column3: so artifacts like different parts of the same Boyz n the Hood scene used at the beginning of ""Ignorntsht"" and end of ""Gotstaprove"" are welcome pop culture Easter Eggs for the film enthusiasts. Anthologies have no hidden messages or intricate narrative structures; they're collections meant to be taken at face value. Wraptaypes
column4: however
column5:
is as much a snapshot of Knxwledge's mind as it is an aggregate of music. Each component and pairing speaks to how he interprets music and assembles his own.

Years before he moved to Portland and adopted the name ""Elliott
column2: Steven Paul Smith was a sunny and unassuming kid growing up in the Dallas suburbs
column3: living a surprisingly all-American existence. He played football; his family went to church occasionally. He played clarinet in middle-school band and was elected Byrd Symphonic Band president in 1982; he cracked up his friends with goofy impressions. His best friend was a fellow ""Dungeons & Dragons"" obsessive named Steve Pickering (nickname: Pickle)
column4: with whom he recorded dozens upon dozens of original songs

column1: In the countless interviews that Smith’s friends and loved ones have granted since his death

column9: for example

column3: and none of them are more important than the version of ""True Love"" that appears here. The song dates from the early Jon Brion sessions of From a Basement on a Hill
column4: before Brion allegedly confronted Smith about his escalating drug use and Smith packed off
column5: with his then-girlfriend Valerie Deerin and all of the two-inch reels from the sessions

As the rock version of ""Christian Brothers"" or the rough-but-still-revelatory version of ""Coast to Coast"" here demonstrate

bounding freely and unencumbered. It is gawky and innocent and heartbreakingly pure.

column1: Here
column2: it draws a closed circle around Cardinal by commenting on the album opener ""Old Friends"": Hall resolves to make new friends—""I liked my old ones
column3: but I fucked up
column4: so I'll start again."" It sounded wistful and clever on Everything So Far

column2: they probably picture the rickety

column6: the one-time progressive musician-turned-superstar who went on to sell over 60 million albums in the '70s and '80s. The predominant sound is cheerful
column7: celebratory
column8: welcoming
column9: sincere
column10: just like the Greek people: Throughout the nation’s history
column11: woe—the invasions of Persians
column12: Turks
column13: and Nazis
column14: starvation and famine
column15: sickness or death—results in revelry. When times are tough

column1: Unlike the rest of contiguous Eurasia
column2: Greece’s unique geography has enabled it to remain impervious to Western influences: the northern border is shaped by treacherous mountain ranges
column3: while the south and east is dominated by hundreds of rocky
column4: isolated islands. These barriers have also enabled each individual village to retain its unique cultural identity in relation to the broader canon of <i>demotika

column1: The 28 tracks King’s assembled for Why the Mountains Are Black sound nothing like the chirpy
column2: cheery music of those Athenos feta commercials—in fact
column3: it sounds downright inhospitable at times
column4: closer to free jazz or even drone music. The instantly-recognizable bouzouki is largely absent
column5: as is any distinguishable melodic patterns
column6: with fiddles

column9: needle-sharp wind instrument) takes on a role akin to a jazz saxophone
column10: screeching stream-of-consciousness phrases above the din like a furious harpy. And yet—these are celebratory songs with clear form and purpose
column11: defined dances that continue to be performed to this day
column12: if not on a national scale then a local one. The steady 4/4 beat of contemporary dance music
column13: after all
column14: is a Western creation. Greek musical tradition is instead rooted in time signatures (7/8
column16: and so forth) that date back to the Byzantine era—so
column17: while songs like ""Enas Aetos - Tsamiko (An Eagle ? Dance)"" and ""Syrtos Haniotikos (Syrtos Dance from Hania)"" are likely to make a non-Greek throw up their hands in confusion
column18: anyone who’s ever attended a Greek dance will recognize the constancy latent in these eccentric tempos.

column1: Speaking with the LA Times
column2: King argued that suffering—rather than celebration
column3: or simple expressions of hometown pride—provides the spark in these maddened
column4: frantic songs. ""The function of music among the countryside-dwelling Greeks was both to ameliorate an often short
column5: hard and somewhat isolated life
column6: he noted
column7: ""but also to protect against….'Dangerous Hour': the times of crisis
column8: danger
column9: uncertainty
column10: pain
column11: longing and death that faced rural Greeks for millennia."" From the shoddy recording quality of this collections’ tunes (made all the more abrasive by King’s remastering) to the aforementioned howls of fiddles and pipizas gasping into the din
column12: every square inch of these songs brims with primal indignance

column14: but an affirmation of life in spite of all that these musicians had to endure. It is this spirit—and King’s awareness of it—that enables this initially baffling collection to transcend its esotericism and connect with a global audience
column15: perhaps even with those who’ve never had a sip of ouzo in their life. After all
column16: from the mountains of Greece to the hills of Appalachia
column17:
to dance in spite of certain doom is to be human.

German keyboardist and composer Nils Frahm's music has always been
column2: at its heart

column1: The Gamble loosely explores and repurposes old informal recordings Frahm made with fellow bandmates Frederic Gmeiner and Sebastian Singwald in Germany in the early '90s. The recently reunited nonkeen recorded over and sampled mixdowns from the original
column2: often degenerated '90s 4-track tapes

column1: The short record's unusual production style is essential because it helps shape and enhance its raw musical building blocks. Some of these pieces might sound a touch too non-descript if they had been realized in a more polished way. It's the cleaner

column1: The use of bottom-shelf

The finicky materials result in feedback and odd bursts of incidentally rhythmic noise which often become the highlights of the songs. On ""Pink Flirt""—featuring Frahm's electric piano and organ—the tape slows down suddenly to create a majestic sweep. It's the album's central

In his 1982 film
column2: Koyaanisqatsi
column3: director Godfrey Reggio sought to explain the relationship between human beings
column4: nature and technology. He presented a gorgeous collage of scenic landscapes and rolling clouds
column5: set against an equally riveting score. The movie said everything it needed without any spoken dialogue
column6: which can be nearly impossible in cinema and music.

column1: Jazz trio GoGo Penguin rescored the film in a one-off event this past fall
column2: which makes total sense the more you assess the band’s art. Drummer Rob Turner
column3: bassist Nick Blacka and pianist Chris Illingworth fuse classical and electronic elements while keeping with jazz’s improvised nature. Much like Koyaanisqatsi
column4: GoGo Penguin’s music is full of subtle shifts that allow its composers to shine equally. For Man Made Object
column5: the band’s third album
column6: many of its 10 tracks started as electronic compositions
column7: created on Logic and Ableton by the group’s percussionist.

column1: GoGo Penguin opts for an energized sound on Man Made Object
column2: conjuring pastoral imagery while loosely exploring scientific concepts. Between its title and multifaceted sonic approach
column3: the LP seems directly influenced by Koyaanisqatsi
column4: bringing to mind the same sorts of aerial views we see during the movie’s 86 minutes. The album comes on the heels of a revival of sorts for jazz music
column5: where artists like Kendrick Lamar
column6: David Bowie
column7: Flying Lotus and Kamasi Washington fused the genre with their own blends of rap
column8: rock
column9: electronica and soul. The success of their respective LPs brought jazz back into mainstream view and made it more accessible for younger listeners.

column1: Man Made Object resides in similar space. Much like the band’s first two albums—Fanfares and v2.0
column2: the latter of which was shortlisted for a Mercury Prize Album of the Year—the band’s new album takes hold right away and sustains an upbeat groove. Even in its quieter moments
column3: like those on “GBFISYSIH” and “Initiate
column4: ” they carry a reflective vibe without losing momentum. GoGo Penguin creates jazz in the same vein as Robert Glasper: It’s a piano-driven blend with all the traditional aspects you’d expect from the genre while still scanning as something refreshingly vibrant and contemporary. Theirs is a percussive strain of frenetic drum breaks and rock-infused instrumentals
column5: like on “Smarra
column6: ” where a fluttering bass line takes center stage
column7: ramping up the rhythm until it burns to a smoldering heap. It’s the best moment of an album filled with unique creative twists.

column1: Yet despite these details
column2: Man Made Object is largely devoid of standout
column3: calling-card tracks. “Smarra” and “Protest” hit hardest at first glance
column4: but the other tracks take longer to build up
column5: one leading to the next for a unified listening experience. Man Made Object is tailor-made for laid-back enjoyment
column6:
to be consumed at a moderate volume without much fuss. It marks a nice step forward for a group that lives comfortably beyond artistic restraints.
