If your first foray into capital-P Pop didn't do as well as your label expected—even though you won a Grammy—how do you bounce back
column3: especially when you’re only in your mid-twenties? Prepped and primed to be a star with ""indie"" sensibilities
column4: Foxes (aka Louisa Rose Allen) debuted in 2013 with Glorious
column5: a synth-pop record that didn't quite manage to win over international hearts. Though the record and its singles charted decently in the UK
column6: Foxes is perhaps more recognizable when you realize she’s the voice on Zedd’s 2012 pristine EDM super hit ""Clarity."" As a solo act
column7: Allen was set to be a low-key star without any fuss; she had the vocal talent without any of the frills of a generic pop star. No dance routines
column8: matching outfits
column9: or expensive-looking music videos. Maybe Allen and her team hoped this sort of 'realness' could appeal to a generation that prefers One Direction’s lack of conformity to boy band standards like
column10: say
column11: the Backstreet Boys.

column1: Two years later
column2: Allen’s sophomore effort All I Need shifts the focal point from synths to her vocals. However
column3: they're still not enough for this record to be memorable. All the ingredients for a pop hit are latent
column4: but unrealized. Tracks like ""Feet Don't Fail Me Now"" have a repetitive hook
column5: strong vocals
column6: and a familiar story of lost love
column7: but it just doesn't stand out the way a meticulously crafted earworm should. After listening to All I Need for the first time
column8: nothing remains or sticks with you
column9: which is maybe the most damning thing you can say about a pop record aimed at big international markets and radio takeovers.

column1: The record has cohesion and was clearly written to generate hits
column2: but it’s lacking almost entirely in oomph. Co-written with Dan Smith of Bastille (another band that churns out synth hits but similarly manages to underwhelm)
column3: ""Better Love"" manages to hark back to '80s sensibilities
column4: something monotonous and exhausted within the modern British synth-pop sphere. There are inevitable shifts in tone on All I Need but they prove to be small risks that don't pay off. One instance is marked with insipid piano ballad ""On My Way
column5: which was co-written by Jesse Shatkin
column6: one of the collaborators on One Direction’s rather weak single ""Perfect."" Another example is R&B and dancehall crossover ""Cruel
column7: which just sounds cheaply produced—think SoundCloud bro with a MacBook Air and a pirated copy of Logic Pro X.

column1: It’s unclear as to what Allen’s (and her label’s) objectives are for her career—is she supposed to be a mainstream hit or are they just fine with her doing reasonably well? Working with a ""mindie"" artist like Smith and a One Direction collaborator like Shatkin makes this record feel lost. Additionally
column2: the middle-of-the-road ""mindie” shtick proved to be close to career suicide for Carly Rae Jepsen with E•MO•TION
column3: but the difference here is that Jepsen had good songs (and much-deserved critical acclaim) by her side. Being successful without seeming successful is a difficult medium to achieve and maintain; it’s why Frankmusik is nowhere to be seen despite propelling Myspace protégé Ellie Goulding to global superstardom.

column1: As much as you want to root for Foxes to find her feet
column2: there’s nothing rule-breaking or remotely interesting about this record. Of all the shifting demands on pop stars and hits over the years
column3: catchiness is the one element that remains unchanged
column4: and it's completely missing here. Anonymity isn't a virtue: Even singers who aren't nearly as gifted as Allen (Jennifer Lopez
column5: Kylie Minogue) have managed to break into the music industry with a lot of success because they had catchy tunes behind them. What makes All I Need even weaker is that it doesn’t offer you something else in lieu of big
column6: brain-sticking instant anthems. It's just kind of a ""nothing"" record. Considering Allen hails from a country that has bred synth-pop darlings like Ellie Goulding and the inimitably cool Charli XCX in recent years
column7:
All I Need had the potential to be so much more than mediocre and forgettable.

In the music video for Porches’ ""Be Apart
column2: Aaron Maine and his band wear black turtlenecks as they mope around an apartment decorated like a dollhouse. They bounce basketballs
column3: play ping-pong
column4: strip down to share a bubble bath
column5: activities that might take place at a party thrown for the very idle rich. Near the halfway mark
column6: they stare into the camera like the Children of the Corn
column7: barely mouthing along to words in a way that will make you suspect they have either an awful or incredible sense of humor. The song is about whether Maine wants to be apart or a part of it all—and the sight of five hip youngs looking sad at a social event leads you to think he’s stuck in between.

column1: Mopey New Yorkers are endlessly renewable in independent music
column2: but here’s the thing: You can sort of dance to ""Be Apart."" On Pool
column3: his newest record and first for Domino
column4: Maine has shed the murky folk of previous recordings for a homespun electronic sound that consciously pulls away from the ""rock"" elements. (Call him another indie kid who sold his guitars and bought turntables.) Fittingly for a record titled Pool
column5: it sounds like it was recorded with one in the room. Oceanic synths
column6: wobbly basslines
column7: and precise snare drums cohere into a crisp pop sound
column8: while his high
column9: expressive voice bobs brightly above the surface.

column1: Also fittingly: Water is a recurring theme throughout the LP. Maine watches people slip into swimming pools (""Underwater
column2: ""Pool"")
column3: envisions black water surrounding him as he weighs depression against the need to go out (""Be Apart"")
column4: and fantasizes about washing his car (""Car
column5: which is the closest thing here to a rock song). Getting stoned is a theme
column6: too. Sometimes
column7: he lights one up and hangs out by the metaphorical pool
column8: as on ""Hour
column9: whose dark electronics evoke the dinginess of a locker room at the Y.

column1: In an interview on Pitchfork Radio
column2: Maine said he wanted to make something ""more positive"" that could be energetically performed live
column3: and that he wants people to dance to his music. The shimmering groove on ""Braid"" and ""Mood"" will make you believe in his ambitions—people will at least be swaying—as does the boogie that breaks out at the end of the title track. The singer Greta Kline
column4: who fronts Frankie Cosmos and is also Maine’s girlfriend
column5: loans backing vocals or basslines to the half-dozen best songs. Her plucky strumming on ""Mood"" and ""Glow"" creates the record’s most genuinely funky moments
column6: when you can imagine the shy kids thrusting hips in their living rooms.

column1: Maine isn’t an involved lyricist
column2: but his melodic instincts connect the gap between intent and outcome. He has an alien-yet-captivating way of phrasing syllables that recalls the unblinking stoicism of Majical Cloudz’ Devon Welsh
column3: or the weirdo brooding of Arthur Russell. The melodramatic sigh in the chorus of ""Be Apart""—""And I-I-I-I want to be apart""—reminds me of Morrissey
column4: as does the lyrical preoccupation with whether or not to go out that night.

column1: You could also observe that Morrissey had the gumption to rhyme ""rusty spanner"" with ""play piano
column2: and that some of that spirit might be missing here. The piercing clarity of Maine’s voice imbues his relatively simplistic lyrics with profundity
column3: but you might wonder how much is going on in his brain at times. At least one Pitchfork co-worker gasped when I suggested Pool sounded like a chillwave record
column4: but it does remind me of how that micro-genre enabled listeners most likely to get lost in a K-Mart to wade through shallow depths.

column1: But a wading pool can be a perfect meditative space. Pool is an introspective record
column2: tailormade for lonesome nights. It was made in Maine’s apartment
column3: and while the record has a noticeably professional pop sheen
column4: there are still vestigial hints of amateurism (such as the sound of fingers squeaking against the strings on album opener ""Underwater"") that convince me of its ideal setting. Anyone who lives in a city knows how easy it is to be pulled between lonely apartments and lonelier dance floors. By the end
column5: the appeal of water becomes clear. You immerse yourself in it
column6: disappearing from the rest of the world
column7:
but you’re still close to land.

On their collaborative new album Who the Fuck Is Chris Spencer??
column2: underground Chicago rappers Vic Spencer and Chris Crack appear wholly ignorant of all recent trends
column3: as if they've emerged untouched from a late-'90s time capsule. The record goes against the popular grain in every sense
column4: from the production—sample-based
column5: replete with chiming vibraphones—to the duo's explicit allegiance to capital-L Lyricism. It's a concept album that seems less concerned with its concept—Chris $pencer is ostensibly a fictionalized fusion of the two MCs—than in world-building
column6: in craft
column7: and devotion to an acerbic
column8: pointed sensibility. Who the Fuck Is Chris Spencer?? draws attention to lost traditions
column9: evoking forgotten and under-explored tributaries of rap—the freestyle- and battle-rooted styles of Lyricist's Lounge CDs and classic hip-hop radio (Stretch and Bobbito
column10: Sway & King Tech). It plays not on what we remember from the past
column11: but on what we've forgotten.

column1: Both Vic and Chris' solo work is worth exploring
column2: but together
column3: their powers are magnified. These are not radio records; they are not ""bangers."" Their songs take up space
column4: as if the duo were less interested in persuading listeners to jump on the bandwagon than in drawing a line between their Backwoods-smoke-filled living room and the one outside. Needless to say
column5: their songs are also not paeans to positivity. <span id=""docs-internal-guid-f0ab5f2d-bf06-eb23-4008-758b97955709""><span>(Vic: ""Y'all got an A plus for suckin' balls/Leave your ass blind in your house
column6: left you touchin' walls."") Yet they are invigorating
column7: the kind of music which gives voice to all our righteous suspicions that the wider world is smugly disingenuous—an especially resonant
column8: if unpopular
column9: sentiment in an age built on friendly alliances. Chris enjoys a good conspiracy theory
column10: and Vic is the self-described ""rapping bastard."" Both rappers revel in playing the heel. Where other artists seem obligated to veer experimental or populist
column11: they choose neither.

column1: Yet the album is bold
column2: forward-thinking
column3: and singular nonetheless
column4: because it treats hip-hop as a lineage inherently worthy of celebration
column5: with no other justification needed. Like high school cafeteria battles taken to their outer limit
column6: Who the Fuck Is Chris Spencer?? focuses on the art of rapping not as a technical exercise but as a freewheeling session of shit-talking. This is the dozens on steroids. Songs are shaped by verses rather than the other way around. Their flows never fall into familiar patterns
column7: nor do their twisting narratives
column8: which weave in and out like a boxer
column9: defiantly unpredictable. On ""What's Saturday?
column10: Chris Crack's tale of breaking and entering suddenly goes left
column11: as he fantasizes about being smothered by ""big girls
column12: before glossing over the story's expected climax (""we got the money
column13: nobody was hurt"") and hitting the highway. The story arc is incidental. This is lyrical rap which reclaims the word ""lyrical"": no longer a trap for those who would fetishize arbitrary formal techniques
column14: it is reborn as a synonym for freedom—where verses operate by their own volatile logic.

column1: The closest thing to a ""single"" on the album is ""No Biggie
column2: a record which flips the same Screamin' Jay Hawkins sample as Biggie's ""Kick in the Door."" Even there
column3: the underlying ""pop"" impulse of the DJ Premier flip is cut into jagged shards
column4: while Vic's corkscrew baritone and Chris' raw
column5: high-pitched sneer move at hard angles. The album's main compositional framework comes not from the immediacy of the pop song
column6: but from the smoky
column7: expansive comfort of its atmosphere. Chris and Vic's world is never entirely exposed to the light: The tranquil ""Cement
column8: for example
column9: with its melodious chorus from C. Rich
column10: makes one feel as if they've nodded off in a beanbag chair at the recording session
column11: lyrics filtering in while flitting in and out of consciousness.

column1: Their work expresses a contradiction: Chris $pencer cares too deeply while not giving a fuck. Something important is at stake
column2: and yet Chris and Vic live precariously
column3: as if truth and provocation are the only things worth holding onto. If there's a theme which unites Who the Fuck Is Chris Spencer??
column4: it's one of perpetual skepticism: distrust of ideologies
column5: of consensus
column6: of hype
column7: propaganda
column8: publicity
column9: and bullshit. This oppositional spirit is best captured by a younger generation in the sardonic
column10: cutting perspectives of Earl Sweatshirt and Vince Staples. But unlike the stoned mumble of the Odd Future-affiliated
column11: Vic and Chris' vocals carve through beats with a wiry
column12: manic
column13: animated energy—best described in the sampled interview with Chicago rapper Drunken Monkee on the song ""Drunken Monkee"": ""It's a lot of niggas that can rap over ill beats but they don't know how to bring that shit to life. And that's what we do

dawg.""

Music
column2: the world's universal language
column3: is for everybody. The music industry
column4: however
column5: is a loosely regulated crap shoot which
column6: while occasionally lifting a creative genius to godlike status
column7: leaves a trail of decimated bands under its boots. For every Nirvana
column8: there are a dozen Mudhoneys; for every Marc Bolan there is a Jobriath; an artist of essentially equal opportunity that for whatever reason—timing
column9: money
column10: plain old shit luck—gets left behind on the path to superstardom. However
column11: if those artists are lucky
column12: they can accumulate years and years of goodwill among music fans who excavate and polish these diamonds in the rough.

column1: Milk 'N' Cookies are the latest such group to benefit from this history-revising eye. They formed in the early 1970s in Woodmere
column2: Long Island
column3: a short drive from the bustling proto-punk scene in New York City
column4: where the New York Dolls reigned supreme and their brand of glam-influenced gutter rock was already beginning to burn out under its own brilliance. While most of the local bands around them were steeped in stadium rock
column5: Milk 'N' Cookies
column6: still in their teens
column7: decided to record 4-track songs influenced by the British glitter rock of the era—T. Rex
column8: Bowie
column9: Sweet
column10: Roxy Music
column11: et al.—and perhaps unwittingly became precursors to U.S. power pop. They have a major hand in creating the ""tough glam"" aesthetic
column12: a sort of blend of UK androgyny
column13: N.Y. grit and L.A. glamour that continued to rear its sequined head from the New Romantics to hair metal to Britpop
column14: and beyond.

column1: In their very first photo shoot
column2: Milk 'N' Cookies sport long manes of brown hair
column3: wearing novelty bowties and clutching teddy bears
column4: yet the songs compiled on their first LP
column5: reissued here by Captured Tracks
column6: are all about girls
column7: sex
column8: and letting loose
column9: still slightly scandalous subjects for suburban America at that point. Frontman Justin Strauss uses a sing-song
column10: breathy voice
column11: like a lovesick schoolboy taunting his crush on the playground. It's not emasculating at all
column12: more of an assertion of desire that makes every Milk 'N' Cookies song seem ripped from a teenager's diary (which they very well may have been).

column1: Somewhat self-prophesying
column2: ""(Dee Dee You're) Stuck on a Star"" addresses a girlfriend more interested in chasing a famous popstar than seeing her boyfriend's band
column3: and the song launches the compilation on a strong note
column4: with searing riffs from the kind of super-dry guitars and wobbly bass that scream ""'70s garage"" to hardcore fans. The pop sensibility is immediate: Milk 'N' Cookies rarely lets up on powerful melodies
column5: and it's a potent throwback to a time where bands put out albums in which literally every song could be a conceivable single. The band's only official single
column6: the mid-tempo ""Little
column7: Lost and Innocent
column8: coyly begins with the line ""She was underage/ And so was I
column9: which is so much more disarming when sang by well-scrubbed all-American boys who would not have looked out of place in the pages of a vintage Tiger Beat. The barely legal theme reaches its apex with ""Rabbits Make Love
column10: which even has a six-bar breakdown of heavy breathing by Strauss. Despite all this heavy panting
column11: petting
column12: and leering
column13: Milk 'N' Cookies never feel sleazy
column14: just funny and playful and sexy.

column1: After a few years of delayed album releases and relocations to London and Los Angeles (the minutiae of which are rigorously documented in Milk 'N' Cookies' 60-page booklet)
column2: Milk 'N' Cookies star ultimately fizzled
column3: which is a shame; tracks like ""Just a Kid"" and ""Tinkertoy Tomorrow"" are tight and delicious
column4: and hint at a career that could have rivaled the best power pop bands of the decade. This career anthology is about as complete as a collection can get

column11: but for even the most casual '70s rock enthusiast
column12:
this collection is nothing short of essential.

Looking at the respective states of American bro-country and Jamaican dancehall
column3: it's hard to imagine that these genres ever had anything to do with each other. But in the 1960s
column4: the harmonies of country music were big in Jamaica
column5: as can be heard most explicitly on comps like Noah Found Grace. Or
column6: as the owner of reggae specialty shop Deadly Dragon Sound once explained: ""You can always tell when a collection of Jamaican LPs is bona fide when you come across a copy of Marty Robbins' 1959 smash hit Gunfighter Ballads."" This strange hybrid continues on in the work of multitasking singer/songwriter Jeb Loy Nichols.

column1: Nichols—born in Wyoming but now based in Wales—boasts a peculiar skill set that includes doing artwork for the reggae reissue imprint Pressure Sounds as well as curating the Country Got Soul series. So it’s no real surprise that country and reggae commingle on Nichols' eighth album Long Time Traveller
column2: previously only issued in Japan in 2010 and now re-released on On-U Sound with a second disc of alternate mixes. Produced by Adrian Sherwood and since-deceased Roots Radics drummer Style Scott
column3: Traveller has an ease about it that stems from Nichols’ long familiarity with both forms.

column1: A dribble of keys and guitar upstroke introduce ""To Be Rich (Should Be a Crime)
column2: a song that replicates the classic sound of Studio One right down to the Jackie Mittoo-esque keyboard solo taken midway through. Nichols’ drawl is just behind the beat
column3: as easeful as classic rocksteady crooners like Ken Boothe or Errol Dunkley. So closely does Nichols replicate the music of that bygone era that the songs can sound like standards
column4: even though they are primarily originals. Nichols and his mates backing him up aren’t trying to push the envelope so much as just enjoy a mild
column5: swaying lilt
column6: as on ""97 Miles."" It’s relaxed to the point of narcolepsy
column7: and while the cool ruler Gregory Isaacs no doubt figures into Nichols and his vocal delivery
column8: he often just sounds drowsy. There’s a sprinkle of dub effects added to the drums of ""Salt of a Fallen Tear
column9: while there’s a dash acoustic guitar twang on ""Lonely King of the Country
column10: but rarely do Nichols’ country and roots actually entwine. It avoids the weed-infused gimmickry of Willie Nelson’s own stab at reggae on Countryman
column11:
but Traveller could stand either more splinters or more spliffs on its too-smooth moves.

Perhaps appropriately for a genre of music rooted in the enigmatic and the obscure
column2: the minimal synth revival has quietly become a movement without ever quite becoming a bandwagon. Montreal duo Essaie Pas are just one of a scattered network of contemporary groups reviving the sound and aesthetic of a lost generation of DIY-minded synthpop artists of the '70s and '80s
column3: who either by accident or design ended up too rudimentary

column6: if you chose

column9: there is something attractive about minimal synth's severe
column10: austere poise. This music got few props at the time
column11: but at its best—and certainly
column12: Demain Est Une Autre Nuit captures the modern sound more or less at its best—it feels alluringly other: a secret

column1: Essaie Pas are the husband-and-wife duo of Marie Davidson and Pierre Guerineau—she a solo recording artist
column2: he a music engineer who has worked with Montreal musicians such as Dirty Beaches and Femminielli. This
column3: their fourth album and debut for DFA—the title of which translates as ""Tomorrow Is Another Night""—was born out of long winter nights rehearsing at one of Montreal's deserted industrial complexes
column4: which the pair occupied after returning from tour to find their studio and practice space had been shuttered.

column1: Some of this sense of frigidity and dislocation has found its way into Essaie Pas' music – or perhaps more accurately
column2: has intensified and authenticated a spirit that was already there. Moments like ""Dépassée par le fantasme"" and ""Carcajou 3"" recall their New York peers Xeno & Oaklander in their skittery analog intricacy. But Essaie Pas are also wise to dance floor imperatives: deeper into the record
column3: ""Facing the Music"" locks into a mute
column4: driving techno redolent of DFA labelmates Factory Floor
column5: while ""Lights Out"" is a twilit acid pulse through which Davidson periodically announces the title
column6: voice smothered with echo.

column1: The more song-centered moments on Demain Est Une Autre Nuit offer a sense of the pair's influences. Vocals are largely delivered in French
column2: Guerineau dourly intoning longer
column3: narrative passages and Davidson singing choruses
column4: or just holding long
column5: trilling notes that dissolve into texture. Singing in French gives Essaie Pas an umbilical link to earlier continental synth and coldwave groups such as Elli et Jacno (who Essaie Pas covered on their previous album Nuit de noce) and Asylum Party
column6: groups whose lyrics often tipped beyond lovelorn melodrama to a place of bereft existentialism. ""Retox"" is a tale of romantic separation riven with violent imagery
column7: nights spent battling insomnia
column8: and fantasies of screams that bruise flesh; at one point we hear Guerineau lift a receiver and key in the Montreal area code before apparently perishing from the sheer ennui of it all. On ""Le port du masque est de rigueur"" (""Wearing a Mask Is Mandatory"") he picks morbidly over the bones of a love affair. ""J'ai tenté de t'oublier/ Comme on noie une portée de chatons
column9: he sings—""I tried to forget you/ Like drowning a litter of kittens""—as electronics gurgle away maniacally on one chord.

column1: ""La Chute"" ends the album on a dreamier note
column2: a bloody Valentine with just a hint of yacht rock gleam to the synths
column3: and listening to it
column4: it's not hard to imagine Davidson and Guerineau working together at night
column5: as frost collects on windowpanes and breath clouds in the air. Back in the late '00s

column7: DFA's attention was elsewhere

column10: mannered synth music is no throwback
column11: but merely a style ahead of its time
column12:
and one that only now is coming of age.

Eric Prydz got his pop crossover out of the way early. The Swedish DJ and producer broke through in 2004 with ""Call on Me

column3: once they go pop

column6: he performed on the same stage as Calvin Harris

column8: Tiësto
column9: and David Guetta

column11: over-the-top heartstring-pullers like ""Every Day

column1: Opus

column8: bold melodies pitched somewhere between yearning and euphoria; his melodic sensibility is a lot like that of M83

column1: Even with the showiness
column2: Prydz is probably the subtlest DJ ever to headline Madison Square Garden. One of his favorite tricks is to hypnotize listeners with a reassuring chord progression and then
column3: after three or four minutes of eight-bar cycles
column4: to suddenly pivot into a new variation
column5: breaking the imaginary space of the track wide open. He wisely avoids the over-the-top pyrotechnics of main-stage EDM in favor of hypnotic arpeggios and long
column6: teasing filter sweeps; instead of his peers’ Pavlovian sucker-punches
column7: he prefers to seductively blur the line between tension and release. And where big-room DJs deploy rushing snare rolls and vertiginous glissandi to create tension at the close of a 32-bar segment
column8: Prydz uses a single
column9: reverberant snare drum
column10: a sound so imitated that it has come to be called the ""Pryda snare
column11: after one of Prydz’s alter egos. (In theory
column12: each of his aliases has its own sound—Pryda leans toward pure progressive house
column13: Cirez D is reserved for techno
column14: and Prydz’ bigger crossover tracks come out under his own name. In practice
column15: however

column1: Opus oscillates between two poles. On the one side are entrancing progressive house numbers like the bookending ""Liam"" and ""Opus

column3: elegant shapes that arc effortlessly toward the horizon. ""Black Dyce

column6: too. ""Floj"" proceeds along similar lines

column1: At the other end of the spectrum are songs informed by Prydz’s pop instincts
column2: and these can be more of a mixed bag. The slow
column3: snaky ""Breathe"" boasts an excellent synth lead reminiscent of Boards of Canada
column4: but the vocals from Knife Party’s Rob Swire take the song deep into generic
column5: post-grunge stadium rock territory; they’re as faceless as Prydz’s own style is distinct. And ""Every Day

column1: But sometimes he gets it just right: On ""Moody Mondays

column9:
to escape judgement—is deeply woven into the fabric of EDM. And it’s to Prydz’s credit that he makes even these moments of excess sound far classier than any of his peers.

column3: Liz Baker

Most rock'n'roll singers throw parties. Nap Eyes frontman Nigel Chapman attends mixers—which are basically parties for people who don’t get invited to many. But even those are a bit much; two lines into ""Mixer
column2: the elegant
column3: cocktail-clinking song that opens the Halifax quartet’s second record
column4: Chapman is already craning his neck for the exit. ""When I look at myself on the right/ I’m wondering if I’m really here
column5: he sings
column6: like someone who’s pinned up against the wall of an overcrowded bar. That lonely-in-a-crowd feeling permeates the entirety of<i> Thought Rock Fish Scale
column7: but rather than communicate feelings of disillusionment and alienation
column8: Chapman seems remarkably calm and content—because
column9: in this case
column10: social isolation is the first step toward self-actualization.

column1: Nap Eyes sound like the kind of slacker-rock band that plays while slumped over on half-folded futons
column2: but even in its quietest moments
column3: Thought Rock Fish Scale is an album brimming with passion and protest. It finds confidence in humility
column4: power in relaxation. Its lethargy feels like an act of defiance against the hyper-speed pace of modern life. Its pledges of sobriety and good health constitute affronts to peer-pressured intoxication and food-blogged indulgence. And its purity of vision amounts to a declaration of war against a culture that encourages mass distraction. If your idea of a perfect night is sitting on your sofa
column5: reading a listicle on your laptop with Netflix on in the background while carrying on a conversation on your smartphone as you reply to a text
column6: then let this record be the first step in your rehabilitation from information overload.

column1: Thought Rock Fish Scale arrives mere months after Paradise of Bachelors introduced Nap Eyes’ debut
column2: Whine of the Mystic
column3: to Stateside audiences
column4: but they’re already a very different band. While Whine introduced Chapman as one the most intriguingly idiosyncratic lyricists in Canadian indie rock this side of Dan Bejar
column5: the album betrayed competing desires to engage its audience intellectually while cranking out rave-ups that could sate a Saturday-night bar crowd. Thought Rock Fish Scale does away with any such concessions—as Chapman observes early on
column6: ""If you go around trying to please everybody/ It only becomes your crutch."" Though clocking in at a mere 34 minutes
column7: it’s the sort of album that takes its sweet time going where it wants to. While it wields a lighter touch
column8: it strikes a deeper chord
column9: by placing Chapman’s richly detailed ruminations front and center
column10: and cutting the jammed-out clutter. It’s as if their favorite Velvets song has suddenly shifted from ""Foggy Notion"" to ""Pale Blue Eyes
column11: forsaking the visceral
column12: fleeting thrills of rocking out to savor the sustained beauty of lingering on.

column1: Chapman has one of those voices that feels immediately familiar
column2: yet is bracingly distinct. You can hear Lou Reed in his conversational verses; Stephen Malkmus in the voice-cracking choruses; Jeff Mangum in the fantastical
column3: quasi-religious imagery; and (again) Dan Bejar in the tendency to hurriedly overstuff his stanzas while retaining perfect enunciation and rhyme schemes. But his winsome
column4: observational perspective is his own—and not just when he’s referencing the pitfalls of having to work his day job in biochemistry while school’s out (""at the lab
column5: they have turned off the hot-water heater/ from the month of June right through until July""). His lyrics can take the form of self-help mantras (""And now I know who I really
column6: really am/ I’m going to stay on track""); they also speak to more peculiar personal insecurities (""Can you tell me
column7: do I have a glass eyelid?/ Can you tell me
column8: do I have a glass forehead?""). But even his most bizarre musings sound like emotional breakthroughs achieved amid moments of great clarity—""Stargazer"" may speak of of serpent kings and laser beam blasts
column9: but it uses those storybook devices to battle real-life demons.

column1: Chapman particularly excels at writing two kinds of songs. There are perfectly minimal jams like ""Lion in Chains"" and the aforementioned ""Stargazer
column2: each nothing more than a beautifully languorous verse melody—mirrored by gently-weeping guitar refrains—repeated over and over again until they feel like choruses. At the other end of the spectrum are sublime
column3: intricately constructed turns like ""Click Clack"" and ""Alaskan Shake
column4: each a long
column5: winding hallway lined with many doors that open the songs up to surprising new directions at the precise moment when they seem like they’re going to ramble off aimlessly. Appropriately enough
column6: the last words we hear Chapman sing on the record are ""trust
column7: trust
column8: trust
column9: trust me
column10: a plea for redemption doubling as an assurance that
column11: even in the most circuitous
column12: fanciful Nap Eyes song
column13:
Chapman will eventually steer you back on course.

Glaswegian producer/DJ Alex Smoke (aka Alex Menzies) has never made techno you were supposed to dance to. In his more than decade-long career
column2: his mixes and productions have veered far from the main drag of club and dancefloor appeal. More important for Smoke
column3: in all of his work
column4: was emotional exploration. It’s obvious that he has the disposition of a sensitive soul

column6: Love Over Will

column1: Apparently the title of the album is a playful inversion of British occultist Aleister Crowley’s law of Thelema
column2: a thoroughly ambiguous holy writ. In similarly opaque and broad terms

column4: but with an optimism relating to ways forward that are possible."" But does he deliver on such lofty statements? Probably not

column9: the carceral state

column1: The unevenness comes from Smoke’s heavy reliance on his singing
column2: which cannot carry the album's thematic weight.  His vocals dominate
column3: featuring in eight of the 13 songs. Throughout
column4: he sings in a low register
column5: mostly in a monotone
column6: and his voice is always Auto-Tuned or pitch-adjusted. Sometimes the vocals are the perfect complement to his sparse
column7: buoyant productions
column8: and at other times they are far too brittle and inflexible to match the rich sounds around him. The freezingly tender and liquid wall of sound in the album’s opener
column9: ""Fair Is Foul
column10: favorably recalls Mica Levi’s palette of quavering synths for Under the Skin
column11: but the track is nearly ruined by the interjection of lines like ""I never really care about you anyway/ You’re always on the way.""

column1: When his songwriting and singing fit together
column2: Smoke comes very close to the emotional resonance he is striving for. In ""LossGain
column3: as he whispers ""Don’t tell me how I feel when I’m myself
column4: there is an aching sense of strength and affirmation amidst the melancholy. When he sings ""All my atoms/ Struggling to fight them"" in ""All My Atoms
column5: the blunt lyrics propel the energy of the song’s bright keys. Smoke is a sentimentalist at heart
column6: and in the album’s best track
column7: ""Dust
column8: he submits to old desires and calls out to a lover: ""Don’t want to be with anyone else/ Don’t want to be separate.""

column1: Like Holly Herndon and Jam City
column2: Smoke attempts to politically radicalize his music. Unlike the other two artists
column3: he is hesitant to go full hog
column4: and only devotes two tracks to explicitly political themes: ""Fall Out"" and ""Yearning Mississippi."" ""Fall Out"" is partially inspired by the trials and tribulations of hacker folk hero Edward Snowden. As he sings ""you’ll never know they’re watching you...you’ll never even see
column5: his voice is drowned out by a landscape of computer sounds
column6: not unlike the ones featured in Laura Poitras' film about Snowden
column7: Citizenfour. As the album’s final track
column8: it serves as an almost cheerful acquiescence to the grand scariness of the surveillance state
column9: in favor of ruminating on less dizzying concerns. For ""Yearning Mississippi
column10: he explored ethnomusicologist Alan Lomax’s Cultural Equity Archive and sampled prison songs from Mississippi. This is an interesting detail
column11: but it would be impossible to notice on its own
column12: making the potential critique of the prison system miss its mark.

column1: Overall
column2: Smoke still gets over on his ability to craft rich
column3: moody soundscapes
column4: although almost all the tracks on the album would have worked better as standalone instrumentals. Unlike his last project
column5: Wraetlic
column6: a woefully dreary and depressive piece
column7:
Love Over Will projects a hopeful sense of growth for Smoke. The sadness here is somehow more buoyant and more comforting. It leaves a kernel of warmth on otherwise very cold days.

column1: Despite this
column2: you could never call Islah (named after Gates' eldest daughter
column3: who often appears on camera with Gates in the rapper's Instagram videos) mournful or depressing. Like any street rapper determined to survive the late-'00s rap-album-budget implosion intact
column4: Kevin Gates has become his own best hook singer
column5: his best songwriter
column6: and the best (and usually only) rapper on his songs. On Islah
column7: his hook-writing is sterling. The chorus of mid-album track ""Time for That"" has the rhythmic playfulness of Jeremih's ""Pass Dat
column8: while ""2 Phones
column9: in which Gates struggles with the mobile-phone implications of the ""keep your business and family completely separated"" Crack Commandment
column10: is deliriously good
column11: the sort of hook you plunk down in front of an A&R rep and immediately collect house-down-payment money. But it's all Gates.

column1: His emotional appeal
column2: along with his ear for affecting melodies
column3: makes him an odd sort of crossover star. His music has everything hardcore rap fans look for—emotional immediacy
column4: a compelling voice
column5: unimpeachable integrity—but he lacks some things that can reliably be counted on to draw in interested outsiders: a novel style
column6: a flashy or ""weird"" persona. Gates is weird
column7: yes
column8: but not the kind brands typically attach themselves to. Imagine the chipper associate social media manager trying to build a ""strategy"" around Gates' famous admission that he discovered he was accidentally sleeping with his cousin
column9: and feel a twinge of pity and horror.

column1: And yet when you listen to the sure-to-be upcoming single ""Hard For
column2: you start to see it: The unlikely but powerful Gates fan coalition. The song is tremendously unusual—with its acoustic guitar backing and chorus chant ""you’re the only one that my dick’ll get hard for
column3: it’s practically an Uncle Kracker song about erectile dysfunction. But it’s also improbably beautiful: The second line of that couplet is ""I’m confused
column4: what the fuck you want my heart for?""
column5: a line that cuts painfully to the core of heartbroken post-relationship confusion. This is the humanity that brings out the best in Gates: His music paints a picture where life is messy
column6: where close friends cross uncrossable lines all the time. Out of love and out of a healthy appreciation for the workings of karma
column7:
you massage your temples and forgive them.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/22822/homepage_large.24d29923.jpg|Big Black Coat|2229.0|Junior Boys|['Rock'
column3: Ontario-based duo Junior Boys have released consistently stellar
column4: deeply personal records
column5: balanced perfectly between the body and the mind. In the five years since their excellent fourth studio album
column6: It's All True
column7: they've moved past the introverted electro-pop of their previous records into territory that feels both fresh and pointedly familiar. On Big Black Coat
column8: you hear some mid-era Kraftwerk
column9: a big debt to Detroit techno
column10: that sweet spot in the mid-'70s when krautrock met disco
column11: several of Arthur Russell's many house aliases
column12: and even Prince circa Controversy. It's an impressive juggling act
column13: and most importantly
column14: it never lapses into pastiche or boredom
column15: wearing its influences squarely on its sleeve while standing as one of the highlights of Junior Boys' discography.

column1: The album is purposefully sexy
column2: but never orgiastic: Like actual
column3: real sex
column4: it's a mix of abandon and introspection. When frontman Jeremy Greenspan sings ""C'mon Baby
column5: it's a plea
column6: a supplication
column7: not a wanton come-on. On ""No One's Business
column8: the line ""When I kiss you/ I'm on fire"" sounds as painful as it does lustful. The ultra-warm synth stabs of album opener ""You Say That"" offers a cocooned sense of security
column9: paired with the kind of driving cymbals you feel in your legs before your ears. But  the song ends abruptly with Greenspan hacking a cough into the mic
column10: as if he's just taken this new
column11: dancier version of himself to its absolute limit. It's funny
column12: irreverent
column13: and refreshingly self-aware: In other words
column14: it's pure Junior Boys.

column1: A handful of tracks even delve boldly into techno
column2: like the epic ""What You Won't Do for Love
column3: Greenspan's understated falsetto bubbling up from beneath a sea of arpeggiated tones. Follow-up ""And It's Forever"" would fit perfectly in a comedown house set
column4: down to its repetitive vocal edit and pulsating bassline. It sort of sounds like if your friends tried to take you to the club after a breakup
column5: but you cancelled on them last minute and spent the night cruising Discogs for old vinyl.

column1: On the title track and closer
column2: they sum up both where they've been and where they're going. It's a sprawling melting pot of a song
column3: and you can hear techno
column4: house music
column5: bedroom pop
column6: IDM
column7: disco
column8: and more
column9: all packaged smartly into seven minutes. It's impressive and frankly unusual to see a band five albums into their career experiment with new sounds and actually make it work
column10:
but Junior Boys have pulled it off. Career longevity looks good on them.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/22861/homepage_large.a0717fdd.jpg|Stand Up and Speak|33491.0|DJDS|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Loma Vista']|2016-02-04 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 16:01:49.938653|"

The first album Jerome LOL and Samo Sound Boy made together
column2: 2014’s Friend of Mine (released under the name DJ Dodger Stadium)
column3: so perfectly replicated not only the sound of vintage house and techno but its particular melancholy-tinged
column4: ecstatic mood that they probably could have passed it off as a long-lost classic if they’d felt like it. So it’s commendable that on their second album
column5: the duo (now going by the slightly less confusing moniker DJDS) decided to chuck the proven formula and try something new.

column1: For Stand Up and Speak
column2: the pair have rethought nearly every aspect of their collaboration
column3: from the overall sonic identity all the way down to the way it was recorded. Instead of mining old records for samples like they did so effectively on Friend
column4: they created nearly every element on Speak from scratch
column5: going as far as hiring vocalists off Craigslist and recording live instruments.

column1: Leaning on organic sounds and performances that aren’t computer-controlled gives the album a warmer feel throughout. The streaks of heartbrokenness that ran through Friend have mostly been scrubbed away and replaced by a more uplifting mood. There’s a hint of sadness in the chopped-up vocal melody that ""In the Flames"" revolves around
column2: but it’s more than sufficiently offset by the nimble
column3: burbling bassline behind it. The penultimate track ""I Don’t Love You"" is as much of a breakup anthem as the title suggests
column4: but it’s less the ""wallow in your own misery"" type and more the ""get out to the club and dance it off"" kind
column5: building over its succinct three-and-a-half minutes to an emotional and sonic climax that’s downright triumphal.

column1: The pair also seem to have shifted their influences from club culture’s earliest
column2: most underground days to the period shortly thereafter where it first began to make inroads into the pop mainstream—less Paradise Garage and more ""Club MTV."" References to late-'80s/early-'90s club pop and vocal house abound. Sometimes it’s explicit
column3: like the vocal loop
column4: syncopated synth-tambourine
column5: and brightly digital-sounding piano riff that underpin the hooky ""You Don’t Have to Be Alone."" Sometimes it’s more subtle
column6: just a touch of breakbeat on the snare parts and a hint of the same exultant mood that groups from Deee-Lite to Black Box rode to surprising crossover success.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: the pair’s willingness to mess with a proven formula doesn’t translate into a more satisfying experience. For every ""You Don’t Have to Be Alone' or ""I Don’t Love You""—instantly memorable anthems that pretty much every type of dance DJ could find room for in their sets—Speak offers one or two tracks that just don’t generate a spark. And unlike Friend
column3: which still stands up as a solid front-to-back listen
column4: their use and reuse of the same few production techniques—most noticeably two-bar vocal loops and snare rolls—gives the album the feel of a couple great singles packaged with the half-baked demos that led up to their creation. Speak isn’t exactly a step forward or a step back
column5: but more to the side
column6: onto a new path with plenty of potential
column7:
as well as room for future improvements.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/22774/homepage_large.f782e249.jpg|SeeFu Lilac|5277.0|Black Moth Super Rainbow|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rad Cult']|2016-02-04 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 16:01:50.659361|"

For an artist
column2: consistency is a murky indicator of success. What looks like the honing of craft and technique via repetition can easily be confused for homogeneity and a Clive Cussler-esque predictability. You run the risk of being trapped on an artistic treadmill if you don't decide to throw some of your old tricks in the garbage. And it's awfully hard. But in all arts
column3: be it writing
column4: or the making of psychedelic pop music
column5: sometimes you have to kill all your darlings.

column1: Last time we saw Black Moth Super Rainbow it was 2012
column2: and they were riding high off the spoils of Kickstarter booty and an album that was an index for how far they had come. In Cobra Juicy
column3: Tom Fec and his merry band of freaks seemed to have finally revealed the intimations of a more mature musical project. Fast forward to November of last year: With no sixth album in sight
column4: Black Moth Super Rainbow decided to unload
column5: in their own words
column6: ""neon flavored outtakes from a 6th album that doesn't yet exist."" SeeFu Lilac is just that
column7: outtakes and fragments
column8: musical ephemera at best
column9: perfectly suited for the rabid BMSR fanbase but not much else.

column1: Clocking in at a scant 19 minutes
column2: SeeFu Lilac is a collection of nine songs which slavishly adhere to the sounds and tropes which made BMSR famous in the first place. The ubiquitous vocoder vocals and the patina of vintage synths are all here
column3: along with the same self-satisfied
column4: isolationist nostalgia
column5: which to some paints BMSR as refreshingly authentic and to others gimmicky cranks who haven't listened to an album made after the year 1993. When the band released a stream of the record on Facebook
column6: they proudly rallied against trendiness or marketability
column7: proclaiming ""no glam shots
column8: no press releases
column9: no problem.""

column1: The one thing that separates SeeFu Lilac from previous BMSR efforts is the noticeable change in disposition. The record as a whole feels sunnier and the nostalgia is less sinister and somehow saccharine. Gone is the seething pop evil that coated Cobra Juicy. Instead of toeing the line between beautiful and grotesque
column2: in these sketches of songs BMSR is trying to sound more subdued and much prettier. Seefu Lilac's most exciting moments come in small instrumental bursts that are calming and melodic. In the album's title track
column3: a ruminative acoustic guitar is put in conversation with a wall of warm synths
column4: and the result is nicely organic and effortless. It gives a hint of the sound BMSR might want to work with in future records.

column1: They benefit from uncluttering their music and removing the fading drapery of distorted effects and wonky inversions
column2: because it showcases what made BMSR so interesting earlier in the 2000s: vintage gear and earnest analog sentimentalism. But this sentimentalism is the very reason why this record is so uninteresting: It's a love letter to their previous work.

column1: I wonder if Fec should toss the vocoder aside. The same suite of effects used to achieve the throaty and warbled vocals hasn't changed at all since Dandelion Gum. At this point
column2: it wouldn't be unfair to say that it's become a gimmick
column3: especially when deployed to tackle subjects like love or loss. The vocoder flattens and parodies whatever emotions a song might be meditating on. In ""Since You've Seen Her
column4: it's hard to take Fec seriously as he sadly croons ""make a wish"" over and over again.

column1: In a recent interview addressing the album
column2: Fec said that he thought a lot of contemporary music felt ""so desperate."" He made sure to backtrack and soften this statement
column3: saying that: ""Maybe I am kind of a recluse
column4: and maybe..I don't have the greatest perspectives of everything."" Fec has painted himself as an outsider for years
column5: and it's not surprising that he finds so much of music just outside his lair unrelatable; you can hear it in the music he makes. It's the product of living in an echo chamber and not paying attention to the changes in both DIY and synth-driven music in the last four years. Fec has admitted to a certain amount of frustration with the sixth proper BMSR album
column6: and the release of SeeFu Lilac is music he ""needed to get out of [his] head"" because it didn't fit in where he was going artistically. Hopefully Fec and friends have exorcised their nagging demons with SeeFu Lilac
column7:
and move forward into something very different.

"|21464.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21464-seefu-lilac/|5.5|Kevin Lozano

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/22793/homepage_large.59767ba0.jpg|Scheherazade|1553.0|Freakwater|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Bloodshot']|2016-02-04 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 16:01:51.190653|"

When Freakwater made their first recordings in the late '80s
column2: they set a template that would serve them well for the next 27 years: a darkly austere country sound rooted in the sisterly harmonies of Catherine Irwin and Janet Beveridge Bean. Making good use of a minimal backing band—often just their own guitars and an upright bass
column3: with flourishes of pedal steel and electric guitar—they updated the downcast vocals of the Carter Family and wrote songs set in some alternate-reality American past. It seemed like there was a ghost or a corpse on every album. Freakwater had a simple
column4: yet powerful palette to match the Appalachian gothic tone
column5: and that combination has kept the band alive and relevant even as many of their alt-country peers have fallen by the wayside. Their best albums—especially 1995’s Old Paint—sound less like products of a particular scene and more like the sepia-toned recordings of eccentric artists dislocated from history.

column1: Even when they’ve put a full decade between albums
column2: Bean and Irwin have never strayed far from their recognizable sound or their bleak subject matter. But on Scheherazade
column3: their eighth album overall and their first since 2005
column4: they overhaul it dramatically: For the first time since they recorded demos in the Bean's parents’ basement
column5: they ventured out of Chicago and recorded in Louisville
column6: the city with which the band has long been identified. They also recruited a slew of Northern Kentucky musicians
column7: including Sarah Balliet from Murder by Death
column8: Morgan Geer form Drunken Prayer
column9: and Evan Patterson of Young Widows. Noted Louisville resident Will Oldham doesn’t show up
column10: disproving my theory that he is required by law to play on every local release. On the other hand
column11: Warren Ellis of the Dirty Three and the Bad Seeds does play violin and flute.

column1: It’s the largest cast and crew they’ve assembled under the Freakwater banner
column2: and as a result
column3: Scheherazade sounds fuller and looser
column4: a bit rougher around the edges
column5: with more rock in the arrangements. It’s their most cinematic album yet
column6: with the music functioning almost as a soundtrack to Irwin and Bean’s short
column7: violent songs. On the very first song
column8: ""What the People Want
column9: somebody throws a baby down a well
column10: accompanied by tense swirls of strings. On ""Down Will Come Baby
column11: they rewrite the old
column12: twisted lullaby ""Rock-a-bye Baby
column13: and the band navigates a series of key changes that lends a vertiginous effect
column14: as though the cradle is in freefall.

column1: The presence of so many imperiled infants on Scheherazade is oddly reassuring
column2: a nice reminder that this is a Freakwater album after all. The tight harmonies that marked their previous efforts here come slightly unraveled; they sing against each other as often as with each other. These are some of their most visceral performances
column3: as rough-hewn on quiet numbers like ""Ghost Song"" as one heavier numbers like ""Take Me With You
column4: which features roof-raising hollers by Bean. There’s something invigorating about hearing two alt-country veterans take apart their tried-and-true sound and reassemble it slightly askew
column5:
and Scheherazade is not only their most modern-sounding record; it might be their best since Old Paint.

"|21484.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21484-scheherazade/|7.5|Stephen M. Deusner

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/22809/homepage_large.47acae31.jpg|Still in a Dream: A Story of Shoegaze 1988-1995|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Cherry Red']|2016-02-03 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 16:01:51.714601|"

Like band names
column2: genre terms usually lose their literal meaning once they get established. Just as the corny reference of ""My Bloody Valentine"" was wiped away by the band’s might and majesty
column3: ""shoegaze"" became a phonetically evocative word—those oozy vowels and soft sibilants—that suited the blurry sound. The literal meaning—and the fact that it was initially intended as a derisive term— disappeared.

column1: The compressed accusation in ""shoegaze""—coined by someone at NME
column2: a music paper less supportive of the genre than its rival Melody Maker—is that these were bands too bashful to meet the audience’s eyes. Unlike the attention-seeking egos that typically front British bands
column3: the shoegazers were self-effacing
column4: hiding behind their hair and glancing down at the array of effects pedals at their feet. Shoegazers were insufficiently invested in the performative aspects of rock: the genre was all about sound
column5: not show.

column1: Despite starting as a slur
column2: ""shoegaze"" fit the genre like a glove and soon supplanted the competing descriptors. ""Dreampop
column3: an invention of A.R. Kane’s
column4: enjoyed small and short-lived currency in the U.S. The other contender was The Scene That Celebrates Itself
column5: coined by a Melody Maker editor. A tautology
column6: of course—show me a Scene That Denigrates Itself—but it did convey the incestuous vibe of the early movement. Most of the bands knew each other and fraternized
column7: and they generally hailed from the Thames Valley (London
column8: Reading
column9: Oxford).

column1: Remembering shoegaze’s other name made me think of Brian Eno’s ""scenius"" concept: the idea that music evolves through collective processes
column2: in an incremental and reactive way
column3: rather than through heroic innovators making giant steps that everyone else follows. A sound emerges and everyone wants in; the style—usually a mixture of new technological possibilities and aesthetic choices—becomes the idiom through which you express what you have to say. Like all languages
column4: the style stipulates and restricts possibilities as much as it creates them.

column1: The first few discs of Still in a Dream
column2: a new 5xCD box from Cherry Red
column3: make a good argument in favor of scenius. Picking almost randomly
column4: one example of the perfectly generic here is Pale Saints' ""Sight of You."" It is not ur-shoegaze (that would be MBV’s ""You Made Me Realise"")
column5: but it is echt-shoegaze. The name Pale Saints vaguely gestures at the Pre-Raphaelites and mystic devotion; the song title proposes love as a rapture of the gaze rather than a fever of the flesh; the sound is choirboy-pure vocals and guitar that works as a billowing curtain of texture rather than propulsive riff. Two other absolutely typical
column6: absolutely lovely specimens of shoegaze here are Lush’s ""De-Luxe"" (like being buffeted by flower petals in a wind-tunnel) and Slowdive’s ""Slowdive
column7: where the slightest of chord sequences ripples the silvery guitar wooze. Where the genre’s progenitors My Bloody Valentine—mystifyingly absent from the box despite providing its title—churned with dizzy-making desire
column8: the effect with second-wave shoegaze tends to be more virginal. Slowdive certainly emit none of the dark erotic energy of the Siouxsie and the Banshees song from which they took their name.

column1: Along with ""scenius
column2: another Eno thought sprang to mind when listening through the box: Eno hailed MBV’s ""Soon"" as ""the vaguest music ever to have been a hit."" That got me musing: why would ""vague"" be a good thing for music to be? How would you distinguish between the deliberately indistinct and the merely insubstantial? And how does this sonic vagueness relate to life?

column1: Shoegaze’s nebulousness has to do with its slightly ""off"" relation with both rock and pop. The genre fetishizes the sound of the guitar
column2: but is relatively uninterested in the other things that guitars have traditionally done—riffs
column3: solos
column4: grooving. Shoegaze introduced a new generation of guitar heroes who weren’t dramatic. Rather than the spotlight of a solo
column5: there would be a mid-song caesura of abstract carnage. The heroism took the form of explorations into texture. Kevin Shields was the scene's Hendrix figure
column6: but the contrast between Jimi the showman and Shields the shy man is telling. No guitar-face or swaggering about the stage. The music was designed to overwhelm in the live context
column7: but in a way that was impersonal—as though the band were victims of the sound as much as the audience
column8: or simply conduits for the torrential noise.

column1: What also made shoegaze such an indeterminate proposition as regards proper rock and proper pop was the way it used rhythm and the voice. It’s tempting to say that this is a genre consisting of non-drummers and non-singers. Certainly
column2: re-listening to Ride’s ""Drive Blind"" was a bit of a shocker: how did a group get so big with such a shaky voice upfront
column3: with a drummer that could barely hold a beat? But mostly the subdued rhythm and buried vocals was a deliberate aesthetic choice rather than a matter of deficiency. Voices were mixed to be half-obscured by the blizzard of sound; the rhythm section just about kept up with the guitar tumult. Shoegaze was as not-quite-pop as it was not-quite-rock. The melodies harked back beguilingly to a hazy
column4: half-remembered '60s
column5: but had little to do with what '80s chart-pop considered ""a tune."" Shoegaze’s brief stint as the reigning alternative sound in the UK was ended by Britpop
column6: and it’s the emphasis on ""pop"" there that is significant. Groups like Oasis and Blur mixed the voice upfront and above the instrumentation; songs acquired anthemic choruses; singers got cocky and in-your-face.

column1: Shoegaze
column2: in contrast
column3: made a fetish of the swoon. The sighing vocals
column4: the sickly drooping drones and melodic descents
column5: the wavery timbres—these signature sonic effects induced listener responses like rolling your eyes back in your head or swaying slightly as if about to faint. The feeling transmitted by shoegaze at its most compelling combined surging urgency and heavy-lidded languor. It suggested threshold states: drowsily slipping into a nap in the mid-afternoon
column6: not being able to shake off the dream in the morning. The connective thread with all these sensations is the relinquishing of control
column7: the scary bliss of losing orientation and agency.

column1: I don’t think it’s too much of a reach to imagine that this had some kind of semi-conscious resonance for a generation that felt powerless. It’s quite hard to reconstruct how bleak things seemed in the late '80s and early '90s; in both Britain and America
column2: conservative governments were in third-term ascendance
column3: and mainstream popular culture from hair metal to Hollywood seemed be in sync with the rightward shift. For many—not all
column4: but many—this encouraged resignation
column5: a withdrawal verging on hibernation. That’s why American nu-punks L7 wrote their anti-slacker anthem ""Pretend We’re Dead"" as a wake-up call from apathy. That’s why Welsh nu-punks Manic Street Preachers declared that they hated Slowdive more than Hitler—for being so dreamily disengaged
column6: advocates for reverie rather than revolution.

column1: This anti-politics of vagueness comes through clearly on one of Still in a Dream’s more unusual and surprising inclusions
column2: a lost classic that I would never have filed under shoegaze: AC Marias’s ""One of Our Girls Has Gone Missing."" AC is Angela Conway
column3: an associate of Wire (whose Bruce Gilbert was involved in the sculpted-snow sound of ""One of Our Girls
column4: which ought to thrill anyone who loves Chairs Missing and 154.) Drawing on the John le Carré genre of ice-hearted espionage fiction and the idea of the agent who goes AWOL
column5: Conway’s lyric imagines a strategy of dissidence through disappearance:""“She has lost her color/ And faded away/ Moved into thin air.""

column1: As a frontline journalist covering much of this music at the time
column2: I recall that the '60s allegiances of shoegaze seemed obvious and paramount. They were harking back longingly to the '60s as a refusal of the '80s—the decade of Thatcher and Reagan. But that necessarily meant a return of '60s sounds without any of the hope or confident dynamism of that decade; change would not be coming
column3: change in fact was being reversed. That’s one reason why the word ""dream"" was so emblematic of the era (Sonic Youth's Daydream Nation being only the most conspicuous example). Rather than turn dreams into reality
column4: now it was more like dreaming your life away
column5: assisted by recorded relics from that lost time. Rather than ""we want the world and we want it now"" (the Doors) or even ""we’re all normal and we want our freedom"" (Love)
column6: the spirit was crestfallen and crushed: ""There’s a place I’d like to be/ There’s a place I’d be happy"" (Galaxie 500’s ""Tugboat"")
column7: or the murmured
column8: barely audible ""much rather be"" in ""All Different Things"" by Bark Psychosis.

column1: Listening today
column2: though
column3: the '60s-ness of shoegaze recedes to a surprising degree. Especially on the first disc—which includes shoegaze-spawning but not-really-shoegaze greats like Cocteau Twins
column4: the House of Love
column5: A.R. Kane—I don’t hear the Byrds or Velvets
column6: I hear the glassy textures of John McGeoch
column7: Vini Reilly
column8: or Clive Timperley of the Passions (the glorious glistening echoplexed intro to ""I’m in Love With a German Film Star""). Yes
column9: the ""ba ba-ba-ba ba"" bit in ""Christine"" by the House of Love harks back to '60s pop of the Turtles type
column10: but Terry Bickers' crystalline cascades are totally modern in their moment.

column1: In other shoegaze groups
column2: a surprisingly large amount of New Order and the Cure is discernible: the processional glide-rhythms
column3: the high-toned droning basslines. Despite being swathed in prismatic guitar-miasma
column4: Kitchens of Distinction sound like Modern English more than anything on ""3rd Time We Opened the Capsule."" Even with the overtly classicist outfits like Spacemen 3
column5: for all the signposted allusions to the Velvets
column6: Beach Boys
column7: Stooges
column8: and their refusal of '80s tropes (gated drums
column9: Yamaha DX7 synth—i.e. the very things that groups like Haim now deliberately redeploy)
column10: a record like ""Hypnotized"" could only have been made at that particular time. If you placed it alongside records actually made in the '60s
column11: it would jut out jarringly.

column1: Still in a Dream takes a wide trawl approach to its genre
column2: which has upsides and downsides. The stricture of only one track per artist means that the inessential gets inevitably over-represented and the defining greats get short-changed and effectively demoted. A five-disc box set of shoegaze organized around quality and innovation as criteria would be about 1/3 My Bloody Valentine. As with Rhino’s goth box A Life Less Lived
column3: shoegaze is generously interpreted to include antecedents and formative influences
column4: which bulks up the quality. After that you get the influenced: the second and third waves
column5: as well as fellow travelers (Cranes)
column6: outliers (Mercury Rev)
column7: and offshoots (Seefeel). Shrewdly
column8: the compilers cut off in '95
column9: and don’t attempt to corral any of the shoegaze homages or revivalists of the last 20 years.

column1: I had a great time with the first disc (late '80s)
column2: a good time with the second and much of the third (lovely to remake the acquaintance of Moose and the muscular Swervedriver
column3: who had a bit of Thin Lizzy in their make-up)
column4: but by the fourth
column5: the trip down memory lane took on a purgatorial aspect. ""More of the same
column6: only slightly different"" is good up to a point
column7: but with any genre you can have too much of a good thing. Although primarily a UK genre—and in some way reflective of British character traits like diffidence—the Americans did join in: sometimes inventively warping the MBV blueprint (the blow-torched beauty of Medicine’s ""Aruca"") and other times cloning it (Swirlies). You can always quibble about choices (why ""Rollercoaster"" as opposed to two dozen other Jesus and Mary Chain candidates?!). But overall Still in a Dream is a job well done: an accurate portrait of an era that
column8: while it can’t really be described as a lost golden age for rock
column9:
nonetheless provided sorely needed radiance and refuge during a particularly grim period.

column1: As he showed us in ""Marvin Gaye

column7: pleasantly
column8: Ryan Tedder-er (""My Gospel"" is a nicely rumbling One Republic facsimile)

Much of Atlanta rapper 2 Chainz's appeal comes from the specific

column3: his ability to string together zippy comic punchlines and elaborate boasts in quick succession. He is most effective making phrasing and imagery work for him in tandem (think quips like ""Might valet park a Brinks truck"" or ""Got a pocket full of dead prez/ Attached to your girl like a .jpeg""). His recent releases have struggled to duplicate the formula

column1: At just about 20 minutes

column5: woozy synth progression

In 2011
column2: KING's debut EP came out of nowhere to almost-immediate acclaim: Prince
column3: Roots bandleader ?uestlove
column4: and Foreign Exchange frontman Phonte Coleman all praised the group's talent
column5: and rapper Kendrick Lamar sampled ""Hey
column6: arguably KING's best song
column7: for Section.80 track ""Chapter Six."" The group worked with singer Bilal for a song on his 2013 album
column8: A Love Surreal
column9: and with jazz pianist Robert Glasper
column10: on his Black Radio LP. By 2014
column11: at the FYF Fest in Los Angeles
column12: the singers covered Nina Simone's ""To Be Young
column13: Gifted and Black"" alongside Devonté Hynes
column14: Moses Sumney
column15: and Solange. The trio—comprised of Anita Bias and twins Paris and Amber Strother—has seen its stock rise significantly
column16: although it didn't have a lot of music to speak of. Their EP had only three tracks—three wonderful tracks—but a short playlist nonetheless. Behind singles ""In the Meantime"" and ""Mister Chameleon
column17: KING was set to release its long-awaited first LP in 2014
column18: but the year came and went without a full-length project. So there's plenty of interest in We Are KING
column19: even if the singers are just on the periphery of larger mainstream circles.

column1: Fusing dream pop and R&B
column2: KING floats through its debut album
column3: making easy atmospheric blends akin to Sade and Janet Jackson. We Are KING is rich and transformative
column4: centered on hazy mid-tempo grooves that calmly evoke a surreal ambience. KING harkens back to a time when there were clearer distinctions between R&B
column5: pop
column6: and hip-hop
column7: when acts like Jodeci and SWV ruled the airwaves
column8: and the music was lighter and more sensuous. We Are KING recalls the best of that era without completely rehashing it. These sounds are remarkably modern
column9: yet as it plays
column10: you find yourself thinking of simpler times—that homecoming dance or first kiss—as the singers keep their voices supplanted in the backdrop. This isn't an LP of long runs or over-the-top vocal solos. It's a light touch
column11: built to establish a meditative mood. On ""Love Song
column12: for instance
column13: the vocalists hum softly without their words taking shape. The compositions are equally vital
column14: and throughout the album
column15: KING does a stellar job of letting the music breathe for its roughly 60-minute runtime.

column1: Over its 12 tracks
column2: We Are KING slowly reveals itself through sweet one-liners that waft in from distant places
column3: like on ""Supernatural
column4: one of three holdovers from the group's EP. After a brief intro of scenic wails
column5: the song becomes a synthesized ode to puppy love: ""There's magic in everything you do… I'm in love with everything 'bout you."" We Are KING entices us to get away from the mundane
column6: to spend time in grand spaces without smartphones and social media. Among other things
column7: Paris
column8: Amber
column9: and Anita want you to reconnect with real people on real levels
column10: to study their nuances and embrace their intricacies. They'd rather you appreciate what's in front of you
column11: not the artificial world just beyond your passcode. ""Red Eye
column12: a transitional cut near the album's beginning
column13: is about pushing beyond your comfort zone. ""Native Land
column14: the album's closing track
column15: envisions a grand journey to remote shores.

column1: At times
column2: the singers address worldly
column3: more grounded issues
column4: stuff we can all relate to. ""Mister Chameleon"" is a tale of smoke and mirrors
column5: of falling in love with a person you thought you knew. ""Oh
column6: Please!"" depicts a romantic chase: It's the album's most overt display of personality
column7: and the lyrics are more pronounced. As a whole
column8: We Are KING is seamless: It properly showcases the group's breezy aesthetic and has the feel-good creativity of black music's great luminaries. Sure it took some time to get here
column9: but unhurried art has its own special rewards. We Are KING has long-lasting impact
column10:
much like the music it emulates.

Underground rap suffered a bad patch for awhile there in the mid-'00s. It was hard to have fun listening to music that didn’t even sound like it was remotely fun to make
column2: and so much of it felt like attending a lecture that you immediately knew you didn’t want to be at. Besides
column3: it’s an insular world
column4: built on obsessive minutiae and indecipherable jokes
column5: and is usually defined by a focus on lyrics over song structure. If you have ever cared about underground rap
column6: you have not only thrown the word ""lyricism"" around with abandon
column7: you’ve also debated what it really means for 27 years of your life
column8: even if you are only 16. It’s a commitment so heavy that it transcends space and time.

column1: In recent years
column2: though
column3: that’s changed. Thank Earl Sweatshirt. Or thank Kendrick Lamar. Or the new generation of ears trained on MF DOOM's every move. Let’s thank Madlib
column4: too
column5: while we’re at it. The perma-stoned Oxnard producer has been tirelessly working with obscure samples for years
column6: pushing them away from their source material so they take on strange new lives. He’s been a guiding light for a whole new wave of rappers and producers
column7: directly and indirectly helping them shake off the arbitrary rules of a genre that thrives on breaking them.

column1: Enter Chester Watson
column2: a Florida teenager who sits so comfortably and skillfully amongst his influences that he already feels like their peer. His latest release
column3: <i>Past Cloaks
column4: from a new label called POW Records—a project of Pitchfork contributor Jeff Weiss—is an actual cassette
column5: which means that the more you play it
column6: the more it’ll degrade
column7: before eventually breaking down entirely.

column1: But you’ll probably stream this somewhere—I’m streaming it right now—and the beauty is that you don’t lose much of the crust and murk when you listen to it digitally. That’s largely thanks to the production: a hodgepodge of repurposed beats
column2: some done by Watson himself
column3: and some done by a crew of in-house producers like Psymun
column4: Art Vandelay
column5: DRWN
column6: and a bunch more. They’re all working within similar parameters: cracked psychedelia
column7: off-kilter weirdness
column8: and a dedication to a lifestyle with time built in for Saturday morning cartoons
column9: cereal
column10: and pontificating about the world through blunt smoke.

column1: Past Cloaks is
column2: in a way
column3: a very necessary compilation tape. True to underground rap fashion
column4: Watson’s discography is already daunting
column5: but by pulling together material he’s recorded over the past few years—unreleased or otherwise—he’s dialed in on the mythology that he’s been building
column6: focusing it in an unexpectedly breezy 19-track sequence that pulls warbly samples from damaged-beyond-repair records and snatches of TV dialogue
column7: flipping them into compositions that fit together like melted puzzle pieces.

column1: Watson is a formidable rapper
column2: and wastes no time making sure we know that. On opening track ""Phantom
column3: his blunted voice bounces like a half-deflated basketball over keys that sound like they’re being played through an inch of dust. He’s a stream of consciousness rapper
column4: letting vivid moments emerge and then quickly disappear. The entire tape feels like a casual studio session
column5: with guests occasionally flitting in and out
column6: and Watson holding court next to a stack of paperbacks
column7: rapping about the virtues of getting stoned and seeing the world in sepia. It’s the kind of unbridled creativity that feels somehow untampered with.

column1: Watson’s still in the early stages of what will hopefully be a long career. Which means that sometimes
column2: like on ""Purple Leaves
column3: he sounds so much like Earl Sweatshirt that it’s a little distracting. But he’ll continue to develop
column4: and there’s so much promise and endlessly re-playable material here that even the overly referential stuff is a pleasure to listen to. Besides
column5: Watson could do a lot worse than look to Earl for inspiration—especially when he casually drops lyrical gems like ""sippin' syrup in my room and all my clothes are out."" This is the kind of mundane-yet-telling detail that feels bound to cultivate a loyal fanbase.

column1: Speaking of loyal fanbases: There’s another thing you can do with tapes besides listen to them degrade. You can pass them around. Pocket them. Lend them to people. Make dubs of dubs until the original takes on a near-mystical quality. Past Cloaks isn’t perfect enough to be canonized
column2:
but it’s strong enough to form a small cult around.
