When ""Dopamine"" dropped last year
column2: it spent four minutes breaking nearly four years' worth of promises Zachary Cole Smith had made about DIIV’s sophomore album. There was no remnant of the San Francisco magic Smith hoped to conjure by working with Chet ""J.R"" White. It did not sound like Royal Trux and it definitely did not sound like Elliott Smith. It didn't signal that Smith would follow through on his proposed indictment of guitar-based music’s lack of originality and relevance. It was
column3: however
column4: the most sharply written DIIV song to date
column5: making a promise Is the Is Are actually keeps: While it’s mostly about getting high and it sounds exactly like DIIV
column6: it finds more interesting ways to do both of those things.

column1: Though not the Tago Mago or Tusk-style double album Smith originally planned
column2: Is the Is Are makes unusual demands for an indie rock record. With each of the five singles in its protracted rollout
column3: DIIV confirmed they were making their proprietary sound deeper and more immersive. The revelation of a 17-song tracklist promised scatter and sprawl
column4: like a hybrid of Kiss Me Kiss Me Kiss Me and Disintegration. However
column5: this is more in the spirit of Seventeen Seconds to Pornography:  gray
column6: gloomy textures
column7: depressive fatalism. And like those records
column8: Is the Is Are doesn’t engage in fantasy or open up new worlds—it builds a nearly impenetrable wall around the self. Call it Requiem for a Dream-pop
column9: dedicated to a gorgeous yet unglamorous portrayal of addiction.

column1: DIIV's signature trick is conflating the treadmill momentum of habit with the false hope for escape
column2: and this was about the only trick they had going on Oshin. Written and performed entirely by Smith with every instrument mixed evenly
column3: Oshin relied on its cumulative effect
column4: soft-selling its hooks. Whereas Oshin was meditative and static
column5: ""Dopamine"" and ""Under the Sun"" are transportive and intricate
column6: taking mid-song off-ramps to more interesting vistas. Even ""(Fuck)"" serves its purpose as an 17-second cleanse between the record’s murky midsection and its luminous final stretch. Now functioning as a road-tested
column7: democratic band in the studio
column8: every member of DIIV has to assert himself
column9: and the slightest alteration to their usual sound brings out new features—a brief glimmer of piano cuts through an enveloping humidity on ""Healthy Moon"" similar to early R.E.M.; the jumped-up rhythm of ""Valentine"" is sourced from the Smiths while retaining DIIV’s clenched-teeth tension; Devin Perez’s melodic basslines function as a lead instrument and allows Smith and Andrew Bailey’s guitars to search out more interesting textures and harmonies.

column1: An hour of this ensures there are times where DIIV threaten to become too in love with their own sound
column2: particularly toward the middle. But beyond lending Is the Is Are a necessary heft to back Smith’s claims
column3: these songs are convincing portrayals of checked-out living. We don’t get to find out much about the Roi and Grant to whom ""Bent"" and ""Mire"" are dedicated; DIIV’s obsessive tinkering turns everything outside of Smith into a hall of mirrors
column4: false friends and true loves reflecting back on his own struggles. On ""Bent (Roi's Song)
column5: Smith sighs
column6: ""When it feels right
column7: you just lost the fight
column8: a deflated admission of defeat before ""Dopamine"" echoes the same sentiment with a false sense defiance. ""Mire"" repeats ""I was blind but now I see"" as an epiphany
column9: and Smith immediately regrets awareness thereafter by meeting the ""Incarnate Devil.""

column1: You can make legitimate guesses as to whom that song might be dedicated—scene guys in Brooklyn
column2: drugs themselves
column3: people once in his inner circle? Smith’s measure of quasi-celebrity might give him unfair advantage over his stylistic peers
column4: but it’s an advantage all the same
column5: so when his conversational lyrics feel insular
column6: we at least know who’s having the conversation. Sky Ferreira contributes lead vocal on the exhaust-huffing ""Blue Boredom
column7: deadpanning sing-talk beat poetry that imagines the two as Kim Gordon and Thurston Moore rather than Kurt and Courtney. She’s just as present when DIIV allow themselves fleeting hope on the awestruck ""Under the Sun"" and resignation on the heartbreaking ""Loose Ends""—""Does it feel watered down/ Do you feel older now?"" appears in quotes on the lyrics sheet
column8: implying it’s a talk between people stuck having the same conversation over and over again.

column1: Immediately after ""Loose Ends
column2: Is the Is Are goes on the opposite of a victory lap
column3: trudging toward its finish with no hint of optimism. Penultimate track ""Dust"" has been kicking around since 2013
column4: and the lyric ""I’m fucked to die in a world of shit"" immediately jumped out of their practice space. I expected it to be a placeholder
column5: a sentiment to be expressed more artfully at a later date—unlike his heroes
column6: Smith doesn't allow for humor or irony. But the line remains on ""Dust"" and introduces a hint of nihilistic sarcasm that
column7: along with its title
column8: evokes an unintentional grunge-era classic: Alice in Chains’ Dirt
column9: the most harrowing document of smack-addled myopia to ever sell five million copies
column10: the scariest aspect of which was its narrator’s utter refusal to acknowledge outside help
column11: let alone seek it. And immediately after ""Dust
column12: Smith spends Is the Is Are’s eerie closer warding off interventions with a hopeless mantra: ""It’s no good
column13: it’d be a waste of breath.""

column1: Even if DIIV turns its morose self-indulgence into a virtue
column2: it’s unlikely to change the conversation amongst their detractors: those who see DIIV as an embodiment of everything insular and insufferable about Brooklyn indie rock will probably find that Smith is no more capable of filling his ambitions to be a true generational artist as he is one of his oversized T-shirts. But Smith’s willingness to open himself up to criticism by making statements—fashion
column3: musical
column4: or self-promoting—make discussions of DIIV more divisive and passionate than those surrounding similarly positioned bands like Wild Nothing
column5: the War on Drugs
column6: or Real Estate.

column1: This aspect of DIIV aligns with songs like ""Dopamine
column2: ""Dust
column3: and ""Waste of Breath
column4: ensuring that Is the Is Are hits on a visceral
column5: teenage level similar to that of the Cure or Smashing Pumpkins
column6: bands who were also mercilessly mocked in their day by gatekeepers of cool as both social climbing posers and ""stuck in the terminal malaise of adolescent existentialism."" It’s the same immediacy that inspires thousands of high schoolers to rock Unknown Pleasures and Nirvana T-shirts as well
column7: even if they might not understand their cultural impact. But they relate to the disillusion
column8: doubt
column9: and confusion of a compelling
column10:
controversial frontperson because those things never go out of style.

Early success has its perks and its drawbacks. Since the Toronto duo Majid Jordan wrote and and co-produced Drake's ""Hold On
column3: We're Going Home
column4: they've seen every new song and video of theirs given the same treatment as if it were new material from the 6 God himself. The co-sign led to a major-label signing and an eager
column5: supportive audience for their self-titled debut album. But it also means that Majid Jordan are immovably situated in Drake's shadow
column6: and their self-titled debut doesn't really serve to extricate them.

column1: Majid Al Maskati and Jordan Ullman (the group's singer and producer
column2: respectively) aren't run-of-the-mill Drake copycats by any means: They're pop enthusiasts
column3: first and foremost. Witness the synth pads on ""Hold On
column4: We're Coming Home
column5: which were cheesy and irresistible enough for us to take Drake's desire for ""hot love and emotion"" seriously. This sense of fun is often missing on their solo material
column6: where they too often experiment with darker
column7: self-consciously deeper sounds that fall flat. 2014's A Place Like This EP begins at breakneck speed before devolving into easily ignorable background music. Majid Jordan
column8: likewise
column9: mixes brisk pop efforts with moody cuts that blur together.

Listening to them reconfigure tracks by Roxy Music and the Pet Shop Boys—and somehow making an overly covered song like Leonard Cohen's ""Suzanne"" sound weirdly alien—only proved how much Field Music operate on their own strange frequency. At their best
column5: the experience of listening to Field Music is akin to moving into a beautifully designed house in which there are no right angles—everything just slightly and perfectly off.

column5: elegant

column8: harmonize the brothers. ""Why don't you go to bed like everybody else? Why don't you grow old like everybody else?"" The album's 14 tracks function like bits of shared conversation
column9: the brothers' interweaving voices shedding some of the obtuseness of earlier releases in favor of songs that openly address the perils of the everyday—the often mundane nature of relationships

column4: ""The Morning Is Waiting

column7: ""This is as close to perfect as we were wishing for.""

column2: Commontime rarely feels overstuffed or
column3: as was often the case on previous Field Music releases
column4: busy to the point of sounding incoherent. Instead
column5: the album balances the Brewis brothers' predilection for unusual song structures and unconventional instrumentation with a decidedly grown up narrative. It's a kind of album-length conversation best summed up in the record's final track
column6: ""Stay Awake

days away / And I'm sorry if I'm ever short with you / I don't mean it / It's a good job that you know me so well.""

But Jream House doesn't sound like that at all; it turns out to be a euphoric trip that doesn’t shy away from more direct types of gratification.

column9: ""Nike swoosh on bare feet/ Whitney Houston’s crack pipe/ The greatest love of all/ Watch me rise to watch me fall."" He evokes an image of poverty-stricken neighborhoods before settling on a somewhat tired metaphor of ""hacking"" into and disrupting societal disparities as Warpaint vocalist Emily Kokal accompanies him.

column1: MartyrLoserKing may be a call to 21st-century activism
column2: but it also seems anachronistic. Williams’ vision of the Internet as a kind of new frontier resembles a scene from The Matrix
column3: and Warfield’s serrated industrialism is pure '90s. We now know that technology enables our capitalist lusts
column4: and our desire to have every ethnic and gender variation reflected in our culture is often reduced to a mere call for better customer service. Despite his occasionally dazzling wordplay
column5:
Williams doesn’t offer a solution for how we can evolve beyond our own inherent narcissism. He’s too optimistic for that.

column2:
'Outsiders']|2016-02-01 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 16:02:00.314633|"

You’ve seen plenty of press photos like Lion Babe’s over the last few years: A glamorous singer
column3: eyes locked on the camera as she shares the frame with an unassuming
column4: narrow-shouldered guy who doesn’t look like he talks very much. Even if you’re only fleetingly familiar with acts like AlunaGeorge or Quadron
column5: you probably have a good sense of what to expect from this kind of singer/producer pairing: posh
column6: slightly left-field R&B with one foot in the past and the other in future. And sure enough
column7: that’s more or less what Lion Babe deliver—except that compared to their similarly styled peers
column8:
their sound isn’t actually all that left-field at all.

On their debut album Begin
column9: singer Jillian Hervey (the daughter of actress Vanessa Williams) and producer Lucas Goodman (who records under the deceptively Def Jux-y sounding nom de plume Astro Raw) shuffle between disco
column10: house
column11: and neo-soul. And while they update these styles with the airy
column12: wide-open production aesthetic of modern alternative R&B
column13: their songs are rooted squarely in pop. There are no experimental digressions that might alienate the dance floor
column14:
no nods to the salad days of Brainfeeder or Ice Cream Records simply for the sake of bolstering the duo’s music-nerd cred. Lion Babe aren’t after cred. They’re after hits.

So far they don’t have those hits
column15: of course
column16: but they’ve come up with enough passable facsimiles to fill a pretty likeable album. ""Wonder Woman
column17: an anti-cat calling song produced by Pharrell (his atonement
column18: perhaps
column20: doesn’t ping the brain’s pleasure centers like his top-shelf work
column22: a nice throwback to the snappy R&B tracks the Neptunes used to pump out in the mid-'00s. ""Jump Hi""'s kinetic funk loop makes up for a lazy Childish Gambino guest verse
column23: pasted onto the track like a placeholder for a better substitute the label never delivered. Opener ""Whole"" doubles down on the funk
column24: with a jabbing groove that feels like a 2016 update of Nikka Costa’s forgotten hit ""Like a Feather."" There’s no rigid vision tying together this grab bag. Lion Babe are open to any style that might lend itself to a personable
column26:
and that flexibility generally works for them.

In some ways it’s refreshing to see that
column27: after a half-decade of aggressive experimentation
column28: sometimes seemingly for the sake of experimentation
column29: alternative R&B is returning to the basics. Why take R&B to strange new places
column30: Lion Babe seem to be saying
column31: when it’s already in a good place to begin with? That conservatism might be a little easier to appreciate
column33: if Hervey’s voice wasn’t a near dead-ringer for one of R&B’s great risk takers
column34: Erykah Badu. There’s no mistaking the similarities: the jazzy flutter
column35: the way her voice glides under words then curls around them to pull them closer. It’s as if Hervey prepped for each session by listening to ""Bag Lady"" on loop
column36: and that resemblance can work against her. It’s a constant reminder of just how safe Lion Babe play it
column37: as well as the shortcuts they take. Where Badu cultivated a voice that’s distinctly her own
column38:
Hervey is content to simply borrow somebody else’s.

There's a telling line to be found on the back cover of African Head Charge's debut album
column2: My Life in a Hole in the Ground: ""Another 1991 On-U Sound Creation."" That's all well and fine
column3: except the album was made in 1981. It's a playful admission that what African Head Charge was doing to dub
column4: post-punk
column5: Afrobeat
column6: industrial
column7: and world music might make more sense 10 years down the road.

column1: It's now 35 years later and Adrian Sherwood's deconstruction of the music of Africa
column2: Jamaica
column3: and Great Britain might have finally found its proper decade and century. With pop stars like M.I.A. grabbing at Brazilian baile funk; dubstep practitioners like Mala and Pinch favoring tracks that sound like pulled taffy; and the spare electronic contortions of Arca
column4: Oneohtrix Point Never
column5: and the Fade to Mind crew
column6: Sherwood’s tracks are more relevant than ever. Last year
column7: his On-U Sound imprint revived itself and began reissuing a wealth of material
column8: from a survey of Sherwood's decades of dub-punk productions to the dizzying Trevor Jackson-curated Science Fiction Dancehall Classics comp. The music could have dated from 2015
column9: no problem.

column1: Now comes the reissuing of the first four albums of his most heady and vital project
column2: AHC. Taking issue with (or maybe just the piss out of) Eno-Byrne's fake ethnography My Life in the Bush of Ghosts
column3: Sherwood created a studio entity along the lines of Eno’s oft-used quote for a ""vision of a psychedelic Africa."" In much the same manner that Fela's greatest bands had Tony Allen set as the heart
column4: AHC's pulse comes from African percussionist Bonjo Iyabinghi Noah
column5: Sherwood’s co-conspirator throughout AHC. And titling their debut album My Life in a Hole in the Ground was no euphemism
column6: as Berry Street Studios
column7: the space that Sherwood utilized for his early work
column8: was below street level.

column1: Sherwood's work in UK punk and Jamaican expat dub is crucial to understanding post-punk of that era (around this same time
column2: he produced the Fall and many others)
column3: and he was at his finest in African Head Charge. The first album is by far the most experimental of the bunch. Take ""Elastic Dance
column4: the opening track on My Life in a Hole in the Ground. A jaw harp twangs and flanges
column5: a sinewave wheezes up and down
column6: a skittering and skeletal drum and bass pattern emerge. And then all of it gets bandied about the stereo field by Sherwood. Always stretching his components to the breaking point and finding rubbery new spaces between these elements
column7: Sherwood used dub techniques to explore the outer regions of punk
column8: reggae
column9: Indian classical
column10: belly dancer motifs
column11: and more.

column1: And once you're this far beyond a certain genre's gravitational pull
column2: Sherwood realized that these disparate forms could be melted back together into fucked-up shapes. Years later
column3: ""Far Away Chant
column4: featuring the vocals of thunder-throated Prince Far I
column5: even appeared during a violent moment in David Lynch’s Wild at Heart. The emphasis on negative space is such that when Ground standout track ""Stebeni’s Theme"" recently came on my ear buds during rush hour
column6: the introduction of two percussionists on the train blended into that rubbery beat no problem.

column1: Environmental Studies appeared the next year and was also recorded underground
column2: yielding a similarly claustrophobic
column3: dank feel. More so than the first album
column4: Studies scans as the nexus between free improvisation and dub reggae
column5: less interested in melodic fragments and more about exploring the dark space between the two musical forms. The rotating assemblage of players included Jamaican session players like saxophonist ""Deadly"" Headley Bennett and drummer Style Scott
column6: who was part of the riddim team that backed everyone from Gregory Isaacs to Black Uhuru
column7: but it also made room for members of the Pop Group and Rip Rig + Panic
column8: as well as UK free improviser Steve Beresford. ""Beriberi"" showcases a swinging horn line that’s as close to ska as the virtual group ever got while ""Crocodile Hand Luggage"" pits Bonjo’s nyabinghi drums against the sounds of running water and animal cries.

column1: By the time of Drastic Season
column2: their third album in as many years
column3: Sherwood
column4: Bonjo
column5: and cohorts had moved above ground
column6: setting up at Southern Studios and exploring the digital hardware the studio provided. By then
column7: Sherwood had moved beyond the dub template and began to mince the sounds into ever-smaller pieces. The croak of an actual fish becomes the central element of ""I Want Water
column8: as Sherwood drowns it in all sorts of severe
column9: whiplashing effects. Even the smallest of musical gestures
column10: such as the short bass figures and drum taps of ""African Hedge Hog
column11: get amplified until they become labyrinths. At times
column12: the tracks scan more as experiments.

column1: Off the Beaten Track struck the perfect balance between the mad professorial experiments of Sherwood and the crack live band that had Bonjo at the helm
column2: but it also marked the end of the group for the next five years. The dub explorations hewed closer to the rhythms now
column3: a sound that would soon be called ""ethno-beat"" and ""tribal."" Didgeridoos and gypsy violins get turned into gnarly buzzes
column4: African chants turn into incants
column5: Prince Far I’s chopped declamation mixes into Bonjo’s big beat drums
column6: and the barking dog of ""Some Bizarre"" is the most psychedelic canine until that ‘shroom-chewing coyote.

column1: Without as many heavy FX at Sherwood’s mixing desk (but an uptick of Fairlight and Synclavier noises)
column2: the grooves come to the surface. Here’s the clearest correlation from here to the early-'90s post-rock of Tortoise and HiM
column3: the spacy throbs perpetuated by the Orb
column4: and the illbient wooziness of WordSound’s roster. ""Language becomes an instrument of reasoning in the true sense of the word
column5: goes the chorus of ""Language & Mentality
column6: voiced by none other than Albert Einstein. While dealing with sounds over words
column7: Sherwood’s work across these early African Head Charge albums nevertheless increased the vernacular of adventurous producers in the decades ahead
column8:
sounding all the more resonant in the 21st century.

column4: Lush

Sunflower Bean rock out and they can also be trusted to handle more fragile material

The UK producer Anthony Child
column2: better known as Surgeon

column4: British Murder Boys. But even at its most bruising

column7: and Force + Form—seem unusually alive

column1: While he once titled a mix CD This Is for You Shits

column1: With his new album

column3: he wades back into techno's roiled waters. All eight tracks employ four-to-the-floor rhythms
column4: flickering triplets or 16th-note syncopations

column6: just gnarled one- and two-bar loops that wend their way across the tracks' blasted expanse like inchworms through radioactive ash. ""z8_GND_5296"" swings like Kompakt's slinky ""Schaffel"" releases; ""GN-108036"" barrels forward as inexorably as Jeff Mills' most single-minded rollers. (The track titles all reference distant galaxies at the dawn of time; Child imagines the tracks themselves as waveform transmissions from these faraway star clusters
column7: which is itself an idea that goes straight to techno's roots.)

column1: On closer inspection
column2: though
column3: nothing here resembles conventional techno: for one thing
column4: save for the anchoring kicks
column5: where are the drums? This is not your usual percussive array: There are no snares
column6: no hi-hats
column7: no claps
column8: no toms—just knots of metallic whine and white noise. The low tones grumble like weary old men; the high ones scatter like drops of water in an oiled pan. Even the kick drums barely register as such; on the opening ""EGS-zs8-1"" they crumple like paper bags

column1: The more time you spend with the album
column2: the more it begins to feel like a universe of pure texture. But to say that there are no drums is also to acknowledge that there are no ""notes
column3: either: Put another way
column4: it's all drums
column5: just not the usual sound sets we've become accustomed to. Despite the softness of their attacks
column6: every element here is essentially percussive in nature
column7: which imbues the music with an unusually primal sensibility: The gnarled ""A1703 zD6
column8: with its wooden clunk and spongy texture
column9: suggests early humans thwacking gourds and logs
column10: and it heaves like a rotten tree trunk spitting termites.

column1: One of the things that distinguished Maui Jungle was its sense of discipline: Most of its tracks sounded like they had been made using just one machine or process
column2: and From Farthest Known Objects is no different. Despite its greater density and complexity
column3: it represents the same kind of rigor. I have no idea how Child made the music—he has said only that he explored ""new production techniques using old and unlikely hardware""—but it doesn't sound like the output you'd get from a standard array of gear
column4: with drums and bassline down below
column5: and pads and leads on top. It sounds like one source being spun in nearly infinite ways
column6: like a single electrical signal being channeled down a long
column7: convoluted pipe and emerging like a live wire spitting sparks. It feels elemental
column8: which is appropriate
column9:
given the subject matter—like a techno tribute to Carl Sagan's famous maxim: We are made of star stuff.

Animals is Hughes’ follow-up to 2008’s A Love Extreme

column31:

column35: and starts crooning in a low
column36: Stephin Merritt register as he turns toward matters of the heart. Even in this less jocular mode

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/22788/homepage_large.d31422e1.jpg|Suicide Songs|31488.0|MONEY|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Bella Union']|2016-01-28 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 16:02:07.190168|"

""Suffer Little Children
column2: the final track on the Smiths' eponymous 1984 record
column3: was a kind of siren song for romantic miserablism. The song itself might have been based on the infamous Moors murders of the 1960s
column4: but it also served to cement Morrissey's home city in the cultural imagination. ""Oh
column5: Manchester
column6: so much to answer for"" rang like a bell
column7: forever positioning the Northern city (at least for mopey Anglophiles such as myself) as a place where creative melancholy always wins out—a city in which the industrial gray
column8: bitter cold
column9: and ceaseless rain helped to forever nourish great
column10: hopeless art.

column1: On their 2013 debut
column2: The Shadow of Heaven
column3: Manchester’s MONEY upheld this vision
column4: simultaneously playing up to the city's melancholic legacy while also grandly skewering it. (The record’s release involved billboards emblazoned with the words ""Manchester Is Paradise."") By turns dour and swooningly romantic
column5: self-destructive and charmingly fey
column6: the songs on Heaven were sprawling
column7: guitar-driven affairs that often stretched beyond the five-minute mark and sounded as if they might have been recorded in a candle-lit cave. It was the sound of a band almost living up to the scale of its own grand ambitions.

column1: On their second album
column2: the intensely titled Suicide Songs
column3: MONEY appear to have weathered what must have some harrowing sophomore anxieties. The album opens with ""I Am the Lord""—a nearly seven-minute long opus involving Indian dilruba
column4: hushed gospel singers
column5: and gently-employed shakers that sounds more like Storm in Heaven-era Verve than the echoey WU LYF squall of their earlier efforts. ""You are not the same as me/ I'm up there in the clouds
column6: Jamie Lee sings. ""I am the Lord/ He gave me his eyes to see through."" It’s a suitably epic opening for an album that deals largely in seeking transcendence via self-imposed oblivion. And while another record of young Brits singing songs about despair and getting smashed at the pub isn’t exactly a novel concept
column7: MONEY manage to make the prospect of weathering your own personal apocalypse sound not only beautiful
column8: but transformative.

column1: The cover art of Suicide Songs features a black-and-white photo of Lee with a knife that appears to be balancing on (or slowly burying itself into) his forehead. That image—paired with the record’s oblivion-seeking lyrics—makes for what should be a pretty heavy listen. (""I wanted the album to sound like it was ‘coming from death’ which is where these songs emerged
column2: explains Lee in the promo materials). Still
column3: the nine tracks on board never feel oppressive. Even ""Suicide Song
column4: the album’s centerpiece (whose chorus is literally
column5: ""This is your suicide song"") is weirdly more merry than maudlin.

column1: It’s to the band’s credit that this despondency feels exploratory—occasionally even celebratory. Lee
column2: along with bandmates Billy Byron and Charlie Cocksedge
column3: emerges with a record that shines light on the crisis of identity that often befalls creative folk during their late twenties (or
column4: occasionally
column5: their thirties or forties)—Who am I? What do I really have to say? And how can I figure it out without somehow destroying myself? It seems grimly fitting that the album ends with a song called ""Cocaine Christmas and an Alcoholic’s New Year
column6: which is just as much of a glorious drunken bummer as the title would suggest. Alternately making comparisons to both Marilyn Monroe and Jean Genet
column7: Lee allows a sense of levity to permeate even the messiest of moments: ""I've wasted all my time on cocaine at Christmas and bottles of wine
column8: sings Lee
column9: ""And I’m as happy as a child/ Because you don't have to ask me why."" Much like records by the Smiths
column10: Suicide Songs is both consoling and encouraging
column11:
revealing itself fully only after repeated listens and paying dividends each time. Manchester should be proud.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/22735/homepage_large.cec07030.jpg|Original Machines|6565.0|Conrad Keely|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Superball Music']|2016-01-28 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 16:02:08.031570|"

...And You Will Know Us By the Trail of Dead divided one of their albums into suites by guitar tuning and convinced a major label to greenlight this video. They are also named ...And You Will Know Us By the Trail of Dead. I can’t imagine Conrad Keely hears ""no"" a lot within the context of Trail of Dead
column2: or even at all. So it stands to reason that Keely releasing his first solo album this far into his career wouldn’t serve the same purpose as most ventures of this sort
column3: i.e.
column4: to provide a safe space to play with ideas too indulgent for the main gig. Original Machines does the opposite
column5: a clearinghouse for modest songs nowhere near indulgent enough for Trail of Dead.

column1: At the very least

column1: To make music this abstract work

But he doesn’t need the silver screen to get his ideas across; this album has all the drama you could ask for on its own.

The sound of Japan’s early house music scene has only reached the Western hemisphere in the last few years. Even then
column3: we only catch it in glimpses: An RBMA Radio show dedicated to pioneers like Ecstasy Boys and Frankie Knuckles' production partner Satoshi Tomiie; Rush Hour's illuminating Sounds From the Far East compilation
column4: which gathered the crucial productions of Soichi Terada. But there is a wealth of Japanese deep house and dance music that never made it off the island
column5: much less across the Pacific. Add to it now this set from two French DJs
column6: Brawther & Alixkun
column7: who have dug up their favorite tracks for ハウス Once Upon a Time in Japan
column8: spanning the heyday of the Major Force label in the early '90s to the late '90s.

column1: Scrub the ID tags off of the 15 tracks that comprise this set and you’d be hard-pressed to differentiate between these tracks and their U.S./UK counterparts
column2: so expert is their mastery of house music tropes of the era. For new listeners unacquainted with early '90s house
column3: the set could easily scan as just a dope set of unheralded tracks that thumped far from the fare of ""Club MTV."" T.P.O.’s opener ""Punk Inc. (Hiroshi's Dub)"" dates from 1989
column4: when the group was pivoting away from conscious rap toward hip-house (and a few years on
column5: into deep house). Those hip-hop drums are subsumed on the remix in favor of a percolating kick and a phase high enough to give you a nosebleed.

column1: Dig into some of the backstories behind these tracks and it gets slightly odd. The vocalizing that goes with Yutsuko Chusonji’s ""Blessing (Magic Ware Remix)"" scans as gospel house in the vein of the Sounds of Blackness
column2: made all the more baffling by the fact that Chusonji is known as a famous mangaka rather than as a dance music producer. For those taken in either by the pan flutes and saxophones of Mood Hut (or
column3: you know
column4: Biebs)
column5: check YPF’s lone single
column6: ""Trance of Love (Tokyo Offshore Mix)"" which scans as Balearic house complete with sax solo. Or else check the lovely flute that wafts over Akiko Kanazawa’s ""Sawauchi Jinku (Terada Mix)."" Tethered to a tough beat courtesy of Soichi Terada
column7: it’s the most overtly Japanese-sounding track here
column8: as Kanazawa is an enka singer whose career dates back to the mid-'70s.

column1: The echoing piano figures that opens the Ecstasy Boys’s transcendent 10-minute epic ""Chi Chi Chi Gan Kanon"" could slot into almost any attendant Frankie Knuckles remix of that era. Which makes sense in that the trio of Mitsuru Kotaki
column2: Shiro Amamiya
column3: and Tatsuro Amamiya did have singles on N.Y. house labels Quark and Strictly Rhythm
column4: and could have factored into the sets of the day. Throughout the track
column5: the snares stutter
column6: dive and then climb skyward
column7: building until the midway point
column8: wherein that piano returns and takes the track even higher. And even as the track slowly ebbs away
column9: those drums reverberate and shoot up and down like swallows at play. As these 15 tracks suggest
column10: no one comp can serve as a catchall for that country's dance history
column11:
but it's a thrilling overview nevertheless. One hopes that the story behind Once Upon a Time in Japan continues to be told.

column11: or the ballads that used to be near-contractual requirements for pop starlets needing ""mature"" cuts for their records.

column1: Enter Wet
column2: a Brooklyn three-piece that has flitted around synthpop
column3: Cat Power-ish folk
column4: '90s R&B
column5: and modern alt-R&B without quite committing to any of them
column6: which nevertheless positions them perfectly for starring roles in Baby’s All Right showcases
column7: BBC Radio 1 playlists
column8: and hair-whipping clips on Khloe Kardashian’s Instagram. (This is how we 2016.) The uninformed listener might think Wet would be fun. Their band name may or may not be a gag. Their former online presence
column9: squashed for legal reasons
column10: was @kanyewet—it’s goofy! It’s Yeezy! It’s maybe a grab for those typo clicks
column11: if you want to get all cynical about it! Debut album <i>Don’t You
column12: however
column13: is a downbeat
column14: decidedly unfun affair—this is the kind of album where early single ""U Da Best"" turns into ""You’re the Best
column15: from which you can extrapolate a lot.

column1: The main problem with Don’t You: if you set out to be an amalgam of beloved styles
column2: you’d better equal and preferably outdo at least a couple of them once. Wet cite Usher and SWV as touchpoints in almost every press story
column3: but seem to have forgotten all their exciting songs
column4: as well as everything uptempo; most of Don’t You aims for Babyface but lands somewhere around Surfacing-era Sarah McLachlan
column5: except nowhere near as good. Instrumentalists Joe Valle and Marty Sulkow reproduce the slick sounds of background music—synth pads
column6: polite rhythm guitar
column7: vague drum pitter-patter—with sample-replay fidelity. Vocalist Kelly Zutrau’s thin voice has none of the sighing wispiness of Romy Madley-Croft
column8: Tracey Thorn
column9: or even Jennifer Paige
column10: nor the melisma or force of basically any R&B artist Don’t You emulates; her go-to tricks are (admittedly pretty and sometimes inspired) double-tracked harmonies or a Banks-y quaver that’s plaintive the first couple times you hear it. Their songs are near-identical takes on the wallow phase of a breakup
column11: each rendered in passive
column12: beige indifference—one misses the emotional peaks of '90s R&B
column13: which go all the way up to ""If You Died I Wouldn’t Cry."" Yet telling-not-showing lines like ""when you hold me
column14: I still feel lonely"" (responsible for perhaps the best/worst Genius annotation in recent memory) are nevertheless preferable to the likes of ""today
column15: New York feels like an island
column16: a metaphor that manages the remarkable feat of being clichéd and geographically hilarious. (Perhaps they meant upstate?)

column1: Don’t You isn’t without standouts. ""Deadwater"" is well-constructed
column2: though better as a standalone single
column3: and skittery ""All the Ways"" is a standout purely by dint of having a higher tempo. But two-for-eleven does not an album make. ""Don’t Wanna Be Your Girl"" drowns Brian McKnight’s ""Back at One"" and Cat Power’s ""Good Woman"" in a puddle of reverb and repetition. ""Weak"" is an approximation of what it might sound like if Meghan Trainor traded her poodle-skirt-costume versions of the '50s for roller-rink-costume versions on ""Waterfalls."" Either everyone involved with ""You’re the Best"" developed iron deficiencies before its re-recording
column4: or it simply blends in with the rest of the album’s downtempo sulk.

column1: Wet
column2: to their credit and detriment
column3: know they’ve got competition. ""Our music plays into the more general trend of artists incorporating certain elements of R&B and pop into their sound and creating something really unique
column4: Zutrau told Interview. But of those on-trend artists
column5: Haim have more exuberance and better studio players; the xx have more space and ambition; almost any contemporary R&B act has more imagination
column6: more rhythm
column7: and more interesting blues. Wet know this too: ""[We’re] now adults in a time when the music playing on Hot 97 is some of the most exciting music being made right now
column8: Zutrau said. Perhaps the future might capture a bit of that excitement; some names floated as future Wet collaborators include Clams Casino (whose ""Weak"" remix is more sonically interesting alone than anything on this record) and Drake producer Nineteen85. As it stands
column9:
Wet may as well be directing readers toward better versions of them. And there have never been more to choose from.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/22611/homepage_large.540e88f5.jpg|The Waiting Room|4245.0|Tindersticks|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['City Slang']|2016-01-26 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:02:12.347057|"

Tindersticks turn 25 this year. It’s a remarkable feat for any band
column2: but even more impressive than the Nottingham outfit’s longevity is their consistency. Tindersticks have never released a bad album (or even a middling one)
column3: never made an opportunistic
column4: trend-driven shift
column5: and have never done anything that might date their music to its moment of origin. They’re the rare group that can lay claim to a signature sound
column6: yet tweak the formula from album to album so that each of their 10 records possesses its own distinct character. The skies in their world may be forever gray
column7: but the clouds are always moving and morphing
column8: letting in the faintest flickers of light that change the size and shape of the shadows they cast.

column1: The richly atmospheric
column2: nicotine-stained quality of the Tindersticks’ music makes it an ideal complement to TV shows and films
column3: whether their songs are soundtracking pivotal scenes on ""The Sopranos"" or comprising entire scores for French art-house maverick Claire Denis. But on The Waiting Room
column4: that dynamic is reversed: the band handed off its 11 tracks to various filmmaker friends (including Denis
column5: Christoph Girardet
column6: Pierre Vinour
column7: and Gregorio Graziosi) as inspirational fodder for accompanying short films packaged with deluxe editions of the record. The album opens with a cover of Polish composer Bronislau Kaper’s ""Follow Me
column8: aka the theme song from the 1962 film adaptation of Mutiny on the Bounty; in Tindersticks’ hands
column9: the original’s tiki-torch splendor is given a gritty makeover that pushes it closer to Midnight Cowboy territory. It’s a perfect scene-setter—The Waiting Room may not feature any songs about oceanic expeditions
column10: but the band sure know their way around tales of backstabbing and betrayal.

column1: Yet for all the band’s filmic qualities
column2: the action in frontman Stuart Staples' lyrics is always more psychological than physical. The weightless Wurlitzer tones of ""Second Chance Man"" and ""Were We Once Lovers?"" respectively set Staples’ inner turmoil against brassy swells and disorienting disco. And just as the latter track appears to achieve liftoff
column3: Staples delivers a dispiriting chorus line—""how can I care if it’s the caring that’s killing me?""—that forsakes rapture for rupture.

column1: The Waiting Room might be Tindersticks’ most subdued effort to date
column2: but it still flashes the irreverence that enlivened efforts like The Something Rain and Falling Down a Mountain. On ""Help Yourself
column3: an uncharacteristically louche Staples shakes off his troubles by swaggering onto the floor of the Shrine in Lagos circa '72 (and the novelty of the Tindersticks going Afrobeat is savvily mirrored by Denis’ companion clip
column4: which depicts French-Caribbean actor Alex Descas roaming the shopping-mall concourse of a French train station
column5: nonplussed by the white European consumer culture surrounding him). An even more wondrous surprise arrives in the form of ""Hey Lucinda
column6: a wobbly-kneed waltz that finds Staples communing with the spirit of the late
column7: great Montreal chanteuse Lhasa de Sela
column8: an occasional Tindersticks collaborator who died of cancer in 2010. It’s like a fleeting reminiscence of someone who’s passed
column9: but one that leaves you smiling from the warm memories rather than weeping over their absence.

column1: The beautifully languid ""Hey Lucinda"" contrasts sharply with The Waiting Room’s other big-ticket matchup
column2: ""We Are Dreamers
column3: which sees Staples joining forces with Jehnny Beth of Savages and the Tindersticks tapping into that band’s brooding menace. It’s the moment where all of The Waiting Room’s mounting tension is finally released
column4: into an outsider anthem that recasts material impoverishment as spiritual empowerment (""You can rob us/ You can trick us/ Peer over our shoulders and steal our ideas"") as Beth and Staples’ voices intertwine and overlap before locking into the song’s rallying cry: ""This is not us/ We are dreamers!"" But in the Tindersticks’ world
column5: every dream is followed by a rude awakening; following that climax
column6: the bitterly fatalistic closer ""Like Only Lovers Can"" pairs '70s soft-rock sway with a cutting chorus: ""We can only hurt each other the way that lovers can/ So where do we go?"" Appropriately
column7: many of the visuals that accompany these songs emphasize distance and emptiness: black-and-white footage of a wedding from the '50s; a seaside fairground after the tourists have gone home; taxidermied animals. They’re moments and entities once bustling with life
column8: but which now exist as faded memories or shells of their former selves. And for so long as we pine to make them real again
column9:
there will be exquisite Tindersticks songs to help us fill the void.

Before it was a recording studio
column2: Cold Storage was a meat locker
column3: its floors slicked with blood. But under This Heat's occupancy
column4: between 1977 and 1981
column5: the South London space became a laboratory for a strange and volatile new strain of avant-garde rock—by turns thundering and ephemeral
column6: hopeful and wry
column7: surgically precise and caveman-crude—that didn't quite square with anything else that was happening at the time. Their motto was simple: ""All possible processes. All channels open. Twenty-four hour alert.""

column1: Two members of the band
column2: drummer Charles Hayward and multi-instrumentalist Charles Bullen
column3: had been playing in various progressive rock bands for more than a dozen years; Gareth Williams
column4: the group's third member
column5: had no musical training at all. That tension guided them as they established an exploratory practice based on extended collective improvisation that incorporated not just guitar and drums
column6: but also viola
column7: melodica
column8: organ
column9: household objects
column10: and broken toys. They used tape machines to stretch the fabric of time and creative mic placement to warp space. They were fueled not just by formal restlessness but also by rage at consumer society—""Sleep
column11: the opening song on 1981's Deceit
column12: juxtaposes advertising copy with references to Pavlovian experiments in conditioning—and their certainty that humanity was on a nuclear collision course with itself. ""That's why our music wasn't psychedelic and drifty
column13: why it was so hard-edged and angular
column14: Hayward told Simon Reynolds in Rip It Up and Start Again. ""We had no interest in making people stoned with our sounds.""

column1: This Heat released only two albums and one EP during their brief run
column2: and those barely registered amid the competing din of the period. But you can hear in their slim catalog
column3: which returns to wax thanks to these reissues from Light in the Attic
column4: the seeds of vast fields of music that would follow: post-rock
column5: math rock
column6: homemade musique concrète
column7: and experimental electronica. This Heat did not yield a single signature sound so much as a zone of possibilities.

column1: And that very range is part of what makes their music so bracing. Listening to their self-titled 1979 debut album
column2: one moment you are lulled into a meditative state by the incidental bells and airy sax skronk of ""Not Waving""; the next you're given whiplash by churning dissonance and muscular rhythms that anticipate early Swans
column3: along with Shellac
column4: Black Dice
column5: and Lightning Bolt. ""Music Like Escaping Gas
column6: with its trembling organ
column7: dissonant acoustic guitar
column8: and chanted sing-speaking
column9: could be mistaken for a rough Gastr del Sol demo
column10: while ""The Fall of Saigon"" reroutes Brian Eno's wispy art rock through the Velvet Underground's funereal drones. The narcotic texture of that song
column11: gloopy and atonal
column12: stands in stark contrast to the lyrics' sly sense of humor: It begins by making a meal of a cat
column13: and
column14: by the end
column15: the narrator has eaten everything that's not bolted to the floor
column16: right down to the TV and the armchair. The fall of an empire has never been rendered in bleaker
column17: more bitterly humorous terms.

column1: The whole sweep of This Heat's project can be heard on the uncharacteristically optimistic ""Health and Efficiency
column2: the A-side of a 1980 12"". ""Here's a song about the sunshine
column3: they sing over a major-key melody that prefigures Stereolab songs like ""Nihilist Assault Group""; soon
column4: they spiral into a locked groove of violently yanked guitar strings and hypnotically looped drums. The clatter of woodblocks and milk bottles adds to the din; they even mix in the sounds of a nearby playground before the eight-minute side dissolves into a detuned and deconstructed reprise of the main theme. On the flip
column5: the tape composition ""Graphic / Varispeed"" is 11 and a half minutes of held organ tones that rise and fall like the sound of a single-engine propeller plane circling the neighborhood. Stylistically
column6: its musical minimalism is at odds with This Heat's twitchy muscularity
column7: but the intensity of its focus is absolutely in keeping with the group's unflinching approach.

column1: Their second and final album
column2: 1981's Deceit
column3: doesn't entirely do away with the extreme sonic abstraction. ""Radio Prague"" is an experiment in mechanical pulses and cut-up radio broadcasts
column4: and ""Hi Baku Shyo (Suffer Bomb Disease)"" is a kind of expressionist sound painting of a post-nuclear landscape: wails
column5: church bells
column6: buzzing flies. For the most part
column7: though
column8: the album marks a significant leap forward in songwriting. (Mixed by the reggae engineer Martin Frederick
column9: it also marks a significant improvement in fidelity.) Deceit's lyrics encompass both acid critique and post-structuralist philosophy while finding poetry in the everyday
column10: and its grooves are both catchy and strangely inscrutable. This band could also flat-out jam: ""S.P.Q.R.
column11: with its chiming guitars and close-harmonized chants
column12: goes head to head with Mission of Burma's ""Academy Fight Song"" as one of the most triumphant-sounding protest songs of the era. The album's anthemic scale helps explain how This Heat ended up opening for U2 at London's Hammersmith Palais that year.

column1: Thirty-five years later
column2: the depth and breadth of their creativity remain both astonishing and incredibly prescient. On the tribal cut-and-paste piece ""Shrinkwrap
column3: their vocal multi-tracking sounds like the Beastie Boys via Monty Python. And on ""A New Kind of Water
column4: Deceit's climactic penultimate song
column5: their sturm and clang presents a model for the haunted cabling of Sonic Youth's Bad Moon Rising. The song's title is a sendup of marketing
column6: but it ultimately concerns nothing less than the survival of the species: ""Fly away Peter
column7: hide away Paul/ Who can watch as the Earth burns
column8: shatters
column9: and dies?""

column1: For many years
column2: This Heat records were hard to come by
column3: though sporadic reissues and compilation features helped keep their legacy alive. Thanks to the new vinyl reissues and streaming
column4: their catalog is now more widely available than ever. And yet
column5: This Heat also feel further from the zeitgeist than ever. The sort of noisy
column6: difficult rock that they helped pioneer has gone out of favor
column7: and their electronic experiments have become second nature. But that resistance to faddishess helps make their music an exhilarating experience to this day
column8: whether it's a first encounter or the continuation of a years-long relationship. What you hear in a song like ""A New Kind of Water"" isn't just intelligence; it's urgency. We've become far too accustomed to the 24-hour alert; today
column9: This Heat's work is a reminder that we could use more possible processes
column10:
more open channels.

column7: Gqom Nation to name a few)
column8: invite-only WhatsApp group chats

column1: But good luck cataloging any of it

column3: and available mostly in low bitrate formats. Kolè met Lerato Phiri through mutual friends in Rome

column3: an artist featured on Sounds of Durban

column5: the ghetto

column9: or as Kode9 has said
column10: ""<a href=""https://soundcloud.com/gqomu/dominowe-africas-cry"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">like being suspended over the gravitational field of a black hole
column11: and lovin' it."" The entire aesthetic of gqom is steeped in a swashbuckling DIY attitude. Nothing about these productions feels slick or highly processed. The music proudly shows its seams by remaining highly tactile
column12: off the cuff

column1: What Kolè found so attractive about gqom in the first place was that it felt like a perfect artistic expression for the political
column2: economic
column3: and urban contradictions so apparent in Durban and South Africa as a whole. It is among the most Westernized and developed countries on the continent
column4: but the living conditions for the predominately black communities in the townships of South Africa remain dismal. Gqom is still being produced in townships and suburbs
column5: marginal communities by and large where access to Internet
column6: gear
column7: and everything young musicians need is still a struggle. And for the most part gqom artists and gqom music is not played on local radio
column8: nor has it reached any significant popularity outside of Durban
column9: which is often seen as secondary in the music scene to the larger and more visible Johannesburg. While it might seem specious that someone who has never been to Durban become the spokesperson for the genre
column10: Kolè's intentions feel heartfelt and earnest. He's said the artists (whose ages range from 15 to 22) call him ""Malumz"" which means ""uncle"" because he's too old to be a ""bro.""

column1: Phiri and Kolè want gqom to have the same connection to Durban that juke and footwork has to Chicago

column5: up-and-coming grime rapper Stormzy traveled to South Africa to learn about gqom. According to Johannesburg music journalist
column6: Lloyd Gedye
column7: you can even hear strains of gqom's signature stylings in Jamie xx's ""Gosh
column8: which he might have heard in the now-popular gqom nights that are popping up in South London. Even with all the hype attached

column1: The 15 tracks that compose Sounds of Durban Vol. 1 successfully capture the very essence of gqom: the rough-and-tumble vibe
column2: the impressionistic and asymmetrical kickdrums
column3: the hypnotic chanting
column4: and the music's brash youthfulness. Originally referred to as ""Broken Beat"" in the community
column5: gqom is a pushback against spiritual predecessors like Kwaito

column3: it's tougher
column4: angrier. It presents a case for a minimal version of house which is never restrained—the music is always exuberant and riotous. This also means the album can easily move from relentless to tiring
column5: because as a whole it lacks pacing
column6: and it is instead a trial by fire.

column1: Although that is not to say that artists don't stand out. Dominowe's ""Africa's Cry
column2: the album's second track
column3: sets the bar impossibly high. Cruel Boyz's ""Umeqo Emagqomini (Dub Mix)"" was the lead single for the record

column6: almost painterly
column7: use of kickdrums.

All the things that are carefree and rebellious about being young find a way to be showcased in these songs. And if there is any resolution that can feel doable in this new year
column3:
it's to rep this group of young people in Durban as hard as possible when you decide to hijack the speakers at the party you find yourself at tonight.

<div><i>[Ed. Note: In light of David Bowie's passing
column2: Pitchfork commissioned reviews of several of his classic albums.]

column1: In the summer of 1974
column2: as he was traveling across America on his mammoth Diamond Dogs arena-rock tour
column3: David Bowie got deeply into soul music. By July
column4: he was spiking his live sets with covers of the Ohio Players' ""Here Today and Gone Tomorrow"" and Eddie Floyd's ""Knock on Wood
column5: but he was even more interested in what was happening in dance clubs—particularly the new disco coming out of Philadelphia International Records. Bowie booked a mid-tour recording session at Sigma Sound
column6: the studio where Kenneth Gamble and Leon Huff were constructing the sound of Philadelphia. But he wasn't working with Gamble and Huff
column7: or indeed any of the studio's house musicians: He had something else in mind.

column1: The soul-inspired album that came out of the Sigma Sound recordings
column2: Young Americans
column3: was yet another new direction for an artist who staked his career on ceaselessly finding new directions. It was also the first time he’d made an album whose chief purpose was pleasure. There’s nothing like the apocalyptic visions of Ziggy Stardust and Diamond Dogs on Young Americans; it’s as smart as anything he’d recorded before it
column4: but also relaxed and limber-hipped enough for his hardcore fans’ less alienated big sisters and little brothers to get into. And it was the first of his records to feature Carlos Alomar
column5: the ingenious rhythm guitarist who would become his live band’s musical director for more than a decade.

column1: Bowie had met Alomar at a session early in the year
column2: when he'd produced the Scottish pop singer Lulu's covers of his own ""The Man Who Sold the World"" and ""Watch That Man."" He drafted Alomar in to play at the Sigma Sound sessions
column3: and Alomar brought along a couple of singers: his wife
column4: Robin Clark
column5: and his best friend
column6: the then-unknown Luther Vandross. Always quick to recognize talent
column7: Bowie immediately got Vandross and Clark in on the recording.

column1: At those sessions
column2: Bowie recorded enough songs for an album (reportedly meant to be called either ""The Gouster"" or
column3: more cynically
column4: ""Shilling the Rubes"")—although it would've been very different from the Young Americans we know today. Its most radical gesture would have been ""John
column5: I'm Only Dancing (Again)
column6: a rewritten and discofied version of a snarling
column7: homoerotic glam-rock single from three years earlier. (Bowie didn't actually release ""John
column8: I'm Only Dancing (Again)"" until 1979; it was a minor hit in England and ended up on his Changestwobowie compilation.)

column1: ""Young Americans"" the song was a hybrid of contemporary soul (the Vandross-led backup singers were all over it)
column2: the hyper-emotive '50s singer Johnnie Ray
column3: and—another recent obsession of Bowie's—the up-and-coming New Jersey songwriter Bruce Springsteen
column4: whose song ""It's Hard to Be a Saint in the City"" Bowie covered at Sigma Sound. It was also very current: Bowie sang ""Do you remember President Nixon?"" in the middle of a song he'd started recording three days after Nixon's resignation.

column1: After that initial burst of productivity
column2: the Diamond Dogs tour resumed
column3: now so deeply influenced by Philadelphia soul that it was nicknamed the ""Philly Dogs"" tour. Bowie ditched most of his elaborate stage design
column4: and added an opening set by the ""Mike Garson Band""—his own group
column5: fronted by Vandross and Clark. (Their set included a terrific Vandross original
column6: ""Funky Music
column7: as well as a reworked version of Bowie's hippie mantra ""Memory of a Free Festival."") One of the new additions to Bowie's own set was a medley of the Flares' ""Foot Stompin'"" and the old jazz standard ""I Wish I Could Shimmy Like My Sister Kate
column8: powered by a funk riff Alomar had come up with.

column2: they unsuccessfully tried to record ""Foot Stomping."" They did
column3: however
column4: come up with two killer additions to Young Americans: Bowie's dreamy
column5: spiraling slow one ""Win

column1: Bowie had also befriended John Lennon around that time
column2: and invited him along to play guitar on a cover of his Beatles-era song ""Across the Universe"" at a final session in January
column3: 1975. (Also present then

column5: who would go on to be the hidden rhythmic genius of all of his records up through 1980's Scary Monsters.) ""Across the Universe"" is the album's one genuine embarrassment
column6: Vegas-y and bathetic. But bringing Lennon in yielded an unexpected dividend: Alomar's ""Foot Stompin'"" riff
column7: a bit of arrangement brainstorming from Lennon
column8: and a sharp
column9: bitter lyric from Bowie combined
column10: very quickly
column11: into the stunning funk track ""Fame."" (Young Americans ended up being curiously Lennon-heavy: there's even a slightly mangled line from ""A Day in the Life"" in the middle of ""Young Americans."")

column1: ""Fame"" was a knockout
column2: the song that gave Bowie his first American #1 single
column3: and the soul world that he so admired took it to heart. By November
column5: it landed Bowie on ""Soul Train."" (He wasn't the first white solo performer to play the show
column6: but he was close.) George Clinton
column7: by his own admission
column8: modified its groove into ""Give Up the Funk (Tear the Roof Off the Sucker)."" And James Brown paid Bowie the ultimate backhanded compliment: The instrumental track of his 1976 single ""Hot (I Need to Be Loved
column9: Loved

column1: In the context of Bowie's flabbergasting '70s
column2: Young Americans is distinctly a transitional record. It doesn't have the mad theatrical scope of Diamond Dogs or the formal audacity of Station to Station; at times
column3: it comes off as an artist trying very hard to demonstrate how unpredictable he is. You couldn't mistake it for an actual Philly soul record
column4: although like the LPs Bowie was devouring at the time
column5: it often comes off as hits-plus-filler. Still
column6: a good deal of the filler is lovely
column7: and recording funk and disco in 1974 put him way ahead of the curve. While there had already been a handful of disco hits on the pop charts
column8: no other established rock musician had yet tried to do anything similar
column9: and Bowie pulled it off in a way that not only didn't seem crass but gave Luther Vandross his big break.

column1: The album was also a vehicle for Bowie to address one of his favorite topics—pop stardom—from a new angle
column2: at a moment when it seemed likely to destroy him. (""Fame"" shares its title with a Broadway show about Marilyn Monroe's life that closed after one performance in November
column3: 1974; thanks to Bowie's disastrous management deal at the time
column4: its quarter-million-dollar loss effectively came out of his pocket.) When Bowie talked about lower-case fame with Tracey Emin in 2001
column5:
he was a bit more sanguine about it: ""There is nothing there to covet.... I understand that it doesn't even get you a Madonna ticket these days. So I won't be recommending it to my offspring. Having influence is more rewarding for feeding ego."" He had nothing to worry about on that score.

For most of his career as an artist

column7: starting with his soundtrack to 2009's Black Dynamite—a theatrically-released spoof of the genre. While the movie was a sendup of the tropes of all things superfly and jive

column18: and rhapsodic horns

column1: Something About April II represents a return to this love for Younge

column5: Younge has always been a child of hip-hop. The first April record was crafted by someone clearly in love with breakbeats and seemed to aspire to become new sources for crate diggers. (Tellingly
column6: that album was used as source material twice on Jay Z's Magna Carta Holy Grail—""Picasso Baby"" and ""Heaven""—and Younge's compositions provided the samples for DJ Premier's and Royce da 5'9""'s PRhyme album.) But on Something About April II
column7: Younge emerges as someone more interested in creating new classics than new samples.

column1: As always
column2: the music here leans heavily on a roughly five-year slice of Black soul from '68-'73 with Younge helming a Hammond organ
column3: Fender Rhodes piano
column4: vibraphone
column5: and the Selene

column7: featuring frequent vocal collaborator Loren Oden

column9: with acoustic guitar and a lyrical confidence unseen in Younge's earlier work. ""Let's treasure every moment that we share/ Cherish what we have for all time
column10: Oden sings
column11: stretching out and deepening the last two words into a small riff that sounds like it belongs in another song
column12: but fits perfectly. A pair of duets by Laetitia Sadier (of Stereolab) and Bilal—""Step Beyond"" and ""La Ballade""—benefit from Sadier's cool phrasing

column15: making everything sound familiar and new.

column1: The music on Something About April II
column2: although teasingly short—most numbers here clock in under three minutes—sounds like music for music's sake
column3:
not existing solely for samples or as reverence. Even when left largely to his own musings—on the instrumental ""Sea Motet"" and the sparsely accented ""April Sonata""—Younge presents whole thoughts that move with a fluidity that he's seldom exhibited in the past. In short: he's gotten better at everything he does.

column6: dreary ""New Jack Sleaze"" sound (of which Ty Dolla $ign is the current mayor) and obvious nostalgia bait (particularly of the '90s). In both
column7: you can hear the wheels and gears of a talented individual trying to shape himself into something more consumable and familiar to general audiences as though he’s simply another manifestation of a record company business meeting.

column1: Chixtape 3 loosely acts as a concept tape about Lanez’ girlfriend
column2: Jalissa
column3: and his newfound infatuation with her best friend Keisha. It’s a showcase for Tory Lanez the singer
column4: something he’s very good at doing. The problem is he doesn’t actually have anything to say. After years of Drake-wave and clones like Bryson Tiller and PARTYNEXTDOOR beating the sound into the ground
column5: it’s hard to have patience for another moody
column6: emotionally distant piece of one-note R&B dystopia. The brightest moment on Chixtape is ""Juvenile (Freestyle)
column7: in which Lanez rap-sings over Juvenile’s ""Slow Motion."" Nothing particularly interesting is being said
column8: (""Shorty when we meet
column9: gotta fuck for real/ Took the TTC just to get the whole meal/ And we used to fuck
column10: girl it was so trill/ You remind me of Monica
column11: you was so real"") but he sells you on it anyways
column12: riding the instrumental with a quivering
column13: confident sing-song. It’s infectious
column14: even as you become aware of the dullness and grossness of the lyrics.

column1: About those lyrics: Lanez has a disturbing tendency to conflate lines that surpass aggression and tip into assault  (""Now shawty I'mma take it
column2: if you don’t give it to me
column3: from ""Juvenile (Freestyle)"") with ""swagger."" Aggressively dehumanizing women even while serenading them is nothing new in rap or R&B: The Weeknd and Ty Dolla $ign
column4: arguably the new gold standards in the current sound Tory Lanez is chasing
column5: have been just as crude and disrespectful. But Lanez doesn’t have half their talent to make you forgive him. His star power
column6: such as it is
column7: shines in sparks that can barely carry your typical mixtape
column8: much less one with such uncomfortable lyrics.

column1: The best moments on either tape come when he chooses to sing: He seems the most comfortable on songs like ""Them Days
column2: off New Toronto
column3: when he kicks back into crooning about sex with ex-girls rather than the damaged-puppy rapping he spends so much of the tape committed to. It makes you wonder why he doesn’t just commit to that aspect fully. Also
column4: for a Gangsta Grillz tape
column5: DJ Drama makes no impression. Most of the time
column6: you completely forget that he’s there; none of his usual overbearing bombast and record rewinds show up over the tracks
column7: making you wonder whether the fanfare is an extra fee rappers need to pay for.

column1: Despite all this
column2: Tory Lanez does have a buzz going
column3: and it feels like a missed opportunity that neither of these tapes offer anything more than reconstructed pieces of what’s already popular. Lanez has a great voice that appears in glimmers; on ""Say It
column4: his voice is full of vulnerability and a confidence that allows him to stay afloat the easily-recognizable Brownstone sample instead of drowning in it. The New Toronto closer ""Letter to the City"" is stripped of the theatrics and eager need to impress radio
column5: and exhibits a competent rapper trying to be heard living in a city increasingly being crafted into a hub of Drake impersonators. Competency may seem like a low bar
column6: but for now
column7:
it’s the best thing going for an artist with a lovely voice and absolutely nothing to say.

For the better part of the last decade
column3: Snoop Dogg has trafficked in clicks and views more than in listens. He's capitalized on his celebrity as well as any veteran rapper: He’s just recently spun a web-series into a legitimate TV talk show
column4: he’s still nursing and launching on-brand marijuana industry investments
column5: he makes headlines ranting to Bill Gates about Xbox on Instagram. But his music felt like a listless afterthought (remember Bush?). Daz Dillinger
column6: Snoop’s cousin
column7: has kept a lower profile: Despite producing for 2Pac on albums like All Eyez on Me
column8: his biggest headlines of recent years are probably from him trying desperately to get a Dogg Pound biopic off the ground. Still
column9: the two have never stopped recording music together.

column1: Cuzznz
column2: a full-length collaboration between Daz and Snoop
column3: was announced with the October release of a new Dâm-Funk-produced song called ""Sho You Right."" Another new single
column4: ""Best Friend
column5: followed
column6: but the album is primarily an outgrowth of years-old mixtape material repurposed as album filler. New songs pepper the tracklist instead of providing its substance
column7: and several of the recycled tracks were throwaways to begin. Adding to the album's ""what is this thing?"" quality: A limited hard-copy version was supposedly released last fall
column8: but it’s just recently become available digitally. Cuzznz was also released by a record label apparently operated by Daz Dillinger himself
column9: and
column10: a handful of new songs aside
column11: it seems entirely possible that Snoop isn’t aware that his cousin has compiled this effort.

column1: Of the 14 songs on Cuzznz
column2: around three are exclusive to the album. The newer songs
column3: including previously released tracks from an EP last year
column4: offer the only continuity here
column5: largely attributable to Dâm-Funk. Dâm's’s production on the album
column6: the type of low-stakes but infectious funk boogie he mined for 7 Days of Funk
column7: is the sustained highlight. ""It’s Not a Secret
column8: an Auto-Tune-laced glider
column9: brings the best out of Snoop’s lazily conversational delivery. ""Have U Eva"" accomplishes the same trick
column10: and Daz’s contrastingly shouty verse here might be his best on the project. ""N My System"" is an off-kilter spin on the same sound; the track is chunkier and a looped up cowbell lends an unexpected flair to the beat.

column1: By contrast
column2: the oldest song here
column3: ""Keep’a N***a High
column4: dates back to 2012 and was a sparsely produced dud back then too. A couple of other older songs
column5: like ""Happy Birthday"" and ""Phenomenon
column6: come off like failed experiments
column7: and neither neither rapper escapes looking awkward. The generic reggae hip-hop beat of ""Six N’Da Morning"" offers Snoop a chance to revisit the unfortunate
column8: forced Jamaican patois of his 2013 Snoop Lion persona. The song also highlights the type of clunky bars Snoop has stretched thin for years: ""We headed to the hookah bar/ Man
column9: I’m chilling like a superstar
column10: he says
column11: only half-rapping. The same delivery might work over different production
column12: but here it snags: These days Snoop can’t reliably carry a beat so much as slip into it.

column1: At its best
column2: Cuzznz is breezy and digestible
column3: a funky outlet for the type of relaxed rapping that both artists can still spew out endlessly. Unfortunately
column4: the album’s low points are the most memorable
column5: not only because the music is sloppy and dated
column6: but because the songs feel so awkwardly cobbled together from previous projects. Especially for a pair of accomplished veterans
column7: the album functions primarily as unnecessary compilation. If anything
column8:
Cuzznz might leave a fan wanting less instead of more.

Moths seem like an error in evolution. Instead of morphing into the bright symmetry of a butterfly
column2: a caterpillar becomes a dull and monochromatic flicker
column3: flying in meaningless orbits around a light source and sometimes annihilating itself in it. There’s something familiar in this pattern
column4: though; it resembles something as exposed and human as falling in love. ""We liked the idea of the moth as a metaphor for vulnerability
column5: Caroline Polachek of Chairlift said in an interview with Pitchfork last year. ""There are risks everywhere
column6: but it doesn’t question them.""

column1: ""Crying in Public
column2: one of the advance singles from the duo’s new album
column3: Moth
column4: is about being so overwhelmed with emotion
column5: with the feeling of falling in love
column6: that the narrator starts crying on the train. ""Each autumn leaf and passing breath
column7: Polachek sings. ""Each antidote to sudden death."" The song captures the near-panicky edge to this feeling
column8: the moment your environment becomes so charged with possibility you find yourself noticing everything: birds
column9: breakdancers
column10: light pouring in through trees. It's too much
column11: and its too-muchness makes you feel small
column12: like an exposed nerve in a vast world. On Moth
column13: Polachek and her bandmate Patrick Wimberly aim to embrace this too-muchness
column14: expanding their sound and opening themselves up
column15: and the result is the indie pop band’s most emotionally generous and consistent effort yet.

column1: ""Crying in Public"" is the song on Moth that most resembles their earlier work
column2: a kind of flowing and gelatinous synth pop that feels dense and enveloping
column3: the texture of feeling itself. It seems related to the buoyancy of ""Bruises
column4: from their debut
column5: or to ""I Belong in Your Arms
column6: from 2012’s Something
column7: but while those records described the cellular rush of love
column8: ""Crying"" describes love’s ability to gently create inner and outer space. There’s also a groove buried in the texture of the song
column9: a kind of irregular flutter at its center
column10: as if Chairlift are deliberately trying to simulate heart arrhythmia.

column1: It’s in this often-fidgety percussion that Moth distinguishes itself from Chairlift’s other records. Sometimes it feels as if the drums were sketched out first and the songs built organically around them. Lead single ""Ch-Ching"" forms itself explicitly around handclaps alternating with glassy and brittle drums. It’s both animated and oddly inflexible
column2: and the effect is disconcerting
column3: like watching a skeleton learn how to walk. ""Show U Off"" inherits its groove from Busta Rhymes’ ""Put Your Hands Where My Eyes Could See"" and fills its blank spaces in with nervous post-disco guitar.

column1: Sometimes this instability intensifies their compositions. Closer ""No Such Thing as Illusion"" feels so empty that it sort of works like an incomplete jigsaw puzzle
column2: its pockets of nothing enhancing the something. ""Polymorphing"" evolves through at least three different arrangements. The horn charts are possibly the most striking feature of the record; saxophones unreel in trembling ribbons or sprout from the songs in abrupt
column3: harmonic blooms. It’s only when Moth loses this tailored sense of groove that it starts to feel shapeless; ""Ottawa to Osaka"" melts in and out of coherence
column4: and ""Unfinished Business"" is only motivated by an irregular
column5: clustering snare and Polachek’s vocal
column6: which approaches notes as if they were mapped coordinates.

column1: Sometimes the arrangements verge on fussy; there’s an airless quality to ""Romeo
column2: which is both distracting and appropriate
column3: as the song’s about running
column4: exhaling instead of inhaling. Polachek sings from the perspective of Atalanta
column5: an elusive character from Greek mythology
column6: and the drums underpinning the song give it the rhythm of one of Atalanta’s footraces
column7: to which she would challenge her potential suitors in order to avoid marriage. ""I’m going to run/ ‘Til you give me a reason to stop/ To fall on my knees
column8: Polachek sings
column9: as if challenging someone to surprise her
column10: as if she’s allowing herself the capacity for surprise.

column1: For all of these tics and irregularities
column2: Moth is overall Chairlift's best and smoothest long-player statement. As much as the singles on Something thrilled
column3: it struggled for coherence from song to song. The songs on Moth feel related and extroverted
column4: pulled together by a common purpose. They have a charming asymmetry
column5:
they drift in sometimes oblique and irregular patterns. This is pop that wants to show you what it’s made of.
