This past October
column2: Eleanor Friedberger released ""False Alphabet City
column3: a groovy one-off single all about the ""city that betrayed her."" Like many musicians before her
column4: Friedberger has long made New York City her favorite stage. Her songs
column5: which roll with a bouncy '70s pop nostalgia
column6: are peppered with stories of getting sick riding the Coney Island Cyclone
column7: snapping pictures in front of a sweet Lamborghini on Manhattan Avenue
column8: and the small
column9: poignant act of muting Taxi TV. But with a bitter edge in its tone
column10: ""False Alphabet City"" played like an earnest goodbye
column11: to the noise
column12: to whoever hurt her
column13: to the false glamour of urban spaces.

column1: So after over a decade of Brooklyn dwelling
column2: Friedberger moved to upstate New York and wrote her third solo album New View. And while Personal Record was populated with energized
column3: electric rock songs and party-hopping anthems
column4: New View’s territory is far more easygoing
column5: more traditional in its structure. The record’s no-fuss
column6: featherlight acoustic pop songs weave into one another seamlessly
column7: Friedberger’s melodies familiar and redolent of artists like Harry Nilsson and Neil Young without playing like nostalgia. But even if New View’s overall aesthetic may pair nicely with your laziest summer Sunday morning
column8: there’s an undercurrent of serious melancholia in Friedberger’s writing here
column9: setting it apart tonally from her previous two records.

column1: What’s palpable on New View is a sense of loneliness. You might even say hermitry
column2: as Friedberger’s writing here suggests
column3: at times
column4: a mindset distanced from physical society. The hazy ""Open Season"" plays like Friedberger writing a letter to a long-lost friend or lover whose whereabouts she doesn’t know. ""Is it freezing over there? I’m opening a tree museum
column5: that’s my new hobby
column6: she sings
column7: seemingly poking fun at how settled her life has become. On ""Cathy With the Curly Hair
column8: a bopping
column9: synth-laden outlier
column10: Friedberger goes through the calendar months recounting memories of an unraveled relationship. In a year when catching up on an old friend’s whereabouts is as easy as Googling their name
column11: New View’s ponderings might seem anachronistic
column12: too reliant on in-person communication. But perhaps we all know by now that loneliness can be just as prevalent in a hyper-connected present.

column1: An interesting thread throughout New View’s equal parts wistful and frustrated tales of breakups is how often Friedberger explicitly refers to writing about them. She mentions that she knows she'll write about someone
column2: to the experience of listening to her own songs when she has nothing more to say
column3: to her own stage fright. On ""Never Is a Long Time
column4: Friedberger invokes the cynical energy of Lindsey Buckingham’s Tusk cuts
column5: particularly ""Walk a Thin Line
column6: as she sings of a relationship's undoing in an uncharacteristically low and trembling voice
column7: a single drum banging haphazardly in the background. ""We are less than nothing
column8: nothing is a perfect rhyme
column9: she sings.

column1: In the past
column2: Friedberger has loaded her music with little pedestrian anecdotes that feel specific to her songwriting
column3: bits of wordplay and vivid descriptions of acquaintances and locations. Sometimes she gets there on New View
column4: particularly on ""Does Turquoise Work?"" and ""All Known Things"" which includes kissing in a mausoleum
column5:
but the album is largely devoid of these lyrical quirks. In their place is a kind of self-aware storytelling that plays like Friedberger is letting us in to a very personal process. At times New View can seem like a concept record detailing Friedberger's ambivalence about her main gift: spinning fragile memories and feelings into accessible songs.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/22612/homepage_large.326f21d2.jpg|Night Thoughts|3970.0|Suede|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Suede Limited']|2016-01-20 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 16:02:27.231148|"

Blackstar isn’t the only album released this month to take on added poignancy in the wake of David Bowie’s passing. Suede are releasing a new album mere weeks after Bowie did the same—just like in March 2013
column2: when both parties released comeback records following decade-long hiatuses. And while the timing may be purely coincidental
column3: it’s an uncanny circumstance for a band that
column4: throughout the '90s
column5: provided the most resounding reminder of Bowie’s early-'70s supremacy
column6: and helped rehabilitate his rep amidst a career nadir for a new generation of pretty things. Listening to Night Thoughts now is like hearing a eulogy from a favorite son—from its quasi-conceptual structure to its stardust-speckled guitar riffage to its abundance of misfit anthems and concert hall-crumbling ballads
column7: the record is a testament to Bowie’s steely determination to make every song a seismic event.

column1: That said
column2: Suede are like the faithful scions who inherited the old family home
column3: but didn't do much redecoration. They never shared their godhead’s flair for radical reinvention and experimentation; their discography effectively imagines an alternate 1975 where Bowie never went to Philly and continued to mine the dark majesty of the Aladdin Sane/Diamond Dogs era on through the '80s. The parameters of their sound were pretty much set with their first two albums—1993’s snappy
column4: scrappy self-titled debut and 1994’s darkly ornate Dog Man Star—and the records that followed slid back and forth between those extremes. Bloodsports
column5: their laudable 2013 return effort
column6: hedged its bets by positioning itself smack dab in the middle of that spectrum
column7: with the album’s invigorating first side balanced by a weightier second act. Their comeback now assured and their bravado fully restored
column8: with Night Thoughts
column9: Suede once again leap up off the dancefloor to swing from the chandeliers.

column1: Night Thoughts isn’t a rock opera per se
column2: though it gamely assumes the form of one. Several songs bleed into one another through swirling interstitials; the opening track is reprised in the penultimate position
column3: Sgt. Pepper’s-style; and it sounds like at least half the recording budget was spent on the orchestra. It’s also accompanied by a fitfully bleak feature-length film (directed by NME photographer/Libertines documentarian Roger Sargent) that shows a drowning man’s reminiscences about the familial tragedy that’s driven him to commit suicide in the sea. (The band previewed the album last fall with front-to-back live performances synced up to the film.) But the songs themselves don’t actually form a linear narrative arc
column4: reference specific characters
column5: or directly correlate to the visuals. They’re more discrete portraits of passion
column6: ostracization
column7: betrayal
column8: and depression—hardly uncharted territory for a Suede record. But the sheer
column9: fetishistic intensity with which Brett Anderson delivers his lascivious lyrics—coupled with the balcony-baiting
column10: pomped-up performance of the band—makes the wounds feel newly opened and the bruises freshly pressed.

column1: That Night Thoughts’ cinematic companion piece centers around the story of an unglamorous middle-class family—rather than
column2: say
column3: the freakish
column4: fashionable deviants that populate the band’s signature songs—underscores an essential truth about Suede today: They are no longer young people
column5: and no longer speaking for them. Once the poster children for porcelain-skinned druggy excess
column6: they’re now the embattled survivors sharing cautionary tales of bad decisions and dreams unfulfilled. Night Thoughts is framed by the opening ""When You Are Young"" and its late-album echo ""When You Were Young""—shore-crashing surges of symphonic psychedelia that dissipate into Anderson’s rueful ruminations about the idealism of youth and the impossibility of recapturing it. While the album’s title may hint at seedy suggestion
column7: Night Thoughts is more about those traumatic
column8: sleep-depriving memories that have you tossing and turning and ""tumbling out of a single bed.""

column1: It’s a record about addiction
column2: to be sure
column3: but to an intoxicant more elusive
column4: potent
column5: and damaging than any street drug: desire. And like any stimulant
column6: the highs are ecstatic (see: ""Outsiders
column7: a stained-sheet celebration of odd-couple consummation
column8: or the nostalgically trashy ""Like Kids"") and the lows are crushing (see: pretty much everything else). The titles tell you exactly what you’re getting yourself into—""I Don’t Know How to Reach You
column9: ""What I’m Trying to Tell You
column10: ""Tightrope
column11: ""I Can’t Give Her What She Wants""—each song more desperate and depraved than the one before
column12: culminating in the latter’s intimations of violence (""The keys are falling from her coat/ As I weave my fingers around her perfumed throat""). Though a master of evocative detail
column13: Anderson doesn't care much for narrative exposition—rather than set a scene
column14: he prefers to thrust you into the thick of the moment where it’s all about to fall apart. And depending on your disposition
column15: Night Thoughts concludes with either with a happy ending
column16: or a dispiriting one. The swashbuckling
column17: orchestro-ballad finale
column18: ""The Fur & the Feathers
column19: finds Anderson valorizing ""the thrill of the chase""—an optimistic suggestion that even the most bitter
column20: agonizing breakup can’t diminish the rush of romance
column21: or the brazen affirmation of a damaging
column22: heart-ravaging habit that’ll inevitably lead to more sleepless nights. For the sake of Suede’s ongoing renaissance
column23:
let’s hope it’s the latter.

"|21417.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21417-night-thoughts/|7.5|Stuart Berman

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/22704/homepage_large.3af9de07.jpg|School Girl Distortional Addict|33416.0|Number Girl|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Jetset']|2016-01-20 00:00:00|1999|2016-06-11 16:02:27.496121|"<div class=""contents dropcap"" data-reactid="".1v4u9ui0k5c.1.6:0.1.0.$21400/=1$21400.0.3.2.0.1.0.1""><div class=""ii gt m152316f5b59cee6f adP adO"" id="":1j4"">

As the 1990s crawled to a close
column2: the Japanese music industry—and the nation as a whole—was at a crossroads. The economy held strong and Japan had fostered a ""cool"" image globally
column3: reflected in the slick Eurodance-inspired songs being exported across the continent and the jet-setting sampledelica of Shibuya-kei
column4: highlighted by genre heavyweights Cornelius and Pizzicato Five who landed on U.S. imprint Matador Records. Yet as 2000 came into view
column5: the mood started to change
column6: as what many now label the ""Lost Decade"" came of age and music sales peaked in 1999
column7: in decline ever since.

column1: Amidst all this pre-millennial tension
column2: a quartet reared on distortion called Number Girl landed on major label EMI Music Japan and spiked the nation’s rock scene for good. They played fast and abrasive music prone to sudden tempo changes
column3: with guitarist and lead vocalist Shutoku Mukai’s snarled vocals adding extra force and honesty to their feedback-bludgeoned songs. This wasn’t—and still isn’t—the easiest route to goofy TV interviews and massive festival scream-alongs in Japan
column4: but from 1999 until disbanding in 2002
column5: Number Girl left a deep impression on domestic listeners and carved out a cult following abroad. Universal Music Japan is reissuing the group’s three major-label albums this month
column6: a trio of work still looming large over the country’s rock scene and among the best music to come out of the country in recent memory.

column1: Mukai formed Number Girl in 1995
column2: but his initial lineup dissolved quickly. He reached out to other musicians in Fukuoka—a city resting far south from the glitz of Tokyo—and found guitarist Hisako Tabuchi
column3: bassist Kentaro Nakao
column4: and drummer Ahito Inazawa. The four
column5: all in their early twenties
column6: drew inspiration from 1980s American indie
column7: taking cues from Hüsker Dü and Pixies among others
column8: and sometimes nodded to their influence via lyrics or song titles (""Iggy Pop Fan Club""). Number Girl offered glimpses of what they would become across two self-released cassette tapes and their 1997 indie debut School GirlBye Bye: Mukai’s larynx-ripping singing
column9: Tabuchi’s commanding guitar solos
column10: and a lyrical fixation on adolescence. Yet in these early years
column11: they turned to the records their idols made like CliffsNotes
column12: leaning too much on replication rather than finding their own sound.

column1: After moving to Tokyo in 1998
column2: the band snagged more attention for their live shows
column3: leading to EMI scooping them up in 1999. That summer
column4: they broke through with School Girl Distortional Addict
column5: a frantic 36-minute affair pairing pummeling noise with the catchiest melodies Number Girl ever laid down. Despite major label backing
column6: Distortional Addict sounds raw
column7: several songs opening with tape hiss and screamed countdowns
column8: like they were coming straight from the cramped clubs Number Girl normally played. From opener ""Touch""'s pound to ""Tenkousei""'s guitar blitz
column9: the songs here hit hard
column10: even before Mukai’s voice tumbled in and added extra unpredictability.

column1: Although Number Girl still wore their sonic influences proudly—the second song here is called ""Pixie Dü""—they had evolved from kids imitating their favorite CDs into a group confident enough to get their own voice out into the scrum. Distortional Addict zooms in on the teenage experience the band’s members weren’t far removed from
column2: echoed in the album artwork and the video for lead single/album highlight ""Toumei Shoujo."" The songs could sound angry
column3: but were never self-loathing or cynical. Rather
column4: they captured the confusion of leaving childhood behind and the uncertainty that follows. The characters roaming these songs grapple with the fear of mortality (on the shrapnel-sharp ""Sakura No Dance"") to the recurring desire to chase one’s dream (a reflection of Number Girl’s own decision to leave the comforts of Fukuoka for Tokyo). Yet Mukai’s songwriting made room for other viewpoints
column5: too. ""Nichijou Ni Ikiru Shoujo"" starts as a punk-friendly mosher
column6: but eventually everything stops and it turns into a half-speed meditation on what leading an ""everyday life"" entails.

column1: Distortional Addict also tapped into pre-millennial anxiety
column2: a tension that popped up frequently in other Japanese pop culture in 1999. It was there in the novel Battle Royale (which
column3: like Distortional Addict
column4: focused on teenagers) and in fellow Fukuoka artist (and deep fan of Tabuchi and her attention-demanding playing) Sheena Ringo’s popular debut album released just before Number Girl's. Distortional Addict
column5: though
column6: captured the vibe better than the rest
column7: balancing anxiety about tomorrow with a sweet nostalgia for the past.

column1: That sweetness all but vanished on the following year’s Sappukei
column2: wherein adulthood’s ugly realities pushed youth away. The band had attracted a large fanbase in Japan
column3: but also caught the ear of longtime Mercury Rev and Flaming Lips producer David Fridmann
column4: who stepped on to produce Number Girl’s much-anticipated follow-up (and their final album). The overall sound didn’t change radically
column5: as the songs still mostly power ahead with a few sudden shifts in speed (and a lot of fierce solos courtesy of Tabuchi)
column6: but everything sounds grimier. Fitting
column7: given Mukai’s sudden shift to singing about the ugly parts of urban living. Whatever optimism snuck into their previous material was snuffed out here.

column1: Number Girl could still write a battering number
column2: but Sappukei (translation: ""Tastelessness"") also found Mukai simply screaming more. When done right
column3: it hit hard
column4: like on the push-pull guitar surge of ""Zegen Vs Undercover
column5: but elsewhere it just upped the volume without adding impact. Sappukei found Number Girl experimenting a touch more
column6: but ultimately comes off like a transitional piece for a band starting to get restless with their sound
column7: but not ready to throw caution totally away.

column1: They got weird on 2002’s Num-Heavymetallic
column2: a gleefully confrontational set from a band who easily could have by then coasted on a solid fan base. The title track opens with the sound of Mukai screaming frantically from far away before he switches abruptly into the traditional Japanese enka style of singing
column3: while his bandmates show they can sound just as heavy at a narcotized pace. That’s followed up by ""Num-Ami-Dabutz
column4: a lurching number constantly buzz-sawed in half by Tabuchi’s guitar. Mukai breaks into a spoken-word that gave his bleak outlook on urban life a hypnotic quality. It’s a high point in the band’s history
column5: and definitely a favorite when trying to figure out the most bizarre song to ever crash the Japanese singles chart.

column1: Nothing else on the album approached the wildness of those two songs
column2: but the rest of Num-Heavymetallic highlighted the outfit’s growing interest in more fragmentary compositions. Some experiments worked better than others—""Frustration in My Blood"" is the point where Number Girl could get too aggro—and overall it doesn’t feel coherent. That was the point though—by 2002
column3: all the artists who had captured the uneasy feeling of the new millennium a few years prior were moving on to new territory. Num-Heavymetallic ended up being Number Girl’s last collection
column4: as bassist Nakao opted to step away
column5: and the other three decided to stop the band rather than replace him. They all went on to new
column6: successful projects
column7: highlighted by Mukai and Matsushita’s Zazen Boys outfit
column8: which continued down the wonky road their final album hinted at.

column1: Ultimately
column2: these vinyl reissues exist to capitalize on Japan’s current LP trend
column3: and the only added feature—a Fridmann remastering of all three—feels unnecessary
column4: as the often hissy sound added to these album’s charm. But they mostly feel strange because Number Girl’s music remains so visible
column5: both in a literal sense (these have already been released as special edition CDs multiple times) and in a more abstract way. Few Japanese bands have proven to be as influential as Number Girl
column6: with festival-headliners such as Asian Kung-Fu Generation and rising groups like tricot claiming them as primary influences. But even more important are the countless bands wailing away in small live houses in Fukuoka and in Tokyo’s Koenji neighborhood and in any small countryside town
column7: because of these four
column8: not to mention the non-Japanese listeners seeking something different
column9: who hunted the group’s material down through Soulseek or shady message boards before YouTube became reliable. They came to prominence at a time when many felt anxious about the future
column10: but Number Girl carried the same torch held by their U.S. indie idols and showed a whole new generation of kids in Japan they could make any music that they wanted.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/22766/homepage_large.17411326.jpg|Here Come the Rattling Trees|1942.0|The High Llamas|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Drag City']|2016-01-20 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 16:02:28.212888|"

Here Come the Rattling Trees
column2: the 11th studio album by baroque pop ensemble the High Llamas
column3: exists as a means to an end. As the cover says
column4: the music on this short and sweet LP was written by the group’s leader and principal songwriter Sean O’Hagan to accompany a theater production of the same name
column5: with the brief interludes and tunes meant to be woven between monologues by the play’s six characters. Initially presented in October of 2014 at the Tristan Bates Theatre in London’s Covent Garden
column6: the intention is to eventually take the show on a tour through Europe and the U.S. But since O’Hagan has no theatrical bona fides to speak of
column7: the only way to make it happen is to treat it like the promotional campaign for a new record.

column1: Revealing Rattling Trees as a soundtrack from the jump puts the Llamas at an advantage and a disadvantage. It helps to explain the structure of the album
column2: which kicks off with an overture that touches on all the melodic themes to be heard later
column3: followed by quick instrumental bits that precede actual songs. But without the full text of the play or a chance to see it before hearing the music
column4: these pleasant-but-slight songs become more negligible.

column1: It’s a shame
column2: too
column3: because the play happens to be quite affecting. Rattling Trees uses extended anecdotes to comment on the rapid changes happening in London
column4: particularly in Peckham
column5: a region in the southeastern part of the city where O’Hagan has lived for over 20 years. As the performance moves along
column6: we hear from a plumber
column7: a cafe worker in her sixties
column8: a decorator
column9: a housewife
column10: and a health fanatic
column11: each lamenting or appreciating the monied middle class pouring into the neighborhood and bringing with them higher rents and expensive tastes.

column1: With just the music to go by
column2: the lyrics lose much of their impact. So
column3: too
column4: does the sparkling ""Livorno"" need the context of the plumber marveling at the pretentious attitudes of the bourgeois couple he’s working for to really give the song some weight. Other tracks fare better: The lovely ""Jackie"" leavens the melancholy of the cafe worker’s rather drab day-to-day existence with a bouncy

column3: with actors standing in the middle delivering their lines. This meant that O’Hagan was forced to strip back the instrumentation considerably
column4: and he really rose to the challenge: Even without those extra Van Dyke Parks-like splashes of symphonic color
column5: the album is still instantly recognizable as a High Llamas production. Instead
column6: the space gets filled with quick stabs of upright piano or wah-wah-ed guitar lines or
column7: on the plucky ""Mona’s Song
column8: some tight vocal harmonies repeating a single phrase.

column1: The play is set in front of an old leisure centre that has been bought up by a larger company and rebranded with a new name and look. As each character enters the show
column2: they comment on this change
column3: often wondering why the change needed to happen. Though O’Hagan surely didn’t mean it as such
column4: that stands as a tidy metaphor for the pop music landscape that he and his Llamas enter into every few years or so. For 25 years now

column6: but we also need to ask: Even when the music is wrapped up within the framework of a theater performance

will there be anyone listening?

Whether under his own name or from various side projects
column2: Ty Segall has kept new music waiting around the corner for years. Over a mountain of releases
column3: he's proven that he can shred multiple times over
column4: and that he can match that intensity in his acoustic singer/songwriter mode. It's fair to ask what else he can do at this point. With Emotional Mugger
column5: we've arrived at a turning point for Segall: After inundating us for years
column6: what can he do to keep people listening?

column1: Emotional Mugger needed to be special to stand apart—a shock to the Segall system—and he hints at a new aesthetic direction from the outset. Where his last album Manipulator opened with stately organ
column2: the synthesizers on Mugger are abrasive and off-kilter. Throughout the album
column3: he is less focused on hitting the exact right notes and more concerned with establishing an offbeat vibe
column4: one matching the cheerful menace of the smiling doll heads on the sleeve. The pace and structure of ""California Hills"" is briefly upended a few times for short bursts of frantic guitar work
column5: and throughout the album
column6: he switches between his traditional singing voice and a throaty
column7: affected mystic dirtbag caricature.

column1: There's also an underlying narrative
column2: although it would be a reach to call it a full-on ""concept album."" Each song seems to be an oblique short story about cheap thrills
column3: and throughout
column4: his metaphor of choice is candy. The album's populated with addicts—people engineered to come back for more despite how shitty it may ultimately make them feel. Sub out the word ""candy"" for pretty much any other vapid
column5: hollow pleasure in the world (and sometimes you wish he would—I respect his wish to keep his metaphors consistent
column6: but occasionally his repetition of the same words leads the songs to blur together).

column1: Since it's an album sending up society's constant demand for instant gratification
column2: it feels petty and impatient to occupy its world thinking
column3: ""This hook was cool at first
column4: but it's losing my attention."" But that's the truth of Emotional Mugger—a few songs just churn over the same hook
column5: and ultimately
column6: there's just not enough happening to hold interest. Despite an assist from Mikal Cronin and Melvins' Dale Crover
column7: Segall's take on Eddy Grant's Equals song ""Diversion"" is repetitive
column8: unvarying
column9: and notably less interesting than the source material.

column1: Thankfully
column2: it's a Segall album
column3: which means his missteps are tempered by a few phenomenal performances. ""Candy Sam"" features one of his best big-tent guitar solos on record
column4: though the album's best song is ""Mandy Cream""—there's not much else that sounds like it in Segall's discography. The drums root the song in funk (courtesy of Segall's frequent collaborator Charles Moothart) while a droning synthesizer and his guitar solo bring both percussive supplements and weird punk hooks into the fold. Also worth noting: There are vocals from King Tuff.

column1: That's another major departure for Segall on Emotional Mugger—his team. In addition to his usual co-conspirators Cronin and Moothart
column2: he's surrounded himself by heavy-hitters like Kyle Thomas
column3: producer F. Bermudez (who helmed recent records by Gun Outfit and No Age)
column4: Wand's Cory Hanson and Evan Burrows
column5: and the Cairo Gang's Emmett Kelly. And with his collaborators (dubbed ""the Muggers"") at his side
column6: he's done an excellent job of establishing an unsettling tone across the album—one where cooing moans of pleasure on ""Baby Big Man (I Want a Mommy)"" are bulldozed by him grunting the words ""BIG MAN.""

column1: When Segall rolled out the album by mailing VHS copies to writers
column2: he shared a clinical definition of ""emotional mugging
column3: explaining
column4: ""The over-communication relayed in cell based technology and content driven media further detaches passengers of our modern society from deep emotional understanding."" Put more simply: The Internet makes everything and anything immediately available
column5: and that's probably fucking up how people interact and have their desires addressed. It's a relevant subject without question—one he addresses on the album with varying degrees of success. Maybe its diciest moments can be chalked up to the album's inherent feeling of uneasiness
column6:
but Emotional Mugger still feels transitional—either the moment before he tucks in and gets way weirder or another stepping stone before he switches gears all over again.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/22648/homepage_large.393069a7.jpg|Bells/Prophecy|184.0|Albert Ayler|['Jazz']|0.0|0.0|1.0|['ESP-Disk']|2016-01-18 00:00:00|1964|2016-06-11 16:02:33.018002|"

Albert Ayler’s music was defined by its excesses. He played tenor saxophone with too much vibrato and too much feeling
column2: outlining melodies that were too simple and too catchy before descending into skronky noise that was too harsh and too unsettling. Where jazz had been defined by its relationship to form
column3: with musicians practicing their craft within established idioms or inching beyond them to create something else
column4: Ayler’s music was too amorphous for any container
column5: a volatile liquid churning and splashing and running over and generally making a glorious mess.

column1: Ayler’s epochal studio recordings were made for the tiny ESP-Disk label in 1964 and '65. The first released was Spiritual Unity
column2: and it was immediately recognized by those who heard it as a landmark. Five years earlier
column3: saxophonist Ornette Coleman had reconfigured his group so that it no longer contained a piano
column4: the first crack in the fissure that would soon become free jazz. By de-emphasizing chord changes
column5: which provide the harmonic foundation for improvisation that had defined jazz since its inception
column6: Coleman opened the music to new possibilities but also created confusion: If you could play virtually anything when you soloed
column7: what made one player or one composition better than another?

column1: On his early recordings
column2: working with the trio of bassist Gary Peacock and drummer Sunny Murray
column3: Ayler helped clarify the answer to that question. The general shape of <i>Prophecy
column4: a live record capturing a date in June 1964 and reissued here in expanded form
column5: hews very closely to that of Spiritual Unity
column6: which was recorded in the studio one month later. Ayler’s trio begins a given piece by playing one of the sing-song melodies that were pouring out of him during this period
column7: melodies often based on simple folk songs from Western Europe. These fragments are so simple and memorable
column8: in fact
column9: that they are pretty much the definition of what we would now call earworms
column10: the kind of tunes you might hear a five-year-old humming—think ""Patty Cake"" or ""The ABC Song""— or else melodramatic march songs
column11: like Ayler’s ""Spirits Rejoice
column12: based on the French national anthem ""La Marseillaise."" Much of the tension in Ayler’s early work comes in waiting for these theme statements to splinter and fall apart and be pulled into unrecognizable shapes. Once that happens
column13: beauty clashes with ugliness
column14: lines between joy and mourning dissolve
column15: and the music becomes a torrent of undifferentiated emotion.

column1: Despite his music’s structural freedom
column2: technique was essential to Ayler’s art. He had a booming
column3: bottom-heavy tone reminiscent of the honking sax players who dominated 1940s and '50s R&B
column4: but he could also reach to the shrillest higher registers
column5: and he played with an ultra-wide
column6: quavering vibrato that brought to mind the ecstatic trembling of gospel music. Bassist Gary Peacock alternated droning bowed lines with a spindly single-note attack
column7: and Murray moved drumming away from its timekeeping role and
column8: leaning heavily on his cymbals
column9: into the realm of pure texture. All this comes together here on ""Ghosts
column10: Ayler’s definitive piece—he recorded it over and over during his early years
column11: both live and in the studio
column12: finding new possibilities every time he deconstructed its jaunty opening theme. Prophecy presents both the ""First Variation"" and ""Second Variation"" (Ayler’s song titles were often confusing
column13: with the same titles sometimes used for different pieces)
column14: which both found their way to Spiritual Unity. The trio crackles with life as they present the song here
column15: seemingly aware that they were ushering in a new era.

column1: The original Prophecy consisted of five tunes; this expanded version presents those alongside the rest of the music recorded that evening
column2: which initially appeared on the Holy Ghost box set in 2004. Having it all together in one place makes sense. The other music included on this reissue is the 20-minute piece ""Bells
column3: which was recorded live in 1965 and initially released as a one-sided EP. Though they have been paired together on CD for some time now
column4: there’s no particular reason for ""Bells"" and Prophecy to be considered together
column5: but early Ayler has been re-released and re-packaged steadily in the CD era.

column1: If Prophecy found Ayler at the dawn of his game-changing new sound
column2: ""Bells"" hinted at where he would go in his middle period
column3: expanding his band and stringing together longer pieces built from smaller parts. (Though presented as a single piece
column4: ""Bells"" is a number of shorter tunes that flow into each other.) Adding alto saxophonist Charles Tyler and his brother Donald Ayler on trumpet and switching Lewis Worrell for Peacock on bass
column5: ""Bells"" explores how Ayler’s music worked in an ensemble. In another year he would add strings to his then-current touring band and they would become a bizarre and supremely moving sort of chamber orchestra (the peak recordings of this band can be found on The Complete Greenwich Village Sessions). ""Bells"" has hints of that development; it’s an essential snapshot of the moment if not quite one of Ayler’s essential releases.

column1: One of the most telling sounds on this release exists outside the music. As ""Ghosts (Second Variation)"" ends in an impassioned stream of notes from Ayler and moaning vocals from one of his sidemen and he re-states the opening theme
column2: we hear the applause of the audience
column3: which sounds like it’s coming from 10 people tops. It’s true that this is Ayler at the start of his career
column4: but it hints at the lonely road walked by an artist who sees the world differently. Ayler had a huge raft of great music ahead of him
column5:
but also a lot of heartache.

"|21345.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21345-bellsprophecy/|8.4|Mark Richardson

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/22762/homepage_large.987b48c0.jpg|A Coliseum Complex Museum|5134.0|The Besnard Lakes|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Jagjaguwar']|2016-01-18 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 16:02:33.644408|"

The Besnard Lakes are named for a real lake
column2: but they’ve always been more closely associated with a studio. During the great Canadian indie rock boom of the mid-'00s
column3: singer/guitarist Jace Lasek’s Breakglass Studios hosted bands like Wolf Parade
column4: the Unicorns
column5: Stars
column6: and Land of Talk
column7: capturing the imagination of music writers eager to pinpoint a connective thread behind Montreal’s music scene. Few of the acts that passed through Breakglass’s doors
column8: however
column9: put the studio to use quite like Besnard Lakes
column10: who committed themselves to the ""studio as an instrument"" mentality of Lasek’s idol Brian Wilson on each of their sweeping
column11: meticulously crafted albums. They’re the type of records that could have only been made by a band with a producer in its ranks.

column1: The studio’s influence remains as strong as ever on the Besnards’ fifth album
column2: A Coliseum Complex Museum
column3: but this time the band’s namesake lake also makes its presence felt. For the first time
column4: Lasek and bassist/co-lead Olga Goreas began demoing songs at the remote lake in Saskatchewan
column5: where the couple had often discussed music but as a rule had previously resisted recording it. ""It’s a great place for contemplation
column6: Lasek explained in an interview last year. ""There’s nobody up there
column7: it’s really hard to get to and you could spend a whole day not seeing anybody
column8: just standing on a beach surrounded by trees and water."" Coliseum’s lyrics draw from those natural surroundings
column9: fixating on the skies
column10: the elements
column11: and animals
column12: both real and imagined (the album opens with ""The Bray Road Beast"" and ""Golden Lion
column13: each about a fantastical creature).

column1: So A Coliseum Complex Museum is the band’s nature album
column2: but mostly it’s another Besnard Lakes album
column3: and more or less a mirror of 2013’s <i><a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17749-the-besnard-lakes-until-in-excess-imperceptible-ufo/"">Until in Excess
column4: Imperceptible UFO
column5: right down to its refrigerator magnet poetry title
column6: glimmering guitars
column7: and Floydian ambitions. ""The Bray Road Beast"" wastes no time channeling Dark Side of the Moon
column8: with a star-gazing guitar line traced from ""Eclipse
column9: while ""Pressure of Our Plans"" and ""Towers Sent Her to Sheets of Sound"" each culminate in a thicket of swirling psychedelia. These songs run a bit shorter than those on Until in Excess
column10: but they’re every bit as dense.

column1: The album lightens somewhat in its second half
column2: as Goreas takes on a greater role vocally. Her game spotlight turn on the slick
column3: unusually groove-oriented ""The Plain Moon"" is the closest Coliseum comes to matching the hooky rush of Until in Excess’ standout ""People of the Sticks."" The Low-esque ""Necronomicon"" is even dreamier
column4: a respite from some of the album’s busier tracks that shows how good this band can sound when they dial things back. As if to make up for that relative restraint
column5: though
column6: the album closes on a note of excess with ""Tungsten 4: The Refugee
column7: six minutes of heaving classic rock that signs off with a purge of blustery guitar solos.

column1: Coliseum stacks everything in the right place
column2: and it’s all executed with the usual precision
column3: so why doesn’t the album dazzle quite like the last few? Like the four albums before it
column4: the Besnards self-recorded and self-produced this one at Breakglass
column5: and more than its predecessors
column6: it begs for an outside collaborator
column7: somebody to shake up the band’s routine and perhaps lend some new tricks to their shrinking playbook. The joy of a great space-rock album
column8: after all
column9: comes not just from the sense of vastness
column10: but also from the potential for surprise
column11: the possibility that a thrilling reveal could be hiding behind every turn. After five albums
column12: the Besnard Lakes don’t have many of those big surprises left in them. They still have galaxy-sized ambitions
column13: but the galaxy they’re constructing is beginning to feel like a very small
column14:
overly familiar place.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/22707/homepage_large.7125dfc3.jpg|Ou|32573.0|Lucrecia Dalt|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Care of Editions']|2016-01-18 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:02:34.678950|"

Experimental electronic artist Lucrecia Dalt explores uncertainty. It's what she does best
column2: with curiosity and a self-effacing confidence; it's no coincidence that the title of her fifth record literally translates to ""or"" in Portuguese. It’s an album of options
column3: expectations
column4: and the lingering hope that occurs when there’s a possibility of something better. Dalt repurposed her studio as a makeshift theater to screen films by Rainer Werner Fassbinder
column5: Helke Sander
column6: and other New German Cinema greats and Ou's cinematic feel is the direct result. ""When I have input from outside
column7: I start to see more surprises in what I’m making
column8: she told Julia Holter in conversation for Electronic Beats. For her
column9: movies act as personal creative partners
column10: and the four-track LP and its subsections are a live unraveling of all the surprises that come from the process.

column1: The first step is removing herself from the vocal spotlight. Opener ""OVER UNITY"" sees her whisper one indecipherable line
column2: chop it up
column3: and feed it through vocal effects to intensify each word. That’s the album’s only lyric. Meanwhile
column4: a soft beep ticks like a metronome. She uses that constant element to contrast alternative forms of timekeeping in the piece
column5: like the sputtering synths in the background. Dalt bypasses realism to pursue sounds rarely experienced in reality
column6: a point she underlines on ""OVER UNITY"" when she reshapes the piece into a traditional song structure midway
column7: drawing out asymmetrical melodies and an unconventional bassline.

column1: As fascinated as it is with time
column2: Ou is too ravenous to explore any single perception in depth. ""IOT"" breaks into three parts: ""Roto
column3: an anxious pulse of downbeats that closes with bashful clarinet; ""Quebrado
column4: a collection of broken telephone beeps and pitched-down gasps mimicking church bells; and ""Suelto
column5: a loose percussive arrangement accented with keys. The way Dalt sees it
column6: time is an object passing through various forms of sound. Why waste it standing still when you can see it through a dozen lenses?

column1: She does this by replicating Shepard tones throughout the album. Like the swirling stripes of a barber’s pole
column2: these tones—a play on pitch where a note appears to move upward or downward—is an auditory illusion that plays with perceived direction. They’re superpositioned sine waves separated by octaves
column3: swelling like that stale hum of an airplane lifting off or the rising and falling notes of THX’s infamous sound effect. The only piece exempt from this sound is also Ou’s darkest
column4: ""FLOTO
column5: where ominous saxophone and wobbling bass recall the soundtracks of low-budget alien invasion flicks.

column1: Like Laurie Anderson and those before her
column2: Lucrecia Dalt is concerned not with upholding traditions
column3: but reorganizing them—just like the label releasing the record
column4: Care of Editions
column5: which pays listeners to download its albums. On ""ELEANORE
column6: she combines wind chimes
column7: cold percussive slaps
column8: and descending string sections to draw emotional depth from daily banalities the same way the album’s artwork—sunlight leaking through a window shade like visual sine waves —does. Consider it disembodied pop where Dalt
column9: a civil engineer who specialized in geotechnics
column10: patiently reworks theories until they become scalable to the average listener. As a result
column11: Ou sounds like a test of specific temporal concepts that is best observed from a distance. If you listen too close
column12: its concept thins
column13:
and you lose your grip on the very abstract ideas Dalt is exploring.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/22736/homepage_large.04658c62.jpg|Agony Planet|32102.0|DUST|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['2MR']|2016-01-18 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 16:02:35.283346|"

The throwback house and techno that forms the foundation of DUST's Agony Planet has long been overrun with producers aiming for the crispest
column2: clearest
column3: most audiophile-quality sounds the human mind can conceive of
column4: but the Brooklyn trio goes in the opposite direction. They have coated their debut album in a fine layer of hiss and sonic grime
column5: and if you’ve been around dance music for long
column6: the murkiness might remind you of a time before the post-scarcity age of streaming music
column7: when rave devotees would trade cassette dubs of rare 12''s.

column1: Or it might remind you of an overdriven P.A.
column2: pushed far past its capabilities to power some kind of under-the-radar
column3: probably illegal rave. Coming out of the Brooklyn DIY electronic music scene
column4: that’s something DUST's members–John Barclay
column5: Mike Sherburn
column6: and Greem Jellyfish–know all about. Barclay in particular is a tireless advocate for pre-EDM
column7: pre-superclub rave ethics
column8: which he wove deeply into the events he threw at already-legendary spaces like 285 Kent (which he helped open
column9: and where DUST was among the last acts to play before it was shuttered) and Trip House
column10: a run-down Bushwick mansion that he turned into a 20-room party palace. More recently he’s gone legit with the Bossa Nova Civic Club
column11: whose shadowy back room has become a mecca for hardcore house and techno freaks.

column1: Barclay’s ventures as a promoter suggest not just nostalgia for a time when dance music was still dangerous
column2: but a fairly successful attempt to yank that kind of seductively undomesticated energy out of the good old days and into the here and now. Agony Planet fits into that scheme nicely. The music has a raw edge that comes part from the redlined production and part from the relentless body-jacking four-on-the-floor beats and stroboscopic synth arpeggios
column3: as well as tempos that feel pitched up a few percentages by the type of DJ who likes to test their audience’s physical endurance.

column1: Singer Greem Jellyfish
column2: a multimedia artist who designs her own surreal stage costumes
column3: helps push the album’s manic energy over into madness. Inverting the concept of a disco diva
column4: she yelps
column5: shrieks
column6: and moans her vocal parts
column7: drawing out the dark
column8: slightly sadistic quality woven into the beats
column9: and really all good techno in general. Her frequently wordless vocalizing suggests someone who’s lost her mind so thoroughly to the music that she’s gone post-verbal.

column1: When Agony Planet really comes together—and it doesn't
column2: always
column3: but it's a hard spot to locate— on tracks like ""Alien Prey"" and ""Tell Me
column4: the effect is downright magical. It can transport you to an unrehabbed industrial loft or maybe even the abandoned loading dock where I went to one of the best parties I’ve ever been to in my life
column5:
and recreates those transcendent moments where the DJ finds the sweet spot as close to the edge of blowing out the P.A. as they can get and all the individual spirals of drug-altered moods on the floor line up and the whole dingy space seems to lift off from Earth. And then it’ll make you want to go out this weekend and find that same sensation all over again.

"|21431.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21431-agony-planet/|6.8|Miles Raymer

Last year
column2: Kelela returned with honed-in vision
column3: sharpened songwriting
column4: and 23rd-century production for Hallucinogen
column5: a half-hour probe into the inner workings of love
column6: lust
column7: and codependency. Hallucinogen's amniotic take on club
column8: R&B
column9: and pop paired with a stronger vocal performance worked so well that it made her 2013 mixtape Cut 4 Me look like batting practice in comparison. But Kelela has always been an artist who works best when her unfettered voice is placed against unexpected backdrops: She brought effortless calm to Kingdom's metallic
column10: bass-heavy club music on Cut 4 Me; sultry pathos to Kindness' loungey
column11: sax-heavy sophomore LP Otherness; and a sense of gravity to Arca's nebulous electronics on Hallucinogen. This past Christmas
column12: in a seeming bid to show off this versatility
column13: Kelela dropped Hallucinogen Remixes
column14: an EP containing remixes of four Hallucinogen tracks that spin her style into footwork
column15: grime
column16: baile funk
column17: and other genres.

column1: Remixes opens with a high-energy mix of ""A Message
column2: courtesy of footwork legend DJ Spinn. Spinn leaves the song's structure relatively as-is
column3: adding fills of high-speed drum patterns beneath Kelela's verses to give the song a shuddering spark that puts it at thrilling odds against the original's languorous production. Brazilian baile funk artist MC Bin Laden's take on ""Rewind"" goes big
column4: using a single line from the song and studding it with drops and verses from the MC to turn it into a towering baile number that wouldn’t sound out of place on the last Major Lazer record. It's riveting
column5: but ultimately feels like filler against a vet like Spinn
column6: who evokes the same urge to dance with significantly less pomp.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: Bristol producer Kahn gives Hallucinogen highlight ""All the Way Down"" an ominous grime re-do and recruits rising Brixton artist Gaika for a guest verse
column3: whose elastic rapping and low-pitched voice work as a good complement to Kelela's diaphanous vocals. Melbourne producer Air Max ’97 gives the same song an undertow of fast-paced drumming and a few floating synth lines
column4: focusing on vivid
column5: key lines to dramatic effect: ""I'm doing things that I don't do/ So comfortable when I'm with you... I'm staying over at yours tonight/ I'm calling late
column6: let's exercise."" The most distinct remix here comes from club and ballroom DJs Mike Q and Divoli S’vere
column7: who strip away the reeling bass of Hallucinogen closer ""The High"" and substitute just a pounding heartbeat and skittering
column8: sped-up samples of Kelela’s voice. It's a creative flip on the original that
column9: alongside DJ Spinn and Kahn's entries
column10: also makes a good case for this collection's existence.

column1: That being said
column2: Hallucinogen Remixes doesn't eclipse its source material by any means—it's probably only essential if you're already a Kelela diehard. Paired with the original
column3: it at least makes for a good holdover until an official debut LP

column6:
Remixes is sufficient enough.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/22709/homepage_large.1f6ea9fe.jpg|King Stays King|5205.0|Timbaland|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2016-01-15 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:02:36.449928|"

At one point
column2: it would have seemed unfathomable that Timbaland would be making a play for relevancy. In the latter part of the '90s
column3: his full-length contributions for Aaliyah
column4: Missy Elliott
column5: and Ginuwine redirected R&B from its increasing reliance on relaxed grooves and hip-hop drums to slick
column6: broken
column7: hi-hat happy rhythms that were playful
column8: sophisticated
column9: and not-infrequently referred to as ""futuristic."" His work in R&B established him as visionary
column10: and the echoes of his sound are all over today's musical landscape—from Noah ""40"" Shebib's atmospheric moodiness to the worldwide underground of Soulection's beat scene. Timbaland took many cues from UK electronic soul styles
column11: but he also gave them back: it's impossible to listen to dubstep without hearing Ginuwine's ""Pony"" in its DNA; it's hard to imagine the UK grime scene without Missy's Da Real World. Timbaland may not have invented any of these styles but he seemed to predict and inspire them all
column12: down to EDM.

column1: If these were his only contributions to music
column2: his new mixtape—King Stays King
column3: released this past Christmas—would make sense. It would be a rehashing of glory days by a once uber-influential musician. But Timbaland's prowess wasn't limited to R&B—he also released major and minor hits for rappers of note and footnote
column4: and ushered pop artists into adulthood while blurring the lines between mature swing and youthful bounce
column5: mainstream and urban. In terms of reach
column6: his only peer of the past 20 years would be maybe Dr. Dre
column7: or Tim's hometown colleague
column8: Pharrell Williams.

column1: But in the past few years
column2: as Dre repolished his laurels and Pharrell refined himself into an inescapable pop force
column3: Timbaland languished as a struggling legacy act
column4: releasing respectably selling
column5: but forgettable solo efforts and attempting to create buzz with his Timbaland Thursdays series. None of this is what anyone saw for Timbaland—at best he would still be a major cultural power; at worst a reclusive genius releasing small
column6: but impactful records that ousted music forward. At the least
column7: he should have been Swizz Beatz—caught up with ventures beyond music but returning occasionally to the table
column8: if only to prove that he still has it. But scoring lowbrow fare like ""Empire"" and releasing a middling compilation like King Stays King
column9: was not in the trajectory.

column1: There's precious little that's adventurous about this new effort. Blaze Serving's ""Where You At!"" is darkly bubbling
column2: but leans too heavily on Future's ""Fuck Up Some Commas
column3: coming off like a local DJ's remix he plays during his set to take a bathroom break. The album's best number comes from Rico Richie
column4: a rapper perhaps best known for getting arrested when the authorities raided Young Thug's studio. On ""Drug Dealer"" Timbaland seems to be aping the Neptunes
column5: alternating between a moderately ominous swing and cavernous drums (an interesting turn
column6: considering Tim's brain-melting work on Pusha T's recent Darkest Before Dawn) but Rico
column7: like many of the rappers here
column8: comes through with mostly generic baller boasts tinged with just a hint of creativity: ""I flew her out to L.A. for the summer/ And she said she love me
column9: even though a nigga used to hit her cousin/ My niggas say I'm trippin'
column10: I'm like
column11: 'Fuck it
column12: I don't need a rubber.'"" Even the established stars fail to register above serviceable here. Who wouldn't want to hear the erratic madness of Migos
column13: 2 Chainz' goofy eccentricities
column14: and Young Thug's swallowing and taffy-like yelping on a Timbaland beat? It may be a case of elevated expectations
column15: but all their songs sound relatively straightforward—the raps feeling phoned in
column16: the beats playing catch-up.

column1: Perhaps the biggest disappointment here is that Timbaland comes off as beatmaker instead of a producer. In an era where producers like Mike WiLL Made-It and Metro Boomin cater their sounds around their artists
column2: adding subtle fluctuations
column3: transitions
column4: and progressions to their music (things Timbaland once did so well)
column5: most of the tracks here plod straight ahead. The R&B numbers here don't sound like Timbaland; they sound like the modern day sub-Timbaland impressions that get pushed on your Soundcloud playlist via algorithm. It's all functional
column6: but there isn't a single standout performance here.

column1: It can be said that Timbaland hasn't been able to create stars—most of his hits have come courtesy of artists with strong songwriting ability and intrinsic inventiveness. Aside from Missy
column2: Timbaland's most notable collaboration on this front was with Aaliyah—together the two sculptured R&B in their own image. Aaliyah appears here posthumously on ""Shakin"" and she's in classic form. As always
column3: her delivery dances with a light grace
column4: but the song sounds more like a redundant album cut than a lost gem. While it's great to hear some new classic Aaliyah
column5:
hearing not-quite classic Timbaland in 2016 only makes him seem dated.

In a Brooklyn metal scene that can sometimes seem too precious
column2: drunk on high drama and revisionist approaches
column3: Krallice have emerged as workaday heroes. In only eight years
column4: they've issued five LPs
column5: a single
column6: and an EP of sometimes absurdly rich
column7: long-form black metal. Krallice’s records have served as their manifestos
column8: their music as their answer to every online ""hipster metal"" kerfuffle in which they’ve been unwillingly implicated.

column1: This isolationist approach came into focus last July
column2: when Krallice self-released the excellent and compact Ygg Huur online with no advance notice or industry assistance. Though the move felt logical after 2012’s independently issued Years Past Matter
column3: Ygg Huur’s hype-free entry still felt like a statement about the ability of signal to transcend noise. The new Hyperion
column4: actually recorded two years before Ygg Huur

column8: 24 minutes later

column1: Taken together
column2: these three songs speak to vastly different approaches to the band’s black metal background. ""Assuming Memory"" recalls Krallice of yore
column3: its 10-minute expanse sweeping from a ruminative opening to pirouetting solos to a soft-focus close that drifts into a shoegaze haze. The title track
column4: on the other hand
column5: mirrors the concision of Ygg Huur. Krallice ricochets between sets of complementary riffs and rhythms
column6: as though trapped among the overclocked paddles of a pinball machine.

column1: But it’s between these two bookends
column2: during ""The Guilt of Time
column3: that Krallice hits a new compositional apex. It's so sly and subtle that it's easy to miss it. After about three minutes of rather conventional surges and stops
column4: the band settles into a drift and lingers there before emerging above a sustained blast beat
column5: Colin Marston and Mick Barr's guitars soaring above the rhythm section as though it were a ski jump. The guitars hold that position
column6: locked inside a piercing little back-and-forth riff; meanwhile
column7: Weinstein breaks his beat to pound out syncopated drum phrases that suggest warped snippets of military marches or maybe even a funk band. What sounds like a sustained
column8: full-band blast beat
column9: then
column10: is actually a reinforced feint. This is a new level of hyperactivity for Krallice and one of the most thrilling
column11: difficult two-minute clips of the band’s career. After you notice it
column12: you have to hear it again and again
column13: standing back to marvel at the sheer audacity of the moment.

column1: A little less than three years passed between the release of Years Past Matter in 2012 and Ygg Huur last July. It was the longest break in Krallice’s career
column2: as they’d issued at least an album every year (except 2010) since their self-titled debut. Now
column3: though
column4: they appear to be back on pace
column5: and the consecutive successes of Ygg Huur and Hyperion reinforce what (aside from the songs themselves) has long been most admirable about Krallice. This band keeps improving incrementally
column6: avoiding major statements of reinvention or re-emergence in favor of doggedly refining what it is they’ve done from the very start. Hyperion’s lyrics are loaded with references to astral objects
column7: solar bodies
column8: and mythological figures. But this is the work of a delightfully earthbound and centered band—part of a scene
column9: sure
column10: but apart from it
column11: too
column12:
more focused on the work itself than the worry around it.

The difference between a well-executed cover song and recorded karaoke is all in the details. A truly great cover retains the essence of the original while transforming it. We've seen this done well throughout the years: Aretha Franklin's unmatchable wail on Carole King's ""A Natural Woman
column2: Whitney Houston's matter-of-fact depth and gravitas on Dolly Parton's ""I Will Always Love You."" On her Covers album
column3: Cat Power infused enduring rock songs with melancholic heft
column4: occasionally mutating the source nearly beyond recognition. In every case
column5: great cover artists use another song to pull something intangible out of themselves.

column1: That is a why Mila J’s COVERGIRL never quite hits the mark. The collection of covers from R&B singers and groups feels perfectly selected
column2: but lacks the sort of personal depth to progress the project somewhere beyond the amusing. After years spent collaborating with other artists (Trey Songz
column3: Omarion) and performing under a different stage name
column4: Japallonia
column5: Mila J (born Jamila Akiko Aba Chilombo) returned in 2014 to release her debut EP
column6: M.I.L.A. The collection—featuring a collaborator on nearly every track—was a commendable if slightly forgettable collection of atmospheric tracks.

column1: It's difficult to not draw comparisons to her sister
column2: Jhené Aiko
column3: but a quick listen to M.I.L.A. and COVERGIRL clarifies the differences. Aiko
column4: despite her limited vocal range
column5: has a confidence to her aesthetic: She understands just what kind of music she aims to make and surrounds herself with the right creators to help make it. On M.I.L.A.
column6: Chilombo’s tracks drown under the weight of its production and its collaborators
column7: feeling less and less like an introduction to Mila J as the EP progresses.

column1: In some instances
column2: like the cover of Sade's ""Sweetest Taboo
column3: the production wraps itself too tightly around the original. In fact
column4: it draws your attention to the more progressive construction of the original: Sade’s ""Sweetest Taboo
column5: (and really
column6: the group’s entire catalog) survives and translates to numerous generations because it is so secretly challenging and charismatic and weird. Chilombo's cover
column7: while technically ""correct
column8: strips from the ingrained eerie heart of the original
column9: but doesn't replace it with anything else.

column1: Consider another recently released mixtape (Erykah Badu’s But You Caint Use My Phone)
column2: which features a number of covers and reworkings of telephone-themed tracks. That record was brilliant and biting
column3:
digging deep conceptually to critique and cherish it's inspiration as well as dive into the psyche of Badu. Audiences should want the same from Chilombo. What COVERGIRL tells us most about Chilombo is that she is a music fan.

If you've ever set foot in an art gallery
column2: then you know what it's like when an artist's description of their work turns out to be way more compelling than the work itself. Clearly
column3: the act of creating something distorts the perspective of the person making it
column4: which means that artists can sometimes be the least qualified people to shed light on the things they make.

column1: According to the members of Bloodiest
column2: the Chicago sextet's music is related to metal
column3: but has more in common with composers like Karlheinz Stockhausen and Morricone. That sounds enticing on paper
column4: but it's not what you hear on album opener ""Mesmerize
column5: a fairly straightahead number built on an insistent riff that manages to borrow from Tool guitarist Adam Jones while leaving out the intangibles that distinguished Jones' playing from the riffmongers of his era. The fact that a band so focused on mood and dynamics would emulate the most superficial and brutish aspects of Jones' playing makes you scratch your head—and also speaks to the pitfalls of playing musical dress-up.

column1: Though they're enthusiastic fans of metal
column2: the members of Bloodiest aren't dyed-in-the-wool metalheads. The group identifies as underground indie/post-rock at heart
column3: which makes sense considering that at various points its membership has included alums from experimental Chicago acts like 90 Day Men
column4: Lustre King
column5: and Russian Circles. Founding guitarists Tony Lazzara and Eric Chaleff played together in Sterling and Follows
column6: and vocalist Bruce Lamont plays sax and howls in the more jaggedly experimental quartet Yakuza. For better or worse
column7: they have little collective experience playing heavy stuff that openly identifies as such.

column1: To be fair
column2: sometimes you get very ""authentic"" results from people who aren't ""natives"" to the style they play. In fact
column3: several of metal's most iconic trailblazers never actually listened to the stuff much. But as you make your way through Bloodiest
column4: the band’s follow-up to its 2011 debut Descent
column5: it's hard to shake the feeling that Lazzara
column6: Chaleff
column7: and their cohorts handle these riffs with the same combination of fascination and distance that tourists show when they're in the gift shop of a foreign country
column8: where the untrained eye has a hard time spotting the difference between cliché
column9: truth
column10: and the gray area where most cultural hallmarks are actually both.

column1: There are times on Bloodiest where the band does twist otherwise conventional riffs into shapes they wouldn't have assumed in their usual habitat. On ""Broken Teeth
column2: for example
column3: one of the guitarists takes the familiar theme from Holst's ""Mars"" (the same melody you hear at the beginning of Metallica's ""Am I Evil"" cover)
column4: puts it on a cutting board
column5: and dices it up. Later in the same song
column6: Chaleff and Lazzara counterpose another coiling Adam Jones-esque riff against a drum pattern that former 90 Day Men drummer Cayce Key purposely drags so far behind the beat that it makes the whole band sound like it's stuttering. Meanwhile
column7: pianist Nandini Khaund underlays the dense
column8: sludgy wall of sound with elegant chords that hint at what Dixieland jazz might sound like in a cough-syrup induced nightmare. At moments like these
column9: regardless of whether this band falls as close to modern classical
column10: post-rock
column11: or film scores as it would have you believe
column12: it does manage to find itself in art-metal terrain that's still mostly untouched.

column1: When fringe musicians with indie sensibilities dabble in metal
column2: they tend to either put a ponderous spin on it (Liturgy) or a campy one (Dave Pajo's one-off group Dead Child). Bloodiest most definitely leans towards the former
column3: especially during its lengthy stretches of classical-tinged guitar spiked with ethereal chanting. Almost three decades since John Zorn compared Napalm Death to free jazz
column4: the genre still has a way of luring dilettantes who can't resist what they perceive as its lowbrow/junk-culture temptations. Never mind that
column5: musically speaking
column6: Zorn's comparison was totally fair; it still smacked of unintended snobbery.

column1: But Bloodiest doesn't come off as the product of well-intentioned but privileged slumming. After all
column2: this band is from Chicago
column3: where musicians inclined to shuttle between various genres have long felt free to do so. Most of the members of Bloodiest have roots in bands that operate or operated at the outskirts of metal anyway. With this album
column4: they stake their claim to a musical inheritance left behind by predecessors who flouted boundaries and bastardized conventional notions of heaviness. Fittingly
column5:
they make the best of that inheritance by striking out on their own.

When Busta Rhymes and Q-Tip released ""Thank You
column2: a rap relay featuring Kanye West and Lil Wayne
column3: it fueled speculation that the two might be working on a project together
column4: something those entrenched in New York rap’s history had been pining for. What we got instead was The Abstract and the Dragon
column5: a mixtape that turned out to be a chill way to revisit the pair’s enviable chemistry and friendship but not much else.

column1: Two years later
column2: Busta Rhymes is back with a new tape of unheard material
column3: this time without Q-Tip. The Return of the Dragon (The Abstract Went on Vacation) doesn’t exactly herald the return of Peak Busta or even Good Busta—in fact
column4: it does the opposite. The raps are mostly uninspired and sometimes they don’t even make sense (""My money long
column5: thicker than a waffle
column6: on ""God’s Plan""; ""I’m Def Leppard and I ain’t tryna hear the noise
column7: on ""Choose a Side""). When they do communicate
column8: the thoughts and observations are unbearably generic
column9: the kind of bars a rap generator might cough up. And on top of all that
column10: Busta packs his words into the husks of worn tracks that somehow escaped the first Obama term.

column1: Many of these B-sides sound years old—songs recorded for alternate purposes that were at one point or another shelved and never should’ve seen the light of day. For starters
column2: there’s a guest appearance from long-forgotten R&B singer J. Holiday on a song ironically titled ""Hits for Days."" When Styles P and Jadakiss do their usual back-and-forth on ""Respect My Conglomerate 2
column3: a sequel to the 2009 Busta song of the same name
column4: there’s a reference to the bank Wachovia
column5: which was absorbed by Wells Fargo in 2008. Some other songs feel like relics from a bygone era
column6: especially ""Real Niggas
column7: which reeks of Lex Luger ""MC Hammer""-like trap opulence with big
column8: dramatic chamber orchestration (and a Rick Ross feature to boot). ""UFC (Tap-Out)"" reunites Waka Flocka Flame and Gucci Mane
column9: a dated pairing given their contentious recent history and Gucci’s overlapping prison stint.

column1: Whether or not these songs actually are old isn’t the issue—rappers put album throwaways on mixtapes all the time
column2: and some of these releases exist to serve that exact purpose. The issue is that this particular batch feels old. These throwaways are stale
column3: and to present them to rap fans as some sort of gesture of good faith on Christmas Day seems like a cheap trick.

column1: If you manage to hang in for a bit
column2: The Return of the Dragon isn’t without its moments: Chance the Rapper’s lengthy verse on ""Hello"" is a barn burner (""I know contracts are like handcuffs/ I know combat when it’s hand to hand or with handguns/ I know answers
column3: I know man to man
column4: can’t stand us/ I know exactly how you wanna brand us"")
column5: the cathedral organ tenor of the choir-backed
column6: Mary J. Blige-featuring ""Your Loss"" is heavy and evocative
column7: and there’s a vintage Raekwon showing on the gritty outro to ""Watch How You Move."" On ""Tonight
column8: a horn-heavy funk gem from the Pharrell archives
column9: Sean Paul lathers his signature patois yelps over a pounding bass
column10: and the sensory experience is a pleasant blast from the past. But the shoehorned-in Busta verses sound labored
column11: especially when his words are heard outside of densely packed double-time raps.

column1: There are flashes where Busta Rhymes’ juking
column2: stutter-step flow
column3: which can burst into an elastic double-time on a whim
column4: is sharp and reminiscent of his best performances. The BJ the Chicago Kid-featuring ""In the Streets
column5: which carries a pair of MF DOOM verses to its credit
column6: is highlighted by one of the strongest Busta verses in recent memory. ""We Home
column7: which reunites Leaders of the New School with fantastic results
column8: is one of the few instances of unadulterated bliss. But these are momentary reprieves from a slog of tiresome listens. Busta Rhymes will forever be known for one of the most fluid deliveries in the genre’s history
column9: but this rap giant is slowing and his wit seems to be dulling. ""Ain’t nothing changed
column10: I’m still the Goliath of this rap shit
column11:
he spits on ""Hits for Days."" Someone should remind him how that fable ends.

""I’ve been wanting to spit on you all night
column2: sneers 7 Year Bitch’s Elizabeth Davis-Simpson. The throwaway line from Live at Moe

column5: 7 Year Bitch’s blunt and spiky rock music married social commentary with punk brevity and Riot Grrrl righteousness. Crowning their ferocious riffs on sex
column6: trouble
column7: and death were Davis-Simpson's heat-seeking remonstrations
column8: which were as precise as they were lethal. Live is a powerful showcase—a welcome document that adds meaningfully to the band’s oeuvre while capturing a moment in the thriving Seattle scene of the '90s.

column1: On Live at Moe
column2: we hear a band in transition but not necessarily in decline. The opener
column4: 900 Miles Per Hour
column5: from 7 Year Bitch’s third and final album Gato Negro
column6: is a furious demonstration of the band's broadening palette. Selene Vigil-Wilk’s melodic narration
column7: detailing the demise of a ""poor white trash"" girl
column8: has a looser cadence and more languid delivery than anything from the band’s earlier catalog—the song sounds like a Daydream Nation outtake
column9: until the vocal snarls suddenly in the chorus. This version cleaves to the studio iteration but thrums with sharper urgency.

column1: The live spark transforms other songs from Gato Negro
column2: the band’s first and only album with Atlantic Records
column3: which was simultaneously less scrappy and less compelling than 1992 debut Sick’Em and 1994’s ¡Viva Zapata!. Wandering beyond their original metal-underscored feminist fury to introduce funk idiom and bluesy touches

column6: with its plodding chorus and piqued nursery-rhyme rhythm (""They like the kind of girl/ The kind they cannot tame"") gets a thoroughly menacing showing here; Valerie Agnew’s hi-hats pull tension lines tight
column7: and Elizabeth Davis-Simpson’s nimble
column8: subterranean bass anchors the sparse instrumentation. While the live mix isn’t uniform between tracks—the recording was originally streamed online—it’s generally even-handed; it breathes
column9: often capturing the distinctive character of the musicians’ contributions.

column1: Nuclear force arrives in the set with ""M.I.A.

column3: who was raped and murdered in 1993. Directed at the killer
column4: at any abuser of women
column5: the song unites the band’s dual strengths of raw sonic power and scarifying screed: ""Will there be hundreds mourning for you?/ Will they talk of the talent and inspiration you gave?/ No."" Vigil-Wilk’s blistering delivery speaks of monstrous anger and loss
column6: articulating a remembrance that is both salute and spur. ""Hip Like Junk
column7: also a ¡Viva Zapata! cut
column8: prowls the dark grounds of drug abuse and addiction
column9: a perennial theme for 7 Year Bitch after the drug-related death of original guitarist Stefanie Sargent in 1992.

column1: ""Lorna
column2: from Sick ‘Em
column3: harks back to beginnings
column4: when the band’s sound had more in common with contemporaries L7 and Babes in Toyland
column5: like surf rock filtered through granite. The penultimate offering is classic brat directive ""The Scratch."" Live at Moe’s version swaggers
column6: growls
column7: and grabs; ""I want it
column8: yells Vigil

column10: introduced as the last song guitarist Roisin Dunne would be playing with the group before departing. Given 7 Year Bitch would break up the next year
column11: the energetic exit feels bittersweet but apt. Live at Moe is a fierce hello-again-and-farewell to an iconic group

like a skirt that says ""Fuck you"" on the butt.

There's an area in the South Shore neighborhood of Chicago known as Terror Town. It’s a 2-block-by-4-block area that has seen no less than three large-scale shootings in the last 3 years. This is where the rapper Lil Bibby lives
column2: he of the boyish looks and the grown-ass man voice. He debuted nationally in August of 2012 alongside lifelong friend Lil Herb via ""Kill Shit
column3: a song that stands out as the absolute hardest song recorded by children I’ve ever heard. Bibby's work is a live play-by-play of chaos
column4: with numerous references to paranoia that comes with simple trips to the store—""<span>This real life
column5: real facts
column6: this ain't rap/ Walk into that corner store
column7: we had to stay strapped/ Yeah
column8: most of these niggas can't relate to that
column9: he raps on ""EBT to BET.""

column1: The moment that gave Bibby his introduction to the world—the initial gold rush of the drill sound
column2: with every rapper with a 773 or 312 area code getting a look and/or a deal—has passed now. His latest tape
column3: Free Crack 3
column4: feels like a game attempt to escape the box that being labeled a ""drill"" artist puts you in. The tape comes with via a mix of big-name grabs (Future and Metro Boomin on obvious radio ploy ""Aww Man"") and local legends (Jeremih
column5: R. Kelly
column6: and Common
column7: who drops one of his better verses in awhile on ""Speak to ‘Em
column8: all appear). The C-Sick produced ""If He Find Out"" features a stellar collaboration between Tink and Bibby. As expected
column9: Lil Herb stops by for ""Ain't Heard Nuthin Bout You
column10: and the song is such a great example of the chemistry between the two that they’ve been promoting the single as ""Kill Shit pt. 2.""

column1: As he expands his range of guests
column2: his lyrical ability leveled up significantly. By and large
column3: Bibby’s been out of town doing shows and recording
column4: and in a recent interview on Chicago’s WGCI radio station
column5: he acknowledged the change has been daunting for his creative process: When I be in Atlanta too long I can’t write too many songs. I have to always come back to Chicago. There's nothing like the Chicago feeling."" The travel may have ultimately been good for him
column6: though
column7: broadening his worldview and leading him to delve into newer ideas and to sharpen his focus. On Free Crack 3
column8: he switches perspectives ably
column9: from a survivor determined to better the lives of himself and the people around him (the Five Stairsteps-sampling ""Things Will Get Brighter"") and a 21-year-old with a little money in his pocket and some time to kill
column10: like <span id=""docs-internal-guid-0fdb360f-3c1b-599e-be8f-fe9ea9d050c3""><span>""Aww Man."" Through all of it
column11: he remains self-aware of the choices he’s made and how they’ve made him into who he is. On ""Word Around Town
column12: he chuckles
column13: ""Probably could've been a mathematician/ But a nigga made bad decisions/ Momma told me but I didn't listen/ Judge sent my bad ass to prison.""

column1: In lieu of struggling to keep up and stay relevant
column2: Bibby has found success mostly by sticking to the program that got him here: consistent quality. While this tape marks the conclusion of the Free Crack series
column3: he recently announced a debut
column4: FC3: The Epilogue
column5: coming next month. A few months back
column6: Bibby posted to social media that he received his G.E.D and was now thinking of attending UCLA. For various reasons
column7: it’s hard not to listen and root for him.
