The Oakland band Lycus make funeral doom that's unique and accomplished without rejecting the basic tenets of the style. The music is slow and heavy
column2: the three-part vocals mournful and guttural
column3: the cover art by Italian painter Paolo Girardi melancholic and romantic
column4: the subject matter bleak. For instance
column5: ""This wretched body/ The prison of the soul/ Weighted by the chains of depression/ I could never bear to let you in."" Or: ""Oh Mother/ Oh Father/ Relinquish this mistake of a life."" But
column6: all said
column7: it’s also uplifting.

column1: This has a lot to do with the guitars and tone. On the quartet's new album Chasms
column2: fire and heat are mentioned in the lyrics
column3: and even if they show up in a negative sense (""The sun will burn the cancer we have become/ Death will be the savior"")
column4: you get the sense of the night turning into day here. It was produced by Jack Shirley
column5: who also helmed Deafheaven’s Sunbather and New Bermuda (and a ton of other records)
column6: and he gives the songs a very big feel.

column1: Lycus’ first record
column2: 2013’s Tempest
column3: featured three tracks spreading across 42 minutes
column4: though the last one
column5: ""Tempest
column6: drifted off at the end with low-level hiss and feedback. The more tightly packed Chasms features four songs in 44 minutes
column7: and each second is fully loaded. From blistering black metal freak-out to crushing Neurosis climax to an unexpected psychedelic undertow
column8: there's no incidental music here.

column1: They added a second guitarist
column2: which brings a compelling texture to the sound
column3: and there’s also the presence of go-to Bay Area metal cellist Jackie Perez Gratz  (Giant Squid
column4: Amber Asylum). She weaves the songs together into a kind of extended suite
column5: and her work brings to mind another of her collaborators
column6: Asunder
column7: who released one of the great underground Bay Area doom albums
column8: Works Will Come Undone
column9: in 2006. Asunder
column10: like Lycus
column11: found a way to make a lot happen with a little.

column1: This is one of my favorite records of the sort since then
column2: which is saying a lot. Lycus maintain a specific atmosphere—deep greens
column3: browns
column4: dark shadows—but find a number of paths through it. Each feels right
column5: the blending of genres and approaches and patterns seamless. More important
column6: though
column7: is the effect music of this sort can have on a listener. It's highly cathartic. It will move you emotionally. At the end of the haunting closer ""Obsidian Eyes
column8: which finds the protagnist ""suffer[ing] through the void/ On the perilous bridge/ Between body and spirit
column9: the band pushes forward with all their force into a gentle cymbal wash that closes the record. It's one of the few soft moments on <i>Chasms
column10: and it's welcome: a place to rest your head after experiencing this overwhelming
column11: ecstatic
column12:
surprisingly meditative album.

column1: Shame
column2: which came out in October last year
column3: functions well enough as an indie rock record
column4: but its atmosphere is nervous and defeated
column5: both the frenzied search for a cigarette and the long exhale of smoke layered on top of each other. Lotz describes scenes
column6: relationships
column7: and emotions in fragments. ""A bulb/ A thought/ A home you’re not
column8: ” she sings in ""Feel."" Her voice is clear and direct
column9: and illuminates her songs internally
column10: like a skeleton made of Christmas lights. Sometimes she crafts an unstable reality
column11: the physics of which are susceptible to anxiety. ""Being mocked by the crack in the ceiling at the top of the stairs
column12: she sings in ""Sooner."" ""Wishing it’d swallow me whole."" Later in the same song she threatens to ""sow a garden of backbones I never had."" Her imagery is rich and often moves like poetry
column13: knowing just when to slip out of sense into a region that feels blurred and indefinite
column14: yet true to the lived experience of love and panic—all this atomic activity beneath an otherwise placid surface. Lotz’s lyrics are also funny; in ""Chandelier Thief
column15: she instructs someone to ""be thankful for the floor/ it leads you to a new place.""

column1: Fellow Scranton band Tigers Jaw acts as Lotz’s band on Shame; their playing is precise yet also softens at its edges. Chords appear like bruises
column2: vivid shapes with unclear borders. In ""Camera Lens II
column3: there’s a delightful
column4: lopsided quality to the changes; they almost seem to collapse on each other. ""Nature"" is the opposite; it’s completely skeletal
column5: just vocals and drums
column6: and yet it communicates with extreme precision something as shapeless as falling in love. ""It’s like you have an innate sense of me
column7: Lotz sings. ""Like you’ve lived in my head waiting patiently/ To tell me 'you’re so afraid
column8: just breathe.'""

column1: Lotz's finest moment is on ""Photobooth
column2: which unfolds patiently as she sings
column3: ""Kissed under the streetlight/ By your friend’s house."" Then the image recedes into a cerebral space
column4: while the song itself amplifies and expands: ""I guess what I mean is that if I could/ Pick out all the parts of my brain/ I would leave the place where you made your home."" This is the lingering quality of Shame: Lotz’s ability to translate the imprecision of a kiss
column5: the quality of a streetlight
column6: the decay of a shadow into a memory so powerful it consumes everything. Shame is an album of preserved traces
column7:
of things that were.

The 2015 documentary Rubble Kings is one of many pieces of cultural ephemera about New York City in the '70s to emerge recently. It focuses on the chaos of the Boogie Down Bronx at a time when the borough was dealing with turbulence so intense that it was liable to burst into flame
column2: but it avoids lazily conflating the chaos of the city and the beauty of the culture that emerged around the same period. Instead
column3: it points to the Hoe Avenue peace meeting
column4: a truce between gangs in the Bronx
column5: as the catalyst for an artistic explosion that presaged the birth of hip-hop.

column1: The soundtrack was produced by Little Shalimar
column2: who scored the documentary and has worked as a producer with Run the Jewels among others. The music splits its time between rap tracks and instrumental music by Shalimar that take inspiration from various sonic flavors that were percolating through the Bronx in the '70s. Perhaps attempting to imitate the arc of the film
column3: the album stumbles in the early going with the tough-talking track ""Savage Habits
column4: which
column5: even though it features Killer Mike and Bun B
column6: doesn’t quite pound in the way you might hope. (Also
column7: it’s bullshit provincial homerism
column8: but honestly: New Yorkers should open a New York album!)

column1: But Little Shalimar makes several clever curatorial choices. Mr. Muthafuckin’ eXquire hasn’t never quite managed to echo the success of 2011’s Lost in Translation
column2: but he sounds energized on ""Warrior Thing
column3: as do indispensable voices like Ka and Ghostface Killah
column4: who show up on later tracks. For the most part
column5: lyrically
column6: the actual bars being spit here are less moving than the voices and vibe. That’s a credit to Shalimar
column7: who has assembled worthwhile soundscapes for at least a couple of rappers who have had a below-average record in the booth in recent years. The Run the Jewels track ""Rubble Kings Theme (Dynamite)"" is the high point of the rap cuts
column8: Killer Mike spitting steel-toed syllables over a concrete staircase of a beat
column9: El-P gleefully playing with sibilants in the second verse.

column1: The best moments come when Shalimar sticks to instrumentals. His work with the musician Jeremy Wilms (together
column2: they call themselves King Mono) on ""Bouncy 3"" is a standout. ""Partytime"" is a tribute to the breaking culture of outdoor block parties
column3: a mix of hard funk rythms and riffs
column4: and snazzy ballpark synths that sound imported from a Dire Straits song.

column1: The narrative arc of the album isn’t quite as arresting as that of the film
column2: but Shalimar does make an effort to say something with the song structure here. That comes into play most notably at the album’s close
column3: with the one-two punch of ""The Piano District (Gentrification Boogie)"" and ""Phoenix."" The first is an instrumental track
column4: part lament
column5: part testimonial to the inexorable movement of money into the Bronx. (That a borough with such a venerable nickname should be renamed so casually by developers is the kind of Gotham micro-tragedy to which city-dwellers are consistently subjected.)

column1: ""Phoenix"" broadcasts its message through its name. The artists featured
column2: Tunde Adebimpe of TV on the Radio and the singer/songwriter Roxiny (who sounds a little like early Santigold which is to say
column3: amazing) sing an anthem of rebirth
column4: a hopeful song that corresponds with the message of Rubble Kings. But here
column5: as on the album as a whole
column6: any kind of explicit statement has been wrested from a canvas of evocative sonic ideas. The music comes first every time
column7:
ably conjuring up the milieu that served as hip-hop’s cradle.

column1:

So far
column2: there's not much to know about New York four-piece WALL. Bassist Elizabeth Skadden was in Finally Punk
column3: guitarist Vince McClelland in Keepsies. Singer/guitarist Sam York has modeled for Terry Richardson. Wharf Cat is releasing their self-titled debut EP
column4: which was produced by Parquet Courts' Austin Brown. They have given no interviews and maintain no social media profiles—just a single monochrome homepage. Maybe they're being secretive in that faintly annoying blogs-circa-2010 fashion
column5: but maybe it's just that they're brand new. May the period that they're not beholden to the Internet and being asked crap questions about being girls (and one boy) in a band last as long as possible.

column1: The context for their music
column2: however
column3: suggests itself immediately—a tarnished
column4: shouty clangor that recalls Mission of Burma
column5: Wire circa Pink Flag
column6: Pylon
column7: and an extremely misanthropic B-52s
column8: all anchored by Vanessa Gomez's brisk drumming. York's lyrics often tackle the false identities necessary to survive 21st century New York
column9: and it's hard not to hear a new band making this kind of crucible-forged post-punk as its own kind of costume: Is slavish adherence to a 30-year-old template really the best way to rail against the expectations of the modern age? That aside
column10: WALL are innovative students.

column1: For one
column2: they're funny: ""Big black suits dressed as little white lies/ Fresh baked bread keeps the pigs well fed
column3: York blares on ""Cuban Cigars
column4: a jab at the whelps of Wall Street. A few verses later
column5: she abandons her severe incantations for a mocking sing-song that evokes Kathleen Hanna. Her delivery on closer ""Milk
column6: a smokier song than its brittle predecessors
column7: echoes Kim Gordon's soft disaffection as she observes how
column8: ""The sky opened up/ Milk poured out."" That is
column9: until the kicker
column10: where she sounds like Mark E. Smith after a few hours on Tumblr. ""Two-thousand feline mistresses!/ Laying all over the cobblestone!""

column1: The appearance of these insubordinate sunbathing animals in the lyrics fits the absurdist streak that gives the EP much of its appeal
column2: though its most exciting moment comes as York succumbs to the city's pressures. ""Fit the Part"" finds her flitting between the different roles she plays throughout the course of the day
column3: and as the pressure mounts
column4: so does the pace; from a stiff
column5: spidery lumber to a rushed run-on
column6: and a flooring white-hot tirade of panic and empty self-assurances. ""My blood's the same I know it is/ Just the exterior changes/ Shedding layers as I race to the next task/ Looking in the mirror to the face of a stranger/ Know the heart but not the face and I/ Gotta fit the part/ Gotta fit the part to get the part
column7: York rattles off
column8: as if trying to grab hold of a lightning bolt.

column1: If where WALL are coming from is entirely apparent
column2: where they're going isn't
column3: thanks to these adrenaline surges and hectic rhythmic swerves. There's no color to their music
column4: and little fluidity
column5: yet in their intense fits and starts
column6: they develop a compelling effect that has the magnetism of good melody
column7: even in its near-total absence. ""Last Date"" is the simplest song here—another tirade of words so staccato that it's hard to discern the lyrics about being crushed by the weight of someone else. While the guitar is high and insistent
column8: York and Skadden sing in sour
column9: mismatched harmonies. Without really altering their resolutely monotone delivery
column10: they seem to burrow deeper into the earth. In tricks like these
column11:
WALL wriggle out from the under the weight of history.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/22727/homepage_large.cd6e598a.jpg|From My Mind to Yours|1903.0|Richie Hawtin|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Plus 8']|2016-01-13 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:02:44.382561|"

The title of Plus 8 Records' 25th anniversary release—which is also Richie Hawtin's first official studio album for over a decade—From My Mind to Yours
column2: directly mirrors a compilation put out by the label in 1991-2
column3: From Our Minds to Yours. That symmetry forms a tidy back to the label's origins
column4: and it also serves as the crowning moment of this uncharacteristically nostalgic chapter of Richie Hawtin's career. Thus far
column5: Hawtin has cultivated a reputation as techno's future fetishist
column6: most literally through Minus
column7: the heavily stylized record label that provided minimal techno with one of its key aesthetics during its mid-2000s heyday: subtractively austere
column8: steely and clinical.

column1: The video interview that accompanied the surprise release of From My Mind to Yours in December found Hawtin in a completely different place. He was positively twinkly-eyed with nostalgia
column2: as he talked of ""going back to basics."" He credits vintage string sounds and production tricks
column3: while speaking of stripping racks of gear back to the essentials in a Berlin studio that
column4: by chance
column5: replicates the dimensions (and spatial sweet spot) of a former production space from his formative years in Canada. In the weeks leading up to the final reveal of From My Mind to Yours
column6: Plus 8 pressed up a series of album teasers; it was widely speculated that Hawtin
column7: an occasional critic of the ""pain in the ass"" vinyl format
column8: was behind the anonymous
column9: white-label productions. In the midst of this campaign
column10: he revived his 1990s rave night
column11: Jak
column12: for a one-off reunion party in Detroit
column13: and made arrangements to pull the plug on the Ibiza superclub residency of his popular club night
column14: ENTER.

column1: From My Mind to Yours similarly hints towards some gratifying full-circle moments. ""Them
column2: under the F.U.S.E moniker
column3: unfolds with slow-reveal hypnotism
column4: and works as a faithful tribute to the classic blueprint of Midwest techno. Album opener ""No Way Back"" draws together various strands of Hawtin's production personalities
column5: casting a crystalline modern sheen over a thickened kick drum and twisting 303 line. Yet the album's genuinely compelling moments are scattered out over spotless plains of DJ-tool functionality
column6: mechanically loopy acid
column7: and towering-but-harmless walls of precise techno sound design.

column1: The most Hawtin-esque production tropes since the inception of Plus 8 (and Minus) reappear here
column2: but with neither the vigour needed to push his futurist agenda
column3: nor the dynamic context of his rich back catalog.""Stretching"" requires a vivid imagination to find an appeal beyond its minimalist bare bones
column4: and Circuit Breaker's only appearance—the curiously unmoving ""Systematic""—doesn't begin to approach the gruffness of that alias' industrial past. The clutch of tracks that fall under the 80XX alias play directly to the critical cliches that Hawtin is often accused of creating. Plastikman
column5: the most beloved of Hawtin's identities
column6: fares the best across the two-volume album. His signature hyper drums appear on the bold ""Purrkusiv
column7: and its visceral power is undeniable; follow-up track  ""Gymnastiks"" deploys its sleazy bassline and wispy drum echoes to a satisfying yin-yang effect.

column1: Hawtin's '90s techno hero status was cemented with landmark classics like ""Spastik"" and ""Elektrostatik
column2: which in turn assured a spot for Plus 8 in the annals of techno history. The label's only other recent release arrived unannounced last year: an anonymous record that was eventually revealed to be produced by electro house megastar and Twitter hothead Deadmau5. This was an unpopular revelation in certain quarters
column3: but it worked both as a gossip-worthy moment and an effective jolt of renewal for the label's run-up to its 2015 anniversary; the tracks's production standards signalled a revived richness of sound that the label lacked in its latter years. At moments
column4: From My Mind to Yours captures some of that same texture and immediacy
column5: but the spontaneity and looseness that Hawtin speaks of so passionately have been diluted through the process of translation. Rather than feeling like the beginnings of a new phase
column6:
From My Mind To Yours presents a version of a fertile past that isn't working toward the benefit of the present.

Sweden's Witchcraft are key figures in the so-called hard rock revival: Originally conceived at the start of the century by singer Magnus Pelander as a tribute to the pioneering doom outfit Pentagram
column2: the group has since expanded those paradigms to encompass Palm Desert stoner rock
column3: Jethro Tull-style blues
column4: and the heady psych of the '60s. Compared to the rudimentary sounds of peers like Graveyard
column5: Kadavar
column6: and Truckfighters
column7: Witchcraft's music—however indebted to the past—skews progressive
column8: a cumulative approach to riff-building beget by several decades' worth of influences.

column1: On their fifth album Nucleus
column2: Witchcraft continue to carry the torch of '70s hard rock/proto-metal bands while striving torward a broader sound. Pelander has put down his axe to focus entirely on singing
column3: as well as production; unsurprisingly
column4: the mix that he and producers Philip Gabriel Saxin and Anton Sundell decided upon gives him all the space he needs to croon to heart’s content. Apart from that
column5: the album sounds downright gargantuan. From the airtight
column6: string-inflected boogie of ""The Outcast"" to the grizzled march of the title track
column7: each cut optimizes volume over vulnerability
column8: a torrent of liquid lead rushing into the ears. Folk
column9: and maybe even a little bit of jazz
column10: sveltely sneak their way into the mix in the form of of flutes and strings—but by and large
column11: Nucleus is an album that refuses to stay quiet
column12: roaring and clawing forth for over an hour before coming to a shuddering halt.

column1: Like so many of the groups before them
column2: Witchcraft draw inspiration from high fantasy
column3: an aesthetic that manifests itself with the ren-faire woodwind and string arrangements and in the epic tales of wanderlust
column4: misplaced faith
column5: and heroic striving in the lyrics. Thankfully
column6: the fanciful mood never gets mired in Blind Guardian-style goofiness
column7: gesturing more generally to the haggard adventurer in us all: ""The Outcast"" focuses not on some wayward brigadier
column8: but rather on the growing alienation of a global population becoming more resigned and hopeless by the second. The universality makes the record more approachable
column9: but the lyrics can’t rise to accommodate it
column10: as evidenced by the aformentioned track’s head-scratching
column11: grammatically-tenuous refrain: ""Save a nation from a bad economy/ Is like sailing away on an endless sea."" Pelander’s stilted cadence compounds the problem; if he’s not squeezing an extra syllable out of a word like ""indecision
column12: he’s attempting to rhyme ""loving parents"" with ""discontent""—and botching the emphasis on both.

column1: It’s up to Rage Widerberg on drums and Tobias Anger on bass to convey what Pelander’s words can’t
column2: and they deserve a considerable amount of credit for channeling all the rage and confusion coursing through tracks like ""Malstroem"" and ""The Obsessed""'s percolating
column3: crowd-pleasing doom riffs. Unfortunately
column4: the glacial pacing of Nucleus’ slow burn frequently snuffs its own flame. Following ""Maelstrom""’s opening inertia
column5: the album sinks into a figurative tar pit: a seemingly endless progression of the smoky
column6: wail-ridden jams Blue Cheer could write in their sleep. Even by doom’s slow standards
column7: the record’s second half is plodding and woefully self-indulgent
column8: relying more on Pelander’s killer pipes than on developed songcraft. Of course
column9: it goes without saying that Nucleus rocks: its nine tracks (two of which extend past the 14-minute mark) pack in enough solemn solos
column10: furied backbeats
column11:
and majestic stoner breakdowns to hold fans over until next time. But how good is pure volume when it's lacking a furious heart to match?

Completists have it easy with Cozz. Where most rappers have their growing pains scattered around Soundcloud or on shoddy tape dubs
column2: the South Central rapper emerged fully-formed
column3: all grit
column4: learned distrust
column5: and half-full/half-empty 40s. Two years ago
column6: his pair of debut singles
column7: ""Dreams"" and ""I Need That
column8: shook the Los Angeles street-rap community to its core; by the fall of 2014
column9: the ink was dry on his deal with Interscope and Dreamville Records
column10: the imprint run by J. Cole. News of the signing was followed in quick order by Cozz & Effect
column11: an excellent mixtape that paired his forceful
column12: sandpapered voice with spare beats.

column1: Cozz’s breakout comes in the midst of a renaissance for L.A.: Kendrick Lamar and YG with their variations on the familiar Compton myths; Open Mike Eagle and Busdriver with their looking-glass art rap; Earl Sweatshirt with his white-knuckled self-improvement; and excellent
column2: often daring music from the likes of Cam & China
column3: Skeme
column4: Speak
column5: Nocando
column6: and more. (Vince Staples and Boogie are lurking down the 710 in Long Beach.) But what makes him stand out in the crowded field is his restlessness. Cozz’s writing keeps a sense of forward motion
column7: where each high school liquor store excursion or bus ride from Manhattan Beach back to 65th and Western is as sleek and economical as a film script.

column1: His new offering
column2: Nothin Personal
column3: is a low-concept stroll through the Crip-controlled blocks of Cozz’s youth. On the somber
column4: reflective ""Grow
column5: he remembers accounting for the $10 his father used to leave him for lunch money: ""I used to spend five dollars on the weed/ A 40 ounce with the other half—every day/ Starving myself for the hunger of a buzz."" In other hands
column6: ""Choice Today"" might come off as dull moralizing; here
column7: it’s the eerie
column8: slinking voice in your head that tries
column9: often successfully
column10: to drag you off track. That song is also vocally experimental in a way he hasn't tried yet: he mostly abandons his staccato cadences for a slow warble
column11: something he also trots out for ""Grey Goose"" and on the latter half of ""Tell Me."" Unfortunately
column12: the latter is also the clumsiest moment on the record
column13: a song about sex that’s really a song about control in the least interesting way possible.

column1: The tape’s high-water mark is ""City of God
column2: which pairs him with Boogie for a slow creep that darts from battered Ford Explorers to boardrooms and back again. One one level
column3: it’s two of Southern California’s finest trading cracks about piety and iPhone read receipts; on another
column4: it finds them in awe of the fact that things are finally
column5: mercifully panning out. But each rapper is inherently skeptical of what’s laid out before them—so it’s back to speeding through Florence
column6:
eyes on the road.

People who still keep up with rapper and social media mystic Lil B have their own personal rubric for grading his tapes. What tracks I can show to my friends that think Lil B can’t rap? How ridiculous are the style experiments? What funny celebrities does he have ""more bitches than
column2: and have ""hoes on his dick like""? Is anything on this as good as ""Like a Martian""? Is anything on this as good as ""I’m God""? At this point
column3: B's set his own parameters such that there’s no way to identify what ""going astray"" might look like for him. In everything from his capricious tweets to his mixtapes
column4: he’s made a perspective in every direction a perspective in itself.

column1: So how do we rate new DatPiff-based landfills full of Lil B music
column2: which arrive about three years since he has done anything genuinely surprising
column3: or figured out that he didn’t have to? Sometimes it feels like you have to commit to either categorically disdaining the BasedGod brand
column4: or endorsing all of it. When you have a 50-plus track Lil B release
column5: like the recent Thugged Out Pissed Off
column6: there’s a song or 10 to satisfy any of your favorite B song types or subjects. The majority of his tapes since 2012’s God’s Father have been this large-scale: Perhaps there’s no going back when you’ve gotten into the habit of running long and holding yourself to a standard that no one except you remotely understands. How does he decide when a tape is done? With Lil B
column7: you can’t qualify what you’ll never feel like you really processed.

column1: The tape kicks off with the musical equivalent of a slow-motion strut into the boxing ring with the robe hood up: a trap-ified flip of Giorgio Moroder’s funereal Scarface theme. The track sets the mood for the tape pretty well
column2: insofar as we can generalize that of a 63-track-long collection of freestyles: Thugged Out Pissed Off is a little more self-serious
column3: a little more dead-eyed
column4: and a little more disinterested. It lacks the exuberance that made 2014's Hoop Life and last year's Chance the Rapper collaboration charming. You
column5: the listener
column6: will spend a little more of the portion of the collection asking ""Why this?""

column1: As with a lot of the music which defines the notorious genre of cloud rap—from Raider Klan affiliates to disciples like Yung Lean—part of the appeal of Lil B (or
column2: at least
column3: the source of his novelty) for his fans is the contradictory perspectives he squirms in and out of. He’s usually playing at some comic book version of a hard-ass
column4: a bathetic mystic
column5: or a confessional ""real hip-hop""per. On this tape—as if celebrating of the impending release of Deadpool—he’s in full-on noxious mode. He plays the anti-heroic Stanley Kowalski of hustlers with a ""dirty dick like Charlie Sheen
column6: and dallies on the subject of ""knocking out bitches."" It seems as if he's intending to indict roided-up possible form of masculinity through first-person character study
column7: and as always with B
column8: it’s hard to put together any fixed explanation. ""I’m a jealous guy so I beat up my bitches/ I’m so insecure
column9: I don’t even trust me
column10: he drawls on ""Play the Hood
column11: showing his cards a bit.

column1: Lamentably
column2: there is little in the way of songs fit for crying in pet stores or fun
column3: non sequitur-filled bangers to balance all this out
column4: or make the body of this thing—the middle two hours
column5: perhaps—less boring. If you love the playful WTF moments
column6: they don’t get too much more compelling than flips of ""Coco"" and ""Jumpman"" (the choruses
column7: respectively: ""I’m in looove with the Based God"" and ""Based God
column8: Based God
column9: Based God
column10: Based God""). These are exercises which it’s hard to imagine even the most diehard
column11: TYBG-tatted devotee getting excited about.

column1: The best songs on this tape pair oddball versions of party-rap production—a fair amount of Mannie Fresh’s laser-tag bounce and calls of ""whodie"" here—or slurred
column2: I’m Gay (I’m Happy)-style boom-bap
column3: with lyrics revolving around racial identity. ""I Was Born Poor"" couples a Hot Boys-ready
column4: cymbal-driven beat with a velour sitar sample
column5: and finds B dreamily murmuring about his ancestry (""Booker T. Washington
column6: still got that honor/ Born into bondage
column7: still became a scholar""). On the purely musical end
column8: there are a handful of unusual gambits that stick with you: the triumphant singing on ""With Me"" is placed like a R&B break in the middle of an early '00s rap track and comes out sounding like something close to Tiny Tim.

column1: But even the pleasant details are forgotten too quickly. Even more than
column2: say
column3: 2013’s 101-track 05 Fuck Em—a similarly unwieldy but much more engaging release thanks to a good haul of truly bizarre style experiments—it feels like B is just hitting a deadline and releasing what he has lying around. Sure
column4: that’s probably what he’s always done
column5: but this feels more like a perfunctory archive purge. Thugged Out Pissed Off creates the image of a Lil B who is unsure if he wants to keep up things exactly as he’s been doing them
column6:
but doesn’t know exactly what he should do instead.

""I used to pass the Warehouse after school

column3: late in the evening and I wondered why there were so many people hanging out in the street
column4: Chicago producer Larry Heard told XLR8R back in 1995
column5: admitting he had never once set foot in the birthplace of house music. ""I guess I was pretty naive."" By the time Frankie Knuckles moved over to the Powerplant in 1985
column6: Heard finally checked him out. And while still not the biggest fan of house music
column7: he shared Knuckles’ tastes
column8: a zealotry for both '70s R&B and Moroder-style Eurodisco. Heard
column9: the drummer for a Yes cover band and multi-instrumentalist
column10: began making his own productions as Mr. Fingers soon after
column11: which brought things full circle; ""Mystery of Love"" and ""Washing Machine"" became both the urtext for house music and staples of Frankie’s sets.

column1: Heard’s productions remain the gold standard for dance music. While he’s not as prolific in the 21st century
column2: Heard’s still the person acts like Lana Del Rey and Disclosure tap for cred-boosting remixes. But finding and hearing Heard’s albums has never been easy
column3: even in 1988
column4: when he released two of house music’s finest full-lengths: Ammnesia (credited to Mr. Fingers) and Another Side
column5: his sterling collaboration with vocalists Robert Owens and Ron Wilson as Fingers Inc. Both are beacons of American dance music
column6: and ironically neither album was ever released stateside.

column1: Nearly 30 years later
column2: Another Side finally gets reissued on Heard’s Alleviated label
column3: remastered and spread across three pieces of vinyl (it's also available digitally). Another Side might sound unfamiliar to modern EDM listeners
column4: who might wonder where the incessant wallop and insipid vocals signifying ""deep house"" in 2016 went. The album opens with the shimmering keys and by-turns gritty and gentle soul vocals of Owens on ""Decision
column5: Heard’s programmed drums swinging around but never quite settling into a four-four. The downtempo rhythmic figures
column6: silken pads
column7: and whispers of ""Bye Bye"" only reinforce the anecdote that in 1992 Sade Adu personally approached Heard about producing her band's album
column8: a collaboration that sadly never came to pass.

column1: But while we may never hear the man in conjunction with Ms. Adu
column2: Heard found a singular vocalist in Robert Owens. Forceful enough to growl over an 808 and smooth enough to slot into adult contemporary
column3: Owens’ formidable talents are still not appreciated today. While his fellow Chicagoans were overt in their influences
column4: be it Jamie Principle’s Prince obsession or Darryl Pandy’s Teddy Pendergrass impression
column5: Owens balances between those two giants of R&B without ever being beholden to either. It’s a voice that conveys emotions rarely found in dance music these days: grace
column6: gratitude
column7: giddiness
column8: forlornness
column9: estrangement
column10: defiance.

column1: All those emotions can be not just heard
column2: but felt on songs like the title track
column3: ""I’m Strong
column4: and ""Bring Down the Walls."" ""Be strong
column5: Owens and backing vocalist Ron Wilson advise on ""Another Side
column6: hopeful for a better tomorrow
column7: repeating as mantra: ""Someway/ Someday/ Somehow/ (Carry on)."" Whether you hear ""I’m Strong"" and ""Bring Down the Walls"" as a resilient call to arms for gay men
column8: for the impoverished
column9: for inner-city African-Americans
column10: for South Africans under apartheid
column11: or just for all the oppressed people seeking solace on a darkened dancefloor
column12: they still resonate as that rare breed
column13: elegant yet body-jacking songs of protest. Not bad for a song like ""Walls
column14: which Owens admitted to writing on toilet paper during his break at the hospital.

column1: For all the sophistication
column2: smooth jazz chords
column3: and political undertones of the album
column4: it's important to note that it still knocks. The programming of tracks like ""Distant Planet
column5: ""Music Take Me Up
column6: and ""I’m Strong"" still define dance music and elevate the room at peak hour. You could just as easily retitle the latter half of the album House Music’s Greatest Hits
column7: as it’s filled with seismic tracks like ""Mystery of Love
column8: ""Feelin’ Sleazy
column9: ""Bring Down the Walls
column10: and ""Can You Feel It.""

column1: While ""deep house"" now means certain club-friendly clichés to a generation of YouTube commenters and Boiler Room attendees
column2: an album like Another Side has only had its title grow in meanings over the intervening decades. It suggests that at its inception
column3: ""house"" was not a simple square but instead polygonal. Or as one of Heard’s devotees
column4: Todd Terry
column5: would put it a few years on
column6: ""house is a feeling."" Another Side showcased Larry Heard’s myriad other sides
column7: be it tropical ambient
column8: grown-ass R&B
column9: deft jazz chops
column10: island rhythms
column11: and even prog-rock’s embrace of early synthesizer technology. But ultimately
column12: the music that Heard and Owens rendered back then was a way to make cheap synths and cast-off drum machines emote and express the tumult of human emotions that could arise after a long night at the Warehouse

column14:
it sounds now like the path not traveled by the masses.

Look up ""re-recorded"" on whatever streaming site you use
column2: and you’ll find original performers doing hasty and underwhelming renditions of their biggest hits. Everything from ""Hang On Sloopy"" to ""Pour Some Sugar on Me"" to ""O.P.P."" stand as testaments that it’s nearly impossible to improve upon a definitive version. Villagers prove to be the exception to this rule with Where Have You Been All My Life?
column3: a collection of re-recordings of material from their three previous albums that reframes the songs in an impressively cohesive manner.

column1: Many artists re-record their best work because they’re in a dry spell and/or they’re sick of watching their old label make money off of the songs they made when they were young and signed a bad contract. What usually hinders re-recorded versions is a sense of ""we got it right the first time"" frustration that undermines the spirit of the original
column2: but the new versions on Where Have You Been… swell with a different determination
column3: one of ""We’ve got to get it right this time."" Recorded in one day last July
column4: these mostly acoustic versions were reportedly all first or second takes with no overdubs.  The band had already been touring in support of last April’s Darling Arithmetic for three months by the time they went into RAK Studios in London. Arithmetic tracks account for half of the songs on here

column6: unifying them in their delicate harmonies
column7: brushed drums
column8: and double bass arrangements.

column1: A definite highlight on this collection is ""Memoir
column2: which Charlotte Gainsbourg recorded a version of in 2011 and which appeared as a Villagers B-side a year later. The distracting crowd noise and flat-tire-on-the-highway rhythm of that version were wisely left off this most recent recording
column3: and the song touches a nerve even more discomfiting than before. Its desperate romantic lyrics hit more directly. ""In the orgy I can vaguely hear the outline of your call
column4: singer and songwriter Conor O’Brien sings at one point before telling the subject of the song
column5: ""you were the lighthouse to my broken boat."" The latter image connects the song on this compilation with ""My Lighthouse
column6: which first appeared on 2013’s {Awayland}.

column1: ""The Waves
column2: also originally from {Awayland}
column3: is another highlight. On that album
column4: it had an electronic undercurrent
column5: which was later taken several fathoms deeper when remixed by house duo Psychemagik. The drastic acoustic reinterpretation on this album feels like the song’s natural state
column6: the long-building crescendo threatens to swallow the singer before he has finished saying his piece.  The Where Have You Been All My Life? title comes from a line in “The Soul Serene
column7: ” but naming it as such feels like Villagers begging for new audiences to ask that same question of the album. The music within warrants it.

Paper Days is a four-piece outfit from San Diego with an unadorned ""California sound"" in an era when the sound of Southern California has become increasingly hard to define. Brothers Niko and Xander Sitaras
column2: Jordan Graham

column1: This isn’t to say that Paper Days are reckless
column2: or that their music is unhinged. Their EP was recorded without overdubs in an homage to the live-show experience; this is a group that wants to sound like they’re in the room with you
column3: playing at a house party the likes of which Paper Days have channelled into something of a mini-cult following in SoCal (thus the name of their EP: Fun for Family & Friends). The overarching sound here is wave-washed rock from a bass-
column4: drums-
column5: and two-guitar configuration. ""Kind Guidance"" and ""Sweet Destiny
column6: the band’s two lead singles

column8: but percussive and turbulent in their messiest moments thanks to Graham’s forceful timekeeping and the synergy between Blake and the Sitaras bros’ kaleidoscopic guitar tones (Xander Sitaras plays bass).

column1: There’s an atmospheric feel in Paper Days’ music
column2: and singer Niko Sitaras uses this context as a means of both poetic conveyance and care-free musing. ""I had to be a believer to know when I was wrong
column3: he croons on ""Kind Guidance

column5: more explicitly: ""You had your back/ Against the wall for me
column6: baby."" There’s a slickness to lyrics like this that feels more social than angsty; ""Boy""—which is inspired by Caitlyn Jenner—is a reflection on gender stereotypes that still manages to sound fun-loving despite the embedded provocations in the lyrics (""For a boy to be a man/ He’s gotta learn it with his hands""). Here
column7: Sitaras' vocals
column8: which were written collectively by the band

column1: The entire EP is loose and layered
column2: with several elements that occasionally feel too cluttered to cohere (cc: ""Lightning Cola"")—but then again
column3: some of the cuts here
column4: like the title track

column6: raw takes meant to emulate that ""living room"" feel that often defines small-town bands. Lyrically speaking

column10:
he could be part of theirs.

It doesn’t take long to reach the heart of Anderson .Paak’s new album
column5: Malibu. Just a minute into opening track ""The Birds

column7: strained
column8: and conversational

column11: soulful project

column1: Brandon Anderson Paak has seen a lot in his 29 years. His mother was a farmer from South Korea
column2: and his father served in the Air Force and later worked as a mechanic until he was sent to prison. ""I didn’t see him again until he was being buried
column3: .Paak told Consequence of Sound in a 2015 interview. All of this life experience is reflected in Malibu

column6: .Paak celebrates his progression by acknowledging where he’s come from

column8: living under my greatness

column1: Kendrick's spirit feels present at many points on Malibu. .Paak's quicksilver flow on ""Your Prime"" feels teleported in directly from To Pimp a Butterfly as the music flows expansively from creamy soul harmonies to trap cadences. But .Paak is a confident and unique presence

column1: On ""The Dreamer

column5: watching old reruns."" This is powerful art

you can go anywhere and reach glorious heights.

An Abundance of Strawberries both is and isn’t a Julia Brown album. While the Maryland-based indie pop outfit intended to record an album in 2014

column1: Ironically

column4: before giving way to cymbal crashes and a cavalcade of voices as the song expands and blossoms. Likewise

column1: An Abundance of Strawberries is a dense collection
column2: but it coheres thanks to Ray's ability to twist a connective melody out of the most unlikely of places. It feels indebted to the Elephant 6 creative model

it’s heartening to know that the band was able to end on such a grand statement.

It's often said that dance music has a short shelf life—that once-novel sounds and techniques are eventually flattened by the technological steamroller that is Moore's Law. That's not necessarily true
column2: though. If the retro fixations of the current century have told us anything—from electroclash's fascination with the early '80s to the recent revival of grime's bleepy fundamentals—it's that dance music's period-specific patinas are a big part of its enduring charm.

column1: A new anthology of the duo Mood II Swing is
column2: if anything
column3: overdue. Their productions in the '90s helped establish a style of house music—moody
column4: colorful
column5: and rhythmically inventive—that has had a profound impact on several successive generations of club producers. Their unique sense of swing helped feed the slinky syncopations of UK garage around the turn of the millennium; more recently
column6: the hypnotic and soulful aspects of their sound have influenced revivalist house music from the underground all the way to the top of the charts
column7: from tunes like Jack J's ""Thirstin'"" to Duke Dumont's ""Need U (100%)."" The bulk of the songs collected here date from between 1992 and 1997
column8: but the uninitiated listener hearing them for the first time might well mistake many of them for brand-new productions. Many sound uncannily current; the best sound timeless.

column1: That Mood II Swing (consisting of Lem Springsteen and John Ciafone) established such an immediately recognizable style is all the more impressive for the fact that most of the time they were remixing other artists. Only 14 of the 33 songs here are originals; the rest are remixes for a diverse lot of pop and R&B acts whose names have mostly faded from view
column2: like Kim English
column3: Loni Clark
column4: and Ultra Naté
column5: whose career peak
column6: 1997's ""Free
column7: was co-written with and produced by Mood II Swing. No matter who the credited performer is
column8: though
column9: a number of hallmarks remain constant throughout. The most obvious is the group's infectious and inimitable sense of the groove. Around steady kicks and hi-hats
column10: regular as fence posts
column11: snake vine-like figures dipping and bobbing in the breeze—shakers and congas
column12: hiccupping accidentals and sidewinding basslines that turn even the most linear rhythms into controlled explosions of kinetic energy.

column1: On a song like Doubleplusgood's ""Conga Té (Mood II Swing 12"" Mix)
column2: you can hear the influence of hip-hop
column3: particularly Public Enemy and the Bomb Squad: Every inch of the track is stuffed with elements until it all ignites like a sky full of fireworks. A typical Mood II Swing track is charged with so much friction
column4: you expect sparks to fly
column5: and that's particularly true when they indulge their fondness for busted and broken sounds. You can hear that in the distortion of BT's ""Remember (Mood II Swing Remix)
column6: in which the kick drum rattles like a shredded speaker cone
column7: and the nervy squelch of the heavily filtered ""Slippery Track
column8: which rivals Matthew Herbert's most aggressively funky work of the period.

column1: The compilation is split more or less evenly between vocal tracks and instrumentals or dub versions
column2: and in the case of Eric Gadd's ""The Right Way
column3: which is presented in both versions
column4: you can hear how differently the duo approached those two contexts. The vocal mix leaves the singer's whispery falsetto unadulterated
column5: and the results sound a lot like early '90s R&B with a piano-house underpinning. (The vocalists they worked with tend to be soulful belters; your appreciation for the vocal side of their catalog will depend largely upon your fondness for that emphatic
column6: melismatic style.) On the dub
column7: though

The city of Warsaw has two (equally dour) associations in rock history. It was the original name of a certain morose Mancunian post-punk band before they got all inside-baseball with their World War II references
column2: and it was the inspiration for ""Warszawa
column3: the haunting ambient symphony that heralds the foreboding second act of David Bowie's Low. As the first Warsaw-based musician in years to plug into the North American indie industrial complex
column4: Tobiasz Biliński doesn't do much to dispel those grim allusions. He may possess the gentle voice of a sensitive folksinger and the byzantine mind of a composer
column5: but at the core of his music beats the blackened heart of a goth.

column1: The Provider is Biliński's third album as Coldair
column2: but the first to land in the U.S. (through a publishing and digital distribution deal with Sub Pop). And from an aesthetic standpoint
column3: it may as well be his proper debut
column4: because it's less a full realization of what he's been working toward than a wholesale reformulation of it. Coldair's previous efforts were more like warm gusts: gentle Nick Drakean serenades guided by winsome
column5: wandering melodies and buttressed by brass fanfares. But 2013's Whose Blood suggested a creeping unease
column6: with digital jolts and foreboding
column7: Swans-like percussion that poked black holes in the scenery. On The Provider
column8: Biliński reaches into those fissures and tears them wide open
column9: allowing that darkness to become all-consuming. Listen close and you can still hear the acoustic strums and trombone trills that underpinned his earlier work
column10: but here they're subservient to frosty synth drones
column11: icy 808s
column12: and synthetic handclaps that sting like smacks to the face on a winter's night. As the arresting opener ""Endear"" emerges from a misty haze into an urgent
column13: industrial-grade throb
column14: Biliński is transformed from humble troubadour to the high priest at black mass
column15: complete with an ominous church-organ hum that powers the song's intense finale.

column1: But there's a bit of a Wizard of Oz effect at play on The Provider—the songs may project a majestic ultraviolet glow
column2: but the dry ice eventually clears to reveal the lonely
column3: wounded soul pulling the levers behind the curtain. Biliński's language has become brutally direct: ""My whole life is falling apart so fast
column4: he sings at one point
column5: and The Provider can be heard as his attempt to put the pieces back together
column6: resulting in songs that seem both fragile and imposing in their construction
column7: all jagged edges and exposed wires. The overwhelming mood of distress is reflected in the unsettled arrangements—electro-shocked beats clash with militaristic drum fills
column8: pianos and shoegaze guitar drizzle rub up against anxious tick-tock rhythms
column9: meditative melodies hover above dirty dancefloor grinds. But that internal tension dissipates when the songs start to sprawl out
column10: as on the synth-smeared title track or the sputtering bombast of ""Suit Yourself.""

column1: The Provider is most compelling when its textural expanse induces claustrophobia. Beneath the clatter
column2: The Provider elicits the discomfiting sensation of eavesdropping on Biliński's private conversations—with family members
column3: with ex-lovers
column4: with himself—about his feelings of inadequacy in the face of parental and societal pressures. But his voice remains as light as the subject matter is heavy
column5: and is often double-tracked into angelic harmonies that help smooth over the songs' corrosive surfaces. And even when working with electro-sonics and brittle beats
column6: Biliński's classically-trained approach to songcraft prevails—on strobe-lit standouts like ""Perfect Son"" and ""Denounce
column7: he builds big hooks out of scraps and shards
column8: skilfully layering and arranging his minimal elements to maximize their dramatic impact. Ironically
column9: the more oppressive environs of The Provider prove to be a more effective showcase for Biliński's emotionally charged songcraft than his heart-on-sleeve folkie phase. Because that's the funny thing about cold air—when the weather turns so frigid that your exhalation produces visible vapors
column10:
it feels like you're breathing fire.

We are not

column6: bluesy track with blunt lyrics about lying politicians and media manipulation that don’t read much different from a teenager’s Tumblr post encouraging readers to ""stay woke."" Later

column3: it's fun to imagine how classic Prince records might sound to fresh ears

column5: after all
column6: and even as his reputation looms larger than ever

column8: a millions things obviously—a particular melodic sensibility
column9: the urge to continually reinvent
column10: the indelible stories
column11: his undeniable chops

column13: Prince's best work took new
column14: unfamiliar paths to familiar feelings. Established song forms rebuilt the ""wrong"" way
column15: Prince's discography has a stiff
column16: funky
column17: uncanny-valley relationship with the pop that came before.

column1: And this is why HITNRUN Phase Two is an underwhelming entry in the artist formerly known as the Artist Formerly Known as Prince's canon. Relative to the idiosycratic and all-over-the place first iteration of the HITNRUN series
column2: Phase Two is an organic-textured
column3: polished
column4: and predictable release. From beginning to end
column5: Prince seems more interested in establishing his proficiency with pop forms
column6: demonstrating his facility with the materials  to craft
column7: as it were
column8: a sturdy wooden table. Rather than an artist's interpretation

column1: This is in part due to the absence of Joshua Welton
column2: formerly of forgotten R&B group Fatty Koo. Welton  co-produced the bulk of the first HITNRUN album
column3: accenting it with EDM flourishes in a way that felt mildly adventurous. Without them

Whether the references are knowing (a nod to Prince's own ""Kiss"" partway through dancefloor record ""Stare"") or simply dial up favorites from R&B's celestial jukebox (the extended highlight ""Groovy Potential"" surely recalls Oliver Cheatham's ""Get Down Saturday Night"")
column6: the songs rarely cohere into unique shapes. Or when they do
column7: there's something quaint and mediated about the whole ordeal: the swaggering protagonists of ""Stare
column8: (""Now we got the sound that's popping in the street"") may have the ""party going ham"" but the strutting feels calculated and theatrical.

column1: We also get the waltz of ""When She Comes
column2: like an action-figure version of Otis Redding's ""I've Got Dreams to Remember
column3: or the ludicrous chorus of garage-rock vehicle ""Screwdriver
column4: which was first premiered in 2013 and could have been written for the Hives. Lyrics tend to be forgettably symbolic; ""I'm in the big city when I'm in your arms."" I mean
column5: sure? This is perhaps most jarring on topical opener ""Baltimore
column6: which not only strikes a bum note tonally—the reassuriningly jaunty vibe is miles away from ""Alright""—but just seems lazy: ""We're tired of crying
column7: and people dying/ Let's take all the guns away."" OK
column8: so no one needs Prince to offer policy positions
column9: but in contrast with even the hippy idealism of his incredible '90s anti-gun anthem ""Love Sign
column10: ""Baltimore"" suggests complete creative fatigue.

column1: The redeeming moments are ones which make some unpredictable moves—any shocks are welcome on a record as polite and poised as this. Near the end comes ""Revelation
column2: a spare version of an Isley Brothers-style ballad which holds attention by withholding. Prince's vocal performance has a touching grace
column3: but what makes the song work is its subversive refusal to entirely exist: it feels like a shadow. But perhaps the album's true star is ""Xtraloveable
column4: a silly record with an amusing chorus conceit: ""Whenever you need someone to take a shower with
column5: call me up
column6: please."" It strikes a rare relatable-goofy balance
column7: and like 2014's ""Breakfast Can Wait"" or 2015's ""1000 X's and O's
column8: this gives the record some weight and substance. It's a bit odd to imagine that shower sex is the most exciting part of Prince's day—after all
column9:
he's still a superstar living in a $10 million Paisley Park estate—but no reason not to take what you can get.

Listen to enough music
column2: and go to enough shows
column3: and you're bound to stumble across an unknown artist that blows you away and makes you wish you had the means to put their music in front of every serious listener you know. Sure
column4: there's a perverse thrill in digging on something that few other people know about
column5: but it can actually be painful to harbor a lifelong love for band that's been all but erased from history.

column1: That might sound a tad dramatic to you
column2: but it's a safe bet that it doesn't sound that way to Hank Shteamer
column3: the producer and driving force behind this three-album box set. (Full disclosure: Shteamer is an occasional contributor to Pitchfork). As a 16-year-old
column4: Shteamer's mind was so thoroughly blown by the Cleveland quintet craw that no other music has affected him in quite the same way since. He currently plays drums in STATS and Aa
column5: serves as senior music editor at rollingstone.com
column6: and continues to chart connections between metal and jazz via his interview blog
column7: Heavy Metal Be-Bop. With this box
column8: listeners get an opportunity to re-trace Shteamer's steps through the band's first three albums. (craw's fourth and final LP
column9: 2002's Bodies for Strontium 90
column10: is still available via Hydra Head.)

column1: If you've never heard craw's work
column2: you'd have every reason to be skeptical about how it might hold up in a climate where even groups like the Dillinger Escape Plan and Gorguts have a hard time keeping up with the accelerated mutation they inspired in other bands with their classic output. Indeed
column3: Lost Nation Road
column4: craw's 1994 sophomore LP
column5: includes a song
column6: ""Bypass
column7: that drifts uncomfortably close to the silt-coated riverbed that Tool illustrated so memorably on 1993's landmark Undertow. ""Bypass"" is immediately followed by ""Botulism
column8: Cholera + Tarik
column9: a chaotic saxophone orgy (courtesy of guest horn players Matt Dufresne and Marcus Rosinski) that recalls the expulsive spirit of Mr. Bungle splattered with a little John Zorn for good measure.

column1: Other than those two moments
column2: however
column3: this set demonstrates over and over how craw found their way to their own musical island
column4: and listening to these three albums for the first time today is like traveling to a remote
column5: untouched location and discovering strange wildlife and fauna that have evolved in genetic isolation. If you were forced to categorize this music—or
column6: more aptly
column7: to describe it in terms that people will understand—craw carved out a space where post-hardcore
column8: technical metal
column9: math rock
column10: and experimental noise all flow together under a hazy smog of something that resembles jazz
column11: but isn't always clearly definable as such.

column1: Craw specialized in shifting
column2: nonlinear song structures where rhythms
column3: riffs
column4: harmonies
column5: and atmospheres seep into one another—a stark contrast from the enduring metal/post-hardcore standard where bands flash their chops by stringing together part after part after part. Craw actually had more in common with Pony Express Record-era Shudder to Think and These Arms Are Snakes than they ever did with Botch or Converge
column6: and an unhinged semblance of jazz permeates their material like a spectral presence. Of course
column7: their music sounds more fitting of a psychiatric ward than the urbane lounges—or even the piss-stained lower-Manhattan sidewalks—that jazz was heavily associated with in the '90s.

column1: As much as bands like Candiria and Shining deserve credit for transplanting horns into their respective takes on street-level hardcore and black metal
column2: craw were clearly aiming for a creative dimension you can't arrive at by stylistic gene-splicing alone. Neil Chastain
column3: who played drums on the first two albums
column4: helped shape craw's warped sense of structure by applying concepts he'd discovered in the music of Neubauten and Edgard Varèse. Likewise
column5: guitarist and self-described ""math and science geek"" Rockie Brockway used a numbers-based system to write riffs. But those things don't necessarily do justice to the sound that craw came up with. ""We were trying
column6: Chastain recalls
column7: ""to dig through your comfort layers and make you feel something."" The realization that this band was searching for something intangible lurks at every turn
column8: but as you grow more familiar with craw's vocabulary
column9: that ""something"" remains as vague and hard to pinpoint as it must have sounded to people's ears in the mid-'90s. And it is that mystery that ultimately pulls you in.

column1: Shteamer recalls that at the six or seven craw shows he attended
column2: there were fewer—""sometimes far fewer""—than 20 people in the room. Unsurprisingly
column3: he brings a missionary's fervor to documenting the band's history via an accompanying 200-page book that comes stuffed with interviews (conducted by Shteamer himself)
column4: a complete catalog's worth of lyrics
column5: and an abundance of photos
column6: show flier and album artwork (much of it courtesy of famed cover artist Derek Hess)
column7: handwritten notes
column8: a complete gigging history as best as everyone can remember it
column9: and miscellaneous ephemera including a merch order invoice. According to Shteamer
column10: even the most diehard experi-metal aficionados have never heard of craw
column11: but this box presents as thorough an opportunity to play catch-up as one could ever hope to get for any artist
column12: let alone a band that makes Barkmarket and Thought Industry look like household names by comparison.

column1: The lyric sheets and voluminous interviews included in the book give listeners plenty of perspective on frontman Joe McTighe's way with words
column2: but suffice it to say that his images walk the fine line between demented and acutely aware—much in the same way schizophrenics can appear at once utterly detached from ""reality"" while speaking with intuitive precision about their surroundings. McTighe's reference to the car-bombing of real-life environmental activist Judi Bari is as captivating as it is uncomfortable to stomach—and just one of many examples that set his lyrics in a class by themselves. Likewise
column3: even through his barking/gurgling/whispering style
column4: McTighe's words are almost always intelligible. Some heavy bands—the majority of them
column5: arguably—play heavy music to aggress
column6: to go fists-up and balls-out into life. For others such as craw
column7: heaviness represents a barrier behind which one retreats and stews in observation of the outside world.

column1: Early on in their career
column2: craw moved away from a riff-based approach and began writing as an ensemble. It shows
column3: more or less
column4: from note one of this set. Musicians in particular should find craw's approach to structure especially illuminating
column5: even though
column6: when taken as one entire chunk
column7: it's sometimes difficult to tell one album apart from another. It doesn't help that Steve Albini's thoroughly unremarkable recording style fails to capture the raw immediacy of a band in the room while also forcing the band to shy away from using the studio as a means to create the atmosphere and ""album feel"" that its material rightfully called for. Luckily
column8: though
column9: there are times when the audio mix recalls the charming timbre of the cassette demos that were common during craw's years of activity.

column1: In any case
column2: long before you arrive at 1997's <i>Map
column3: Monitor
column4: Surge it becomes obvious that craw didn't fit any of the commonly accepted storylines that media outlets like this one depend on and
column5: essentially
column6: manufacture. And unlike
column7: say
column8: Helmet or the Jesus Lizard
column9: craw didn't benefit from a media climate that embraced their exotic other-ness and allow them to exist in multiple camps simultaneously. Who knows what other factors played into craw's career trajectory
column10: but looking back it's easy to imagine that this band was more or less destined for obscurity.

column1: In the best sense of the term
column2: craw's music is an acquired taste. Immediately on hitting play
column3: one understands that this was not a band that got to the point quickly or shied away from making long
column4: drawn-out albums. Sometimes
column5: though
column6: more does end up being more. And this box provides an appropriately exhaustive vehicle for taking the time it requires to sit with and digest a body of work that's still revealing itself to a lifelong fan like Hank Shteamer so long after the fact. Listening back
column7: you have to wonder how many other trailblazing groups have existed that you'll never know about. But as you work your way through 1993-1997
column8:

column1:
1|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/22631/homepage_large.b4687769.jpg|craw|33379.0|craw|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Northern Spy']|2016-01-08 00:00:00|1993|2016-06-11 16:02:56.394298|"

Listen to enough music
column2: and go to enough shows
column3: and you're bound to stumble across an unknown artist that blows you away and makes you wish you had the means to put their music in front of every serious listener you know. Sure
column4: there's a perverse thrill in digging on something that few other people know about
column5: but it can actually be painful to harbor a lifelong love for band that's been all but erased from history.

column1: That might sound a tad dramatic to you
column2: but it's a safe bet that it doesn't sound that way to Hank Shteamer
column3: the producer and driving force behind this three-album box set. (Full disclosure: Shteamer is an occasional contributor to Pitchfork). As a 16-year-old
column4: Shteamer's mind was so thoroughly blown by the Cleveland quintet craw that no other music has affected him in quite the same way since. He currently plays drums in STATS and Aa
column5: serves as senior music editor at rollingstone.com
column6: and continues to chart connections between metal and jazz via his interview blog
column7: Heavy Metal Be-Bop. With this box
column8: listeners get an opportunity to re-trace Shteamer's steps through the band's first three albums. (craw's fourth and final LP
column9: 2002's Bodies for Strontium 90
column10: is still available via Hydra Head.)

column1: If you've never heard craw's work
column2: you'd have every reason to be skeptical about how it might hold up in a climate where even groups like the Dillinger Escape Plan and Gorguts have a hard time keeping up with the accelerated mutation they inspired in other bands with their classic output. Indeed
column3: Lost Nation Road
column4: craw's 1994 sophomore LP
column5: includes a song
column6: ""Bypass
column7: that drifts uncomfortably close to the silt-coated riverbed that Tool illustrated so memorably on 1993's landmark Undertow. ""Bypass"" is immediately followed by ""Botulism
column8: Cholera + Tarik
column9: a chaotic saxophone orgy (courtesy of guest horn players Matt Dufresne and Marcus Rosinski) that recalls the expulsive spirit of Mr. Bungle splattered with a little John Zorn for good measure.

column1: Other than those two moments
column2: however
column3: this set demonstrates over and over how craw found their way to their own musical island
column4: and listening to these three albums for the first time today is like traveling to a remote
column5: untouched location and discovering strange wildlife and fauna that have evolved in genetic isolation. If you were forced to categorize this music—or
column6: more aptly
column7: to describe it in terms that people will understand—craw carved out a space where post-hardcore
column8: technical metal
column9: math rock
column10: and experimental noise all flow together under a hazy smog of something that resembles jazz
column11: but isn't always clearly definable as such.

column1: Craw specialized in shifting
column2: nonlinear song structures where rhythms
column3: riffs
column4: harmonies
column5: and atmospheres seep into one another—a stark contrast from the enduring metal/post-hardcore standard where bands flash their chops by stringing together part after part after part. Craw actually had more in common with Pony Express Record-era Shudder to Think and These Arms Are Snakes than they ever did with Botch or Converge
column6: and an unhinged semblance of jazz permeates their material like a spectral presence. Of course
column7: their music sounds more fitting of a psychiatric ward than the urbane lounges—or even the piss-stained lower-Manhattan sidewalks—that jazz was heavily associated with in the '90s.

column1: As much as bands like Candiria and Shining deserve credit for transplanting horns into their respective takes on street-level hardcore and black metal
column2: craw were clearly aiming for a creative dimension you can't arrive at by stylistic gene-splicing alone. Neil Chastain
column3: who played drums on the first two albums
column4: helped shape craw's warped sense of structure by applying concepts he'd discovered in the music of Neubauten and Edgard Varèse. Likewise
column5: guitarist and self-described ""math and science geek"" Rockie Brockway used a numbers-based system to write riffs. But those things don't necessarily do justice to the sound that craw came up with. ""We were trying
column6: Chastain recalls
column7: ""to dig through your comfort layers and make you feel something."" The realization that this band was searching for something intangible lurks at every turn
column8: but as you grow more familiar with craw's vocabulary
column9: that ""something"" remains as vague and hard to pinpoint as it must have sounded to people's ears in the mid-'90s. And it is that mystery that ultimately pulls you in.

column1: Shteamer recalls that at the six or seven craw shows he attended
column2: there were fewer—""sometimes far fewer""—than 20 people in the room. Unsurprisingly
column3: he brings a missionary's fervor to documenting the band's history via an accompanying 200-page book that comes stuffed with interviews (conducted by Shteamer himself)
column4: a complete catalog's worth of lyrics
column5: and an abundance of photos
column6: show flier and album artwork (much of it courtesy of famed cover artist Derek Hess)
column7: handwritten notes
column8: a complete gigging history as best as everyone can remember it
column9: and miscellaneous ephemera including a merch order invoice. According to Shteamer
column10: even the most diehard experi-metal aficionados have never heard of craw
column11: but this box presents as thorough an opportunity to play catch-up as one could ever hope to get for any artist
column12: let alone a band that makes Barkmarket and Thought Industry look like household names by comparison.

column1: The lyric sheets and voluminous interviews included in the book give listeners plenty of perspective on frontman Joe McTighe's way with words
column2: but suffice it to say that his images walk the fine line between demented and acutely aware—much in the same way schizophrenics can appear at once utterly detached from ""reality"" while speaking with intuitive precision about their surroundings. McTighe's reference to the car-bombing of real-life environmental activist Judi Bari is as captivating as it is uncomfortable to stomach—and just one of many examples that set his lyrics in a class by themselves. Likewise
column3: even through his barking/gurgling/whispering style
column4: McTighe's words are almost always intelligible. Some heavy bands—the majority of them
column5: arguably—play heavy music to aggress
column6: to go fists-up and balls-out into life. For others such as craw
column7: heaviness represents a barrier behind which one retreats and stews in observation of the outside world.

column1: Early on in their career
column2: craw moved away from a riff-based approach and began writing as an ensemble. It shows
column3: more or less
column4: from note one of this set. Musicians in particular should find craw's approach to structure especially illuminating
column5: even though
column6: when taken as one entire chunk
column7: it's sometimes difficult to tell one album apart from another. It doesn't help that Steve Albini's thoroughly unremarkable recording style fails to capture the raw immediacy of a band in the room while also forcing the band to shy away from using the studio as a means to create the atmosphere and ""album feel"" that its material rightfully called for. Luckily
column8: though
column9: there are times when the audio mix recalls the charming timbre of the cassette demos that were common during craw's years of activity.

column1: In any case
column2: long before you arrive at 1997's <i>Map
column3: Monitor
column4: Surge it becomes obvious that craw didn't fit any of the commonly accepted storylines that media outlets like this one depend on and
column5: essentially
column6: manufacture. And unlike
column7: say
column8: Helmet or the Jesus Lizard
column9: craw didn't benefit from a media climate that embraced their exotic other-ness and allow them to exist in multiple camps simultaneously. Who knows what other factors played into craw's career trajectory
column10: but looking back it's easy to imagine that this band was more or less destined for obscurity.

column1: In the best sense of the term
column2: craw's music is an acquired taste. Immediately on hitting play
column3: one understands that this was not a band that got to the point quickly or shied away from making long
column4: drawn-out albums. Sometimes
column5: though
column6: more does end up being more. And this box provides an appropriately exhaustive vehicle for taking the time it requires to sit with and digest a body of work that's still revealing itself to a lifelong fan like Hank Shteamer so long after the fact. Listening back
column7: you have to wonder how many other trailblazing groups have existed that you'll never know about. But as you work your way through 1993-1997
column8:
you do get the distinct impression that none of them sounded quite like this.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/22710/homepage_large.c2b751b9.jpg|Sorry for the Late Reply: Various Remixes for Various Reasons|33417.0|Young Marco|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Safe Trip']|2016-01-08 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:02:57.166527|"

Back before he began releasing his own singles and remixing others as Young Marco
column2: Amsterdam’s Marco Sterk was gainfully employed by Rush Hour
column3: the city’s vital record store/ dance music distribution hub/reissue imprint. Perhaps it stems from his handling of the label’s archival overviews—of such unheralded electronic music producers ranging from Anthony ""Shake"" Shakir to the Burrell Brothers to Daniel Wang—but Young Marco has absorbed their sense of craft. It’s understated yet undeniable
column4: and in a few short years he’s racked up a good deal of remix work.

column1: Ten of these remixes are compiled as Sorry for the Late Reply
column2: its title no doubt a nod to the hectic touring schedules of most in-demand DJs/ producers (when I spoke to him last year
column3: Sterk had recorded in Bali
column4: toured the West Coast with Jamie xx
column5: and was about to do more club dates in Europe). No doubt some of these remixes were done on the fly
column6: but each submission sounds as if Marco missed its deadline to finesse a small detail and make each track land just right.

column1: The remix that kicks off the set is the one that’s traveled the furthest
column2: Michael Ozone’s ""Hetrotopia
column3: thanks to its inclusion on a Boomkat comp
column4: a Ben UFO mix
column5: and on John Talabot’s DJ-Kicks. Marco takes the queasy
column6: anxious arpeggio of the original and shoots it through with sunlight and a sense of ease. The beat sways between bubbling acid and a touch of hand drum
column7: shot through with echoing jungle cries and a voice sneering: ""Freaks come out at night."" The cheap Casio underpinning Heatsick gets paired with a swinging drum and hi-hat figure on ""Dream Tennis
column8: giving the stiffness of the original a bit more bend.

column1: For most of the set
column2: Young Marco prefers subtle builds
column3: simmering drum programming
column4: and playful recasts of his source material
column5: with only a stomping track like Causa’s ""Alji"" serving as a peak-hour track. Otherwise
column6: Late Reply will get the most work for building up sets or else easing things down at the end of the night (the shimmering downtempo take on Tony G’s ""Simple Dreams"" is an album stand-out). If ""tropical house"" weren’t already a cringeworthy subgenre
column7: I might try to use it to describe Marco’s ability to add lilting island rhythmic patterns to house’s grid.

column1: Regardless
column2: it’s when he’s working with decidedly non-electronic material that Marco’s eclectic handiwork shines. Take two curious remixes
column3: of mop-topped Dutchman troubadour Jacco Gardner and of Cameroonian musician/author Francis Bebey. Gardner’s wistful ""The End of August"" shades into Hot Chip/Kindness territory in Marco’s hands. It gets a rhythmic nudge in the form of a wispy conga pattern and hissing drum machine
column4: Gardner’s gentle voice garlanded by blips that swoop down like swallows. Marco doesn’t bear down too hard on the track
column5: but keeps it light on its feet. For Bebey’s quaint and charming ""The Coffee Cola Song
column6: Marco takes a brief pip of Francis Bebey’s nose flute and makes it into something as effervescent as the title suggests

column6: you know

column3: though. Conversely
column4: on Blackstar

column2: its blend of jazz
column3: codes
column4: brutality
column5: drama
column6: and alienation is not without precedent in his work. Bowie’s first proper instrument was a saxophone
column7: after all

column10: Eric Dolphy
column11: and Beat Generation ideals. The links connecting Bowie
column12: his brother
column13: and jazz feel significant. Burns suffered from schizophrenia throughout his life; he once tried to kill himself by jumping out of a mental hospital window and eventually committed suicide by putting himself in front of a train in 1985.

column1: Perhaps this helps explain why Bowie has often used jazz and his saxophone not for finger-snapping pep but rather to hint at mystery and unease. It’s there in his close collaborations with avant-jazz pianist Mike Garson
column2: from 1973’s ""Aladdin Sane (1913-1938-197?)"" all the way to 2003’s ""Bring Me the Disco King."" It’s in his wild squawks on 1993’s ""Jump They Say

""I’m dying to push their backs against the grain and fool them all again and again

column13: he’s making the most of his latest reawakening
column14:
adding to the myth while the myth is his to hold.

column11: immutable sense of joy.

column1: In March of 2014
column2: Boosie was released from that (barely) repurposed plantation in Louisiana after beating a drug smuggling case and first-degree murder charge. He seemed
column3: finally
column4: free—a pair of freestyles recorded on the ride home had him singing about seeing his kids and figuring out when he could squeeze in a haircut. He quickly went scorched-Earth with a series of guest features and loose singles that saw him very near

column2: in mid-December

Film Music arrives in the West with little in the way of context. Without any context

column7: unforced range that covers humble piano suites

column10: rambunctious klezmer

column1: Tariverdiev’s eclecticism allows these songs to exist apart from the films that inspired them and to speak to Western audiences. In fact
column2: Film Music gives you a strong
column3: yet fleeting impression of Russian cinema during the latter half of the 20th century. You would imagine any film accompanying this music would balance whimsy and melancholy
column4: humor and tragedy

column1: There are fleeting moments
