column3: he manages one of the album’s more memorable lines
column4: repeating ""hate the drugs but I love the numb."" When he hits on a nice guitar tone or melody or lyric
column5: the songs are so simple that they assume a semi-meditative quality. The title track is the best song here
column6: with a nostalgic breakbeat and Cudi softly singing about manic depression: ""If I crash
column7: or when I land
column8: no matter the case
column9: I’m all smiles."" It’s a simple but effective tone poem.

column1: And sometimes the songs are so uncomfortably direct it feels wrong to be evaluating them at all: How do you judge the value of ""Fuchsia Butterflies""' chorus ""I’ll be happy getting shitfaced by myself?"" It might be a confessional
column2: but again Kid Cudi undercuts himself: If he is committed to this direction
column3: and the album’s flaws are just the result of his limited voice and guitar skills
column4: why include ""The Nothing
column5: a song that’s a riff on ""Mary
column6: Mary Quite Contrary""? Moments like this only reinforce the impression that the whole project is one long failed joke
column7: a comedian bombing onstage trying to will it into performance art. So again: is he serious? Either way
column8: Speedin' Bullet is a remarkable flop
column9:
and there is a certain amazement whenever something this self-indulgent and messy gets released on a major label.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/22683/homepage_large.36a6340b.jpg|From Joy|29118.0|Kyle Hall|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Wild Oats']|2016-01-06 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:03:00.689137|"

Through no fault of his own
column2: Kyle Hall landed in the somewhat precarious position of having Detroit's hopes pinned to him. Since the young DJ and producer debuted in 2007 on fellow Detroiter Omar S's FXHE imprint
column3: Hall has been viewed as the great hope for the next generation of Detroit dance music. Hall kept up his end of the bargain
column4: fostering the potent Wild Oats label
column5: throwing parties in the city and
column6: crucially
column7: not absconding to New York or London or Berlin. Kyle Hall is doing it all
column8: and his 2013 debut album
column9: The Boat Party
column10: sounded like it
column11: anxiously flitting between a host of styles: electro
column12: ghetto tech
column13: filter disco
column14: beat tracks.

column1: It's against this backdrop of fervent activity that Hall's second album
column2: From Joy
column3: stands out so fully. A richly melodic exploration that expertly balances astral reverie with rhythmic heft
column4: it's the kind of fully realized statement no one was really expecting Hall to make. Not because he didn't have the talent
column5: but because
column6: well
column7: he seemed busy. A three-LP set featuring eight expansive tracks
column8: From Joy is ambitious but warm and approachable. In its openness
column9: imagination
column10: and sense of history
column11: From Joy feels like the child of Detroit's legendary exploratory radio shows. The concept is simple: jazzy pianos
column12: walking basslines
column13: and probing synth explorations welded to house music's 4/4 drum templates.

column1: Jazz has always been valuable in house music—as source material and as a thematic link to another form of (largely black) outsider expression—but From Joy uses jazz a little differently than usual. Hall doesn't sample much here
column2: instead borrowing from jazz its ensemble nature
column3: the sense of unity achieved when the elements of a track lock together just so. Where most dance music feels sequenced
column4: From Joy feels played. Where most machine music employs randomizations and swung notes to remind you of its human nature
column5: From Joy just kind of flows.

column1: Hall is able to achieve this in part because From Joy sounds fantastic. You will pass entire tracks—five- and six-minutes long—zeroing in on the richness of one tone or another. For all of a synthesizer's endless possibilities
column2: it's easy to remember that many of them were conceived with the more conservative purpose of emulating traditional instruments. And From Joy is conservative in this sense
column3: dialing up exquisite
column4: harmonically rich synth basslines—see opener ""Damn! I'm Feeln Real Close""—and sonorous leads. One of the album's least dance-y tracks
column5: the contemplative ""Wake Up and Dip
column6: is a showcase for a squelchy solo as expressive and felt as any old vanguard. Hall does all this without betraying his dance music bonafides
column7: as side-long tracks such as ""Dervenen"" and ""Strut Garden"" offer DJs and dancers ample acreage. The latter track improbably lives up to its name
column8: a whole lawn of little jukes and swaggers. Its bassline makes all the familiar moves
column9: freeing you to make the unfamiliar ones.

column1: From Joy effortlessly functions as both dance music and a home listening experience. Kyle Hall
column2: an artist who has built his young career around doing it all
column3: has made an album that does it all. From Joy
column4: imbued with the past but not overly reverent of it
column5: is Hall cashing in on the prodigious talent glimpsed in his prior work. It's tempting to hold it up as a capital-letter statement
column6: a totem of his hometown. It's equally tempting
column7: and probably healthier
column8:
to spin it back and delight in its abundance.

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/22724/homepage_large.7eb45917.jpg|Dreamville II: Revenge of the Dreamers|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Interscope'
column3: J. Cole has made it abundantly clear that he wants to be judged alongside rap's all-time greats. So let's do that: Revenge of the Dreamers II
column4: the new nine-song compilation from his Interscope imprint
column5: Dreamville Records
column6: is not The Dynasty—it doesn't have the color
column7: the heart-wrenching personal asides
column8: the 1-900 numbers that teach you how to sell crack. Nor does it have the slick condescension of any Bad Boy collaboration
column9: the virtuosity of Soundbombing
column10: the knowing sneer of anything the Diplomats made on their worst day.

column1: The problem with Revenge of the Dreamers II
column2: beyond the absence of a ""This Can't Be Life"" or a ""Dipset Anthem
column3: is the same as the problem with much of Cole's solo catalog: In his desperation to be canonized beside his idols
column4: he shies away from the risks they took to earn those spots. His performance on a song-by-song basis from his debut
column5: Cole World: The Sideline Story
column6: to last December's 2014 Forest Hills Drive oscillates wildly
column7: but never shakes the feeling that it's checking boxes
column8: doing X because Kanye did and Y because Pac did.

column1: Take the opener
column2: ""Folgers Crystals
column3: where Cole compares himself to Bob Marley and Nat Turner in the first handful of bars. In many ways
column4: his background is remarkable; the Fayetteville
column5: N.C. native has detailed his experiences in schools with various socioeconomic makeups
column6: including his time at St. John's University in New York. (As always
column7: his rapping on Revenge owes more to the latter locale.) His plan to turn his childhood home—on Forest Hills Drive—into a shelter where single mothers can live rent-free is not just admirable
column8: but is a sincere
column9: inspired way to alleviate the conditions he grew up in and around. But in Cole's more serious writing
column10: most of that personal touch is filtered out
column11: replaced by blunt aphorisms: ""'Cause still I rise
column12: it's ill-advised to bet against him/ Raised in hell but heaven sent him/ Let 'em diss him.""

column1: That kind of toothless penmanship might slide if it weren't delivered so deliberately. Cole's always been at his best when the stakes are low
column2: or at least self-contained; when he's rapping for its own sake
column3: or reveling in the fact that he signed his friends (""Night Job"")
column4: he can be a well above-average technician. (To be fair
column5: that song is nearly derailed when he says he's ""Horny like that Coltrane album
column6: one of a handful of sex-centric bars that he and his Queens-bred signee Bas inexplicably cling to.) But when he's moralizing or getting somber
column7: it's robotic
column8: as with ""Caged Bird""'s refrain
column9: ""Freedom's just an illusion/ That's my conclusion."" On ""Crystals
column10: he punctuates a particularly intense
column11: clumsy passage with
column12: ""So you can take my cock and chew on it
column13: a line that needs a wink or some levity to redeem itself
column14: but is given neither.

column1: Fumbled legacy-building though it is
column2: Dreamers is not without its bright spots. The tape introduces the label's two newest signees: the Washington
column3: D.C.-bred singer Ari Lennox and lute
column4: a rapper from Charlotte who joins Cole in representing North Carolina. Each artist contributes one song here
column5: both of which are among the best on the tape; lute's Dilla-cribbing ""Still Slummin"" in particular is superb
column6: throwing you immediately into his world (""Took off my work badge
column7: realized I'm back in the hood"") and dispensing plaintive
column8: delightfully un-cinematic notes: ""Lost more friends to bullshit than a bullet.""

column1: Lennox's introduction comes in the form of ""Backseat
column2: a song that racked up tens of thousands of plays between its October 2014 release and when it was scrubbed from the Internet last month. It's a knowing
column3: slinking cut that succeeds on almost every front: fun
column4: warm
column5: a little sleazy. Cozz
column6: the Los Angeles rapper who inked his Dreamville deal last year
column7: updates the single with an uncharacteristically flat verse; fortunately
column8: his later contributions to the tape
column9: ""Tabs"" and especially the introspective closer ""Grow
column10: are excellent. (His pre-Interscope singles ""Dreams"" and ""I Need That"" remain two of the most delightfully menacing street rap songs of the past several years.)

column1: Bas—whose braying ""Housewives"" is the weakest cut by a country mile—is joined in Dreamville's relative old guard by Omen
column2: a Chicago native. He and Cole mostly sleepwalk through ""Caged Bird
column3: but his headlining song
column4: the Donnie Trumpet-assisted ""48 Laws
column5: is a welcome contrast; Omen finds the kind of pocket that always seems to elude his more famous partner
column6: and it makes for a sleek
column7: collected track that feels immediately more vibrant than any of the tape's weightier material. And that
column8: in many respects
column9: is Revenge of the Dreamers II: compelling when its focus is at its most narrow
column10: leaden and impersonal when it reaches for the Very Serious and Very Important. It's like Bleek said: ""The strong move quiet
column11:
the weak start riots/ We know you got a brick but sell 'em 20s 'til they tired.""

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/22673/homepage_large.19e93acd.jpg|T r i s h EP|3201.0|Odd Nosdam|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Sonic Cathedral']|2016-01-06 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:03:01.803255|"

What does it mean to remember someone? Beyond the abstract idea of remembrance lie some hard truths about our own limitations: our memories are imperfect and constructed and they degrade over time much as we do ourselves. Odd Nosdam’s T r i s h EP is an act of remembrance that wrestles with these limitations. Its six largely instrumental songs bear the tenor of memories: at once warmly familiar and hazily indistinct.
Nosdam recorded the T r i s h EP in memory of the late Trish Keenan of English noise-pop act Broadcast. Originally released as a limited-run cassette on the Baro label in 2013
column2: the out-of-print EP is now seeing wider release on vinyl. While Nosdam is known best as a producer of cerebral hip-hop beats
column3: the songs on T r i s h are comparatively formless
column4: often eschewing low-end and percussion altogether. This is Nosdam at his most abstract and untethered
column5: dispensing with any notion of genre to explore the evocative qualities of sound. Working with tape loops
column6: samples
column7: and layers of distortion
column8: he constructs churning songs whose melodies lie buried under blankets of static. While Nosdam is certainly no stranger to noise in his work
column9: these tracks often push into Broadcast territory
column10: sounding like transmissions from a radio station that’s just out of range.

column1: Nosdam’s primary focus here is texture; he spends much of T r i s h smearing recognizable shapes into more impressionistic forms. Take the chiming opening melody of ""O l y n n
column2: which feels like it was ripped straight out of a Broadcast song. Around the two-minute mark
column3: the track cuts to silence before that same melody returns
column4: pitched up
column5: massively delayed and barely recognizable. Grouper’s Liz Harris contributes a vocal to the song—a haunting
column6: wordless wail—but even that ultimately gets swallowed up by a cloud of echo as well. Nosdam approaches samples with a similarly warped sensibility on T r i s h; ""L o n j a e"" sounds like a yé-yé 45 left skipping on a turntable until it transforms from a song to a drone.

column1: Broadcast’s greatest trick might have been sculpting pop songs out of noise and Nosdam manages to perform a similar alchemy on the closing track
column2: ""T r i s h."" Here
column3: the producer gives himself over fully to Broadcast’s school of songcraft
column4: employing the sort of fuzzy organ and heavily distorted bass that became hallmarks of that band’s sound. Even more striking
column5: though
column6: is the vocal that floats through the middle of the track. It's a sample from a late-'60s Norwegian folk record but the singer
column7: Annlaug Lofthus
column8: is a dead ringer for Keenan. For a brief moment
column9: amid swells of noise
column10: we catch a glimpse of Trish Keenan through the haze. And then
column11: just like that
column12: she’s gone.

column1: Correction (1/6
column2: 3:50 p.m. EST): An earlier version of this review incorrectly identified the singer on ""T r i s h"" as Trish Keenan. It is Annlaug Lofthus
column3:
as now stated.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/22655/homepage_large.86fbf6a5.jpg|The Bell|6324.0|Ches Smith|['Jazz']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['ECM']|2016-01-06 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 16:03:03.325821|"

Ches Smith is best known to indie rock liner-note devotees as a percussionist who has appeared on over half a dozen Xiu Xiu releases (going all the way back to Knife Play). In recent years
column2: he’s been consistently active on the contemporary jazz circuit—lending his talents to a series of celebrated albums by artists such as guitarist Mary Halvorson and saxophonist Tim Berne. The music of both those composers occasionally strays close to avant-rock
column3: which helps explain Smith’s in-demand status around jazz’s cutting-edge galleries. But he also led those bands through quieter
column4: softer passages
column5: proving his depth and range.

column1: For his first album as a composer and bandleader on Germany’s iconic ECM label
column2: Smith has chosen a subtlety that seems influenced by his most recent bandmates and peers. It’s a stylistic course that will be broadly familiar to fans of Manfred Eicher’s jazz-and-classical imprint
column3: and less so to fans of Women as Lovers. But The Bell isn't placid
column4: either: In the company of pianist Craig Taborn and violist Mat Maneri—an experienced pair of collaborators—Smith forges a quiet intensity. There’s heat here
column5: even if it takes some time to feel it.

column1: Things begin calmly. The album’s title-track opener announces itself with a lone
column2: delicate smack of pitched percussion
column3: before the other players enter. Though the nine-minute piece never strays very far from a static and spacious feel
column4: there’s often something new happening: Smith moves from the bell-like elements in his kit to some vibraphone shimmers
column5: or thrumming timpani playing. Maneri moves from a low drone on his viola to high-pitch wisps of brief
column6: almost-scratchy timbre. Collectively
column7: the group’s sound is constantly tempting you into a false sense of ease that individual players delight in subverting with little tics—adding extra notes to minimalist phrases before they become too predictable.

column1: While all The Bell’s tracks were composed by Smith
column2: the group’s status as ""an improvising trio"" is clear during ""Barely Intervallic
column3: a cut where Smith indulges skittering
column4: freer playing. ""I’ll See You on the Dark Side of the Earth"" and ""I Think"" follow the big-canvas
column5: pensive-but-driven feeling of ""Isn’t It Over?""<span> In the album's final third
column6: ""Wacken Open Air"" gives up its theme right away
column7: the better to let us hear the group work the spare material into a potent acoustic riff. Maneri deals in some lyrical soloing toward the end of ""It’s Always Winter Somewhere."" And the finale
column8: ""For Days
column9: re-establishes the set’s quiet equilibrium.

column1: The largely hypnotic
column2: not-quite-repetitive quality of the music will
column3: for some listeners
column4: call to mind Taborn’s own Junk Magic
column5: an early-21st century triumph of electrified chamber jazz (and an album that also featured Maneri). But The Bell isn’t just some less kinetic
column6: acoustic redo of that project
column7: with Smith holding down the percussion chair. Despite the album’s restricted range
column8: it suggests a malleable aesthetic
column9: likely the result of the year and a half these improvisers put in together before recording their debut outing. You can imagine this band doing a wide variety of impressive work
column10: in the very near future: perhaps adding in some electronics
column11: or including compositions from all members. But for now
column12:
it’s persuasive enough as a demonstration of Smith’s continued career shift into contemporary jazz.

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/22674/homepage_large.3be1fec7.jpg|The Hateful Eight|2903.0|Ennio Morricone|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Third Man'
column2:
'Decca']|2016-01-05 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:03:03.810723|"

Eighty-seven-year old legend Ennio Morricone occupies a unique position among film composers. He's known outside of his industry
column3: a rarity for any score-writer not named John Williams. And he's one of the few film composers whose work has had a significant impact on rock music (perhaps only John Carpenter can claim more). In fact
column4: the work that first brought him fame—his iconic soundtracks for Sergio Leone's mid-1960s Spaghetti Westerns—might have had more influence on rock musicians than film composers. Whenever I hear dramatic rock using echoey twang and dusty atmospheres—examples include Labradford
column5: Thinking Fellers Union Local 282 (who covered Morricone's music for Leone)
column6: and Earth—I immediately think of scenes from The Good
column7: The Bad
column8: and The Ugly.

column1: All of which makes Morricone's decision to score Quentin Tarantino's The Hateful Eight immediately interesting
column2: since it's the first Western-themed film he has worked on in over 30 years. Doubling the intrigue is the fact that some of the music is a cross-pollination of Morricone and Carpenter's visions. Due to time constraints
column3: Morricone re-used pieces he wrote for the latter's 1982 thriller The Thing which Carpenter ultimately didn't include. Then there are the facts that Tarantino has never made a fully-scored film before—he's only used previously-recorded music—and that Morricone once said he ""wouldn't like to work with [Tarantino] again
column4: on anything"" (a statement he later partially rescinded.)

column1: So there's a lot of promise in The Hateful Eight soundtrack
column2: and the final result delivers—though not necessarily due to the factors above. Morricone's return to the Western genre ends up somewhat coincidental; this music is more in line with his later
column3: traditionally-filmic orchestral work
column4: and there's nary a guitar twang to be heard. The score's relation to Carpenter (whose own music has undergone a recent underground revival) is more evident. Morricone's themes have the kind of primal tension that Carpenter used so well in his other movies
column5: but in this case transposed from synth to orchestra.

column1: Ultimately
column2: Morricone's music for The Hateful Eight is rich and evocative regardless of the circumstances of its creation. You might guess that after this long
column3: he'd have to make increasingly complex pieces to find new things to say. Yet the opposite is true: his melodies are still simple
column4: relying on a few notes to form a backbone from which he never strays far. His arrangements and flourishes build momentum
column5: but the core is always powerfully uncluttered. Morricone trusts that a few strong musical ideas can supply lots of atmosphere and emotion throughout an epic-length film.

column1: The Hateful Eight isn't all Morricone
column2: though. Tarantino can't resist DJ-ing a little bit
column3: sprinkling in a short gem from the second White Stripes album
column4: an excellent mid-'60s Roy Orbison single
column5: a David Hess track from the 1972 Wes Craven movie The Last House on the Left
column6: and a fascinatingly-unpolished version of the Australian folk song ""Jim Jones at Botany Bay"" as sung by Jennifer Jason Leigh in the film itself. There are also snippets of movie dialogue interspersed throughout
column7: which are entertaining but too short to be very meaningful (they also include what has to be the most uses of the n-word on any Morricone album).

column1: All those Tarantino additions add texture to The Hateful Eight soundtrack
column2: but Morricone's music by itself is more than enough. There's a wealth of both visceral adventure and reflective emotion in hs pieces. At best
column3: these songs are thrill rides
column4: mood swingers
column5: and thought provokers
column6: all at once. That makes them a perfect fit for a Tarantino movie—but then
column7: as he's proven for over half a century
column8:
Morricone is the right choice for any filmmaker.

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/22646/homepage_large.21b15074.jpg|Leave Me Alone|33252.0|Hinds|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Mom & Pop']|2016-01-05 00:00:00|2016|2016-06-11 16:03:04.367177|"<div class=""contents dropcap"" data-reactid="".gvq4xxtzwg.1.6:0.1.0.$21343/=1$21343.0.3.2.0.1.0.1""><div class=""ii gt m151ff95dad229f70 adP adO"" id="":ss"">

The Madrid-based quartet Hinds makes fuzzy garage pop that seems as intrinsically linked to the warmth and sunshine of their home as California-infused idleness is to many Burger Records bands. They began as a duo called Deers after Carlotta Cosials and Ana Perrote met back in 2011. Inspired by bands like the Black Lips
column2: Mac DeMarco
column3: and the Strokes
column4: the pair wrote woozy pop tracks about love
column5: partying
column6: and the complicated problems that occur when mixing the two. After releasing their first single
column7: 2014's DEMO
column8: Hinds completed their lineup with Ade Martin on bass and Amber Grimbergen on drums
column9: and soon after were forced to change their name due to legal issues (Hinds means a female deer). Hinds may be aware that their casual origin story and goofy demeanor (catch them cracking beers and dancing on tables in their videos) may cause some to think they are not a serious project
column10: so the foursome chose to challenge themselves on their debut LP Leave Me Alone
column11: and the decision pays off.

column1: Hinds have described the 12 tracks on Leave Me Alone as the various ""faces of love"" they experienced while writing their debut
column2: and therefore is more emotionally varied than their previously lighthearted singles. While the title indicates detachment
column3: a majority of the songs suggest the opposite
column4: pleading quite literally on ""Fat Calmed Kiddos"" ""please don't leave me."" Leave Me Alone is a record of human contradictions
column5: of the admissions of vulnerability
column6: and the realization that these things are beautiful. It's no coincidence that the phrase ""You're on my mind"" appears on several songs; for better or worse
column7: Hinds realize that there are some feelings that cannot be escaped.

column1: Leave Me Alone's singles focus on their purely poppy side
column2: from the smooth opener ""Garden"" to the glorious jangle of ""San Diego"" to the wailing harmonies of ""Bamboo."" The previously released ""Castigadas En El Granero
column3: which translates to ""punished in the barn
column4: is perhaps the most frenzied track on the album
column5: which is only amplified by rapid-fire
column6: somewhat absurd observations like ""All I see is a big cow/ And now I'm eating all your corn."" Another particular standout is ""Fat Calmed Kiddos
column7: a sunny whirlpool of a song with a particularly poignant chorus: ""And I needed to risk 'cause I needed to try/ And I needed a breath 'cause you were out tonight.""

column1: These tracks show off what truly sets Hinds apart: Cosials and Perrote's shared vocal responsibilities
column2: which fit together perfectly. Cosials' voice switches between a silky drawl and a Joplin-like howl while Perrote's is grounding and steady. When one is singing
column3: the other often emphasizes or counters
column4: the Ego and Id so to speak. The best moments on Leave Me Alone occur when Cosials and Perrote are going all-out
column5: belting together without restraint.

column1: But even on the ""slower"" songs (there isn't really a lull on Leave Me Alone
column2: except for the midway instrumental interlude ""Solar Gap"") the possibility exists for the energy to be cranked up all the way. After a few final mellow jams like the spacey ""And I Will Send Your Flowers Back"" and ""I'll Be Your Man""
column3: Hinds conclude with ""Walking Home""
column4: a fuzzy and almost-tropical declaration of love. The song embraces silly metaphors like ""You're the map to my toe"" and ""You're the rice of my bowl"" before softly fading out with the words
column5: ""You're the love of my life."" ""Walking Home"" is a lovely reminder of two important facts: that love does not need to be complicated and that Hinds are not afraid to wear their hearts on their sleeves.

column1: "|21343.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21343-leave-me-alone/|7.5|Quinn Moreland

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/22644/homepage_large.c5ff26a6.jpg|This Thing Called Life|33385.0|August Alsina|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Def Jam']|2016-01-05 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:03:05.097960|"

Ever since August Alsina emerged in 2012 with his first official mixtape The Product
column2: he's been somewhat of a curio. In essence
column3: he's a rapper in an R&B singer's body
column4: more likely to sing about his harrowed past and the things he's done to keep food on the table for his family than some romantic tryst. Even ""Would You Know?
column5: the lone love song on the New Orleans native's latest album
column6: This Thing Called Life
column7: is a conflicted ballad on which Alsina is a ball of nerves
column8: afraid that opening up to the possibility of love would leave him vulnerable. But Alsina applies the tender
column9: ruminative aspects of R&B—and its sense of longing
column10: especially—to his street tales
column11: and his second studio album solidifies his place amongst the upper echelon of modern-day R&B.

column1: Like many of his contemporaries
column2: Alsina shares the same interest as Jeremih and PARTYNEXTDOOR—even Young Thug—in exploring the percussive elements of rapping and the myriad of ways they can be married to melody. On sepia-toned lead single ""Hip-Hop
column3: he effortlessly slips back and forth between sweet rhythmic singing and melody-oriented rapping as he describes the environment he grew up in and how he ""came up in criminal ways."" The chorus of ""Dreamer"" finds Alsina employing a triplet cadence à la Migos
column4: a clever flip of the rap-song-with-a-sung-chorus template. Alsina's line-blurring between rapping and singing is never quite as experimental as someone like Jeremih or Young Thug
column5: but it feels completely natural.

column1: Alsina's music also gestures towards his gospel roots. A singer in his church's choir as a child
column2: he hangs hard onto the idea that salvation can be found through perseverance and a strong sense of belief
column3: whether in a higher power or simply your own ability to get through the day. Persistence is Alsina's default mode of engaging with the world—when he's boasts about ""buying the same thing three times"" on ""Why I Do It

column3: waiting to be stumbled upon by accident or odd search (in other words

column8: for example

column12: colliding and collapsing until the junk gets vulcanized into a speedy machine.

column5: anonymous nature of the website. But there are many tracks on the record—""I Love Your Ass
column6: "" Fire Island of the Mind
column7: the title track—that bring the queer-as-fuck energy of Daniel's earlier material. ""Are You Looking?"" assembles results for the terms ""Looking"" and ""Step"" into a brittle-sounding dancefloor turn
column8: solidified by a sample from Madonna's ""Vogue

column10: the former keyword links a classic term for soliciting gay sex to the act of trolling YouTube

mind-numbing state that we all acquiesced to (however subconsciously) when we clicked on that play button for the first time.

America's Greatest Hits
column2: the first full-length by Olympia hardcore act Gag

column4: cracking jokes in the humorless confines of hardcore. They are deeply entrenched in the underground: The album is out on Iron Lung

column6: Jensen Ward

column9: demonstrate a rigorously fundamental understanding of hardcore: forbidding thickets of guitar feedback; dour
column10: mid-tempo riffs evocative of dogged trudging and furrowed brows; and rhythmic motifs limited to lumbering backbeat and pugilistic punctuation.

column1: That makes Gag at once highly traditional—wavering little from formal touchstones like
column2: say
column3: Poison Idea's original ""Pure Hate""—and at odds with hardcore's prevailing inclinations today. There's none of the studied staccato blitzkrieg of Punch

column6: while ""Pretty Boy"" is all showy strut and bratty leads. Trenchant and thuggish without relief

column8: Gag threatens to depose its masters.

column1: Indeed
column2: the ghoulish jester adorning the cover of last year's Locker Room EP looks something like Gag's spiritual advisor. And America's Greatest Hits
column3: like Gag's catalog at large
column4: is distinguished by its humor. Historically
column5: hardcore has prized clarity—rejecting irony and sarcasm in favor of a more imperative and sincere tone—whereas punk is more likely to traffic in farce and black humor. Gag
column6: however
column7: forces an impressive amount of sardonic punch lines
column8: guttersnipe mockery
column9: and macabre wit into its otherwise purist hardcore. In the squelched
column10: scabrous vocals
column11: quizzical references to shrimp
column12: sunglasses
column13: and Wal-Mart abound. ""It's Just Me"" begins
column14: ""There's no justice/ There's no justice—just me<i>
column15: "" which illustrates how skillfully Gag uses the few syllables allotted each line: there's a simplistic pun
column16: a cynical assertion
column17: and even something of a political statement.

column1: All throughout America's Greatest Hits
column2: Gag fulfills the music's nearly monosyllabic requirement with a rare capacity for invention and play. But they aren't simply clever. They mix mastery and transgression. Perhaps Gag explains its perspective best: Consider one of its finest little maxims

column4:
it's inarguable and essential. And America's Greatest Hits affirms that Gag guffaws in the face of death.

Pusha T occupies a unique spot in hip-hop. He's a twenty-year veteran with access to the swankiest production but very little of the nagging pressure to surf mainstream trends that runs his peers ragged. He wrestled the major label rap machine and won
column3: and his scathing sneer has menaced a decade of hip-hop top dogs
column4: from Lil Wayne to Drake. He's the rare instance of a rap talent sharpening over time; few who made their first recordings in the late '90s
column5: as he did as one half of the Clipse
column6: can be argued to possess a firmer grasp on their voice today than in their youth. Since jumping to Kanye West's G.O.O.D. Music after the Clipse began a now-permanent hiatus
column7: Pusha T has zeroed in on a mercenary style both weathered and totally disrespectful; he's seen whole labels
column8: crews
column9: and organizations dissolve
column10: and he's happy to tell you how yours will come apart on you if you're not careful.

column1: A popular rapper with a disdain for the machinery of hip-hop fame is a dangerous assassin
column2: and Pusha spends a good piece of his sophomore studio album King Push – Darkest Before Dawn: The Prelude pulling back the curtain on rap stardom to reveal it for smoke and mirrors. ""M.F.T.R."" razzes rappers who'd ""rather be more famous than rich
column3: and <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/tracks/17877-pusha-t-crutches-crosses-caskets/"">""Crutches
column4: Crosses
column5: Caskets"" shames a platinum rapper whose ""momma lives in squalor
column6: before smirking that Push's own mother is ""in the Bahamas for the month/ She probably sittin' in her pajamas
column7: having lunch."" In a year where a multi-platform media mogul like 50 Cent declared bankruptcy
column8: and Drake and Lil Wayne grumble publicly about Cash Money not paying up
column9: Push's dart in the Biggie-sampling lead single ""Untouchable"" about which companies' checks don't bounce is sound business advice as savage quip (or vice versa).

column1: Darkest Before Dawn isn't all trash talk; Pusha still takes inspiration from his dealer days
column2: both good and bad. Some of the more revealing corners of the record delve into how he coped when things went sour. ""The crash don't kill
column3: it's how you survives it
column4: he raps on ""Keep Dealing."" Early on in ""F.I.F.A."" he snaps ""I'm my city's Willy Falcon/ How you niggas celebrating Alpo?"" in reference to the Floridian coke trafficker who once beat charges of pushing nearly 80 tons of white by bribing the jury and the Harlem shooter Alpo Martinez
column5: subject of the movie Paid in Full. Pusha's second act
column6: both after his group folded and after the Clipse's former manager pled guilty to charges alleging he was a drug kingpin
column7: is a rebirth few inside rap or out have enjoyed. Irv Gotti was never the same after the Feds ran into the Inc offices
column8: and try as he might
column9: Family Hustle Tip will never be King again.

column1: Imagine Tony Montana slipping out of the country scot-free ahead of his career-ending Scarface raid
column2: and you arrive at the cocktail of spite and incredulity fueling Darkest Before Dawn. The swing from moneyed gall to grizzled paranoia is a well-trodden path in hip-hop and elsewhere
column3: but the eye for detail in the writing and the claustrophobic
column4: foreboding sonics set it apart from other rote goon rap fare. That these 10 songs hang together is testament to the writer's bleak vision
column5: since they're technically flotsam from the forthcoming King Push (hence the protracted The Prelude subtitle). Perhaps the prevailing feeling he's not trying to impress us comes from the records he really intends to impact radio being saved for a different project. Whatever the case
column6: Pusha dragged a crack team of rap maestros well outside their respective comfort zones for the occasion.

column1: The production on Darkest Before Dawn is uncompromising headphone boom bap from people who don't really make it anymore. The curt ""Intro"" is a Metro Boomin beat uncharacteristically light on hellacious synths and heavy on cavernous
column2: tribal stomp. For ""Untouchable
column3: Timbaland leaves his trademark bells and whistles behind for a skeletal array of dizzyingly tricky bass and snare hits. ""M.P.A."" is the most unfussed Kanye West production since ""Otis."" ""F.I.F.A."" gets a sputtering Rick Rubin style breakbeat from Q-Tip. Rap producers are dying to make and sell weird shit like this
column4: but thirst for easily recognizable signature sounds pigeonholes rapper and beatsmith alike. Pusha T getting his collaborators to set aside their pet sounds is the mark of fearless showmen and inimitable chemistry.

column1: To that end
column2: Darkest Before Dawn is best explained as an exercise in pure craft for everyone involved
column3: the kind of record being scared out of existence because chickenshit execs won't fund what they can't see topping the charts. The beats sound like money
column4: and the raps are whip smart and cleanly tailored. Like Pusha's career post-Clipse
column5:
it's godly providence everything has gone as swimmingly as it has here. The resourceful hustler always finds his way.

column1: The vibe of ""Loaded"" was unusual enough. The identity of its makers was what really startled. Primal Scream had already jumped from sweet-toothed jangle-pop
column2: which Bobby Gillespie’s reedy voice suited well

column4: the Beloved

column3: rave

column7: but Gillespie’s conviction makes it essential to the record.

column1: The other is producer Andy Weatherall’s. Weatherall
column2: along with Terry Farley who remixed the ""Come Together"" single
column3: was part of the Boy’s Own DJ and fanzine collective in the earliest days of London Acid House. Boy’s Own loved big
column4: uplifting records
column5: played any genre they fancied

column2: celebratory club music and rock star fandom – is what gives Screamadelica its particular mood
column3: half strutting with confidence
column4: half yearning for transcendence. One result is that the record is often better when Bobby Gillespie is a presiding spirit rather than an actual singer. Compare album centrepiece ""Come Together"" with its single version
column5: where Gillespie enacts a loved-up Ecstasy high in winsome style. The LP drops his vocals

column2: and others
column3: quickly retreated from this answer doesn’t make it less true. But even by 1992’s Dixie-Narco EP – included on this reissue - the band were downplaying the clubbing influence in favour of something more rootsy

column3: his son

column5: the crew buries him
column6: murders his son
column7: and abandons their bodies
column8: continuing the journey unaware that DiCaprio escaped the grave to seek revenge. Calling The Revenant ""intense"" doesn't begin to do it justice; among other things
column9: it's a meditation on the unholy perseverance of the human soul. Yet its soundtrack—co-created by Japanese composer Ryuichi Sakamoto
column10: German electronic musician Alva Noto
column11: and multi-instrumentalist Bryce Dessner of The National—wisely opts to complement that savagery rather than illustrate it.

column1: Iñárritu’s Birdman
column2: the 2015 Academy Awards' Best Picture winner
column3: stuttered its way through an unconventional drum score by Antonio Sánchez. Here
column4: things get even more minimalist. The Revenant trades in sixteenth notes on hi-hats for minute-long fermatas
column5: or held notes
column6: on cellos. Throughout all 23 tracks
column7: the score straddles the line between weariness and wonder
column8: like someone constantly recalling the danger this stunning planet is capable of unleashing. Under conductor André de Ridder
column9: Berlin-based orchestra s t a r g a z e plays expansively and with great care
column10: its 25 players sporting a serious side compared to their work with artists like Deerhoof and Arcade Fire's Richard Reed Parry.

column1: That organic swelling matches the dramatics beneath the film. Iñárritu fought to keep CGI out of The Revenant. He fought to use natural light on set. He fought to film so deep within nature that 40% of the day was spent traveling there.  Each of the three contributors uphold this commitment to naturalism
column2: even with Alva Noto's electronica. Sakamoto favors simplicity and clarity; as DiCaprio crosses frozen rivers and sleeps in animal carcasses
column3: the brevity of Sakamoto's ""Killing Hawk"" illustrates the strength of Sakamoto's tight focus. On the minute-long ""Arriving At Fort Kiowa""
column4: a single cello is joined by trotting string support
column5: the group leaning forward in rhythm as a unified organism.

column1: Noto brings three different dream sequences to the table—""First Dream""
column2: ""Church Dream""
column3: and ""Second Dream""—where electronic bass thuds in the background like a mattress falling to the floor of an empty room. It's eerie without offering obvious indicators as to why. In that
column4: Noto's a pro. His use of electronics mimics the eldritch stares of a stalker
column5: especially on ""Goodbye to Hawk""
column6: creating the kind of anxiety heard in films like Drive and Under the Skin. Familiarity with the film's graphic scenes or the brutal landscapes of southern Argentina isn't required. Noto's written work acts as the terrified heartbeat fueling Iñárritu's violent winter all on its own.

column1: Bryce Dessner is the least involved of the three songwriters
column2: but when he contributes
column3: he creates a world overwhelmingly rich with life – the very thing DiCaprio's character clings to. The most emotional number on the album
column4: ""Imagining Buffalo""
column5: introduces one violinist to another and another
column6: stitching them together so they form a single note stretching into the infinite and spilling joy over into illusory insanity. ""Looking For Glass"" rides a similar crescendo. When all three men join forces again
column7: songs like ""Cat and Mouse"" use handclaps and violin tremors to communicate the indefatigability of cheating death. Sometimes
column8: the soundtrack traces the film’s woes without coloring them in
column9: but it’s still successful in creating the sound of mental exhaustion choosing life over death
column10:
no matter how torturous and unforgiving it — and we — may be.

Since releasing his first single as Zoo Kid in 2010
column4: the Londoner Archy Marshall has treated his creative output like loose change spilled into couch cushions. He's released hip-hop mixtapes
column5: ambient instrumentals
column6: and remixes of other acts' songs; only some of his output has been under the name King Krule
column7: the moniker he settled on for his 2013 debut full-length
column8: meaning it's flown beneath the radar of casual music fans who were stunned by 6 Feet Beneath the Moon. The work of tracking what he does now has fallen to hardcore faithful
column9: which seems like a smart long-term survival strategy and a sensible reaction to early career hype: halve your visibility
column10: double your productivity
column11: and wait for the universe to catch up.

column1: A New Place 2 Drown is a name given to three new projects—there is also a handsome 208-page art book of sketches
column2: photographs
column3: and poetry from Marshall alongside his older brother Jack
column4: and a short film. And then there is this album. All of it surfaced together this week
column5: and the shared title seems to make an offer to fans and clarify a wish to the larger world. Marshall wants to be swallowed by his work
column6: and he's offering you a chance to join him.

column1: Marshall has often seemed eager for disappearance—journalists have dubbed him ""press-shy
column2: a euphemism for ""loathes journalists""—but on A New Place 2 Drown
column3: he achieves it completely. His voice was the star of 6 Feet Beneath the Moon
column4: a blood-red streak against black
column5: but here he dissolves it into the grey mist of his beats. Mostly he croons or mutters over crackles
column6: drips
column7: and clanks. He is an element in his landscape now
column8: not a spotlit singer-songwriter or an ersatz modern-day blues singer. There isn't a single guitar audible on the album's drifting
column9: dreamlike 37 minutes
column10: and not a single song you could imagine Willow Smith attempting to cover.

column1: What it shares with his older work is the septic world it depicts
column2: full of flickering halogen bulbs
column3: sticky synth keys
column4: and corroded outputs. He's made tremendous strides as a producer
column5: to the point where his touch exceeds Rodaidh McDonald's work on his debut. His sound is more three-dimensional
column6: a series of shrouded corners and murmured conversations. This is wandering
column7: grey-skies music
column8: finding pleasure and even sensuality in solitude.

column1: Like most others in the sentient universe
column2: Marshall is a professed fan of hardcore '90s NYC hip-hop
column3: stuff like Wu-Tang and D.I.T.C. Unlike everyone else
column4: he gorgeously reproduces its gloom and loneliness
column5: and finds a way to integrate it into his own style. He does this mostly with a succession of sounds so obsessively perfect and tactile they seem like whole songs themselves: The hollow
column6: rounded thunk of the drum track on ""The Sea Liner MK 1"" precisely mimics the sound of colliding pool balls
column7: and hearing it for only a measly four minutes seems like a cheat
column8: somehow: It is a drum knock so perfect you would cross the street to listen to it.

column1: The formal grain of his music bends increasingly towards hip-hop: The sluggish tempo and tar-thick synths of ""Dull Boys"" and ""Thames Water"" suggest across-the-pond admiration of Houston's DJ Screw
column2: as does the halting sing-song of ""Buffed Sky"". His mumbly
column3: string-of-conscious delivery on ""Sex With Nobody"" conjures early-'00s indie rappers like Serengeti or Atmosphere. He is steadily narrowing the gap between the rap he admires and the music he makes
column4: and A New Place 2 Drown seems like evidence that he should start producing for rappers regularly.

column1: Marshall's own words are haunting but elusive
column2: ripples moving across the surface of his music that dissipate before your ear focuses on their meaning. But you get a peek into a mind state and a mood with every legible phrase: ""I'm pretty sure I'm dying as I speak
column3: he offers on ""Arise Dear Brother"". ""She plays me Barry White
column4: all night/ She drift into the light
column5: he sings wistfully on ""Ammi Ammi"". The most ringing line
column6: clearest in both its setting and its intention
column7: comes from ""Buffed Sky"": ""I'll fly solo
column8: he sings
column9:
drawing out the second syllable of the last word for relish and emphasis. It seems like it's working for him.

column2: a 22-year-old from the Upper West Side
column3: is best known as the linchpin in Ratking
column4: the trio whose 2014 LP So It Goes is one of the clearest articulations of New York City in the 21st century. Lots of the writing
column5: critical and otherwise
column6: about the group's music has really been about revivalism. Is Ratking bringing the '90s back? Should they bring the '90s back? (How much Avirex do they own?)  In reality
column7: both So It Goes and the follow-up EP
column8: 700 Fill
column9: are forward-thinking. The group's ties to Clinton-era New York are ethereal—Wiki's affinity for Cam'ron-esque marriages of crass humor and life advice
column10: Sporting Life's winter-resistant drum programming
column11: Hak's careening narratives. And every piece of Ratking's New York has been picked for a purpose
column12: even if it's dragged through mud and sleet and trampled on by commuters afterward.

column1: The young rapper's solo debut
column2: Lil Me
column3: is an act of decluttering. Where he was once verbose and technical at the expense of his message
column4: here he pares down his writing: ""Light Ls
column5: make it glow/ It takes a toll on my health
column6: from the closer ""Sun Showers"". In some ways
column7: this is Wiki's touring record
column8: but it's not about groupies or friction in a relationship back home. It's pointedly unglamorous
column9: all stale gas station food and cramped van seats. On ""Living With My Moms"" he raps
column10: ""I don't even know/ It's wherever the label tell me to go""; on ""Seedy Motherfucker""
column11: he tells us about getting booed during his set. Even the victories (clean sound checks
column12: crowds who half-understand the lyrics) seem smaller-than-life. Wiki alludes to graver problems—coke habits
column13: robberies
column14: loaded guns—but lets them linger in the margins.

column1: The out-of-town dates serve primarily as an excuse for Wiki to re-examine his hometown. On the Madlib-produced half of the opener ""WikiFlag""
column2: Wiki's pining: ""It's been a minute since I've been given a New York dap."" ""3 Stories""
column3: one of two songs produced by the Montreal-based DJ Kaytranada
column4: is a detail-obsessed narrative in the classicist vein. ""Hit the L""
column5: which reassembles the Ratking lineup
column6: could unfurl in a dozen different directions
column7: but it stays fixed in a smoky room
column8: walls closing in. Sporting Life hooks up a turn-of-the-century chipmunk soul loop
column9: yet chops it into two one-second samples
column10: and uses those sparingly.

column1: The song that follows
column2: Old Blocks New Kids""
column3: is Lil Me's thematic center. Reigns at the top are short like leprechauns
column4: and the song (another furnished by Sporting Life) celebrates the turnover. ""Oh pops
column5: I know you thought that you could do this/ You ain't stupid
column6: but you old
column7: pops—new kids."" That's Wiki's New York: cold
column8: cutthroat
column9: decaying
column10: being reborn. Over and over
column11:
stripping away anything that's unnecessary.

Digging into the music of Can
column3: Neu!
column4: Cluster
column5: and early Kraftwerk has become a record-collector rite of passage
column6: but during the early '70s
column7: when these bands were in their most active and exploratory years
column8: very few people knew this music existed. Of the many German bands from the period that would later be called ""krautrock""
column9: Harmonia
column10: though ostensibly a ""supergroup
column11: were among the most obscure. Comprised of Dieter Möbius and Hans-Joachim Roedelius of astral synth explorers Cluster and guitarist Michael Rother of Neu!
column12: Harmonia was less a band than a two-year-long Iron John retreat
column13: with electronics swapped out for the customary hand drums. Living
column14: practicing
column15: and recording in the hamlet of Forst
column16: Germany
column17: Harmonia managed two full-length records in their short lifetime
column18: and neither made a dent in the consciousness of your average German music fan. But copies of their records found their way into some famously open-eared and influential fans in the UK—Brian Eno and David Bowie
column19: among others—and Harmonia’s music has been part of the experimental rock canon ever since.

column1: As with many krautrock O.G.s
column2: Harmonia’s initial standing was enhanced by the fact that their records were never easy to find
column3: even after they were discovered by cognoscenti. That was especially true in the U.S.
column4: where their records were reissued sporadically
column5: sometimes on dodgy labels. This heavy box set from Gronland fixes that. Gathering everything the group recorded together in one place—and it turns out to be quite a lot
column6: with more music than they managed to release in their lifetime
column7: including newly unearthed fragments released here as Documents 1975—and augmenting the audio with a book of photos and an essay by krautrock expert Geeta Dayal and other goodies
column8: it offers the definitive portrait of the band. With a group as odd as Harmonia
column9: you take all the context you can get.

column1: Harmonia were a key krautrock band because they brought together the most familiar strands of the sound and effectively perfected the whole. Krautrock in its platonic ideal should be basically instrumental; it should should seamlessly meld electronics and rock instruments;  it should favor long
column2: drawn-over structures over short dynamic shifts
column3: and steady-state rhythms over syncopation. Can were too funky and had too much of an ear for pop; Neu!’s albums had jarring shifts in noise; early Kraftwerk leaned too heavily on flute and mid-period Kraftwerk was too heavy on synths; Ash Ra Tempel had a weakness for bluesy soloing
column4: Popol Vuh changed their sound too often
column5: and Amon Düül II were really a prog-rock band. Harmonia
column6: in the midst of too much
column7: was just right. And if that means their music could sometimes be pleasant and ambient instead of bold and challenging
column8: that’s not a slight. They made virtues of control
column9: understatement
column10: shading
column11: and texture.

column1: Musik von Harmonia
column2: the group’s 1974 debut
column3: was a precise meeting of their constituent parts—Roedelius’ eerie beauty
column4: Möbius’ sense of tension
column5: Rother’s cool exploration—with each member contributing to the sound equally. It’s a shade darker and a half-turn more tense than what would follow
column6: and was also more crudely recorded. Tracks like ""Sonnenschein"" and ""Watussi"" are already underway when we first hear them
column7: making them feel like they’ve always existed and go on forever. ""Dino""’s trebly rhythm brings to mind Lou Reed’s hypnotic major-chord strum in the Velvet Underground
column8: and on top of the rhythm bed Michael Rother’s leads seem guided more than played
column9: like he’s directing the flow of water through a maze. The meditative ""Ahoi"" is both futuristic and folky with its piano chords and gently plucked guitar
column10: channeling the type of new age that taps into something ancient while warmly embracing current technology. From the beginning
column11: Harmonia could take what sounded like an interlude and make it hold your attention for minutes on end.

column1: If Musik von Harmonia mapped the range of everything Harmonia would ever do
column2: 1975’s Deluxe used a more limited palette to paint a more beautiful picture. Working with master engineer Conny Plank and adding the deeper bottom end of drummer Mani Neumeier from Guru Guru
column3: Harmonia refined their approach into a kind of shimmering pastoral dub. ""Walky-Talky"" is right there with Kraftwerk’s ""Autobahn"" and Neu!’s ""Hallogallo"" for the definitive smooth-humming motorway anthem; ""Notre Dame"" is an electro-pop update on Terry Riley in joyfully trippy ""Rainbow in Curved Air"" mode
column4: and ""Gollum"" is a startlingly minimal and precise look ahead at the sound the Too Pure catalog would be known for two decades hence. Even when adding new wrinkles
column5: as with the chanted vocals on the opening ""Deluxe (Immer wieder)""
column6: Harmonia sound tremendously self-assured and comfortable in their sound. And their integration of something approaching proper songcraft intersected quite closely with experiments being done some distance away by the former keyboardist of Roxy Music
column7: a young man who became enamored of Harmonia named Brian Eno.

column1: Harmonia was pretty much always on the verge of breaking up
column2: but not because of personal animosity; since the group was not well known
column3: rarely played live
column4: and was made up of three musicians who had other projects close at hand
column5: their status was always tenuous. After Deluxe
column6: they had no plans to continue
column7: but Brian Eno asked to record with them and they re-grouped once more in Forst in 1976. The sessions with Eno were not released at the time
column8: but have been re-packaged in various configurations since
column9: and they are included here as Tracks & Traces. Eno’s presence is clear and the music is more atmospheric
column10: feeling more like soundscapes than the low-key minimalist rock songs they band made their name with. Not surprisingly
column11: the set also sounds a lot like the electro-acoustic work of the Rother-less Cluster & Eno
column12: a collaboration that would extend into the late '70s over several more records. Tracks & Traces is enjoyable
column13: but serves more as a look ahead to those records rather than something that builds on what came before.

column1: The real heart of the box
column2: a disc that sums up the band as well as any
column3: is the 1974 live set. It’s both surprisingly high quality in its recording and also speaks to what made this band special. Rather than recreating tracks they had recorded for this album
column4: they apply their music-making principles to a set of jams that are as beautiful as anything on their proper records. Thick with drones
column5: highly repetitious
column6: and often flat-out gorgeous
column7: Live 1974 throbs
column8: tumbles
column9: pulsates
column10: and twinkles
column11: a gentle explosion in super slo-mo that unfolds over an hour.

column1: Taken as a whole
column2: The Complete Works doesn’t reveal Harmonia to be an especially varied group
column3: but it does demonstrate that they did a small handful of things brilliantly well
column4: and those happened to be things that no one else was doing. They also happened to sound like what various kinds of experimental music would sound like 20 years later and
column5: I’m guessing
column6:
what some strains of it will sound like 20 years from now.

column8: ""A lot of the lyrics I wrote on our first record were about coming to terms with being trans

column10: this is an identity! This is GOOD!""

column3: gigantic crushes

column4: Nye began taking testosterone treatment

column2: sensitive

column4: the band appears more serious on Try to Be Hopeful

column6: a track celebrating
column7: clearly
column8: desire with an unrestrained joy. ""I want to run my fingers through your hair/ And you would say you've never done this before/ With someone like me
column9: the four sing in unison. It's great fun
column10:

column16: man-made prejudice. Like ""Tell Me""

column1: Pre-release hype pegs Long Live the Pimp as the culmination of what Pimp C was working on toward the end of his life. But it makes you wonder—why did it take eight years for this stuff to see the light of day? Maybe the best verses he left behind have already been used on UGK's final album

column5: kind of faded

column8: Dallas
column9: Parker
column10: Lambert
column11: Kane
column12: Brett
column13: and even Ash
column14: the android—each have a dream. So does Jonesey the cat. Eight tracks

column17: ""Anamorphosis""

column1: To record the music

column3: piano
column4: and shortwave radio

column1: Using relatively modest means

column3: though
column4: do you hear a note being produced; sounds slink into being like shadows creeping across the wall
column5: and they abscond just as imperceptibly. There's a brief tinkling
column6: as of wind chimes
column7: in ""Stasis 7 (Ash the Android's Dream)""; in ""Stasis 1 (Dallas' Dream)"" there's a sourceless tapping that reappears in ""Stasis 4 (Brett's Dream)""
column8: as if Harry Dean Stanton's character were down in the engine room

column10: though
column11: everything is as soft and sanded down as a coastline worn smooth by the millennia. His abstracted shapes genuinely resemble dreams

column1: It's worth noting that Before Nostromo is a digital-only release—a format that Mathieu has dedicated himself to with religious zeal

column3: Caro Mikalef) and it sounds unusually sumptuous

column5: timbral

column7: absorbing tribute

column9:
and you may find yourself hearing the film as you never have before.

The River doesn’t flow—it floods. Bruce Springsteen’s fifth album gushes forth with the fury of a burst dam

column7: The River not only appears to be a mess but embodies the classic definition of a double album: it seems to be a clearinghouse for every song Bruce Springsteen had at the ready in 1980. The Ties That Bind: The River Collection shows just how wrong that assumption is. Expanding the original 20-song double album to a 4xCD set supplemented with video
column8: it laughs at the notion that the original album was much too much by underscoring exactly how Springsteen intended the album to overwhelm.

column1: Initially
column2: Springsteen planned to follow 1978’s Darkness on the Edge of Town with an album called The Ties That Bind but he withdrew the record in the fall of 1979
column3: believing that it wasn’t ""big enough."" This claim came from the stage during a 2009 performance of The River at Madison Square Garden
column4: with Bruce going on to say
column5: ""I wanted to capture the themes that I’d been writing about on Darkness. I wanted to keep those characters with me and at the same time added the music that made our live shows so much fun and enjoyable for our audience."" On this box
column6: the scrapped The Ties That Bind gets an official airing as the third disc on the set—here it’s dubbed The River [Single Album]—and it does indeed play like a truncated
column7: miniature version of <i>The River
column8: containing in its 10 tracks seven of the double-album’s songs
column9: along with two alternate versions of tunes that wound up on the released record. What’s striking is what’s absent: shorn of its party songs
column10: the record feels gloomy and haunted—even ""You Can Look (But You Better Not Touch)"" in a lonesome Sun rockabilly incarnation feels like a transmission from the lonely black of night. It reiterates many of the themes of Darkness
column11: only without aggression
column12: fury

column1: Surely recognizing this deficit
column2: Springsteen spent roughly another year in the studio
column3: reviving old songs and writing new ones
column4: arriving at full-blown
column5: completed recordings of most of these tunes
column6: then picking and choosing from his surplus to create the final album. The result was enough material for another double album
column7: presented here as The Ties That Bind

column9: even with this abundance

column11: even if some tracks are colored with new Bruce vocals

column1: Listening through the box
column2: it’s hard not to be struck by Springsteen’s labor-intensive creative method. He knew the broad outline of what he wanted to achieve
column3: so he kept tweaking his material in the studio
column4: rearranging and recording until he found just the right emotion. If The Cutting Edge 1965–1966 proves how Bob Dylan sought to capture the lightning of a live performance
column5: Springsteen always is seduced by the illusion of a record: sure
column6: he’s invigorated by live performance—and the Tempe concert included here is tremendous
column7: the E-Street Band at the peak of their power—but he sculpts his albums out of tracks that are powerful as recordings
column8: not simply songs.

column1: This is especially true of The River
column2: which Bruce loaded up with the purest
column3: hardest
column4: and happiest rock’n’roll the E-Street Band ever cut in the studio. ""She’s the One"" pulsated to a beat borrowed from Bo Diddley and Darkness surged with desperate passion
column5: but Bruce’s first four records rarely touched on the ecstatic joy that can be had from just making noise. The River is full of these moments (""Sherry Darling""
column6: ""Crush on You""
column7: ""I’m a Rocker""
column8: ""Cadillac Ranch"")
column9: and some of the weightier items trade in this same sense of exuberance—a sense of desperation cuts against the grain of the sunny hook on ""Hungry Heart""
column10: and ""Two Hearts"" spins headfirst into unfettered romanticism. But this music is so simple
column11: so visceral
column12: that it’s often been tagged as throwaway
column13: the detritus surrounding the haunting ""The River""
column14: ""The Price You Pay""
column15: and ""Stolen Car"".

column1: Thing is
column2: these throwaways give The River its cinematic scope. Some of the newer additions were cut from a familiar forlorn cloth (""Independence Day""
column3: the closing pair of ""Drive All Night"" and ""Wreck on the Highway"") while ""Point Blank"" and ""Jackson Cage"" split the difference between the celebration and sorrow. But the biggest distinction between The River and the original Ties That Bind is this full-on bash
column4: funny and furious and entirely sincere in its worship of the sounds rocking frat houses and AM radio in a '60s that didn’t belong to the Beatles. It’s the Springsteen album that can easily slip onto any show on Little Steven’s Underground Garage
column5: and this party winds up providing an ideal counterpoint to the sweeter
column6: sadder moments on The River.

column1: Take the second side
column2: which opens with ""Hungry Heart""—Bruce’s first genuine hit single
column3: reaching number five on a combination of its hook and Springsteen’s general momentum—then dwells upon the cinematic escape ""Out in the Street"" and serves up two breakneck rockers before settling into the dreaminess of ""I Wanna Marry You"" and the stark ""The River""
column4: the latter two hitting harder due to the companions. Each side is structured similarly
column5: with the last song tipping slightly toward melancholy
column6: the cumulative effect suggesting there’s no separating pleasure from the pain. It all comes at once and
column7: depending on mood
column8: The River either seems like the happiest or saddest of Bruce’s records: in its mess lies a mirror that reflects the listener’s state of mind.

column1: The Ties That Bind illustrates this sprawl was no accident. Within these 22 rejects—some of them sneaking out as B-sides or on previous reissues
column2: including the 1998 box Tracks and the bonus disc on 2003’s The Essential Bruce Springsteen—Springsteen explores the same terrain as he does on The River: urban romance
column3: accidental violence
column4: working-man’s blues
column5: and restless nights. Like its parent
column6: The Ties That Bind achieves a delicate balance between adult despair and adolescent freedom: he may dwell upon ""Little White Lies"" and ""The Time That Never Was""
column7: but he also borrows a song title from Claudine Clark (""Party Lights"") and tips a hat to Connie Francis’ beach classic Where the Boys Are (""Where the Bands Are""). Enough great songs didn’t make a cut that it’s possible to cobble together a killer single album from the outtakes—one that would open with the breathless ""Meet Me in the City"" and contain the cloistered paranoia of ""The Man Who Got Away""
column8: the blank desperation of ""Roulette""

column10: a heightened Chuck Berry story song Bruce turned over to Dave Edmunds. But like the completed album
column11: what resonates is the magnitude of the sprawl itself.

column1: As they spill out
column2: the songs play off each other
column3: accentuating the sorrow or celebration heard in their predecessors. Combing through these outtakes
column4: it quickly becomes clear how Springsteen
column5: Van Zandt
column6: and Jon Landau constructed each track to deliver its own specific visceral thrill and then culled through their finished product to find the cuts that fit their intended design. Some of these rejects rely on that headstrong old time rock’n’roll—""Living on the Edge of the World"" bops along to its syncopated swing
column7: ""Paradise by the C"" is a roadhouse jam highlighting Clarence Clemons—but others play like ripostes to the E-Street Band’s peers: the live ""Held Up Without a Gun"" (which would later morph into the finished ""You Can Look (But You Better Not Touch)"") careens like Elvis Costello & the Attractions

column1: Thirty-five years after the release of The River
column2: it’s easy to think of Bruce Springsteen as existing on a separate plane from such contemporary kindred spirits or perhaps as somebody who only belongs to part of a self-styled lineage that runs through Woody Guthrie and Bob Dylan. By adding The Times That Bind

column6: prosaic ways he belonged to his time. On these 52 songs
column7: Springsteen sings about gas shortages
column8: cold beer
column9: unemployment agencies
column10: busted dreams
column11: and Burt Reynolds
column12: fleeting images of a blue collar America that unknowingly was entering its decay but these words are married to the sound of a working band that knows it has to work
column13: aware that it has to have songs to fuel those marathon three hour shows.

column1: Springsteen never really let these straight-up rockers be part of his records again—maybe on Born in the U.S.A.
column2: but both ""Darlington County"" and ""Working on the Highway"" end in tears—but he also never quite worked the same way again

column4: greater things. The River brought Bruce to those heights
column5: giving him his first number one album and Top 10 single

column7: the last record where he and the E-Street Band were not the biggest band in the land but merely the best. In that light

column9: all in the same spirit and feel as the final album and nearly as good as what made the cut
column10: feels like a gift. And for those who may think four CDs and three DVDs are too much
column11: consider this: for an album that is all about contradictions
column12: excess and mess
column13:
more of everything is most certainly a good thing.

A friend once told me a story about the singer-songwriter Cass McCombs that I've always liked. One night
column4: my friend was at a party in the Bay Area when McCombs showed up with a guest. It was a real punk-rock party. (My friend remembers overhearing someone insist that what people didn't understand about the American Revolution was that the American Revolution was still going on.) My friend was sitting on the porch when McCombs and his guest came out to leave. He said McCombs looked like he was about to cry. Not in a remarkable way
column5: but like about-to-cry was his resting face. ""Well
column6: McCombs said to his guest
column7: ""we were just two sweaters at a sweatshirt party."" They left without saying goodbye.

column1: This was about 15 years ago
column2: before McCombs had released his first album (the enigmatically titled A)
column3: but the sweater bit was prophetic. McCombs is one of those artists who looks out of place no matter where you put him. His biography says he was born in Concord
column4: Calif.
column5: but it seems hard to say where he's from (in the metaphorical sense) or even where he lives (in the utility-bill one). He has no attachment to any particular scene
column6: and though he has collaborated with a hundred unrelated artists over the last decade—including a producer for Vampire Weekend and Adele (Ariel Rechtshaid)
column7: the bass player from Phish (Mike Gordon)
column8: and an Academy Award–nominated actress (the late Karen Black)—he often appears to be totally alone
column9: a tumbleweed drifting through the interior of nowhere. Characters in Cass McCombs songs are executioners
column10: truck drivers
column11: lifelong bachelors who treat liquor as their personal ticket to the moon and other people for whom being alone is not the product of bad luck but of religious election. At one point he only answered interview questions through the mail.

column1: The style of McCombs' music differs from album to album but all shares a low-key American spirit that joins the personal freedom of '60s counterculture with the reticence of late-'90s indie rock—cowboy music for people with a lot of library fines. As a writer
column2: he has a trickster's gift for resignation: He makes misery seem funny and his ability to control it seem smart. (This is why I tell the ""sweater"" story: Half because it presents McCombs as a loner
column3: half because it presents him as someone with the ability to understand his solitude so well that he can turn it into a joke that connects with other people. )

column1: His most recent album is a B-sides and outtakes collection called A Folk Set Apart. It covers 2003 to 2014
column2: from A through the Wild West epic of Big Wheel and Others. On it you will hear songs that resemble garage-punk (""A.Y.D."")
column3: Neil Young ballads (""Bradley Manning"")
column4: nursery rhymes (""Three Men Sitting on a Hollow Log"")
column5: and stretches of recorded sound that people in the commuter pool would probably identify as non-music (""Texas"").

column1: One of my favorite things about listening to McCombs is that he seems unafraid to make some really bad decisions. This is a man who once orchestrated a three-minute outro that sounds like a dog sleeping in a clarinet (""Memory's Stain"") and interrupted an otherwise beautiful song to ask what it was like to shit in space (""Morning Star""). A Folk Set Apart is scattered by nature but it has some of these moments
column2: too—moments in which some line or turn that at first sounds unnatural becomes a signal both of McCombs' quiet confidence and of his casual rebellion against the idea of how songs are supposed to go. It's easy to understand why he was fascinated with someone like Bradley—now Chelsea—Manning
column3: the trans woman dishonorably discharged from the Army and convicted of espionage for her relationship with WikiLeaks: Not only is Manning a modern variation on the American outlaw
column4: but the turns in her life defy every extant script.

column1: So start with Catacombs
column2: or with the funereal WIT'S END or Dropping the Writ. Big Wheel is good
column3: too. They all are in their idiosyncratic
column4: prickly little ways. If pop's goal is to forge a path of identification between artist and listener
column5: McCombs is defiantly un-pop
column6: a singer continually trying to figure out how to outpace his audience's comfort levels without driving them out of the room. In modern parlance
column7:
Cass McCombs didn't come here to make friends. Which is good. There are plenty of sweatshirts in the hamper if you want them.

""Alternative"" (in the loosest sense of the word) Christmas covers are usually brimming with positive holiday cheer
column2: even if they have a slight humorous bent à la Yo La Tengo's ""Toymageddon"" or Ben Folds' ""Bizarre Christmas Incident"". Cassie Ramone's collection of covers
column3: however
column4: forgoes the usual Christmassy spectacle; the songs on here are dark and harrowing in their interpretation. As gusts of wind introduce both the record and Ramone's drawling take on ""Christmas (Baby Please Come Home)""
column5: she immediately projects loneliness and isolation. As she sings ""The snow's comin' down/ I'm watchin' it fall
column6: Ramone counteracts Darlene Love's powerful hopefulness in the original song with sheer hopelessness.

column1: While she had some assistance from Ariel Pink on bass and Jay Heiselmann in mastering on her first solo effort
column2: The Time Has Come
column3: this time Ramone
column4: formerly of Vivian Girls and the Babies
column5: is truly on her own. Christmas in Reno was recorded and mixed mostly by Ramone herself
column6: rendering these covers with a vulnerable and intimate touch. Nothing is tight and structured per se
column7: but everything is meticulously executed in order to reach its intended effect: portraying a despondence and loss of interest in life. Reverb guides Ramone's disturbed voice on her version of Paul McCartney's ""Wonderful Christmastime""
column8: letting her pain linger. The track fades out with a wobbly wah-wah
column9: leading into a haunting and fuzzy rendition of ""Blue Christmas"". ""I'll Be Home for Christmas"" is tragically slurred and toward the end Ramone's recital of Bing Crosby's popular lyrics becomes indecipherable.

column1: ""Run Run Rudolph"" is probably the most upbeat thing here—it sounds like a rough DIY track
column2: which Ramone accentuates with guileless yelping. But even ""Sleigh Ride""
column3: possibly the chirpiest and most festive Christmas ditty of all time
column4: feels haunted. Ramone zooms in on the ""you"" in the line ""It's lovely weather for a sleigh ride together with you
column5: letting it linger with ache; she wants whoever ""you"" is to know how much they hurt her. Her memories of Christmases together with a former lover are too painful
column6: but she tortures herself over and over
column7: ending the song with a repeating ""you.""

column1: Christmas in Reno is uncomfortable to listen to—the tracks that you so often associate with being jolly are torn up into pieces and burned at the core. However
column2: that's exactly Ramone's intention—to find the melancholy in a ""joyful time of year."" Bad things can happen to you no matter the time of year. She affirms this using Nat King Cole's ""The Christmas Song""
column3:
halfheartedly ending the record with a bleak ""Merry Christmas to you.""

Formed in 1996 and over and done within four years
column2: Laddio Bolocko was the strangest
column3: most slept-on New York band of its time. They had some precedent in far-out outfits like Faust and This Heat
column4: who used studio technology
column5: isolation
column6: and willful primitivism to push their music to into extreme places. And
column7: because they blended '70s experimentalism with elements of American underground punk music

column9: like Tortoise and Trans Am (with whom they toured). Their vibe was very different

column1: Live and Unreleased collects odds and ends pulled from Laddio Bolocko's archives
column2: including rehearsal tapes
column3: concert recordings
column4: and a DVD's worth of grainy concert footage. These are hardly throwaways or fans-only ephemera
