column6: allowing a peek into the communal jamming and weeded-out home studio experimentation that drove the band's creative process.

column1: Liner notes by Oneida drummer Kid Millions give insight into the quartet's brief
column2: grubby existence. After relocating to Brooklyn from southern Illinois during the mid '90s
column3: drummer Blake Fleming
column4: guitarist Drew St. Ivany
column5: and bassist Ben Armstrong found a low-rent practice/living space in then-blighted Dumbo that offered no shower
column6: but allowed no-complaints all-hours music-making.

column1: The 20-minute ""43 Minutes of (Excerpt)"" is drawn from this time and captures the trio finding its stylistic footing. They trance out big-time here
column2: with Armstrong and St. Ivany plugging away at car alarm-style riffs on bass and keyboard while Fleming goes wild on the kit. The tape marked the emergence of an idea that would drive the band's later work—mainly
column3: the skewing of the senses through high-volume repetition—and also possibly helped to win over saxophonist Marcus DeGrazia
column4: who engineered the session and who would join the band full-time shortly thereafter.

column1: Looking for a change in scene
column2: Laddio later decamped to an abandoned ski lodge in upstate New York. This period accounts for the collection's darker
column3: more abstract material— where the band moved off the grid and completely into its own territory. Tracks like ""Catskills # 3"" and ""Catskills #5"" are full of alien melodies
column4: haunting found sounds
column5: and phantom piano tones. The music has an eerie energy to it
column6: as if it wasn't so much being consciously written as channeled into existence. It's as if the quartet slipped down some strange Lovecraftian wormhole -- not so much in these sense that the music evokes horror
column7: but that the band's druggy transcendence brings only disquiet and distance. After plotting out the material for their second record
column8: In Real Time
column9: Laddio ended its stay in the countryside and returned to Dumbo
column10: where they landed in an even filthier crash pad. Not long after
column11: the group called it quits. Armstrong and St. Ivany would go on to form the excellent trio
column12: the Psychic Paramount while Fleming would do a few off-and-on stints in the Mars Volta and perform in the band Electric Turn to Me
column13: along with DeGrazia.

column1: Awesome as they were
column2: it's hard to say that Laddio Bolocko has spawned many imitators. They were just too obscure. Millions' band
column3: Oneida
column4: embraced similar ideas and sounds

column6: even he had never heard of the band. But it would be hard to replicate the quartet's magic
column7: anyway.

column1: Laddio toured extensively throughout its existence and the live recordings included here—six songs taped during a performance in Slovenia—provide the some of the set's most compelling material. On stage
column2: the band's strange and diverse ideas gel together perfectly. The songs are otherworldly
column3: but visceral. The quartet performs with intensity and shared purpose that seems somehow paranormal
column4: nudging out of their regular songs into unknown territory
column5:
searching out an ecstatic state.

Guinea’s state-sponsored record label Editions Syliphone Conakry closed permanently in 1984
column2: with the death of President Ahmed Sékou Touré. The economic
column3: cultural
column4: and political situation in the newly independent African country had been sliding downward since the mid-'70s

column6: perceiving that creating a strong national identity for the one-time French colony hinged on developing its culture

column1: The sound that Syliphone promoted was an astonishing

column9: Guinea was in turmoil
column10: with a failed assassination plot on Sékou Touré
column11: and detention of political dissenters. Some of the strongest music from Syliphone predates this struggle
column12: but that's part of what makes Musique Sans Paroles (translation: Music Without Words)
column13: released that same year
column14: such a jewel: Amid increasing unrest
column15: Sans Paroles serves as an oasis.

column1: This compilation documents some of the label’s lesser known acts: Only one of them
column2: alto saxophonist Momo Wandel
column3: has more than one release to his name. Given the turmoil of Guinea
column4: it’s likely that many of these groups never got the chance to record again. Opening band Sombory Jazz most closely resembles the flagship acts of the imprint
column5: the rhythm shuffling between African polyrhythms and Cuban rhumba without quite settling. The horn work evokes comparison to Bembeya Jazz National
column6: the guitar solo imbued with that rippling
column7: eddying guitar tone so prevalent in the era
column8: liquid and psychedelic at once. But from there
column9: Sans Paroles explores little-heard wrinkles. Wandel’s ""Tam-Tam Sax"" emulates Cameroonian saxophonist Manu Dibango but with squawks that bring to mind spiritual jazz players like Pharoah Sanders and Archie Shepp.

column1: Each song shows a stylistic shift. The seldom-recorded Quintette Guinéenne does a rhythm & blues number on ""Douga""
column2: while ""Flute Parlante"" is as close as the album gets to words. Highlighting solo flute
column3: it brings to mind the recordings that the old Folkways Records used to document. The highlight is Quintette Guinéenne’s second contribution
column4: ""Massane Cissé"". A Griot thought to date back to the 12th-13th century
column5: it exemplifies Sékou Touré’s mission to update his country’s traditions in the new century. Between the extended guitar solo and battery of percussion
column6: it brings to mind the exploratory psychedelic rock happening across the Atlantic Ocean. Trio Papa Kouyaté
column7: named and propelled by Miriam Makeeba’s longtime conga player
column8: offers up two nimble acoustic numbers with Kouyaté shadowed by stand-up bass and acoustic guitar. Kouyaté’s conga playing hints at Arsenio Rodriguez’s groups of the 1950s. Close your eyes and the capital of Conakry starts to turn into downtown Havana. Or

the epicenter of San Francisco a decade prior.
